Special thanks are due to Sharon Partridge for extensive proofreading and correction of this etext.

SENSE AND SENSIBILITY

by Jane Austen

-LRB-1811-RRB-

CHAPTER 1

The family of Dashwood had long been settled in Sussex. Their estate was large, and their residence was at Norland Park, in the centre of their property, where, for many generations, they had lived in so respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of their surrounding acquaintance. The late owner of this estate was a single man, who lived to a very advanced age, and who for many years of his (man) life, had a constant companion and housekeeper in his (man) sister. But her (sister) death, which happened ten years before his (man) own, produced a great alteration in his (man) home; for to supply her (sister) loss, he (man) invited and received into his (man) house the family of his (man) nephew Mr. Henry Dashwood, the legal inheritor of the Norland estate, and the person to whom he (man) intended to bequeath it. In the society of his (man) nephew and niece, and their children, the old Gentleman's days were comfortably spent. His (man) attachment to them all increased. The constant attention of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dashwood to his (Dashwood) wishes, which proceeded not merely from interest, but from goodness of heart, gave him (Dashwood) every degree of solid comfort which his (Dashwood) age could receive; and the cheerfulness of the children added a relish to his (Dashwood) existence.

By a former marriage, Mr. Henry Dashwood had one son: by his (Dashwood) present lady, three daughters. The son, a steady respectable young man, was amply provided for by the fortune of his (son) mother, which had been large, and half of which devolved on him (son) on his (son) coming of age. By his (son) own marriage, likewise, which happened soon afterwards, he (son) added to his (son) wealth. To him (son) therefore the succession to the Norland estate was not so really important as to his (son) sisters; for their fortune, independent of what might arise to them from their father's inheriting that property, could be but small. Their mother had nothing, and their father only seven thousand pounds in his (father) own disposal; for the remaining moiety of his (father) first wife's fortune was also secured to her (wife) child, and he (father) had only a life-interest in it.

The old gentleman died: his (gentleman) will was read, and like almost every other will, gave as much disappointment as pleasure. He (gentleman) was neither so unjust, nor so ungrateful, as to leave his (gentleman) estate from his (gentleman) nephew;--but he (gentleman) left it to him (gentleman) on such terms as destroyed half the value of the bequest. Mr. Dashwood had wished for it more for the sake of his (Dashwood) wife and daughters than for himself or his (Dashwood) son;--but to his (Dashwood) son, and his (Dashwood) son's son, a child of four years old, it was secured, in such a way, as to leave to himself no power of providing for those who were most dear to him (Dashwood), and who most needed a provision by any charge on the estate, or by any sale of its valuable woods. The whole was tied up for the benefit of this child, who, in occasional visits with his (Dashwood) father and mother at Norland, had so far gained on the affections of his (Dashwood) uncle, by such attractions as are by no means unusual in children of two or three years old; an imperfect articulation, an earnest desire of having his (Dashwood) own way, many cunning tricks, and a great deal of noise, as to outweigh all the value of all the attention which, for years, he (Dashwood) had received from his (Dashwood) niece and her (niece) daughters. He (Dashwood) meant not to be unkind, however, and, as a mark of his (Dashwood) affection for the three girls, he (Dashwood) left them a thousand pounds a-piece.

Mr. Dashwood's disappointment was, at first, severe; but his (Dashwood) temper was cheerful and sanguine; and he (Dashwood) might reasonably hope to live many years, and by living economically, lay by a considerable sum from the produce of an estate already large, and capable of almost immediate improvement. But the fortune, which had been so tardy in coming, was his (Dashwood) only one twelvemonth. He (Dashwood) survived his (Dashwood) uncle no longer; and ten thousand pounds, including the late legacies, was all that remained for his (Dashwood) widow and daughters.

His (Dashwood) son was sent for as soon as his (son) danger was known, and to him (son) Mr. Dashwood recommended, with all the strength and urgency which illness could command, the interest of his (Dashwood) mother-in-law and sisters.

Mr. John Dashwood had not the strong feelings of the rest of the family; but he (Dashwood) was affected by a recommendation of such a nature at such a time, and he (Dashwood) promised to do every thing in his (Dashwood) power to make them comfortable. His (Dashwood) father was rendered easy by such an assurance, and Mr. John Dashwood had then leisure to consider how much there might prudently be in his (Dashwood) power to do for them.

He (Dashwood) was not an ill-disposed young man, unless to be rather cold hearted and rather selfish is to be ill-disposed: but he (man) was, in general, well respected; for he (man) conducted himself with propriety in the discharge of his (man) ordinary duties. Had he (man) married a more amiable woman, he (man) might have been made still more respectable than he (man) was:--he (man) might even have been made amiable himself; for he (man) was very young when he (man) married, and very fond of his (man) wife. But Mrs. John Dashwood was a strong caricature of himself;--more narrow-minded and selfish.

When he (man) gave his (man) promise to his (man) father, he (man) meditated within himself to increase the fortunes of his (man) sisters by the present of a thousand pounds a-piece. He (man) then really thought himself equal to it. The prospect of four thousand a-year, in addition to his (man) present income, besides the remaining half of his (man) own mother's fortune, warmed his (man) heart, and made him (man) feel capable of generosity.--

``Yes, he (man) would give them three thousand pounds: it would be liberal and handsome! It would be enough to make them completely easy. Three thousand pounds! he (man) could spare so considerable a sum with little inconvenience.'' (He)
-- He (man) thought of it all day long, and for many days successively, and he (man) did not repent.

No sooner was his (man) father's funeral over, than Mrs. John Dashwood, without sending any notice of her (Dashwood) intention to her (Dashwood) mother-in-law, arrived with her (Dashwood) child and their attendants. No one could dispute her (Dashwood) right to come; the house was her (Dashwood) husband's from the moment of his (husband) father's decease; but the indelicacy of her (Dashwood) conduct was so much the greater, and to a woman in Mrs. Dashwood's situation, with only common feelings, must have been highly unpleasing;--but in HER mind there was a sense of honor so keen, a generosity so romantic, that any offence of the kind, by whomsoever given or received, was to her (Dashwood) a source of immovable disgust. Mrs. John Dashwood had never been a favourite with any of her (Dashwood) husband's family; but she (Dashwood) had had no opportunity, till the present, of shewing them with how little attention to the comfort of other people she (Dashwood) could act when occasion required it.

So acutely did Mrs. Dashwood feel this ungracious behaviour, and so earnestly did she (Dashwood) despise her (Dashwood) daughter-in-law for it, that, on the arrival of the latter, she (Dashwood) would have quitted the house for ever, had not the entreaty of her (Dashwood) eldest girl induced her (Dashwood) first to reflect on the propriety of going, and her (Dashwood) own tender love for all her (Dashwood) three children determined her (Dashwood) afterwards to stay, and for their sakes avoid a breach with their brother.

Elinor, this eldest daughter, whose advice was so effectual, possessed a strength of understanding, and coolness of judgment, which qualified her (Elinor), though only nineteen, to be the counsellor of her (Elinor) mother, and enabled her (Elinor) frequently to counteract, to the advantage of them all, that eagerness of mind in Mrs. Dashwood which must generally have led to imprudence. She (Dashwood) had an excellent heart;--her (Dashwood) disposition was affectionate, and her (Dashwood) feelings were strong; but she (Dashwood) knew how to govern them: it was a knowledge which her (Dashwood) mother had yet to learn; and which one of her (Dashwood) sisters had resolved never to be taught.

Marianne's abilities were, in many respects, quite equal to Elinor's. She (Elinor) was sensible and clever; but eager in everything: her (Elinor) sorrows, her (Elinor) joys, could have no moderation. She (Elinor) was generous, amiable, interesting: she (Elinor) was everything but prudent. The resemblance between her (Elinor) and her (Elinor) mother was strikingly great.

Elinor saw, with concern, the excess of her (Elinor) sister's sensibility; but by Mrs. Dashwood it was valued and cherished. They encouraged each other now in the violence of their affliction. The agony of grief which overpowered them at first, was voluntarily renewed, was sought for, was created again and again. They gave themselves up wholly to their sorrow, seeking increase of wretchedness in every reflection that could afford it, and resolved against ever admitting consolation in future. Elinor, too, was deeply afflicted; but still she (Elinor) could struggle, she (Elinor) could exert herself. She (Elinor) could consult with her (Elinor) brother, could receive her (Elinor) sister-in-law on her (Elinor) arrival, and treat her (Elinor) with proper attention; and could strive to rouse her (Elinor) mother to similar exertion, and encourage her (Elinor) to similar forbearance.

Margaret, the other sister, was a good-humored, well-disposed girl; but as she (Margaret) had already imbibed a good deal of Marianne's romance, without having much of her (Marianne) sense, she (Marianne) did not, at thirteen, bid fair to equal her (Marianne) sisters at a more advanced period of life.

CHAPTER 2

Mrs. John Dashwood now installed herself mistress of Norland; and her (Dashwood) mother and sisters-in-law were degraded to the condition of visitors. As such, however, they were treated by her (mother) with quiet civility; and by her (mother) husband with as much kindness as he (husband) could feel towards anybody beyond himself, his (husband) wife, and their child. He (husband) really pressed them, with some earnestness, to consider Norland as their home; and, as no plan appeared so eligible to Mrs. Dashwood as remaining there till she (Dashwood) could accommodate herself with a house in the neighbourhood, his (husband) invitation was accepted.

A continuance in a place where everything reminded her (Dashwood) of former delight, was exactly what suited her (Dashwood) mind. In seasons of cheerfulness, no temper could be more cheerful than hers, or possess, in a greater degree, that sanguine expectation of happiness which is happiness itself. But in sorrow she (Dashwood) must be equally carried away by her (Dashwood) fancy, and as far beyond consolation as in pleasure she (Dashwood) was beyond alloy.

Mrs. John Dashwood did not at all approve of what her (Dashwood) husband intended to do for his (husband) sisters. To take three thousand pounds from the fortune of their dear little boy would be impoverishing him (boy) to the most dreadful degree. She (Dashwood) begged him (boy) to think again on the subject. How could he (boy) answer it to himself to rob his (boy) child, and his (boy) only child too, of so large a sum? And what possible claim could the Miss Dashwoods, who were related to him (boy) only by half blood, which she (Dashwood) considered as no relationship at all, have on his (boy) generosity to so large an amount. It was very well known that no affection was ever supposed to exist between the children of any man by different marriages; and why was he (man) to ruin himself, and their poor little Harry, by giving away all his (Harry) money to his (Harry) half sisters?

``It was my father's last request to me,'' (husband)
replied her (Dashwood) husband,
``that I should assist his (husband) widow and daughters.'' (husband)

``He (husband) did not know what he (husband) was talking of, I dare say; ten to one but he (husband) was light-headed at the time. Had he (husband) been in his (husband) right senses, he (husband) could not have thought of such a thing as begging you to give away half your fortune from your own child.'' (unknown)

``He (husband) did not stipulate for any particular sum, my dear Fanny; he (husband) only requested me, in general terms, to assist them, and make their situation more comfortable than it was in his (husband) power to do. Perhaps it would have been as well if he (husband) had left it wholly to myself. He (husband) could hardly suppose I should neglect them. But as he (husband) required the promise, I could not do less than give it; at least I thought so at the time. The promise, therefore, was given, and must be performed. Something must be done for them whenever they leave Norland and settle in a new home.'' (unknown)

``Well, then, LET something be done for them; but THAT something need not be three thousand pounds. Consider,'' (she)
she (they) added,
``that when the money is once parted with, it never can return. Your sisters will marry, and it will be gone for ever. If, indeed, it could be restored to our poor little boy--'' (she)

``Why, to be sure,'' (husband)
said her (they) husband, very gravely,
``that would make great difference. The time may come when Harry will regret that so large a sum was parted with. If he (Harry) should have a numerous family, for instance, it would be a very convenient addition.'' (husband)

``To be sure it would.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps, then, it would be better for all parties, if the sum were diminished one half.--Five hundred pounds would be a prodigious increase to their fortunes!'' (unknown)

``Oh! beyond anything great! What brother on earth would do half so much for his (brother) sisters, even if REALLY his (brother) sisters! And as it is--only half blood!--But you have such a generous spirit!'' (unknown)

``I would not wish to do any thing mean,'' (he)
he (brother) replied.
``One had rather, on such occasions, do too much than too little. No one, at least, can think I have not done enough for them: even themselves, they can hardly expect more.'' (unknown)

``There is no knowing what THEY may expect,'' (the lady)
said the lady,
``but we are not to think of their expectations: the question is, what you can afford to do.'' (the lady)

``Certainly--and I think I may afford to give them five hundred pounds a-piece. As it is, without any addition of mine, they will each have about three thousand pounds on their mother's death--a very comfortable fortune for any young woman.'' (unknown)

``To be sure it is; and, indeed, it strikes me that they can want no addition at all. They will have ten thousand pounds divided amongst them. If they marry, they will be sure of doing well, and if they do not, they may all live very comfortably together on the interest of ten thousand pounds.'' (unknown)

``That is very true, and, therefore, I do not know whether, upon the whole, it would not be more advisable to do something for their mother while she (mother) lives, rather than for them--something of the annuity kind I mean.--My sisters would feel the good effects of it as well as herself. A hundred a year would make them all perfectly comfortable.'' (wife)

His (mother) wife hesitated a little, however, in giving her (wife) consent to this plan.

``To be sure,'' (she)
said she (wife),
``it is better than parting with fifteen hundred pounds at once. But, then, if Mrs. Dashwood should live fifteen years we shall be completely taken in.'' (she)

``Fifteen years! my dear Fanny; her (Fanny) life cannot be worth half that purchase.'' (unknown)

``Certainly not; but if you observe, people always live for ever when there is an annuity to be paid them; and she (Fanny) is very stout and healthy, and hardly forty. An annuity is a very serious business; it comes over and over every year, and there is no getting rid of it. You are not aware of what you are doing. I have known a great deal of the trouble of annuities; for my mother was clogged with the payment of three to old superannuated servants by my father's will, and it is amazing how disagreeable she (mother) found it. Twice every year these annuities were to be paid; and then there was the trouble of getting it to them; and then one of them was said to have died, and afterwards it turned out to be no such thing. My mother was quite sick of it. Her (mother) income was not her (mother) own, she (mother) said, with such perpetual claims on it; and it was the more unkind in my father, because, otherwise, the money would have been entirely at my mother's disposal, without any restriction whatever. It has given me such an abhorrence of annuities, that I am sure I would not pin myself down to the payment of one for all the world.'' (unknown)

``It is certainly an unpleasant thing,'' (Mr. Dashwood/Mr. Henry Dashwood)
replied Mr. Dashwood,
``to have those kind of yearly drains on one's income. One's fortune, as your mother justly says, is NOT one's own. To be tied down to the regular payment of such a sum, on every rent day, is by no means desirable: it takes away one's independence.'' (Mr. Dashwood/Mr. Henry Dashwood)

``Undoubtedly; and after all you have no thanks for it. They think themselves secure, you do no more than what is expected, and it raises no gratitude at all. If I were you, whatever I did should be done at my own discretion entirely. I would not bind myself to allow them any thing yearly. It may be very inconvenient some years to spare a hundred, or even fifty pounds from our own expenses.'' (unknown)

``I believe you are right, my love; it will be better that there should be no annuity in the case; whatever I may give them occasionally will be of far greater assistance than a yearly allowance, because they would only enlarge their style of living if they felt sure of a larger income, and would not be sixpence the richer for it at the end of the year. It will certainly be much the best way. A present of fifty pounds, now and then, will prevent their ever being distressed for money, and will, I think, be amply discharging my promise to my father.'' (unknown)

``To be sure it will. Indeed, to say the truth, I am convinced within myself that your father had no idea of your giving them any money at all. The assistance he (father) thought of, I dare say, was only such as might be reasonably expected of you; for instance, such as looking out for a comfortable small house for them, helping them to move their things, and sending them presents of fish and game, and so forth, whenever they are in season. I'll lay my life that he (father) meant nothing farther; indeed, it would be very strange and unreasonable if he (father) did. Do but consider, my dear Mr. Dashwood, how excessively comfortable your mother-in-law and her (mother-in-law) daughters may live on the interest of seven thousand pounds, besides the thousand pounds belonging to each of the girls, which brings them in fifty pounds a year a-piece, and, of course, they will pay their mother for their board out of it. Altogether, they will have five hundred a-year amongst them, and what on earth can four women want for more than that?--They will live so cheap! Their housekeeping will be nothing at all. They will have no carriage, no horses, and hardly any servants; they will keep no company, and can have no expenses of any kind! Only conceive how comfortable they will be! Five hundred a year! I am sure I cannot imagine how they will spend half of it; and as to your giving them more, it is quite absurd to think of it. They will be much more able to give YOU something.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word,'' (Mr. Dashwood/Mr. Henry Dashwood)
said Mr. Dashwood,
``I believe you are perfectly right. My father certainly could mean nothing more by his (father) request to me than what you say. I clearly understand it now, and I will strictly fulfil my engagement by such acts of assistance and kindness to them as you have described. When my mother removes into another house my services shall be readily given to accommodate her (mother) as far as I can. Some little present of furniture too may be acceptable then.'' (Mr. Dashwood/Mr. Henry Dashwood)

``Certainly,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
returned Mrs. John Dashwood.
``But, however, ONE thing must be considered. When your father and mother moved to Norland, though the furniture of Stanhill was sold, all the china, plate, and linen was saved, and is now left to your mother. Her (mother) house will therefore be almost completely fitted up as soon as she (mother) takes it.'' (unknown)

``That is a material consideration undoubtedly. A valuable legacy indeed! And yet some of the plate would have been a very pleasant addition to our own stock here.'' (unknown)

``Yes; and the set of breakfast china is twice as handsome as what belongs to this house. A great deal too handsome, in my opinion, for any place THEY can ever afford to live in. But, however, so it is. Your father thought only of THEM. And I must say this: that you owe no particular gratitude to him (father), nor attention to his (father) wishes; for we very well know that if he (father) could, he (father) would have left almost everything in the world to THEM.'' (unknown)

This argument was irresistible. It gave to his (father) intentions whatever of decision was wanting before; and he (father) finally resolved, that it would be absolutely unnecessary, if not highly indecorous, to do more for the widow and children of his (father) father, than such kind of neighbourly acts as his (father) own wife pointed out.

CHAPTER 3

Mrs. Dashwood remained at Norland several months; not from any disinclination to move when the sight of every well known spot ceased to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while; for when her (Dashwood) spirits began to revive, and her (Dashwood) mind became capable of some other exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy remembrances, she (Dashwood) was impatient to be gone, and indefatigable in her (Dashwood) inquiries for a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of Norland; for to remove far from that beloved spot was impossible. But she (Dashwood) could hear of no situation that at once answered her (Dashwood) notions of comfort and ease, and suited the prudence of her (Dashwood) eldest daughter, whose steadier judgment rejected several houses as too large for their income, which her (Dashwood) mother would have approved.

Mrs. Dashwood had been informed by her (Dashwood) husband of the solemn promise on the part of his (husband) son in their favour, which gave comfort to his (husband) last earthly reflections. She (Dashwood) doubted the sincerity of this assurance no more than he (husband) had doubted it himself, and she (Dashwood) thought of it for her (Dashwood) daughters' sake with satisfaction, though as for herself she (Dashwood) was persuaded that a much smaller provision than 7000L would support her (Dashwood) in affluence. For their brother's sake, too, for the sake of his (brother) own heart, she (Dashwood) rejoiced; and she (Dashwood) reproached herself for being unjust to his (brother) merit before, in believing him (brother) incapable of generosity. His (brother) attentive behaviour to herself and his (brother) sisters convinced her (Dashwood) that their welfare was dear to him (brother), and, for a long time, she (Dashwood) firmly relied on the liberality of his (brother) intentions.

The contempt which she (Dashwood) had, very early in their acquaintance, felt for her (Dashwood) daughter-in-law, was very much increased by the farther knowledge of her (Dashwood) character, which half a year's residence in her (Dashwood) family afforded; and perhaps in spite of every consideration of politeness or maternal affection on the side of the former, the two ladies might have found it impossible to have lived together so long, had not a particular circumstance occurred to give still greater eligibility, according to the opinions of Mrs. Dashwood, to her (Dashwood) daughters' continuance at Norland.

This circumstance was a growing attachment between her (Dashwood) eldest girl and the brother of Mrs. John Dashwood, a gentleman-like and pleasing young man, who was introduced to their acquaintance soon after his (acquaintance) sister's establishment at Norland, and who had since spent the greatest part of his (acquaintance) time there.

Some mothers might have encouraged the intimacy from motives of interest, for Edward Ferrars was the eldest son of a man who had died very rich; and some might have repressed it from motives of prudence, for, except a trifling sum, the whole of his (man) fortune depended on the will of his (man) mother. But Mrs. Dashwood was alike uninfluenced by either consideration. It was enough for her (Dashwood) that he (man) appeared to be amiable, that he (man) loved her (Dashwood) daughter, and that Elinor returned the partiality. It was contrary to every doctrine of hers that difference of fortune should keep any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of disposition; and that Elinor's merit should not be acknowledged by every one who knew her (Elinor), was to her (Elinor) comprehension impossible.

Edward Ferrars was not recommended to their good opinion by any peculiar graces of person or address. He (Ferrars) was not handsome, and his (Ferrars) manners required intimacy to make them pleasing. He (Ferrars) was too diffident to do justice to himself; but when his (Ferrars) natural shyness was overcome, his (Ferrars) behaviour gave every indication of an open, affectionate heart. His (Ferrars) understanding was good, and his (Ferrars) education had given it solid improvement. But he (Ferrars) was neither fitted by abilities nor disposition to answer the wishes of his (Ferrars) mother and sister, who longed to see him (Ferrars) distinguished--as--they hardly knew what. They wanted him (Ferrars) to make a fine figure in the world in some manner or other. His (Ferrars) mother wished to interest him (Ferrars) in political concerns, to get him (Ferrars) into parliament, or to see him (Ferrars) connected with some of the great men of the day. Mrs. John Dashwood wished it likewise; but in the mean while, till one of these superior blessings could be attained, it would have quieted her (Dashwood) ambition to see him (Ferrars) driving a barouche. But Edward had no turn for great men or barouches. All his (Edward) wishes centered in domestic comfort and the quiet of private life. Fortunately he (Edward) had a younger brother who was more promising.

Edward had been staying several weeks in the house before he (Edward) engaged much of Mrs. Dashwood's attention; for she (Dashwood) was, at that time, in such affliction as rendered her (Dashwood) careless of surrounding objects. She (Dashwood) saw only that he (Edward) was quiet and unobtrusive, and she (Dashwood) liked him (Edward) for it. He (Edward) did not disturb the wretchedness of her (Dashwood) mind by ill-timed conversation. She (Dashwood) was first called to observe and approve him (Edward) farther, by a reflection which Elinor chanced one day to make on the difference between him (Edward) and his (Edward) sister. It was a contrast which recommended him (Edward) most forcibly to her (Elinor) mother.

``It is enough,'' (she)
said she (Elinor);
``to say that he (Edward) is unlike Fanny is enough. It implies everything amiable. I love him (Edward) already.'' (she)

``I think you will like him (Edward),'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``when you know more of him (Edward).'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Like him (Edward)!'' (mother)
replied her (Elinor) mother with a smile.
``I feel no sentiment of approbation inferior to love.'' (unknown)

``You may esteem him (Edward).'' (unknown)

``I have never yet known what it was to separate esteem and love.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Mrs. Dashwood now took pains to get acquainted with him (Edward). Her (Dashwood) manners were attaching, and soon banished his (Edward) reserve. She (Dashwood) speedily comprehended all his (Edward) merits; the persuasion of his (Edward) regard for Elinor perhaps assisted her (Elinor) penetration; but she (Elinor) really felt assured of his (Edward) worth: and even that quietness of manner, which militated against all her (Elinor) established ideas of what a young man's address ought to be, was no longer uninteresting when she (Elinor) knew his (man) heart to be warm and his (man) temper affectionate.

No sooner did she (Elinor) perceive any symptom of love in his (man) behaviour to Elinor, than she (Elinor) considered their serious attachment as certain, and looked forward to their marriage as rapidly approaching.

``In a few months, my dear Marianne.'' (she)
said she (Marianne),
``Elinor will, in all probability be settled for life. We shall miss her (Elinor); but SHE will be happy.'' (she)

``Oh! Mama, how shall we do without her (Elinor)?'' (unknown)

``My love, it will be scarcely a separation. We shall live within a few miles of each other, and shall meet every day of our lives. You will gain a brother, a real, affectionate brother. I have the highest opinion in the world of Edward's heart. But you look grave, Marianne; do you disapprove your sister's choice?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``I may consider it with some surprise. Edward is very amiable, and I love him (Edward) tenderly. But yet--he (Edward) is not the kind of young man--there is something wanting--his (Edward) figure is not striking; it has none of that grace which I should expect in the man who could seriously attach my sister. His (man) eyes want all that spirit, that fire, which at once announce virtue and intelligence. And besides all this, I am afraid, Mama, he (man) has no real taste. Music seems scarcely to attract him (man), and though he (man) admires Elinor's drawings very much, it is not the admiration of a person who can understand their worth. It is evident, in spite of his (man) frequent attention to her (Elinor) while she (Elinor) draws, that in fact he (man) knows nothing of the matter. He (man) admires as a lover, not as a connoisseur. To satisfy me, those characters must be united. I could not be happy with a man whose taste did not in every point coincide with my own. He (man) must enter into all my feelings; the same books, the same music must charm us both. Oh! mama, how spiritless, how tame was Edward's manner in reading to us last night! I felt for my sister most severely. Yet she (sister) bore it with so much composure, she (sister) seemed scarcely to notice it. I could hardly keep my seat. To hear those beautiful lines which have frequently almost driven me wild, pronounced with such impenetrable calmness, such dreadful indifference!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--
``He (Edward) would certainly have done more justice to simple and elegant prose. I thought so at the time; but you WOULD give him (Edward) Cowper.'' (unknown)

``Nay, Mama, if he (Edward) is not to be animated by Cowper!--but we must allow for difference of taste. Elinor has not my feelings, and therefore she (Elinor) may overlook it, and be happy with him (Edward). But it would have broke MY heart, had I loved him (Edward), to hear him (Edward) read with so little sensibility. Mama, the more I know of the world, the more am I convinced that I shall never see a man whom I can really love. I require so much! He (man) must have all Edward's virtues, and his (Edward) person and manners must ornament his (Edward) goodness with every possible charm.'' (unknown)

``Remember, my love, that you are not seventeen. It is yet too early in life to despair of such a happiness. Why should you be less fortunate than your mother? In one circumstance only, my Marianne, may your destiny be different from hers!'' (unknown)

CHAPTER 4

``What a pity it is, Elinor,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``that Edward should have no taste for drawing.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``No taste for drawing!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``why should you think so? He (Edward) does not draw himself, indeed, but he (Edward) has great pleasure in seeing the performances of other people, and I assure you he (Edward) is by no means deficient in natural taste, though he (Edward) has not had opportunities of improving it. Had he (Edward) ever been in the way of learning, I think he (Edward) would have drawn very well. He (Edward) distrusts his (Edward) own judgment in such matters so much, that he (Edward) is always unwilling to give his (Edward) opinion on any picture; but he (Edward) has an innate propriety and simplicity of taste, which in general direct him (Edward) perfectly right.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Marianne was afraid of offending, and said no more on the subject; but the kind of approbation which Elinor described as excited in him (Edward) by the drawings of other people, was very far from that rapturous delight, which, in her (Elinor) opinion, could alone be called taste. Yet, though smiling within herself at the mistake, she (Elinor) honoured her (Elinor) sister for that blind partiality to Edward which produced it.

``I hope, Marianne,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
continued Elinor,
``you do not consider him (Edward) as deficient in general taste. Indeed, I think I may say that you cannot, for your behaviour to him (Edward) is perfectly cordial, and if THAT were your opinion, I am sure you could never be civil to him (Edward).'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Marianne hardly knew what to say. She (Marianne) would not wound the feelings of her (Marianne) sister on any account, and yet to say what she (Marianne) did not believe was impossible. At length she (Marianne) replied:

``Do not be offended, Elinor, if my praise of him (Edward) is not in every thing equal to your sense of his (Edward) merits. I have not had so many opportunities of estimating the minuter propensities of his (Edward) mind, his (Edward) inclinations and tastes, as you have; but I have the highest opinion in the world of his (Edward) goodness and sense. I think him (Edward) every thing that is worthy and amiable.'' (she)

``I am sure,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, with a smile,
``that his (Edward) dearest friends could not be dissatisfied with such commendation as that. I do not perceive how you could express yourself more warmly.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Marianne was rejoiced to find her (Marianne) sister so easily pleased.

``Of his (Edward) sense and his (Edward) goodness,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
continued Elinor,
``no one can, I think, be in doubt, who has seen him (Edward) often enough to engage him (Edward) in unreserved conversation. The excellence of his (Edward) understanding and his (Edward) principles can be concealed only by that shyness which too often keeps him (Edward) silent. You know enough of him (Edward) to do justice to his (Edward) solid worth. But of his (Edward) minuter propensities, as you call them you have from peculiar circumstances been kept more ignorant than myself. He (Edward) and I have been at times thrown a good deal together, while you have been wholly engrossed on the most affectionate principle by my mother. I have seen a great deal of him (Edward), have studied his (Edward) sentiments and heard his (Edward) opinion on subjects of literature and taste; and, upon the whole, I venture to pronounce that his (Edward) mind is well-informed, enjoyment of books exceedingly great, his (Edward) imagination lively, his (Edward) observation just and correct, and his (Edward) taste delicate and pure. His (Edward) abilities in every respect improve as much upon acquaintance as his (Edward) manners and person. At first sight, his (Edward) address is certainly not striking; and his (Edward) person can hardly be called handsome, till the expression of his (Edward) eyes, which are uncommonly good, and the general sweetness of his (Edward) countenance, is perceived. At present, I know him (Edward) so well, that I think him (Edward) really handsome; or at least, almost so. What say you, Marianne?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I shall very soon think him (Edward) handsome, Elinor, if I do not now. When you tell me to love him (Edward) as a brother, I shall no more see imperfection in his (Edward) face, than I now do in his (Edward) heart.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor started at this declaration, and was sorry for the warmth she (Elinor) had been betrayed into, in speaking of him (Edward). She (Elinor) felt that Edward stood very high in her (Elinor) opinion. She (Elinor) believed the regard to be mutual; but she (Elinor) required greater certainty of it to make Marianne's conviction of their attachment agreeable to her (Marianne). She (Marianne) knew that what Marianne and her (Marianne) mother conjectured one moment, they believed the next--that with them, to wish was to hope, and to hope was to expect. She (Marianne) tried to explain the real state of the case to her (Marianne) sister.

``I do not attempt to deny,'' (she)
said she (Marianne),
``that I think very highly of him (Edward)--that I greatly esteem, that I like him (Edward).'' (she)

Marianne here burst forth with indignation--

``Esteem him (Edward)! Like him (Edward)! Cold-hearted Elinor! Oh! worse than cold-hearted! Ashamed of being otherwise. Use those words again, and I will leave the room this moment.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Elinor could not help laughing.

``Excuse me,'' (she)
said she (Elinor);
``and be assured that I meant no offence to you, by speaking, in so quiet a way, of my own feelings. Believe them to be stronger than I have declared; believe them, in short, to be such as his (Edward) merit, and the suspicion--the hope of his (Edward) affection for me may warrant, without imprudence or folly. But farther than this you must not believe. I am by no means assured of his (Edward) regard for me. There are moments when the extent of it seems doubtful; and till his (Edward) sentiments are fully known, you cannot wonder at my wishing to avoid any encouragement of my own partiality, by believing or calling it more than it is. In my heart I feel little--scarcely any doubt of his (Edward) preference. But there are other points to be considered besides his (Edward) inclination. He (Edward) is very far from being independent. What his (Edward) mother really is we cannot know; but, from Fanny's occasional mention of her (Fanny) conduct and opinions, we have never been disposed to think her (Fanny) amiable; and I am very much mistaken if Edward is not himself aware that there would be many difficulties in his (Edward) way, if he (Edward) were to wish to marry a woman who had not either a great fortune or high rank.'' (she)

Marianne was astonished to find how much the imagination of her (Marianne) mother and herself had outstripped the truth.

``And you really are not engaged to him (Edward)!'' (she)
said she (Marianne).
``Yet it certainly soon will happen. But two advantages will proceed from this delay. I shall not lose you so soon, and Edward will have greater opportunity of improving that natural taste for your favourite pursuit which must be so indispensably necessary to your future felicity. Oh! if he (Edward) should be so far stimulated by your genius as to learn to draw himself, how delightful it would be!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor had given her (Elinor) real opinion to her (Elinor) sister. She (Elinor) could not consider her (Elinor) partiality for Edward in so prosperous a state as Marianne had believed it. There was, at times, a want of spirits about him (Edward) which, if it did not denote indifference, spoke of something almost as unpromising. A doubt of her (Marianne) regard, supposing him (Edward) to feel it, need not give him (Edward) more than inquietude. It would not be likely to produce that dejection of mind which frequently attended him (Edward). A more reasonable cause might be found in the dependent situation which forbade the indulgence of his (Edward) affection. She (Marianne) knew that his (Edward) mother neither behaved to him (Edward) so as to make his (Edward) home comfortable at present, nor to give him (Edward) any assurance that he (Edward) might form a home for himself, without strictly attending to her (mother) views for his (Edward) aggrandizement. With such a knowledge as this, it was impossible for Elinor to feel easy on the subject. She (Elinor) was far from depending on that result of his (Edward) preference of her (Elinor), which her (Elinor) mother and sister still considered as certain. Nay, the longer they were together the more doubtful seemed the nature of his (Edward) regard; and sometimes, for a few painful minutes, she (Elinor) believed it to be no more than friendship.

But, whatever might really be its limits, it was enough, when perceived by his (Edward) sister, to make her (sister) uneasy, and at the same time, -LRB-which was still more common,-RRB- to make her (sister) uncivil. She (sister) took the first opportunity of affronting her (sister) mother-in-law on the occasion, talking to her (sister) so expressively of her (sister) brother's great expectations, of Mrs. Ferrars's resolution that both her (sister) sons should marry well, and of the danger attending any young woman who attempted to DRAW HIM IN; that Mrs. Dashwood could neither pretend to be unconscious, nor endeavor to be calm. She (Dashwood) gave her (Dashwood) an answer which marked her (Dashwood) contempt, and instantly left the room, resolving that, whatever might be the inconvenience or expense of so sudden a removal, her (Dashwood) beloved Elinor should not be exposed another week to such insinuations.

In this state of her (Elinor) spirits, a letter was delivered to her (Elinor) from the post, which contained a proposal particularly well timed. It was the offer of a small house, on very easy terms, belonging to a relation of her (Elinor) own, a gentleman of consequence and property in Devonshire. The letter was from this gentleman himself, and written in the true spirit of friendly accommodation. He (gentleman) understood that she (Elinor) was in need of a dwelling; and though the house he (gentleman) now offered her (Elinor) was merely a cottage, he (gentleman) assured her (Elinor) that everything should be done to it which she (Elinor) might think necessary, if the situation pleased her (Elinor). He (gentleman) earnestly pressed her (Elinor), after giving the particulars of the house and garden, to come with her (Elinor) daughters to Barton Park, the place of his (Barton) own residence, from whence she (Elinor) might judge, herself, whether Barton Cottage, for the houses were in the same parish, could, by any alteration, be made comfortable to her (Elinor). He (Barton) seemed really anxious to accommodate them and the whole of his (Barton) letter was written in so friendly a style as could not fail of giving pleasure to his (Barton) cousin; more especially at a moment when she (Elinor) was suffering under the cold and unfeeling behaviour of her (Elinor) nearer connections. She (Elinor) needed no time for deliberation or inquiry. Her (Elinor) resolution was formed as she (Elinor) read. The situation of Barton, in a county so far distant from Sussex as Devonshire, which, but a few hours before, would have been a sufficient objection to outweigh every possible advantage belonging to the place, was now its first recommendation. To quit the neighbourhood of Norland was no longer an evil; it was an object of desire; it was a blessing, in comparison of the misery of continuing her (Elinor) daughter-in-law's guest; and to remove for ever from that beloved place would be less painful than to inhabit or visit it while such a woman was its mistress. She (woman) instantly wrote Sir John Middleton her (woman) acknowledgment of his (Middleton) kindness, and her (woman) acceptance of his (Middleton) proposal; and then hastened to shew both letters to her (woman) daughters, that she (woman) might be secure of their approbation before her (woman) answer were sent.

Elinor had always thought it would be more prudent for them to settle at some distance from Norland, than immediately amongst their present acquaintance. On THAT head, therefore, it was not for her (Elinor) to oppose her (Elinor) mother's intention of removing into Devonshire. The house, too, as described by Sir John, was on so simple a scale, and the rent so uncommonly moderate, as to leave her (John) no right of objection on either point; and, therefore, though it was not a plan which brought any charm to her (John) fancy, though it was a removal from the vicinity of Norland beyond her (John) wishes, she (John) made no attempt to dissuade her (John) mother from sending a letter of acquiescence.

CHAPTER 5

No sooner was her (John) answer dispatched, than Mrs. Dashwood indulged herself in the pleasure of announcing to her (Dashwood) son-in-law and his (son-in-law) wife that she (Dashwood) was provided with a house, and should incommode them no longer than till every thing were ready for her (Dashwood) inhabiting it. They heard her (Dashwood) with surprise. Mrs. John Dashwood said nothing; but her (Dashwood) husband civilly hoped that she (Dashwood) would not be settled far from Norland. She (Dashwood) had great satisfaction in replying that she (Dashwood) was going into Devonshire.--Edward turned hastily towards her (Dashwood), on hearing this, and, in a voice of surprise and concern, which required no explanation to her (Dashwood), repeated,

``Devonshire! Are you, indeed, going there? So far from hence! And to what part of it?'' (her)
She (Dashwood) explained the situation. It was within four miles northward of Exeter.

``It is but a cottage,'' (she)
she (Dashwood) continued,
``but I hope to see many of my friends in it. A room or two can easily be added; and if my friends find no difficulty in travelling so far to see me, I am sure I will find none in accommodating them.'' (she)

She (Dashwood) concluded with a very kind invitation to Mr. and Mrs. John Dashwood to visit her (Dashwood) at Barton; and to Edward she (Dashwood) gave one with still greater affection. Though her (Dashwood) late conversation with her (Dashwood) daughter-in-law had made her (Dashwood) resolve on remaining at Norland no longer than was unavoidable, it had not produced the smallest effect on her (Dashwood) in that point to which it principally tended. To separate Edward and Elinor was as far from being her (Elinor) object as ever; and she (Elinor) wished to show Mrs. John Dashwood, by this pointed invitation to her (Dashwood) brother, how totally she (Dashwood) disregarded her (Dashwood) disapprobation of the match.

Mr. John Dashwood told his (Dashwood) mother again and again how exceedingly sorry he (Dashwood) was that she (Dashwood) had taken a house at such a distance from Norland as to prevent his (Dashwood) being of any service to her (Dashwood) in removing her (Dashwood) furniture. He (Dashwood) really felt conscientiously vexed on the occasion; for the very exertion to which he (Dashwood) had limited the performance of his (Dashwood) promise to his (Dashwood) father was by this arrangement rendered impracticable.-- The furniture was all sent around by water. It chiefly consisted of household linen, plate, china, and books, with a handsome pianoforte of Marianne's. Mrs. John Dashwood saw the packages depart with a sigh: she (Dashwood) could not help feeling it hard that as Mrs. Dashwood's income would be so trifling in comparison with their own, she (Dashwood) should have any handsome article of furniture.

Mrs. Dashwood took the house for a twelvemonth; it was ready furnished, and she (Dashwood) might have immediate possession. No difficulty arose on either side in the agreement; and she (Dashwood) waited only for the disposal of her (Dashwood) effects at Norland, and to determine her (Dashwood) future household, before she (Dashwood) set off for the west; and this, as she (Dashwood) was exceedingly rapid in the performance of everything that interested her (Dashwood), was soon done.--The horses which were left her (Dashwood) by her (Dashwood) husband had been sold soon after his (husband) death, and an opportunity now offering of disposing of her (Dashwood) carriage, she (Dashwood) agreed to sell that likewise at the earnest advice of her (Dashwood) eldest daughter. For the comfort of her (Dashwood) children, had she (Dashwood) consulted only her (Dashwood) own wishes, she (Dashwood) would have kept it; but the discretion of Elinor prevailed. HER wisdom too limited the number of their servants to three; two maids and a man, with whom they were speedily provided from amongst those who had formed their establishment at Norland.

The man and one of the maids were sent off immediately into Devonshire, to prepare the house for their mistress's arrival; for as Lady Middleton was entirely unknown to Mrs. Dashwood, she (Dashwood) preferred going directly to the cottage to being a visitor at Barton Park; and she (Dashwood) relied so undoubtingly on Sir John's description of the house, as to feel no curiosity to examine it herself till she (John) entered it as her (John) own. Her (John) eagerness to be gone from Norland was preserved from diminution by the evident satisfaction of her (John) daughter-in-law in the prospect of her (John) removal; a satisfaction which was but feebly attempted to be concealed under a cold invitation to her (John) to defer her (John) departure. Now was the time when her (John) son-in-law's promise to his (son-in-law) father might with particular propriety be fulfilled. Since he (son-in-law) had neglected to do it on first coming to the estate, their quitting his (son-in-law) house might be looked on as the most suitable period for its accomplishment. But Mrs. Dashwood began shortly to give over every hope of the kind, and to be convinced, from the general drift of his (son-in-law) discourse, that his (son-in-law) assistance extended no farther than their maintenance for six months at Norland. He (son-in-law) so frequently talked of the increasing expenses of housekeeping, and of the perpetual demands upon his (son-in-law) purse, which a man of any consequence in the world was beyond calculation exposed to, that he (son-in-law) seemed rather to stand in need of more money himself than to have any design of giving money away.

In a very few weeks from the day which brought Sir John Middleton's first letter to Norland, every thing was so far settled in their future abode as to enable Mrs. Dashwood and her (Dashwood) daughters to begin their journey.

Many were the tears shed by them in their last adieus to a place so much beloved.

``Dear, dear Norland!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, as she (Marianne) wandered alone before the house, on the last evening of their being there;
``when shall I cease to regret you!--when learn to feel a home elsewhere!--Oh! happy house, could you know what I suffer in now viewing you from this spot, from whence perhaps I may view you no more!--And you, ye well-known trees!--but you will continue the same.--No leaf will decay because we are removed, nor any branch become motionless although we can observe you no longer!--No; you will continue the same; unconscious of the pleasure or the regret you occasion, and insensible of any change in those who walk under your shade!--But who will remain to enjoy you?'' (she)

CHAPTER 6

The first part of their journey was performed in too melancholy a disposition to be otherwise than tedious and unpleasant. But as they drew towards the end of it, their interest in the appearance of a country which they were to inhabit overcame their dejection, and a view of Barton Valley as they entered it gave them cheerfulness. It was a pleasant fertile spot, well wooded, and rich in pasture. After winding along it for more than a mile, they reached their own house. A small green court was the whole of its demesne in front; and a neat wicket gate admitted them into it.

As a house, Barton Cottage, though small, was comfortable and compact; but as a cottage it was defective, for the building was regular, the roof was tiled, the window shutters were not painted green, nor were the walls covered with honeysuckles. A narrow passage led directly through the house into the garden behind. On each side of the entrance was a sitting room, about sixteen feet square; and beyond them were the offices and the stairs. Four bed-rooms and two garrets formed the rest of the house. It had not been built many years and was in good repair. In comparison of Norland, it was poor and small indeed!--but the tears which recollection called forth as they entered the house were soon dried away. They were cheered by the joy of the servants on their arrival, and each for the sake of the others resolved to appear happy. It was very early in September; the season was fine, and from first seeing the place under the advantage of good weather, they received an impression in its favour which was of material service in recommending it to their lasting approbation.

The situation of the house was good. High hills rose immediately behind, and at no great distance on each side; some of which were open downs, the others cultivated and woody. The village of Barton was chiefly on one of these hills, and formed a pleasant view from the cottage windows. The prospect in front was more extensive; it commanded the whole of the valley, and reached into the country beyond. The hills which surrounded the cottage terminated the valley in that direction; under another name, and in another course, it branched out again between two of the steepest of them.

With the size and furniture of the house Mrs. Dashwood was upon the whole well satisfied; for though her (Dashwood) former style of life rendered many additions to the latter indispensable, yet to add and improve was a delight to her (Dashwood); and she (Dashwood) had at this time ready money enough to supply all that was wanted of greater elegance to the apartments.

``As for the house itself, to be sure,'' (she)
said she (Dashwood),
``it is too small for our family, but we will make ourselves tolerably comfortable for the present, as it is too late in the year for improvements. Perhaps in the spring, if I have plenty of money, as I dare say I shall, we may think about building. These parlors are both too small for such parties of our friends as I hope to see often collected here; and I have some thoughts of throwing the passage into one of them with perhaps a part of the other, and so leave the remainder of that other for an entrance; this, with a new drawing room which may be easily added, and a bed-chamber and garret above, will make it a very snug little cottage. I could wish the stairs were handsome. But one must not expect every thing; though I suppose it would be no difficult matter to widen them. I shall see how much I am before-hand with the world in the spring, and we will plan our improvements accordingly.'' (she)

In the mean time, till all these alterations could be made from the savings of an income of five hundred a-year by a woman who never saved in her (woman) life, they were wise enough to be contented with the house as it was; and each of them was busy in arranging their particular concerns, and endeavoring, by placing around them books and other possessions, to form themselves a home. Marianne's pianoforte was unpacked and properly disposed of; and Elinor's drawings were affixed to the walls of their sitting room.

In such employments as these they were interrupted soon after breakfast the next day by the entrance of their landlord, who called to welcome them to Barton, and to offer them every accommodation from his (Barton) own house and garden in which theirs might at present be deficient. Sir John Middleton was a good looking man about forty. He (Middleton) had formerly visited at Stanhill, but it was too long for his (Middleton) young cousins to remember him (Middleton). His (Middleton) countenance was thoroughly good-humoured; and his (Middleton) manners were as friendly as the style of his (Middleton) letter. Their arrival seemed to afford him (Middleton) real satisfaction, and their comfort to be an object of real solicitude to him (Middleton). He (Middleton) said much of his (Middleton) earnest desire of their living in the most sociable terms with his (Middleton) family, and pressed them so cordially to dine at Barton Park every day till they were better settled at home, that, though his (Barton) entreaties were carried to a point of perseverance beyond civility, they could not give offence. His (Barton) kindness was not confined to words; for within an hour after he (Barton) left them, a large basket full of garden stuff and fruit arrived from the park, which was followed before the end of the day by a present of game. He (Barton) insisted, moreover, on conveying all their letters to and from the post for them, and would not be denied the satisfaction of sending them his (Barton) newspaper every day.

Lady Middleton had sent a very civil message by him (Barton), denoting her (Middleton) intention of waiting on Mrs. Dashwood as soon as she (Middleton) could be assured that her (Middleton) visit would be no inconvenience; and as this message was answered by an invitation equally polite, her (Middleton) ladyship was introduced to them the next day.

They were, of course, very anxious to see a person on whom so much of their comfort at Barton must depend; and the elegance of her (Middleton) appearance was favourable to their wishes. Lady Middleton was not more than six or seven and twenty; her (Middleton) face was handsome, her (Middleton) figure tall and striking, and her (Middleton) address graceful. Her (Middleton) manners had all the elegance which her (Middleton) husband's wanted. But they would have been improved by some share of his (husband) frankness and warmth; and her (Middleton) visit was long enough to detract something from their first admiration, by shewing that, though perfectly well-bred, she (Middleton) was reserved, cold, and had nothing to say for herself beyond the most common-place inquiry or remark.

Conversation however was not wanted, for Sir John was very chatty, and Lady Middleton had taken the wise precaution of bringing with her (Middleton) their eldest child, a fine little boy about six years old, by which means there was one subject always to be recurred to by the ladies in case of extremity, for they had to enquire his (boy) name and age, admire his (boy) beauty, and ask him (boy) questions which his (boy) mother answered for him (boy), while he (boy) hung about her (mother) and held down his (boy) head, to the great surprise of her (mother) ladyship, who wondered at his (boy) being so shy before company, as he (boy) could make noise enough at home. On every formal visit a child ought to be of the party, by way of provision for discourse. In the present case it took up ten minutes to determine whether the boy were most like his (boy) father or mother, and in what particular he (boy) resembled either, for of course every body differed, and every body was astonished at the opinion of the others.

An opportunity was soon to be given to the Dashwoods of debating on the rest of the children, as Sir John would not leave the house without securing their promise of dining at the park the next day.

CHAPTER 7

Barton Park was about half a mile from the cottage. The ladies had passed near it in their way along the valley, but it was screened from their view at home by the projection of a hill. The house was large and handsome; and the Middletons lived in a style of equal hospitality and elegance. The former was for Sir John's gratification, the latter for that of his (Barton) lady. They were scarcely ever without some friends staying with them in the house, and they kept more company of every kind than any other family in the neighbourhood. It was necessary to the happiness of both; for however dissimilar in temper and outward behaviour, they strongly resembled each other in that total want of talent and taste which confined their employments, unconnected with such as society produced, within a very narrow compass. Sir John was a sportsman, Lady Middleton a mother. He (sportsman) hunted and shot, and she (Middleton) humoured her (Middleton) children; and these were their only resources. Lady Middleton had the advantage of being able to spoil her (Middleton) children all the year round, while Sir John's independent employments were in existence only half the time. Continual engagements at home and abroad, however, supplied all the deficiencies of nature and education; supported the good spirits of Sir John, and gave exercise to the good breeding of his (sportsman) wife.

Lady Middleton piqued herself upon the elegance of her (Middleton) table, and of all her (Middleton) domestic arrangements; and from this kind of vanity was her (Middleton) greatest enjoyment in any of their parties. But Sir John's satisfaction in society was much more real; he (sportsman) delighted in collecting about him (sportsman) more young people than his (sportsman) house would hold, and the noisier they were the better was he (sportsman) pleased. He (sportsman) was a blessing to all the juvenile part of the neighbourhood, for in summer he (sportsman) was for ever forming parties to eat cold ham and chicken out of doors, and in winter his (sportsman) private balls were numerous enough for any young lady who was not suffering under the unsatiable appetite of fifteen.

The arrival of a new family in the country was always a matter of joy to him (sportsman), and in every point of view he (sportsman) was charmed with the inhabitants he (sportsman) had now procured for his (sportsman) cottage at Barton. The Miss Dashwoods were young, pretty, and unaffected. It was enough to secure his (sportsman) good opinion; for to be unaffected was all that a pretty girl could want to make her (girl) mind as captivating as her (girl) person. The friendliness of his (sportsman) disposition made him (sportsman) happy in accommodating those, whose situation might be considered, in comparison with the past, as unfortunate. In showing kindness to his (sportsman) cousins therefore he (sportsman) had the real satisfaction of a good heart; and in settling a family of females only in his (sportsman) cottage, he (sportsman) had all the satisfaction of a sportsman; for a sportsman, though he (sportsman) esteems only those of his (sportsman) sex who are sportsmen likewise, is not often desirous of encouraging their taste by admitting them to a residence within his (sportsman) own manor.

Mrs. Dashwood and her (Dashwood) daughters were met at the door of the house by Sir John, who welcomed them to Barton Park with unaffected sincerity; and as he (Barton) attended them to the drawing room repeated to the young ladies the concern which the same subject had drawn from him (Barton) the day before, at being unable to get any smart young men to meet them. They would see, he (Barton) said, only one gentleman there besides himself; a particular friend who was staying at the park, but who was neither very young nor very gay. He (Barton) hoped they would all excuse the smallness of the party, and could assure them it should never happen so again. He (Barton) had been to several families that morning in hopes of procuring some addition to their number, but it was moonlight and every body was full of engagements. Luckily Lady Middleton's mother had arrived at Barton within the last hour, and as she (mother) was a very cheerful agreeable woman, he (Barton) hoped the young ladies would not find it so very dull as they might imagine. The young ladies, as well as their mother, were perfectly satisfied with having two entire strangers of the party, and wished for no more.

Mrs. Jennings, Lady Middleton's mother, was a good-humoured, merry, fat, elderly woman, who talked a great deal, seemed very happy, and rather vulgar. She (woman) was full of jokes and laughter, and before dinner was over had said many witty things on the subject of lovers and husbands; hoped they had not left their hearts behind them in Sussex, and pretended to see them blush whether they did or not. Marianne was vexed at it for her (Marianne) sister's sake, and turned her (Marianne) eyes towards Elinor to see how she (Marianne) bore these attacks, with an earnestness which gave Elinor far more pain than could arise from such common-place raillery as Mrs. Jennings's.

Colonel Brandon, the friend of Sir John, seemed no more adapted by resemblance of manner to be his (Colonel) friend, than Lady Middleton was to be his (Colonel) wife, or Mrs. Jennings to be Lady Middleton's mother. He (Colonel) was silent and grave. His (Colonel) appearance however was not unpleasing, in spite of his (Colonel) being in the opinion of Marianne and Margaret an absolute old bachelor, for he (Colonel) was on the wrong side of five and thirty; but though his (Colonel) face was not handsome, his (Colonel) countenance was sensible, and his (Colonel) address was particularly gentlemanlike.

There was nothing in any of the party which could recommend them as companions to the Dashwoods; but the cold insipidity of Lady Middleton was so particularly repulsive, that in comparison of it the gravity of Colonel Brandon, and even the boisterous mirth of Sir John and his (Colonel) mother-in-law was interesting. Lady Middleton seemed to be roused to enjoyment only by the entrance of her (Middleton) four noisy children after dinner, who pulled her (Middleton) about, tore her (Middleton) clothes, and put an end to every kind of discourse except what related to themselves.

In the evening, as Marianne was discovered to be musical, she (Marianne) was invited to play. The instrument was unlocked, every body prepared to be charmed, and Marianne, who sang very well, at their request went through the chief of the songs which Lady Middleton had brought into the family on her (Middleton) marriage, and which perhaps had lain ever since in the same position on the pianoforte, for her (Middleton) ladyship had celebrated that event by giving up music, although by her (Middleton) mother's account, she (Middleton) had played extremely well, and by her (Middleton) own was very fond of it.

Marianne's performance was highly applauded. Sir John was loud in his (chief) admiration at the end of every song, and as loud in his (chief) conversation with the others while every song lasted. Lady Middleton frequently called him (chief) to order, wondered how any one's attention could be diverted from music for a moment, and asked Marianne to sing a particular song which Marianne had just finished. Colonel Brandon alone, of all the party, heard her (Brandon) without being in raptures. He (Colonel) paid her (Brandon) only the compliment of attention; and she (Brandon) felt a respect for him (Colonel) on the occasion, which the others had reasonably forfeited by their shameless want of taste. His (Colonel) pleasure in music, though it amounted not to that ecstatic delight which alone could sympathize with her (Brandon) own, was estimable when contrasted against the horrible insensibility of the others; and she (Brandon) was reasonable enough to allow that a man of five and thirty might well have outlived all acuteness of feeling and every exquisite power of enjoyment. She (Brandon) was perfectly disposed to make every allowance for the colonel's advanced state of life which humanity required.

CHAPTER 8

Mrs. Jennings was a widow with an ample jointure. She (Jennings) had only two daughters, both of whom she (Jennings) had lived to see respectably married, and she (Jennings) had now therefore nothing to do but to marry all the rest of the world. In the promotion of this object she (Jennings) was zealously active, as far as her (Jennings) ability reached; and missed no opportunity of projecting weddings among all the young people of her (Jennings) acquaintance. She (Jennings) was remarkably quick in the discovery of attachments, and had enjoyed the advantage of raising the blushes and the vanity of many a young lady by insinuations of her (lady) power over such a young man; and this kind of discernment enabled her (lady) soon after her (lady) arrival at Barton decisively to pronounce that Colonel Brandon was very much in love with Marianne Dashwood. She (Brandon) rather suspected it to be so, on the very first evening of their being together, from his (Colonel) listening so attentively while she (Brandon) sang to them; and when the visit was returned by the Middletons' dining at the cottage, the fact was ascertained by his (Colonel) listening to her (Brandon) again. It must be so. She (Brandon) was perfectly convinced of it. It would be an excellent match, for HE (Colonel) was rich, and SHE was handsome. Mrs. Jennings had been anxious to see Colonel Brandon well married, ever since her (Brandon) connection with Sir John first brought him (Colonel) to her (Brandon) knowledge; and she (Brandon) was always anxious to get a good husband for every pretty girl.

The immediate advantage to herself was by no means inconsiderable, for it supplied her (Brandon) with endless jokes against them both. At the park she (Brandon) laughed at the colonel, and in the cottage at Marianne. To the former her (Marianne) raillery was probably, as far as it regarded only himself, perfectly indifferent; but to the latter it was at first incomprehensible; and when its object was understood, she (Marianne) hardly knew whether most to laugh at its absurdity, or censure its impertinence, for she (Marianne) considered it as an unfeeling reflection on the colonel's advanced years, and on his (colonel) forlorn condition as an old bachelor.

Mrs. Dashwood, who could not think a man five years younger than herself, so exceedingly ancient as he (man) appeared to the youthful fancy of her (Dashwood) daughter, ventured to clear Mrs. Jennings from the probability of wishing to throw ridicule on his (man) age.

``But at least, Mama, you cannot deny the absurdity of the accusation, though you may not think it intentionally ill-natured. Colonel Brandon is certainly younger than Mrs. Jennings, but he (Colonel) is old enough to be MY father; and if he (Colonel) were ever animated enough to be in love, must have long outlived every sensation of the kind. It is too ridiculous! When is a man to be safe from such wit, if age and infirmity will not protect him (man)?'' (unknown)

``Infirmity!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``do you call Colonel Brandon infirm? I can easily suppose that his (Colonel) age may appear much greater to you than to my mother; but you can hardly deceive yourself as to his (Colonel) having the use of his (Colonel) limbs!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Did not you hear him (Colonel) complain of the rheumatism? and is not that the commonest infirmity of declining life?'' (unknown)

``My dearest child,'' (mother)
said her (mother) mother, laughing,
``at this rate you must be in continual terror of MY decay; and it must seem to you a miracle that my life has been extended to the advanced age of forty.'' (mother)

``Mama, you are not doing me justice. I know very well that Colonel Brandon is not old enough to make his (Colonel) friends yet apprehensive of losing him (Colonel) in the course of nature. He (Colonel) may live twenty years longer. But thirty-five has nothing to do with matrimony.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``thirty-five and seventeen had better not have any thing to do with matrimony together. But if there should by any chance happen to be a woman who is single at seven and twenty, I should not think Colonel Brandon's being thirty-five any objection to his (Colonel) marrying HER.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``A woman of seven and twenty,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, after pausing a moment,
``can never hope to feel or inspire affection again, and if her (Marianne) home be uncomfortable, or her (Marianne) fortune small, I can suppose that she (Marianne) might bring herself to submit to the offices of a nurse, for the sake of the provision and security of a wife. In his (Colonel) marrying such a woman therefore there would be nothing unsuitable. It would be a compact of convenience, and the world would be satisfied. In my eyes it would be no marriage at all, but that would be nothing. To me it would seem only a commercial exchange, in which each wished to be benefited at the expense of the other.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``It would be impossible, I know,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``to convince you that a woman of seven and twenty could feel for a man of thirty-five anything near enough to love, to make him (man) a desirable companion to her (woman). But I must object to your dooming Colonel Brandon and his (Colonel) wife to the constant confinement of a sick chamber, merely because he (Colonel) chanced to complain yesterday -LRB-a very cold damp day-RRB- of a slight rheumatic feel in one of his (Colonel) shoulders.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``But he (Colonel) talked of flannel waistcoats,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne;
``and with me a flannel waistcoat is invariably connected with aches, cramps, rheumatisms, and every species of ailment that can afflict the old and the feeble.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Had he (Colonel) been only in a violent fever, you would not have despised him (Colonel) half so much. Confess, Marianne, is not there something interesting to you in the flushed cheek, hollow eye, and quick pulse of a fever?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Soon after this, upon Elinor's leaving the room,

``Mama,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Marianne,
``I have an alarm on the subject of illness which I cannot conceal from you. I am sure Edward Ferrars is not well. We have now been here almost a fortnight, and yet he (Ferrars) does not come. Nothing but real indisposition could occasion this extraordinary delay. What else can detain him (Ferrars) at Norland?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Had you any idea of his (Ferrars) coming so soon?'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood.
``I had none. On the contrary, if I have felt any anxiety at all on the subject, it has been in recollecting that he (Ferrars) sometimes showed a want of pleasure and readiness in accepting my invitation, when I talked of his (Ferrars) coming to Barton. Does Elinor expect him (Ferrars) already?'' (unknown)

``I have never mentioned it to her (Elinor), but of course she (Elinor) must.'' (unknown)

``I rather think you are mistaken, for when I was talking to her (Elinor) yesterday of getting a new grate for the spare bedchamber, she (Elinor) observed that there was no immediate hurry for it, as it was not likely that the room would be wanted for some time.'' (unknown)

``How strange this is! what can be the meaning of it! But the whole of their behaviour to each other has been unaccountable! How cold, how composed were their last adieus! How languid their conversation the last evening of their being together! In Edward's farewell there was no distinction between Elinor and me: it was the good wishes of an affectionate brother to both. Twice did I leave them purposely together in the course of the last morning, and each time did he (brother) most unaccountably follow me out of the room. And Elinor, in quitting Norland and Edward, cried not as I did. Even now her (Elinor) self-command is invariable. When is she (Elinor) dejected or melancholy? When does she (Elinor) try to avoid society, or appear restless and dissatisfied in it?'' (Barton)

CHAPTER 9

The Dashwoods were now settled at Barton with tolerable comfort to themselves. The house and the garden, with all the objects surrounding them, were now become familiar, and the ordinary pursuits which had given to Norland half its charms were engaged in again with far greater enjoyment than Norland had been able to afford, since the loss of their father. Sir John Middleton, who called on them every day for the first fortnight, and who was not in the habit of seeing much occupation at home, could not conceal his (Middleton) amazement on finding them always employed.

Their visitors, except those from Barton Park, were not many; for, in spite of Sir John's urgent entreaties that they would mix more in the neighbourhood, and repeated assurances of his (Barton) carriage being always at their service, the independence of Mrs. Dashwood's spirit overcame the wish of society for her (Dashwood) children; and she (Dashwood) was resolute in declining to visit any family beyond the distance of a walk. There were but few who could be so classed; and it was not all of them that were attainable. About a mile and a half from the cottage, along the narrow winding valley of Allenham, which issued from that of Barton, as formerly described, the girls had, in one of their earliest walks, discovered an ancient respectable looking mansion which, by reminding them a little of Norland, interested their imagination and made them wish to be better acquainted with it. But they learnt, on enquiry, that its possessor, an elderly lady of very good character, was unfortunately too infirm to mix with the world, and never stirred from home.

The whole country about them abounded in beautiful walks. The high downs which invited them from almost every window of the cottage to seek the exquisite enjoyment of air on their summits, were a happy alternative when the dirt of the valleys beneath shut up their superior beauties; and towards one of these hills did Marianne and Margaret one memorable morning direct their steps, attracted by the partial sunshine of a showery sky, and unable longer to bear the confinement which the settled rain of the two preceding days had occasioned. The weather was not tempting enough to draw the two others from their pencil and their book, in spite of Marianne's declaration that the day would be lastingly fair, and that every threatening cloud would be drawn off from their hills; and the two girls set off together.

They gaily ascended the downs, rejoicing in their own penetration at every glimpse of blue sky; and when they caught in their faces the animating gales of a high south-westerly wind, they pitied the fears which had prevented their mother and Elinor from sharing such delightful sensations.

``Is there a felicity in the world,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``superior to this?--Margaret, we will walk here at least two hours.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
