Margaret agreed, and they pursued their way against the wind, resisting it with laughing delight for about twenty minutes longer, when suddenly the clouds united over their heads, and a driving rain set full in their face.-- Chagrined and surprised, they were obliged, though unwillingly, to turn back, for no shelter was nearer than their own house. One consolation however remained for them, to which the exigence of the moment gave more than usual propriety; it was that of running with all possible speed down the steep side of the hill which led immediately to their garden gate.

They set off. Marianne had at first the advantage, but a false step brought her (Marianne) suddenly to the ground; and Margaret, unable to stop herself to assist her (Margaret), was involuntarily hurried along, and reached the bottom in safety.

A gentleman carrying a gun, with two pointers playing round him (gentleman), was passing up the hill and within a few yards of Marianne, when her (Marianne) accident happened. He (gentleman) put down his (gentleman) gun and ran to her (Marianne) assistance. She (Marianne) had raised herself from the ground, but her (Marianne) foot had been twisted in her (Marianne) fall, and she (Marianne) was scarcely able to stand. The gentleman offered his (gentleman) services; and perceiving that her (Marianne) modesty declined what her (Marianne) situation rendered necessary, took her (Marianne) up in his (gentleman) arms without farther delay, and carried her (Marianne) down the hill. Then passing through the garden, the gate of which had been left open by Margaret, he (gentleman) bore her (Margaret) directly into the house, whither Margaret was just arrived, and quitted not his (gentleman) hold till he (gentleman) had seated her (Margaret) in a chair in the parlour.

Elinor and her (Elinor) mother rose up in amazement at their entrance, and while the eyes of both were fixed on him (gentleman) with an evident wonder and a secret admiration which equally sprung from his (gentleman) appearance, he (gentleman) apologized for his (gentleman) intrusion by relating its cause, in a manner so frank and so graceful that his (gentleman) person, which was uncommonly handsome, received additional charms from his (gentleman) voice and expression. Had he (gentleman) been even old, ugly, and vulgar, the gratitude and kindness of Mrs. Dashwood would have been secured by any act of attention to her (Dashwood) child; but the influence of youth, beauty, and elegance, gave an interest to the action which came home to her (Dashwood) feelings.

She (Dashwood) thanked him (gentleman) again and again; and, with a sweetness of address which always attended her (Dashwood), invited him (gentleman) to be seated. But this he (gentleman) declined, as he (gentleman) was dirty and wet. Mrs. Dashwood then begged to know to whom she (Dashwood) was obliged. His (gentleman) name, he (gentleman) replied, was Willoughby, and his (gentleman) present home was at Allenham, from whence he (gentleman) hoped she (Willoughby) would allow him (gentleman) the honour of calling tomorrow to enquire after Miss Dashwood. The honour was readily granted, and he (gentleman) then departed, to make himself still more interesting, in the midst of a heavy rain.

His (gentleman) manly beauty and more than common gracefulness were instantly the theme of general admiration, and the laugh which his (gentleman) gallantry raised against Marianne received particular spirit from his (gentleman) exterior attractions.-- Marianne herself had seen less of his (gentleman) Mama the rest, for the confusion which crimsoned over her (Marianne) face, on his (gentleman) lifting her (Marianne) up, had robbed her (Marianne) of the power of regarding him (gentleman) after their entering the house. But she (Marianne) had seen enough of him (gentleman) to join in all the admiration of the others, and with an energy which always adorned her (Marianne) praise. His (gentleman) person and air were equal to what her (Marianne) fancy had ever drawn for the hero of a favourite story; and in his (hero) carrying her (Marianne) into the house with so little previous formality, there was a rapidity of thought which particularly recommended the action to her (Marianne). Every circumstance belonging to him (hero) was interesting. His (hero) name was good, his (hero) residence was in their favourite village, and she (Marianne) soon found out that of all manly dresses a shooting-jacket was the most becoming. Her (Marianne) imagination was busy, her (Marianne) reflections were pleasant, and the pain of a sprained ankle was disregarded.

Sir John called on them as soon as the next interval of fair weather that morning allowed him (hero) to get out of doors; and Marianne's accident being related to him (hero), he (hero) was eagerly asked whether he (hero) knew any gentleman of the name of Willoughby at Allenham.

``Willoughby!'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
cried Sir John;
``what, is HE (Willoughby) in the country? That is good news however; I will ride over tomorrow, and ask him (Willoughby) to dinner on Thursday.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``You know him (Willoughby) then,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood.

``Know him (Willoughby)! to be sure I do. Why, he (Willoughby) is down here every year.'' (unknown)

``And what sort of a young man is he (man)?'' (unknown)

``As good a kind of fellow as ever lived, I assure you. A very decent shot, and there is not a bolder rider in England.'' (unknown)

``And is that all you can say for him (rider)?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne, indignantly.
``But what are his (rider) manners on more intimate acquaintance? What his (rider) pursuits, his (rider) talents, and genius?'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Sir John was rather puzzled.

``Upon my soul,'' (he)
said he (rider),
``I do not know much about him (rider) as to all THAT. But he (rider) is a pleasant, good humoured fellow, and has got the nicest little black bitch of a pointer I ever saw. Was she (bitch) out with him (rider) today?'' (he)

But Marianne could no more satisfy him (rider) as to the colour of Mr. Willoughby's pointer, than he (Willoughby) could describe to her (Marianne) the shades of his (Willoughby) mind.

``But who is he (Willoughby)?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.
``Where does he (Willoughby) come from? Has he (Willoughby) a house at Allenham?'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

On this point Sir John could give more certain intelligence; and he (Willoughby) told them that Mr. Willoughby had no property of his (Willoughby) own in the country; that he (Willoughby) resided there only while he (Willoughby) was visiting the old lady at Allenham Court, to whom he (Willoughby) was related, and whose possessions he (Willoughby) was to inherit; adding,

``Yes, yes, he (Willoughby) is very well worth catching I can tell you, Miss Dashwood; he (Willoughby) has a pretty little estate of his (Willoughby) own in Somersetshire besides; and if I were you, I would not give him (Willoughby) up to my younger sister, in spite of all this tumbling down hills. Miss Marianne must not expect to have all the men to herself. Brandon will be jealous, if she (Brandon) does not take care.'' (he)

``I do not believe,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood, with a good humoured smile,
``that Mr. Willoughby will be incommoded by the attempts of either of MY daughters towards what you call CATCHING him (Willoughby). It is not an employment to which they have been brought up. Men are very safe with us, let them be ever so rich. I am glad to find, however, from what you say, that he (Willoughby) is a respectable young man, and one whose acquaintance will not be ineligible.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``He (Willoughby) is as good a sort of fellow, I believe, as ever lived,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
repeated Sir John.
``I remember last Christmas at a little hop at the park, he (Willoughby) danced from eight o'clock till four, without once sitting down.'' (unknown)

``Did he (Willoughby) indeed?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne with sparkling eyes,
``and with elegance, with spirit?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Yes; and he (Willoughby) was up again at eight to ride to covert.'' (unknown)

``That is what I like; that is what a young man ought to be. Whatever be his (man) pursuits, his (man) eagerness in them should know no moderation, and leave him (man) no sense of fatigue.'' (unknown)

``Aye, aye, I see how it will be,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Sir John,
``I see how it will be. You will be setting your cap at him (man) now, and never think of poor Brandon.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``That is an expression, Sir John,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, warmly,
``which I particularly dislike. I abhor every common-place phrase by which wit is intended; and `setting one's cap at a man,' or `making a conquest,' are the most odious of all. Their tendency is gross and illiberal; and if their construction could ever be deemed clever, time has long ago destroyed all its ingenuity.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Sir John did not much understand this reproof; but he (man) laughed as heartily as if he (man) did, and then replied,

``Ay, you will make conquests enough, I dare say, one way or other. Poor Brandon! he (man) is quite smitten already, and he (man) is very well worth setting your cap at, I can tell you, in spite of all this tumbling about and spraining of ankles.'' (he)

CHAPTER 10

Marianne's preserver, as Margaret, with more elegance than precision, styled Willoughby, called at the cottage early the next morning to make his (Willoughby) personal enquiries. He (Willoughby) was received by Mrs. Dashwood with more than politeness; with a kindness which Sir John's account of him (Willoughby) and her (John) own gratitude prompted; and every thing that passed during the visit tended to assure him (Willoughby) of the sense, elegance, mutual affection, and domestic comfort of the family to whom accident had now introduced him (Willoughby). Of their personal charms he (Willoughby) had not required a second interview to be convinced.

Miss Dashwood had a delicate complexion, regular features, and a remarkably pretty figure. Marianne was still handsomer. Her (Marianne) form, though not so correct as her (Marianne) sister's, in having the advantage of height, was more striking; and her (Marianne) face was so lovely, that when in the common cant of praise, she (Marianne) was called a beautiful girl, truth was less violently outraged than usually happens. Her (Marianne) skin was very brown, but, from its transparency, her (Marianne) complexion was uncommonly brilliant; her (Marianne) features were all good; her (Marianne) smile was sweet and attractive; and in her (Marianne) eyes, which were very dark, there was a life, a spirit, an eagerness, which could hardily be seen without delight. From Willoughby their expression was at first held back, by the embarrassment which the remembrance of his (Willoughby) assistance created. But when this passed away, when her (Marianne) spirits became collected, when she (Marianne) saw that to the perfect good-breeding of the gentleman, he (gentleman) united frankness and vivacity, and above all, when she (Marianne) heard him (gentleman) declare, that of music and dancing he (gentleman) was passionately fond, she (Marianne) gave him (gentleman) such a look of approbation as secured the largest share of his (gentleman) discourse to herself for the rest of his (gentleman) stay.

It was only necessary to mention any favourite amusement to engage her (Marianne) to talk. She (Marianne) could not be silent when such points were introduced, and she (Marianne) had neither shyness nor reserve in their discussion. They speedily discovered that their enjoyment of dancing and music was mutual, and that it arose from a general conformity of judgment in all that related to either. Encouraged by this to a further examination of his (gentleman) opinions, she (Marianne) proceeded to question him (gentleman) on the subject of books; her (Marianne) favourite authors were brought forward and dwelt upon with so rapturous a delight, that any young man of five and twenty must have been insensible indeed, not to become an immediate convert to the excellence of such works, however disregarded before. Their taste was strikingly alike. The same books, the same passages were idolized by each--or if any difference appeared, any objection arose, it lasted no longer than till the force of her (Marianne) arguments and the brightness of her (Marianne) eyes could be displayed. He (man) acquiesced in all her (Marianne) decisions, caught all her (Marianne) enthusiasm; and long before his (man) visit concluded, they conversed with the familiarity of a long-established acquaintance.

``Well, Marianne,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, as soon as he (man) had left them,
``for ONE morning I think you have done pretty well. You have already ascertained Mr. Willoughby's opinion in almost every matter of importance. You know what he (Willoughby) thinks of Cowper and Scott; you are certain of his (Willoughby) estimating their beauties as he (Willoughby) ought, and you have received every assurance of his (Willoughby) admiring Pope no more than is proper. But how is your acquaintance to be long supported, under such extraordinary despatch of every subject for discourse? You will soon have exhausted each favourite topic. Another meeting will suffice to explain his (acquaintance) sentiments on picturesque beauty, and second marriages, and then you can have nothing farther to ask.'' (he)
--

``Elinor,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``is this fair? is this just? are my ideas so scanty? But I see what you mean. I have been too much at my ease, too happy, too frank. I have erred against every common-place notion of decorum; I have been open and sincere where I ought to have been reserved, spiritless, dull, and deceitful--had I talked only of the weather and the roads, and had I spoken only once in ten minutes, this reproach would have been spared.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``My love,'' (mother)
said her (I) mother,
``you must not be offended with Elinor--she (Elinor) was only in jest. I should scold her (Elinor) myself, if she (Elinor) were capable of wishing to check the delight of your conversation with our new friend.'' (mother)
-- Marianne was softened in a moment.

Willoughby, on his (Willoughby) side, gave every proof of his (Willoughby) pleasure in their acquaintance, which an evident wish of improving it could offer. He (Willoughby) came to them every day. To enquire after Marianne was at first his (Willoughby) excuse; but the encouragement of his (Willoughby) reception, to which every day gave greater kindness, made such an excuse unnecessary before it had ceased to be possible, by Marianne's perfect recovery. She (Marianne) was confined for some days to the house; but never had any confinement been less irksome. Willoughby was a young man of good abilities, quick imagination, lively spirits, and open, affectionate manners. He (Willoughby) was exactly formed to engage Marianne's heart, for with all this, he (Willoughby) joined not only a captivating person, but a natural ardour of mind which was now roused and increased by the example of her (Marianne) own, and which recommended him (Willoughby) to her (Marianne) affection beyond every thing else.

His (Willoughby) society became gradually her (Marianne) most exquisite enjoyment. They read, they talked, they sang together; his (Willoughby) musical talents were considerable; and he (Willoughby) read with all the sensibility and spirit which Edward had unfortunately wanted.

In Mrs. Dashwood's estimation he (Edward) was as faultless as in Marianne's; and Elinor saw nothing to censure in him (Edward) but a propensity, in which he (Edward) strongly resembled and peculiarly delighted her (Elinor) sister, of saying too much what he (Edward) thought on every occasion, without attention to persons or circumstances. In hastily forming and giving his (Edward) opinion of other people, in sacrificing general politeness to the enjoyment of undivided attention where his (Edward) heart was engaged, and in slighting too easily the forms of worldly propriety, he (Edward) displayed a want of caution which Elinor could not approve, in spite of all that he (Edward) and Marianne could say in its support.

Marianne began now to perceive that the desperation which had seized her (Marianne) at sixteen and a half, of ever seeing a man who could satisfy her (Marianne) ideas of perfection, had been rash and unjustifiable. Willoughby was all that her (Marianne) fancy had delineated in that unhappy hour and in every brighter period, as capable of attaching her (Marianne); and his (Willoughby) behaviour declared his (Willoughby) wishes to be in that respect as earnest, as his (Willoughby) abilities were strong.

Her (Marianne) mother too, in whose mind not one speculative thought of their marriage had been raised, by his (Willoughby) prospect of riches, was led before the end of a week to hope and expect it; and secretly to congratulate herself on having gained two such sons-in-law as Edward and Willoughby.

Colonel Brandon's partiality for Marianne, which had so early been discovered by his (Willoughby) friends, now first became perceptible to Elinor, when it ceased to be noticed by them. Their attention and wit were drawn off to his (Willoughby) more fortunate rival; and the raillery which the other had incurred before any partiality arose, was removed when his (Willoughby) feelings began really to call for the ridicule so justly annexed to sensibility. Elinor was obliged, though unwillingly, to believe that the sentiments which Mrs. Jennings had assigned him (Willoughby) for her (Jennings) own satisfaction, were now actually excited by her (Jennings) sister; and that however a general resemblance of disposition between the parties might forward the affection of Mr. Willoughby, an equally striking opposition of character was no hindrance to the regard of Colonel Brandon. She (Brandon) saw it with concern; for what could a silent man of five and thirty hope, when opposed to a very lively one of five and twenty? and as she (Brandon) could not even wish him (man) successful, she (Brandon) heartily wished him (man) indifferent. She (Brandon) liked him (man)--in spite of his (man) gravity and reserve, she (Brandon) beheld in him (man) an object of interest. His (man) manners, though serious, were mild; and his (man) reserve appeared rather the result of some oppression of spirits than of any natural gloominess of temper. Sir John had dropped hints of past injuries and disappointments, which justified her (John) belief of his (man) being an unfortunate man, and she (John) regarded him (man) with respect and compassion.

Perhaps she (John) pitied and esteemed him (man) the more because he (man) was slighted by Willoughby and Marianne, who, prejudiced against him (Willoughby) for being neither lively nor young, seemed resolved to undervalue his (Willoughby) merits.

``Brandon is just the kind of man,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
said Willoughby one day, when they were talking of him (Willoughby) together,
``whom every body speaks well of, and nobody cares about; whom all are delighted to see, and nobody remembers to talk to.'' (him)

``That is exactly what I think of him (Willoughby),'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne.

``Do not boast of it, however,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``for it is injustice in both of you. He (Willoughby) is highly esteemed by all the family at the park, and I never see him (Willoughby) myself without taking pains to converse with him (Willoughby).'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``That he (Willoughby) is patronised by YOU,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
replied Willoughby,
``is certainly in his (Willoughby) favour; but as for the esteem of the others, it is a reproach in itself. Who would submit to the indignity of being approved by such a woman as Lady Middleton and Mrs. Jennings, that could command the indifference of any body else?'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

``But perhaps the abuse of such people as yourself and Marianne will make amends for the regard of Lady Middleton and her (Middleton) mother. If their praise is censure, your censure may be praise, for they are not more undiscerning, than you are prejudiced and unjust.'' (unknown)

``In defence of your protege you can even be saucy.'' (unknown)

``My protege, as you call him (protege), is a sensible man; and sense will always have attractions for me. Yes, Marianne, even in a man between thirty and forty. He (man) has seen a great deal of the world; has been abroad, has read, and has a thinking mind. I have found him (man) capable of giving me much information on various subjects; and he (man) has always answered my inquiries with readiness of good-breeding and good nature.'' (unknown)

``That is to say,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne contemptuously,
``he (man) has told you, that in the East Indies the climate is hot, and the mosquitoes are troublesome.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``He (man) WOULD have told me so, I doubt not, had I made any such inquiries, but they happened to be points on which I had been previously informed.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
said Willoughby,
``his (Willoughby) observations may have extended to the existence of nabobs, gold mohrs, and palanquins.'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

``I may venture to say that HIS (Willoughby) observations have stretched much further than your candour. But why should you dislike him (Willoughby)?'' (unknown)

``I do not dislike him (Willoughby). I consider him (Willoughby), on the contrary, as a very respectable man, who has every body's good word, and nobody's notice; who, has more money than he (man) can spend, more time than he (man) knows how to employ, and two new coats every year.'' (unknown)

``Add to which,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``that he (man) has neither genius, taste, nor spirit. That his (man) understanding has no brilliancy, his (man) feelings no ardour, and his (man) voice no expression.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``You decide on his (man) imperfections so much in the mass,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``and so much on the strength of your own imagination, that the commendation I am able to give of him (man) is comparatively cold and insipid. I can only pronounce him (man) to be a sensible man, well-bred, well-informed, of gentle address, and, I believe, possessing an amiable heart.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Miss Dashwood,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
cried Willoughby,
``you are now using me unkindly. You are endeavouring to disarm me by reason, and to convince me against my will. But it will not do. You shall find me as stubborn as you can be artful. I have three unanswerable reasons for disliking Colonel Brandon; he (Colonel) threatened me with rain when I wanted it to be fine; he (Colonel) has found fault with the hanging of my curricle, and I cannot persuade him (Colonel) to buy my brown mare. If it will be any satisfaction to you, however, to be told, that I believe his (Colonel) character to be in other respects irreproachable, I am ready to confess it. And in return for an acknowledgment, which must give me some pain, you cannot deny me the privilege of disliking him (Colonel) as much as ever.'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

CHAPTER 11

Little had Mrs. Dashwood or her (Dashwood) daughters imagined when they first came into Devonshire, that so many engagements would arise to occupy their time as shortly presented themselves, or that they should have such frequent invitations and such constant visitors as to leave them little leisure for serious employment. Yet such was the case. When Marianne was recovered, the schemes of amusement at home and abroad, which Sir John had been previously forming, were put into execution. The private balls at the park then began; and parties on the water were made and accomplished as often as a showery October would allow. In every meeting of the kind Willoughby was included; and the ease and familiarity which naturally attended these parties were exactly calculated to give increasing intimacy to his (Willoughby) acquaintance with the Dashwoods, to afford him (Willoughby) opportunity of witnessing the excellencies of Marianne, of marking his (Willoughby) animated admiration of her (Marianne), and of receiving, in her (Marianne) behaviour to himself, the most pointed assurance of her (Marianne) affection.

Elinor could not be surprised at their attachment. She (Elinor) only wished that it were less openly shewn; and once or twice did venture to suggest the propriety of some self-command to Marianne. But Marianne abhorred all concealment where no real disgrace could attend unreserve; and to aim at the restraint of sentiments which were not in themselves illaudable, appeared to her (Marianne) not merely an unnecessary effort, but a disgraceful subjection of reason to common-place and mistaken notions. Willoughby thought the same; and their behaviour at all times, was an illustration of their opinions.

When he (Willoughby) was present she (Marianne) had no eyes for any one else. Every thing he (Willoughby) did, was right. Every thing he (Willoughby) said, was clever. If their evenings at the park were concluded with cards, he (Willoughby) cheated himself and all the rest of the party to get her (Marianne) a good hand. If dancing formed the amusement of the night, they were partners for half the time; and when obliged to separate for a couple of dances, were careful to stand together and scarcely spoke a word to any body else. Such conduct made them of course most exceedingly laughed at; but ridicule could not shame, and seemed hardly to provoke them.

Mrs. Dashwood entered into all their feelings with a warmth which left her (Dashwood) no inclination for checking this excessive display of them. To her (Dashwood) it was but the natural consequence of a strong affection in a young and ardent mind.

This was the season of happiness to Marianne. Her (Marianne) heart was devoted to Willoughby, and the fond attachment to Norland, which she (Marianne) brought with her (Marianne) from Sussex, was more likely to be softened than she (Marianne) had thought it possible before, by the charms which his (Willoughby) society bestowed on her (Marianne) present home.

Elinor's happiness was not so great. Her (Marianne) heart was not so much at ease, nor her (Marianne) satisfaction in their amusements so pure. They afforded her (Marianne) no companion that could make amends for what she (Marianne) had left behind, nor that could teach her (Marianne) to think of Norland with less regret than ever. Neither Lady Middleton nor Mrs. Jennings could supply to her (Middleton) the conversation she (Middleton) missed; although the latter was an everlasting talker, and from the first had regarded her (Middleton) with a kindness which ensured her (Middleton) a large share of her (Middleton) discourse. She (Middleton) had already repeated her (Middleton) own history to Elinor three or four times; and had Elinor's memory been equal to her (Elinor) means of improvement, she (Elinor) might have known very early in their acquaintance all the particulars of Mr. Jennings's last illness, and what he (Jennings) said to his (Jennings) wife a few minutes before he (Jennings) died. Lady Middleton was more agreeable than her (Middleton) mother only in being more silent. Elinor needed little observation to perceive that her (Elinor) reserve was a mere calmness of manner with which sense had nothing to do. Towards her (Elinor) husband and mother she (Elinor) was the same as to them; and intimacy was therefore neither to be looked for nor desired. She (Elinor) had nothing to say one day that she (Elinor) had not said the day before. Her (Elinor) insipidity was invariable, for even her (Elinor) spirits were always the same; and though she (Elinor) did not oppose the parties arranged by her (Elinor) husband, provided every thing were conducted in style and her (Elinor) two eldest children attended her (Elinor), she (Elinor) never appeared to receive more enjoyment from them than she (Elinor) might have experienced in sitting at home;--and so little did her (Elinor) presence add to the pleasure of the others, by any share in their conversation, that they were sometimes only reminded of her (Elinor) being amongst them by her (Elinor) solicitude about her (Elinor) troublesome boys.

In Colonel Brandon alone, of all her (Brandon) new acquaintance, did Elinor find a person who could in any degree claim the respect of abilities, excite the interest of friendship, or give pleasure as a companion. Willoughby was out of the question. Her (Elinor) admiration and regard, even her (Elinor) sisterly regard, was all his (Willoughby) own; but he (Willoughby) was a lover; his (Willoughby) attentions were wholly Marianne's, and a far less agreeable man might have been more generally pleasing. Colonel Brandon, unfortunately for himself, had no such encouragement to think only of Marianne, and in conversing with Elinor he (Colonel) found the greatest consolation for the indifference of her (Elinor) sister.

Elinor's compassion for him (Colonel) increased, as she (Elinor) had reason to suspect that the misery of disappointed love had already been known to him (Colonel). This suspicion was given by some words which accidently dropped from him (Colonel) one evening at the park, when they were sitting down together by mutual consent, while the others were dancing. His (Colonel) eyes were fixed on Marianne, and, after a silence of some minutes, he (Colonel) said, with a faint smile,

``Your sister, I understand, does not approve of second attachments.'' (he)

``No,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``her (Elinor) opinions are all romantic.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Or rather, as I believe, she (Elinor) considers them impossible to exist.'' (unknown)

``I believe she (Elinor) does. But how she (Elinor) contrives it without reflecting on the character of her (Elinor) own father, who had himself two wives, I know not. A few years however will settle her (Elinor) opinions on the reasonable basis of common sense and observation; and then they may be more easy to define and to justify than they now are, by any body but herself.'' (unknown)

``This will probably be the case,'' (he)
he (father) replied;
``and yet there is something so amiable in the prejudices of a young mind, that one is sorry to see them give way to the reception of more general opinions.'' (he)

``I cannot agree with you there,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.
``There are inconveniences attending such feelings as Marianne's, which all the charms of enthusiasm and ignorance of the world cannot atone for. Her (Marianne) systems have all the unfortunate tendency of setting propriety at nought; and a better acquaintance with the world is what I look forward to as her (Marianne) greatest possible advantage.'' (he)

After a short pause he (acquaintance) resumed the conversation by saying,--

``Does your sister make no distinction in her (sister) objections against a second attachment? or is it equally criminal in every body? Are those who have been disappointed in their first choice, whether from the inconstancy of its object, or the perverseness of circumstances, to be equally indifferent during the rest of their lives?'' (he)

``Upon my word, I am not acquainted with the minutiae of her (sister) principles. I only know that I never yet heard her (sister) admit any instance of a second attachment's being pardonable.'' (unknown)

``This,'' (he)
said he (sister),
``cannot hold; but a change, a total change of sentiments--No, no, do not desire it; for when the romantic refinements of a young mind are obliged to give way, how frequently are they succeeded by such opinions as are but too common, and too dangerous! I speak from experience. I once knew a lady who in temper and mind greatly resembled your sister, who thought and judged like her (sister), but who from an inforced change--from a series of unfortunate circumstances'' (he)
-- Here he (sister) stopt suddenly; appeared to think that he (sister) had said too much, and by his (sister) countenance gave rise to conjectures, which might not otherwise have entered Elinor's head. The lady would probably have passed without suspicion, had he (sister) not convinced Miss Dashwood that what concerned her (Dashwood) ought not to escape his (sister) lips. As it was, it required but a slight effort of fancy to connect his (sister) emotion with the tender recollection of past regard. Elinor attempted no more. But Marianne, in her (Marianne) place, would not have done so little. The whole story would have been speedily formed under her (Marianne) active imagination; and every thing established in the most melancholy order of disastrous love.

CHAPTER 12

As Elinor and Marianne were walking together the next morning the latter communicated a piece of news to her (Elinor) sister, which in spite of all that she (Elinor) knew before of Marianne's imprudence and want of thought, surprised her (Marianne) by its extravagant testimony of both. Marianne told her (Marianne), with the greatest delight, that Willoughby had given her (Marianne) a horse, one that he (Willoughby) had bred himself on his (Willoughby) estate in Somersetshire, and which was exactly calculated to carry a woman. Without considering that it was not in her (woman) mother's plan to keep any horse, that if she (woman) were to alter her (woman) resolution in favour of this gift, she (woman) must buy another for the servant, and keep a servant to ride it, and after all, build a stable to receive them, she (woman) had accepted the present without hesitation, and told her (woman) sister of it in raptures.

``He (servant) intends to send his (servant) groom into Somersetshire immediately for it,'' (she)
she (woman) added,
``and when it arrives we will ride every day. You shall share its use with me. Imagine to yourself, my dear Elinor, the delight of a gallop on some of these downs.'' (she)

Most unwilling was she (Elinor) to awaken from such a dream of felicity to comprehend all the unhappy truths which attended the affair; and for some time she (Elinor) refused to submit to them. As to an additional servant, the expense would be a trifle; Mama she (Mama) was sure would never object to it; and any horse would do for HIM; he (servant) might always get one at the park; as to a stable, the merest shed would be sufficient. Elinor then ventured to doubt the propriety of her (Elinor) receiving such a present from a man so little, or at least so lately known to her (Elinor). This was too much.

``You are mistaken, Elinor,'' (she)
said she (Elinor) warmly,
``in supposing I know very little of Willoughby. I have not known him (Willoughby) long indeed, but I am much better acquainted with him (Willoughby), than I am with any other creature in the world, except yourself and mama. It is not time or opportunity that is to determine intimacy;--it is disposition alone. Seven years would be insufficient to make some people acquainted with each other, and seven days are more than enough for others. I should hold myself guilty of greater impropriety in accepting a horse from my brother, than from Willoughby. Of John I know very little, though we have lived together for years; but of Willoughby my judgment has long been formed.'' (she)

Elinor thought it wisest to touch that point no more. She (Elinor) knew her (Elinor) sister's temper. Opposition on so tender a subject would only attach her (Elinor) the more to her (Elinor) own opinion. But by an appeal to her (Elinor) affection for her (Elinor) mother, by representing the inconveniences which that indulgent mother must draw on herself, if -LRB-as would probably be the case-RRB- she (mother) consented to this increase of establishment, Marianne was shortly subdued; and she (Marianne) promised not to tempt her (Marianne) mother to such imprudent kindness by mentioning the offer, and to tell Willoughby when she (Marianne) saw him (Willoughby) next, that it must be declined.

She (Marianne) was faithful to her (Marianne) word; and when Willoughby called at the cottage, the same day, Elinor heard her (Elinor) express her (Elinor) disappointment to him (Willoughby) in a low voice, on being obliged to forego the acceptance of his (Willoughby) present. The reasons for this alteration were at the same time related, and they were such as to make further entreaty on his (Willoughby) side impossible. His (Willoughby) concern however was very apparent; and after expressing it with earnestness, he (Willoughby) added, in the same low voice,--

``But, Marianne, the horse is still yours, though you cannot use it now. I shall keep it only till you can claim it. When you leave Barton to form your own establishment in a more lasting home, Queen Mab shall receive you.'' (he)

This was all overheard by Miss Dashwood; and in the whole of the sentence, in his (Barton) manner of pronouncing it, and in his (Barton) addressing her (Dashwood) sister by her (Dashwood) Christian name alone, she (Dashwood) instantly saw an intimacy so decided, a meaning so direct, as marked a perfect agreement between them. From that moment she (Dashwood) doubted not of their being engaged to each other; and the belief of it created no other surprise than that she (Dashwood), or any of their friends, should be left by tempers so frank, to discover it by accident.

Margaret related something to her (Margaret) the next day, which placed this matter in a still clearer light. Willoughby had spent the preceding evening with them, and Margaret, by being left some time in the parlour with only him (Willoughby) and Marianne, had had opportunity for observations, which, with a most important face, she (Marianne) communicated to her (Marianne) eldest sister, when they were next by themselves.

``Oh, Elinor!'' (she)
she (Elinor) cried,
``I have such a secret to tell you about Marianne. I am sure she (Marianne) will be married to Mr. Willoughby very soon.'' (she)

``You have said so,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``almost every day since they first met on High-church Down; and they had not known each other a week, I believe, before you were certain that Marianne wore his (Willoughby) picture round her (Marianne) neck; but it turned out to be only the miniature of our great uncle.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``But indeed this is quite another thing. I am sure they will be married very soon, for he (uncle) has got a lock of her (Marianne) hair.'' (unknown)

``Take care, Margaret. It may be only the hair of some great uncle of HIS (uncle).'' (unknown)

``But, indeed, Elinor, it is Marianne's. I am almost sure it is, for I saw him (uncle) cut it off. Last night after tea, when you and mama went out of the room, they were whispering and talking together as fast as could be, and he (uncle) seemed to be begging something of her (mama), and presently he (uncle) took up her (mama) scissors and cut off a long lock of her (mama) hair, for it was all tumbled down her (mama) back; and he (uncle) kissed it, and folded it up in a piece of white paper; and put it into his (uncle) pocket-book.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

For such particulars, stated on such authority, Elinor could not withhold her (Elinor) credit; nor was she (Elinor) disposed to it, for the circumstance was in perfect unison with what she (Elinor) had heard and seen herself.

Margaret's sagacity was not always displayed in a way so satisfactory to her (Margaret) sister. When Mrs. Jennings attacked her (Jennings) one evening at the park, to give the name of the young man who was Elinor's particular favourite, which had been long a matter of great curiosity to her (Elinor), Margaret answered by looking at her (Margaret) sister, and saying,

``I must not tell, may I, Elinor?'' (sister)

This of course made every body laugh; and Elinor tried to laugh too. But the effort was painful. She (Elinor) was convinced that Margaret had fixed on a person whose name she (Margaret) could not bear with composure to become a standing joke with Mrs. Jennings.

Marianne felt for her (Marianne) most sincerely; but she (Marianne) did more harm than good to the cause, by turning very red and saying in an angry manner to Margaret,

``Remember that whatever your conjectures may be, you have no right to repeat them.'' (Margaret)

``I never had any conjectures about it,'' (Margaret)
replied Margaret;
``it was you who told me of it yourself.'' (Margaret)

This increased the mirth of the company, and Margaret was eagerly pressed to say something more.

``Oh! pray, Miss Margaret, let us know all about it,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings.
``What is the gentleman's name?'' (unknown)

``I must not tell, ma'am. But I know very well what it is; and I know where he (gentleman) is too.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes, we can guess where he (gentleman) is; at his (gentleman) own house at Norland to be sure. He (gentleman) is the curate of the parish I dare say.'' (unknown)

``No, THAT he (gentleman) is not. He (gentleman) is of no profession at all.'' (unknown)

``Margaret,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne with great warmth,
``you know that all this is an invention of your own, and that there is no such person in existence.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Well, then, he (gentleman) is lately dead, Marianne, for I am sure there was such a man once, and his (man) name begins with an F.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Most grateful did Elinor feel to Lady Middleton for observing, at this moment,

``that it rained very hard,'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)
though she (Elinor) believed the interruption to proceed less from any attention to her (Elinor), than from her (Elinor) ladyship's great dislike of all such inelegant subjects of raillery as delighted her (Elinor) husband and mother. The idea however started by her (Elinor), was immediately pursued by Colonel Brandon, who was on every occasion mindful of the feelings of others; and much was said on the subject of rain by both of them. Willoughby opened the piano-forte, and asked Marianne to sit down to it; and thus amidst the various endeavours of different people to quit the topic, it fell to the ground. But not so easily did Elinor recover from the alarm into which it had thrown her (Elinor).

A party was formed this evening for going on the following day to see a very fine place about twelve miles from Barton, belonging to a brother-in-law of Colonel Brandon, without whose interest it could not be seen, as the proprietor, who was then abroad, had left strict orders on that head. The grounds were declared to be highly beautiful, and Sir John, who was particularly warm in their praise, might be allowed to be a tolerable judge, for he (judge) had formed parties to visit them, at least, twice every summer for the last ten years. They contained a noble piece of water; a sail on which was to a form a great part of the morning's amusement; cold provisions were to be taken, open carriages only to be employed, and every thing conducted in the usual style of a complete party of pleasure.

To some few of the company it appeared rather a bold undertaking, considering the time of year, and that it had rained every day for the last fortnight;--and Mrs. Dashwood, who had already a cold, was persuaded by Elinor to stay at home.

CHAPTER 13

Their intended excursion to Whitwell turned out very different from what Elinor had expected. She (Elinor) was prepared to be wet through, fatigued, and frightened; but the event was still more unfortunate, for they did not go at all.

By ten o'clock the whole party was assembled at the park, where they were to breakfast. The morning was rather favourable, though it had rained all night, as the clouds were then dispersing across the sky, and the sun frequently appeared. They were all in high spirits and good humour, eager to be happy, and determined to submit to the greatest inconveniences and hardships rather than be otherwise.

While they were at breakfast the letters were brought in. Among the rest there was one for Colonel Brandon;--he (Colonel) took it, looked at the direction, changed colour, and immediately left the room.

``What is the matter with Brandon?'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Sir John.

Nobody could tell.

``I hope he (Colonel) has had no bad news,'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)
said Lady Middleton.
``It must be something extraordinary that could make Colonel Brandon leave my breakfast table so suddenly.'' (he)

In about five minutes he (Colonel) returned.

``No bad news, Colonel, I hope;'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings, as soon as he (Colonel) entered the room.

``None at all, ma'am, I thank you.'' (unknown)

``Was it from Avignon? I hope it is not to say that your sister is worse.'' (unknown)

``No, ma'am. It came from town, and is merely a letter of business.'' (unknown)

``But how came the hand to discompose you so much, if it was only a letter of business? Come, come, this won't do, Colonel; so let us hear the truth of it.'' (unknown)

``My dear madam,'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)
said Lady Middleton,
``recollect what you are saying.'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)

``Perhaps it is to tell you that your cousin Fanny is married?'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings, without attending to her (Jennings) daughter's reproof.

``No, indeed, it is not.'' (unknown)

``Well, then, I know who it is from, Colonel. And I hope she (Jennings) is well.'' (unknown)

``Whom do you mean, ma'am?'' (he)
said he (Colonel), colouring a little.

``Oh! you know who I mean.'' (unknown)

``I am particularly sorry, ma'am,'' (he)
said he (Colonel), addressing Lady Middleton,
``that I should receive this letter today, for it is on business which requires my immediate attendance in town.'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)

``In town!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings.
``What can you have to do in town at this time of year?'' (unknown)

``My own loss is great,'' (he)
he (Colonel) continued,
``in being obliged to leave so agreeable a party; but I am the more concerned, as I fear my presence is necessary to gain your admittance at Whitwell.'' (he)

What a blow upon them all was this!

``But if you write a note to the housekeeper, Mr. Brandon,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, eagerly,
``will it not be sufficient?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

He (Brandon) shook his (Brandon) head.

``We must go,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Sir John.--
``It shall not be put off when we are so near it. You cannot go to town till tomorrow, Brandon, that is all.'' (unknown)

``I wish it could be so easily settled. But it is not in my power to delay my journey for one day!'' (unknown)

``If you would but let us know what your business is,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings,
``we might see whether it could be put off or not.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``You would not be six hours later,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
said Willoughby,
``if you were to defer your journey till our return.'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

``I cannot afford to lose ONE hour.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
--

Elinor then heard Willoughby say, in a low voice to Marianne,

``There are some people who cannot bear a party of pleasure. Brandon is one of them. He (Willoughby) was afraid of catching cold I dare say, and invented this trick for getting out of it. I would lay fifty guineas the letter was of his (Willoughby) own writing.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``I have no doubt of it,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
replied Marianne.

``There is no persuading you to change your mind, Brandon, I know of old,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Sir John,
``when once you are determined on anything. But, however, I hope you will think better of it. Consider, here are the two Miss Careys come over from Newton, the three Miss Dashwoods walked up from the cottage, and Mr. Willoughby got up two hours before his (Willoughby) usual time, on purpose to go to Whitwell.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Colonel Brandon again repeated his (Colonel) sorrow at being the cause of disappointing the party; but at the same time declared it to be unavoidable.

``Well, then, when will you come back again?'' (unknown)

``I hope we shall see you at Barton,'' (ladyship)
added her (Brandon) ladyship,
``as soon as you can conveniently leave town; and we must put off the party to Whitwell till you return.'' (ladyship)

``You are very obliging. But it is so uncertain, when I may have it in my power to return, that I dare not engage for it at all.'' (unknown)

``Oh! he (Whitwell) must and shall come back,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
cried Sir John.
``If he (Whitwell) is not here by the end of the week, I shall go after him (Whitwell).'' (unknown)

``Ay, so do, Sir John,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings,
``and then perhaps you may find out what his (Whitwell) business is.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``I do not want to pry into other men's concerns. I suppose it is something he (Whitwell) is ashamed of.'' (Colonel)

Colonel Brandon's horses were announced.

``You do not go to town on horseback, do you?'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
added Sir John.

``No. Only to Honiton. I shall then go post.'' (unknown)

``Well, as you are resolved to go, I wish you a good journey. But you had better change your mind.'' (unknown)

``I assure you it is not in my power.'' (He)

He (Colonel) then took leave of the whole party.

``Is there no chance of my seeing you and your sisters in town this winter, Miss Dashwood?'' (unknown)

``I am afraid, none at all.'' (unknown)

``Then I must bid you farewell for a longer time than I should wish to do.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

To Marianne, he (Colonel) merely bowed and said nothing.

``Come Colonel,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings,
``before you go, do let us know what you are going about.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

He (Colonel) wished her (Jennings) a good morning, and, attended by Sir John, left the room.

The complaints and lamentations which politeness had hitherto restrained, now burst forth universally; and they all agreed again and again how provoking it was to be so disappointed.

``I can guess what his (Colonel) business is, however,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings exultingly.

``Can you, ma'am?'' (unknown)
said almost every body.

``Yes; it is about Miss Williams, I am sure.'' (unknown)

``And who is Miss Williams?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
asked Marianne.

``What! do not you know who Miss Williams is? I am sure you must have heard of her (Williams) before. She (Williams) is a relation of the Colonel's, my dear; a very near relation. We will not say how near, for fear of shocking the young ladies.'' (she)
Then, lowering her (Williams) voice a little, she (Williams) said to Elinor,
``She (Williams) is his (Colonel) natural daughter.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Indeed!'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes; and as like him (Colonel) as she (Williams) can stare. I dare say the Colonel will leave her (Williams) all his (Colonel) fortune.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

When Sir John returned, he (Colonel) joined most heartily in the general regret on so unfortunate an event; concluding however by observing, that as they were all got together, they must do something by way of being happy; and after some consultation it was agreed, that although happiness could only be enjoyed at Whitwell, they might procure a tolerable composure of mind by driving about the country. The carriages were then ordered; Willoughby's was first, and Marianne never looked happier than when she (Marianne) got into it. He (Willoughby) drove through the park very fast, and they were soon out of sight; and nothing more of them was seen till their return, which did not happen till after the return of all the rest. They both seemed delighted with their drive; but said only in general terms that they had kept in the lanes, while the others went on the downs.

It was settled that there should be a dance in the evening, and that every body should be extremely merry all day long. Some more of the Careys came to dinner, and they had the pleasure of sitting down nearly twenty to table, which Sir John observed with great contentment. Willoughby took his (Willoughby) usual place between the two elder Miss Dashwoods. Mrs. Jennings sat on Elinor's right hand; and they had not been long seated, before she (Jennings) leant behind her (Jennings) and Willoughby, and said to Marianne, loud enough for them both to hear,

``I have found you out in spite of all your tricks. I know where you spent the morning.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne coloured, and replied very hastily,

``Where, pray?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--

``Did not you know,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
said Willoughby,
``that we had been out in my curricle?'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

``Yes, yes, Mr. Impudence, I know that very well, and I was determined to find out WHERE you had been to.-- I hope you like your house, Miss Marianne. It is a very large one, I know; and when I come to see you, I hope you will have new-furnished it, for it wanted it very much when I was there six years ago.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne turned away in great confusion. Mrs. Jennings laughed heartily; and Elinor found that in her (Elinor) resolution to know where they had been, she (Elinor) had actually made her (Elinor) own woman enquire of Mr. Willoughby's groom; and that she (Elinor) had by that method been informed that they had gone to Allenham, and spent a considerable time there in walking about the garden and going all over the house.

Elinor could hardly believe this to be true, as it seemed very unlikely that Willoughby should propose, or Marianne consent, to enter the house while Mrs. Smith was in it, with whom Marianne had not the smallest acquaintance.

As soon as they left the dining-room, Elinor enquired of her (Elinor) about it; and great was her (Elinor) surprise when she (Elinor) found that every circumstance related by Mrs. Jennings was perfectly true. Marianne was quite angry with her (Marianne) for doubting it.

``Why should you imagine, Elinor, that we did not go there, or that we did not see the house? Is not it what you have often wished to do yourself?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Marianne, but I would not go while Mrs. Smith was there, and with no other companion than Mr. Willoughby.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Willoughby however is the only person who can have a right to shew that house; and as he (Willoughby) went in an open carriage, it was impossible to have any other companion. I never spent a pleasanter morning in my life.'' (unknown)

``I am afraid,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``that the pleasantness of an employment does not always evince its propriety.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``On the contrary, nothing can be a stronger proof of it, Elinor; for if there had been any real impropriety in what I did, I should have been sensible of it at the time, for we always know when we are acting wrong, and with such a conviction I could have had no pleasure.'' (unknown)

``But, my dear Marianne, as it has already exposed you to some very impertinent remarks, do you not now begin to doubt the discretion of your own conduct?'' (unknown)

``If the impertinent remarks of Mrs. Jennings are to be the proof of impropriety in conduct, we are all offending every moment of our lives. I value not her (Jennings) censure any more than I should do her (Jennings) commendation. I am not sensible of having done anything wrong in walking over Mrs. Smith's grounds, or in seeing her (Smith) house. They will one day be Mr. Willoughby's, and--'' (She)

``If they were one day to be your own, Marianne, you would not be justified in what you have done.'' (She)

She (Marianne) blushed at this hint; but it was even visibly gratifying to her (Marianne); and after a ten minutes' interval of earnest thought, she (Marianne) came to her (Marianne) sister again, and said with great good humour,

``Perhaps, Elinor, it WAS rather ill-judged in me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby wanted particularly to shew me the place; and it is a charming house, I assure you.--There is one remarkably pretty sitting room up stairs; of a nice comfortable size for constant use, and with modern furniture it would be delightful. It is a corner room, and has windows on two sides. On one side you look across the bowling-green, behind the house, to a beautiful hanging wood, and on the other you have a view of the church and village, and, beyond them, of those fine bold hills that we have so often admired. I did not see it to advantage, for nothing could be more forlorn than the furniture,--but if it were newly fitted up--a couple of hundred pounds, Willoughby says, would make it one of the pleasantest summer-rooms in England.'' (sister)

Could Elinor have listened to her (Elinor) without interruption from the others, she (Elinor) would have described every room in the house with equal delight.

CHAPTER 14

The sudden termination of Colonel Brandon's visit at the park, with his (Colonel) steadiness in concealing its cause, filled the mind, and raised the wonder of Mrs. Jennings for two or three days; she (Jennings) was a great wonderer, as every one must be who takes a very lively interest in all the comings and goings of all their acquaintance. She (Jennings) wondered, with little intermission what could be the reason of it; was sure there must be some bad news, and thought over every kind of distress that could have befallen him (acquaintance), with a fixed determination that he (acquaintance) should not escape them all.

``Something very melancholy must be the matter, I am sure,'' (she)
said she (Jennings).
``I could see it in his (acquaintance) face. Poor man! I am afraid his (acquaintance) circumstances may be bad. The estate at Delaford was never reckoned more than two thousand a year, and his (acquaintance) brother left everything sadly involved. I do think he (acquaintance) must have been sent for about money matters, for what else can it be? I wonder whether it is so. I would give anything to know the truth of it. Perhaps it is about Miss Williams and, by the bye, I dare say it is, because he (acquaintance) looked so conscious when I mentioned her (Williams). May be she (Williams) is ill in town; nothing in the world more likely, for I have a notion she (Williams) is always rather sickly. I would lay any wager it is about Miss Williams. It is not so very likely he (acquaintance) should be distressed in his (acquaintance) circumstances NOW, for he (acquaintance) is a very prudent man, and to be sure must have cleared the estate by this time. I wonder what it can be! May be his (acquaintance) sister is worse at Avignon, and has sent for him (acquaintance) over. His (acquaintance) setting off in such a hurry seems very like it. Well, I wish him (acquaintance) out of all his (acquaintance) trouble with all my heart, and a good wife into the bargain.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

So wondered, so talked Mrs. Jennings. Her (Jennings) opinion varying with every fresh conjecture, and all seeming equally probable as they arose. Elinor, though she (Elinor) felt really interested in the welfare of Colonel Brandon, could not bestow all the wonder on his (Colonel) going so suddenly away, which Mrs. Jennings was desirous of her (Jennings) feeling; for besides that the circumstance did not in her (Jennings) opinion justify such lasting amazement or variety of speculation, her (Jennings) wonder was otherwise disposed of. It was engrossed by the extraordinary silence of her (Jennings) sister and Willoughby on the subject, which they must know to be peculiarly interesting to them all. As this silence continued, every day made it appear more strange and more incompatible with the disposition of both. Why they should not openly acknowledge to her (Jennings) mother and herself, what their constant behaviour to each other declared to have taken place, Elinor could not imagine.

She (Elinor) could easily conceive that marriage might not be immediately in their power; for though Willoughby was independent, there was no reason to believe him (Willoughby) rich. His (Willoughby) estate had been rated by Sir John at about six or seven hundred a year; but he (Willoughby) lived at an expense to which that income could hardly be equal, and he (Willoughby) had himself often complained of his (Willoughby) poverty. But for this strange kind of secrecy maintained by them relative to their engagement, which in fact concealed nothing at all, she (John) could not account; and it was so wholly contradictory to their general opinions and practice, that a doubt sometimes entered her (John) mind of their being really engaged, and this doubt was enough to prevent her (John) making any inquiry of Marianne.

Nothing could be more expressive of attachment to them all, than Willoughby's behaviour. To Marianne it had all the distinguishing tenderness which a lover's heart could give, and to the rest of the family it was the affectionate attention of a son and a brother. The cottage seemed to be considered and loved by him (brother) as his (brother) home; many more of his (brother) hours were spent there than at Allenham; and if no general engagement collected them at the park, the exercise which called him (brother) out in the morning was almost certain of ending there, where the rest of the day was spent by himself at the side of Marianne, and by his (brother) favourite pointer at her (Marianne) feet.

One evening in particular, about a week after Colonel Brandon left the country, his (Colonel) heart seemed more than usually open to every feeling of attachment to the objects around him (Colonel); and on Mrs. Dashwood's happening to mention her (Dashwood) design of improving the cottage in the spring, he (Colonel) warmly opposed every alteration of a place which affection had established as perfect with him (Colonel).

``What!'' (he)
he (Colonel) exclaimed--
``Improve this dear cottage! No. THAT I will never consent to. Not a stone must be added to its walls, not an inch to its size, if my feelings are regarded.'' (he)

``Do not be alarmed,'' (Miss Dashwood)
said Miss Dashwood,
``nothing of the kind will be done; for my mother will never have money enough to attempt it.'' (Miss Dashwood)

``I am heartily glad of it,'' (he)
he (Colonel) cried.
``May she (Dashwood) always be poor, if she (Dashwood) can employ her (Dashwood) riches no better.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, Willoughby. But you may be assured that I would not sacrifice one sentiment of local attachment of yours, or of any one whom I loved, for all the improvements in the world. Depend upon it that whatever unemployed sum may remain, when I make up my accounts in the spring, I would even rather lay it uselessly by than dispose of it in a manner so painful to you. But are you really so attached to this place as to see no defect in it?'' (unknown)

``I am,'' (he)
said he (Willoughby).
``To me it is faultless. Nay, more, I consider it as the only form of building in which happiness is attainable, and were I rich enough I would instantly pull Combe down, and build it up again in the exact plan of this cottage.'' (unknown)

``With dark narrow stairs and a kitchen that smokes, I suppose,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.

``Yes,'' (he)
cried he (Combe) in the same eager tone,
``with all and every thing belonging to it;--in no one convenience or INconvenience about it, should the least variation be perceptible. Then, and then only, under such a roof, I might perhaps be as happy at Combe as I have been at Barton.'' (he)

``I flatter myself,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``that even under the disadvantage of better rooms and a broader staircase, you will hereafter find your own house as faultless as you now do this.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``There certainly are circumstances,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
said Willoughby,
``which might greatly endear it to me; but this place will always have one claim of my affection, which no other can possibly share.'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

Mrs. Dashwood looked with pleasure at Marianne, whose fine eyes were fixed so expressively on Willoughby, as plainly denoted how well she (Dashwood) understood him (Willoughby).

``How often did I wish,'' (he)
added he (Willoughby),
``when I was at Allenham this time twelvemonth, that Barton cottage were inhabited! I never passed within view of it without admiring its situation, and grieving that no one should live in it. How little did I then think that the very first news I should hear from Mrs. Smith, when I next came into the country, would be that Barton cottage was taken: and I felt an immediate satisfaction and interest in the event, which nothing but a kind of prescience of what happiness I should experience from it, can account for. Must it not have been so, Marianne?'' (he)
speaking to her (Marianne) in a lowered voice. Then continuing his (Barton) former tone, he (Barton) said,
``And yet this house you would spoil, Mrs. Dashwood? You would rob it of its simplicity by imaginary improvement! and this dear parlour in which our acquaintance first began, and in which so many happy hours have been since spent by us together, you would degrade to the condition of a common entrance, and every body would be eager to pass through the room which has hitherto contained within itself more real accommodation and comfort than any other apartment of the handsomest dimensions in the world could possibly afford.'' (he)

Mrs. Dashwood again assured him (acquaintance) that no alteration of the kind should be attempted.

``You are a good woman,'' (he)
he (acquaintance) warmly replied.
``Your promise makes me easy. Extend it a little farther, and it will make me happy. Tell me that not only your house will remain the same, but that I shall ever find you and yours as unchanged as your dwelling; and that you will always consider me with the kindness which has made everything belonging to you so dear to me.'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

The promise was readily given, and Willoughby's behaviour during the whole of the evening declared at once his (Willoughby) affection and happiness.

``Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner?'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood, when he (Willoughby) was leaving them.
``I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must walk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton.'' (He)

He (Willoughby) engaged to be with them by four o'clock.

CHAPTER 15

Mrs. Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day, and two of her (Middleton) daughters went with her (Middleton); but Marianne excused herself from being of the party, under some trifling pretext of employment; and her (Marianne) mother, who concluded that a promise had been made by Willoughby the night before of calling on her (Marianne) while they were absent, was perfectly satisfied with her (Marianne) remaining at home.

On their return from the park they found Willoughby's curricle and servant in waiting at the cottage, and Mrs. Dashwood was convinced that her (Dashwood) conjecture had been just. So far it was all as she (Dashwood) had foreseen; but on entering the house she (Dashwood) beheld what no foresight had taught her (Dashwood) to expect. They were no sooner in the passage than Marianne came hastily out of the parlour apparently in violent affliction, with her (Marianne) handkerchief at her (Marianne) eyes; and without noticing them ran up stairs. Surprised and alarmed they proceeded directly into the room she (Marianne) had just quitted, where they found only Willoughby, who was leaning against the mantel-piece with his (Willoughby) back towards them. He (Willoughby) turned round on their coming in, and his (Willoughby) countenance shewed that he (Willoughby) strongly partook of the emotion which over-powered Marianne.

``Is anything the matter with her (Marianne)?'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
cried Mrs. Dashwood as she (Dashwood) entered--
``is she (Dashwood) ill?'' (she)

``I hope not,'' (he)
he (Willoughby) replied, trying to look cheerful; and with a forced smile presently added,
``It is I who may rather expect to be ill--for I am now suffering under a very heavy disappointment!'' (he)

``Disappointment?'' (unknown)

``Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you. Mrs. Smith has this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent cousin, by sending me on business to London. I have just received my dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you.'' (unknown)

``To London!--and are you going this morning?'' (unknown)

``Almost this moment.'' (unknown)

``This is very unfortunate. But Mrs. Smith must be obliged;--and her (Smith) business will not detain you from us long I hope.'' (He)

He (cousin) coloured as he (cousin) replied,

``You are very kind, but I have no idea of returning into Devonshire immediately. My visits to Mrs. Smith are never repeated within the twelvemonth.'' (he)

``And is Mrs. Smith your only friend? Is Allenham the only house in the neighbourhood to which you will be welcome? For shame, Willoughby, can you wait for an invitation here?'' (unknown)

His (Willoughby) colour increased; and with his (Willoughby) eyes fixed on the ground he (Willoughby) only replied,

``You are too good.'' (he)

Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor with surprise. Elinor felt equal amazement. For a few moments every one was silent. Mrs. Dashwood first spoke.

``I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here immediately, because you only can judge how far THAT might be pleasing to Mrs. Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to question your judgment than to doubt your inclination.'' (unknown)

``My engagements at present,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
replied Willoughby, confusedly,
``are of such a nature--that--I dare not flatter myself'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
--

He (Willoughby) stopt. Mrs. Dashwood was too much astonished to speak, and another pause succeeded. This was broken by Willoughby, who said with a faint smile,

``It is folly to linger in this manner. I will not torment myself any longer by remaining among friends whose society it is impossible for me now to enjoy.'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

He (Willoughby) then hastily took leave of them all and left the room. They saw him (Willoughby) step into his (Willoughby) carriage, and in a minute it was out of sight.

Mrs. Dashwood felt too much for speech, and instantly quitted the parlour to give way in solitude to the concern and alarm which this sudden departure occasioned.

Elinor's uneasiness was at least equal to her (Elinor) mother's. She (Elinor) thought of what had just passed with anxiety and distrust. Willoughby's behaviour in taking leave of them, his (Willoughby) embarrassment, and affectation of cheerfulness, and, above all, his (Willoughby) unwillingness to accept her (Elinor) mother's invitation, a backwardness so unlike a lover, so unlike himself, greatly disturbed her (Elinor). One moment she (Elinor) feared that no serious design had ever been formed on his (Willoughby) side; and the next that some unfortunate quarrel had taken place between him (Willoughby) and her (Elinor) sister;--the distress in which Marianne had quitted the room was such as a serious quarrel could most reasonably account for, though when she (Marianne) considered what Marianne's love for him (Willoughby) was, a quarrel seemed almost impossible.

But whatever might be the particulars of their separation, her (Marianne) sister's affliction was indubitable; and she (Marianne) thought with the tenderest compassion of that violent sorrow which Marianne was in all probability not merely giving way to as a relief, but feeding and encouraging as a duty.

In about half an hour her (Marianne) mother returned, and though her (Marianne) eyes were red, her (Marianne) countenance was not uncheerful.

``Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor,'' (she)
said she (Elinor), as she (Elinor) sat down to work,
``and with how heavy a heart does he (Willoughby) travel?'' (she)

``It is all very strange. So suddenly to be gone! It seems but the work of a moment. And last night he (Willoughby) was with us so happy, so cheerful, so affectionate? And now, after only ten minutes notice--Gone too without intending to return!--Something more than what he (Willoughby) owned to us must have happened. He (Willoughby) did not speak, he (Willoughby) did not behave like himself. YOU must have seen the difference as well as I. What can it be? Can they have quarrelled? Why else should he (Willoughby) have shewn such unwillingness to accept your invitation here?'' (unknown)
--

``It was not inclination that he (Willoughby) wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see THAT. He (Willoughby) had not the power of accepting it. I have thought it all over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at first seemed strange to me as well as to you.'' (unknown)

``Can you, indeed!'' (unknown)

``Yes. I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way;--but you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can--it will not satisfy YOU, I know; but you shall not talk ME out of my trust in it. I am persuaded that Mrs. Smith suspects his (it) regard for Marianne, disapproves of it, -LRB-perhaps because she (Marianne) has other views for him (it),-RRB- and on that account is eager to get him (it) away;--and that the business which she (Marianne) sends him (it) off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him (it). This is what I believe to have happened. He (it) is, moreover, aware that she (Marianne) DOES disapprove the connection, he (it) dares not therefore at present confess to her (Marianne) his (it) engagement with Marianne, and he (it) feels himself obliged, from his (it) dependent situation, to give into her (Marianne) schemes, and absent himself from Devonshire for a while. You will tell me, I know, that this may or may NOT have happened; but I will listen to no cavil, unless you can point out any other method of understanding the affair as satisfactory at this. And now, Elinor, what have you to say?'' (unknown)

``Nothing, for you have anticipated my answer.'' (unknown)

``Then you would have told me, that it might or might not have happened. Oh, Elinor, how incomprehensible are your feelings! You had rather take evil upon credit than good. You had rather look out for misery for Marianne, and guilt for poor Willoughby, than an apology for the latter. You are resolved to think him (Willoughby) blameable, because he (Willoughby) took leave of us with less affection than his (Willoughby) usual behaviour has shewn. And is no allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by recent disappointment? Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely because they are not certainties? Is nothing due to the man whom we have all such reason to love, and no reason in the world to think ill of? To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though unavoidably secret for a while? And, after all, what is it you suspect him (man) of?'' (unknown)

``I can hardly tell myself. But suspicion of something unpleasant is the inevitable consequence of such an alteration as we just witnessed in him (man). There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of the allowances which ought to be made for him (man), and it is my wish to be candid in my judgment of every body. Willoughby may undoubtedly have very sufficient reasons for his (Willoughby) conduct, and I will hope that he (Willoughby) has. But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at once. Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at its being practiced by him (Willoughby).'' (unknown)

``Do not blame him (Willoughby), however, for departing from his (Willoughby) character, where the deviation is necessary. But you really do admit the justice of what I have said in his (Willoughby) defence?--I am happy--and he (Willoughby) is acquitted.'' (unknown)

``Not entirely. It may be proper to conceal their engagement -LRB-if they ARE engaged-RRB- from Mrs. Smith--and if that is the case, it must be highly expedient for Willoughby to be but little in Devonshire at present. But this is no excuse for their concealing it from us.'' (unknown)

``Concealing it from us! my dear child, do you accuse Willoughby and Marianne of concealment? This is strange indeed, when your eyes have been reproaching them every day for incautiousness.'' (unknown)

``I want no proof of their affection,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``but of their engagement I do.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I am perfectly satisfied of both.'' (unknown)

``Yet not a syllable has been said to you on the subject, by either of them.'' (unknown)

``I have not wanted syllables where actions have spoken so plainly. Has not his (Willoughby) behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last fortnight, declared that he (Willoughby) loved and considered her (Marianne) as his (Willoughby) future wife, and that he (Willoughby) felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation? Have we not perfectly understood each other? Has not my consent been daily asked by his (Willoughby) looks, his (Willoughby) manner, his (Willoughby) attentive and affectionate respect? My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement? How could such a thought occur to you? How is it to be supposed that Willoughby, persuaded as he (Willoughby) must be of your sister's love, should leave her (sister), and leave her (sister) perhaps for months, without telling her (sister) of his (Willoughby) affection;--that they should part without a mutual exchange of confidence?'' (unknown)

``I confess,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``that every circumstance except ONE is in favour of their engagement; but that ONE is the total silence of both on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``How strange this is! You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby, if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the nature of the terms on which they are together. Has he (Willoughby) been acting a part in his (Willoughby) behaviour to your sister all this time? Do you suppose him (Willoughby) really indifferent to her (sister)?'' (unknown)

``No, I cannot think that. He (Willoughby) must and does love her (sister) I am sure.'' (unknown)

``But with a strange kind of tenderness, if he (Willoughby) can leave her (sister) with such indifference, such carelessness of the future, as you attribute to him (Willoughby).'' (unknown)
