``You must remember, my dear mother, that I have never considered this matter as certain. I have had my doubts, I confess; but they are fainter than they were, and they may soon be entirely done away. If we find they correspond, every fear of mine will be removed.'' (unknown)

``A mighty concession indeed! If you were to see them at the altar, you would suppose they were going to be married. Ungracious girl! But I require no such proof. Nothing in my opinion has ever passed to justify doubt; no secrecy has been attempted; all has been uniformly open and unreserved. You cannot doubt your sister's wishes. It must be Willoughby therefore whom you suspect. But why? Is he (Willoughby) not a man of honour and feeling? Has there been any inconsistency on his (Willoughby) side to create alarm? can he (Willoughby) be deceitful?'' (unknown)

``I hope not, I believe not,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
cried Elinor.
``I love Willoughby, sincerely love him (Willoughby); and suspicion of his (Willoughby) integrity cannot be more painful to yourself than to me. It has been involuntary, and I will not encourage it. I was startled, I confess, by the alteration in his (Willoughby) manners this morning;--he (Willoughby) did not speak like himself, and did not return your kindness with any cordiality. But all this may be explained by such a situation of his (Willoughby) affairs as you have supposed. He (Willoughby) had just parted from my sister, had seen her (sister) leave him (Willoughby) in the greatest affliction; and if he (Willoughby) felt obliged, from a fear of offending Mrs. Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware that by declining your invitation, by saying that he (Willoughby) was going away for some time, he (Willoughby) should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by our family, he (Willoughby) might well be embarrassed and disturbed. In such a case, a plain and open avowal of his (Willoughby) difficulties would have been more to his (Willoughby) honour I think, as well as more consistent with his (Willoughby) general character;--but I will not raise objections against any one's conduct on so illiberal a foundation, as a difference in judgment from myself, or a deviation from what I may think right and consistent.'' (unknown)

``You speak very properly. Willoughby certainly does not deserve to be suspected. Though WE have not known him (Willoughby) long, he (Willoughby) is no stranger in this part of the world; and who has ever spoken to his (Willoughby) disadvantage? Had he (Willoughby) been in a situation to act independently and marry immediately, it might have been odd that he (Willoughby) should leave us without acknowledging everything to me at once: but this is not the case. It is an engagement in some respects not prosperously begun, for their marriage must be at a very uncertain distance; and even secrecy, as far as it can be observed, may now be very advisable.'' (Margaret)

They were interrupted by the entrance of Margaret; and Elinor was then at liberty to think over the representations of her (Elinor) mother, to acknowledge the probability of many, and hope for the justice of all.

They saw nothing of Marianne till dinner time, when she (Marianne) entered the room and took her (Marianne) place at the table without saying a word. Her (Marianne) eyes were red and swollen; and it seemed as if her (Marianne) tears were even then restrained with difficulty. She (Marianne) avoided the looks of them all, could neither eat nor speak, and after some time, on her (Marianne) mother's silently pressing her (Marianne) hand with tender compassion, her (Marianne) small degree of fortitude was quite overcome, she (Marianne) burst into tears and left the room.

This violent oppression of spirits continued the whole evening. She (Marianne) was without any power, because she (Marianne) was without any desire of command over herself. The slightest mention of anything relative to Willoughby overpowered her (Marianne) in an instant; and though her (Marianne) family were most anxiously attentive to her (Marianne) comfort, it was impossible for them, if they spoke at all, to keep clear of every subject which her (Marianne) feelings connected with him (Willoughby).

CHAPTER 16

Marianne would have thought herself very inexcusable had she (Marianne) been able to sleep at all the first night after parting from Willoughby. She (Marianne) would have been ashamed to look her (Marianne) family in the face the next morning, had she (Marianne) not risen from her (Marianne) bed in more need of repose than when she (Marianne) lay down in it. But the feelings which made such composure a disgrace, left her (Marianne) in no danger of incurring it. She (Marianne) was awake the whole night, and she (Marianne) wept the greatest part of it. She (Marianne) got up with a headache, was unable to talk, and unwilling to take any nourishment; giving pain every moment to her (Marianne) mother and sisters, and forbidding all attempt at consolation from either. Her (Marianne) sensibility was potent enough!

When breakfast was over she (Marianne) walked out by herself, and wandered about the village of Allenham, indulging the recollection of past enjoyment and crying over the present reverse for the chief of the morning.

The evening passed off in the equal indulgence of feeling. She (Marianne) played over every favourite song that she (Marianne) had been used to play to Willoughby, every air in which their voices had been oftenest joined, and sat at the instrument gazing on every line of music that he (Willoughby) had written out for her (Marianne), till her (Marianne) heart was so heavy that no farther sadness could be gained; and this nourishment of grief was every day applied. She (Marianne) spent whole hours at the pianoforte alternately singing and crying; her (Marianne) voice often totally suspended by her (Marianne) tears. In books too, as well as in music, she (Marianne) courted the misery which a contrast between the past and present was certain of giving. She (Marianne) read nothing but what they had been used to read together.

Such violence of affliction indeed could not be supported for ever; it sunk within a few days into a calmer melancholy; but these employments, to which she (Marianne) daily recurred, her (Marianne) solitary walks and silent meditations, still produced occasional effusions of sorrow as lively as ever.

No letter from Willoughby came; and none seemed expected by Marianne. Her (Marianne) mother was surprised, and Elinor again became uneasy. But Mrs. Dashwood could find explanations whenever she (Dashwood) wanted them, which at least satisfied herself.

``Remember, Elinor,'' (she)
said she (Elinor),
``how very often Sir John fetches our letters himself from the post, and carries them to it. We have already agreed that secrecy may be necessary, and we must acknowledge that it could not be maintained if their correspondence were to pass through Sir John's hands.'' (she)

Elinor could not deny the truth of this, and she (Elinor) tried to find in it a motive sufficient for their silence. But there was one method so direct, so simple, and in her (Elinor) opinion so eligible of knowing the real state of the affair, and of instantly removing all mystery, that she (Elinor) could not help suggesting it to her (Elinor) mother.

``Why do you not ask Marianne at once,'' (she)
said she (Marianne),
``whether she (Marianne) is or she (Marianne) is not engaged to Willoughby? From you, her (Marianne) mother, and so kind, so indulgent a mother, the question could not give offence. It would be the natural result of your affection for her (mother). She (mother) used to be all unreserve, and to you more especially.'' (she)

``I would not ask such a question for the world. Supposing it possible that they are not engaged, what distress would not such an enquiry inflict! At any rate it would be most ungenerous. I should never deserve her (mother) confidence again, after forcing from her (mother) a confession of what is meant at present to be unacknowledged to any one. I know Marianne's heart: I know that she (Marianne) dearly loves me, and that I shall not be the last to whom the affair is made known, when circumstances make the revealment of it eligible. I would not attempt to force the confidence of any one; of a child much less; because a sense of duty would prevent the denial which her (Marianne) wishes might direct.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor thought this generosity overstrained, considering her (Elinor) sister's youth, and urged the matter farther, but in vain; common sense, common care, common prudence, were all sunk in Mrs. Dashwood's romantic delicacy.

It was several days before Willoughby's name was mentioned before Marianne by any of her (Marianne) family; Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, indeed, were not so nice; their witticisms added pain to many a painful hour;--but one evening, Mrs. Dashwood, accidentally taking up a volume of Shakespeare, exclaimed,

``We have never finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby went away before we could get through it. We will put it by, that when he (Willoughby) comes again...But it may be months, perhaps, before THAT happens.'' (Shakespeare)

``Months!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne, with strong surprise.
``No--nor many weeks.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Mrs. Dashwood was sorry for what she (Dashwood) had said; but it gave Elinor pleasure, as it produced a reply from Marianne so expressive of confidence in Willoughby and knowledge of his (Willoughby) intentions.

One morning, about a week after his (Willoughby) leaving the country, Marianne was prevailed on to join her (Marianne) sisters in their usual walk, instead of wandering away by herself. Hitherto she (Marianne) had carefully avoided every companion in her (Marianne) rambles. If her (Marianne) sisters intended to walk on the downs, she (Marianne) directly stole away towards the lanes; if they talked of the valley, she (Marianne) was as speedy in climbing the hills, and could never be found when the others set off. But at length she (Marianne) was secured by the exertions of Elinor, who greatly disapproved such continual seclusion. They walked along the road through the valley, and chiefly in silence, for Marianne's MIND could not be controlled, and Elinor, satisfied with gaining one point, would not then attempt more. Beyond the entrance of the valley, where the country, though still rich, was less wild and more open, a long stretch of the road which they had travelled on first coming to Barton, lay before them; and on reaching that point, they stopped to look around them, and examine a prospect which formed the distance of their view from the cottage, from a spot which they had never happened to reach in any of their walks before.

Amongst the objects in the scene, they soon discovered an animated one; it was a man on horseback riding towards them. In a few minutes they could distinguish him (man) to be a gentleman; and in a moment afterwards Marianne rapturously exclaimed,

``It is he (man); it is indeed;--I know it is!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--and was hastening to meet him (man), when Elinor cried out,

``Indeed, Marianne, I think you are mistaken. It is not Willoughby. The person is not tall enough for him (Willoughby), and has not his (Willoughby) air.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``He (Willoughby) has, he (Willoughby) has,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``I am sure he (Willoughby) has. His (Willoughby) air, his (Willoughby) coat, his (Willoughby) horse. I knew how soon he (Willoughby) would come.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

She (Marianne) walked eagerly on as she (Marianne) spoke; and Elinor, to screen Marianne from particularity, as she (Marianne) felt almost certain of its not being Willoughby, quickened her (Marianne) pace and kept up with her (Marianne). They were soon within thirty yards of the gentleman. Marianne looked again; her (Marianne) heart sunk within her (Marianne); and abruptly turning round, she (Marianne) was hurrying back, when the voices of both her (Marianne) sisters were raised to detain her (Marianne); a third, almost as well known as Willoughby's, joined them in begging her (Marianne) to stop, and she (Marianne) turned round with surprise to see and welcome Edward Ferrars.

He (Ferrars) was the only person in the world who could at that moment be forgiven for not being Willoughby; the only one who could have gained a smile from her (Marianne); but she (Marianne) dispersed her (Marianne) tears to smile on HIM, and in her (Marianne) sister's happiness forgot for a time her (Marianne) own disappointment.

He (Willoughby) dismounted, and giving his (Willoughby) horse to his (Willoughby) servant, walked back with them to Barton, whither he (Barton) was purposely coming to visit them.

He (Barton) was welcomed by them all with great cordiality, but especially by Marianne, who showed more warmth of regard in her (Marianne) reception of him (Barton) than even Elinor herself. To Marianne, indeed, the meeting between Edward and her (Marianne) sister was but a continuation of that unaccountable coldness which she (Marianne) had often observed at Norland in their mutual behaviour. On Edward's side, more particularly, there was a deficiency of all that a lover ought to look and say on such an occasion. He (lover) was confused, seemed scarcely sensible of pleasure in seeing them, looked neither rapturous nor gay, said little but what was forced from him (lover) by questions, and distinguished Elinor by no mark of affection. Marianne saw and listened with increasing surprise. She (Marianne) began almost to feel a dislike of Edward; and it ended, as every feeling must end with her (Marianne), by carrying back her (Marianne) thoughts to Willoughby, whose manners formed a contrast sufficiently striking to those of his (Willoughby) brother elect.

After a short silence which succeeded the first surprise and enquiries of meeting, Marianne asked Edward if he (Edward) came directly from London. No, he (Edward) had been in Devonshire a fortnight.

``A fortnight!'' (she)
she (Marianne) repeated, surprised at his (Edward) being so long in the same county with Elinor without seeing her (Elinor) before.

He (Edward) looked rather distressed as he (Edward) added, that he (Edward) had been staying with some friends near Plymouth.

``Have you been lately in Sussex?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.

``I was at Norland about a month ago.'' (unknown)

``And how does dear, dear Norland look?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne.

``Dear, dear Norland,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``probably looks much as it always does at this time of the year. The woods and walks thickly covered with dead leaves.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Oh,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``with what transporting sensation have I formerly seen them fall! How have I delighted, as I walked, to see them driven in showers about me by the wind! What feelings have they, the season, the air altogether inspired! Now there is no one to regard them. They are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as possible from the sight.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``It is not every one,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``who has your passion for dead leaves.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``No; my feelings are not often shared, not often understood. But SOMETIMES they are.'' (she)
--As she (Elinor) said this, she (Elinor) sunk into a reverie for a few moments;--but rousing herself again,
``Now, Edward,'' (she)
said she (Elinor), calling his (Edward) attention to the prospect,
``here is Barton valley. Look up to it, and be tranquil if you can. Look at those hills! Did you ever see their equals? To the left is Barton park, amongst those woods and plantations. You may see the end of the house. And there, beneath that farthest hill, which rises with such grandeur, is our cottage.'' (she)

``It is a beautiful country,'' (he)
he (Barton) replied;
``but these bottoms must be dirty in winter.'' (he)

``How can you think of dirt, with such objects before you?'' (unknown)

``Because,'' (he)
replied he (Barton), smiling,
``among the rest of the objects before me, I see a very dirty lane.'' (he)

``How strange!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne to herself as she (Marianne) walked on.

``Have you an agreeable neighbourhood here? Are the Middletons pleasant people?'' (unknown)

``No, not all,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
answered Marianne;
``we could not be more unfortunately situated.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Marianne,'' (sister)
cried her (Marianne) sister,
``how can you say so? How can you be so unjust? They are a very respectable family, Mr. Ferrars; and towards us have behaved in the friendliest manner. Have you forgot, Marianne, how many pleasant days we have owed to them?'' (sister)

``No,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, in a low voice,
``nor how many painful moments.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Elinor took no notice of this; and directing her (Elinor) attention to their visitor, endeavoured to support something like discourse with him (visitor), by talking of their present residence, its conveniences, &c. extorting from him (visitor) occasional questions and remarks. His (visitor) coldness and reserve mortified her (Elinor) severely; she (Elinor) was vexed and half angry; but resolving to regulate her (Elinor) behaviour to him (visitor) by the past rather than the present, she (Elinor) avoided every appearance of resentment or displeasure, and treated him (visitor) as she (Elinor) thought he (visitor) ought to be treated from the family connection.

CHAPTER 17

Mrs. Dashwood was surprised only for a moment at seeing him (visitor); for his (visitor) coming to Barton was, in her (Dashwood) opinion, of all things the most natural. Her (Dashwood) joy and expression of regard long outlived her (Dashwood) wonder. He (visitor) received the kindest welcome from her (Dashwood); and shyness, coldness, reserve could not stand against such a reception. They had begun to fail him (visitor) before he (visitor) entered the house, and they were quite overcome by the captivating manners of Mrs. Dashwood. Indeed a man could not very well be in love with either of her (Dashwood) daughters, without extending the passion to her (Dashwood); and Elinor had the satisfaction of seeing him (man) soon become more like himself. His (man) affections seemed to reanimate towards them all, and his (man) interest in their welfare again became perceptible. He (man) was not in spirits, however; he (man) praised their house, admired its prospect, was attentive, and kind; but still he (man) was not in spirits. The whole family perceived it, and Mrs. Dashwood, attributing it to some want of liberality in his (man) mother, sat down to table indignant against all selfish parents.

``What are Mrs. Ferrars's views for you at present, Edward?'' (she)
said she (Ferrars), when dinner was over and they had drawn round the fire;
``are you still to be a great orator in spite of yourself?'' (she)

``No. I hope my mother is now convinced that I have no more talents than inclination for a public life!'' (unknown)

``But how is your fame to be established? for famous you must be to satisfy all your family; and with no inclination for expense, no affection for strangers, no profession, and no assurance, you may find it a difficult matter.'' (unknown)

``I shall not attempt it. I have no wish to be distinguished; and have every reason to hope I never shall. Thank Heaven! I cannot be forced into genius and eloquence.'' (unknown)

``You have no ambition, I well know. Your wishes are all moderate.'' (unknown)

``As moderate as those of the rest of the world, I believe. I wish as well as every body else to be perfectly happy; but, like every body else it must be in my own way. Greatness will not make me so.'' (unknown)

``Strange that it would!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne.
``What have wealth or grandeur to do with happiness?'' (unknown)

``Grandeur has but little,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``but wealth has much to do with it.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Elinor, for shame!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``money can only give happiness where there is nothing else to give it. Beyond a competence, it can afford no real satisfaction, as far as mere self is concerned.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Perhaps,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, smiling,
``we may come to the same point. YOUR competence and MY wealth are very much alike, I dare say; and without them, as the world goes now, we shall both agree that every kind of external comfort must be wanting. Your ideas are only more noble than mine. Come, what is your competence?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``About eighteen hundred or two thousand a year; not more than THAT.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor laughed.

``TWO thousand a year! ONE is my wealth! I guessed how it would end.'' (unknown)

``And yet two thousand a-year is a very moderate income,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne.
``A family cannot well be maintained on a smaller. I am sure I am not extravagant in my demands. A proper establishment of servants, a carriage, perhaps two, and hunters, cannot be supported on less.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor smiled again, to hear her (Elinor) sister describing so accurately their future expenses at Combe Magna.

``Hunters!'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
repeated Edward--
``but why must you have hunters? Every body does not hunt.'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

Marianne coloured as she (Marianne) replied,

``But most people do.'' (she)

``I wish,'' (Margaret)
said Margaret, striking out a novel thought,
``that somebody would give us all a large fortune apiece!'' (Margaret)

``Oh that they would!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne, her (Marianne) eyes sparkling with animation, and her (Marianne) cheeks glowing with the delight of such imaginary happiness.

``We are all unanimous in that wish, I suppose,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``in spite of the insufficiency of wealth.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Oh dear!'' (Margaret)
cried Margaret,
``how happy I should be! I wonder what I should do with it!'' (Margaret)

Marianne looked as if she (Marianne) had no doubt on that point.

``I should be puzzled to spend so large a fortune myself,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood,
``if my children were all to be rich without my help.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``You must begin your improvements on this house,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
observed Elinor,
``and your difficulties will soon vanish.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``What magnificent orders would travel from this family to London,'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
said Edward,
``in such an event! What a happy day for booksellers, music-sellers, and print-shops! You, Miss Dashwood, would give a general commission for every new print of merit to be sent you--and as for Marianne, I know her (Marianne) greatness of soul, there would not be music enough in London to content her (Marianne). And books!--Thomson, Cowper, Scott--she (Marianne) would buy them all over and over again: she (Marianne) would buy up every copy, I believe, to prevent their falling into unworthy hands; and she (Marianne) would have every book that tells her (Marianne) how to admire an old twisted tree. Should not you, Marianne? Forgive me, if I am very saucy. But I was willing to shew you that I had not forgot our old disputes.'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

``I love to be reminded of the past, Edward--whether it be melancholy or gay, I love to recall it--and you will never offend me by talking of former times. You are very right in supposing how my money would be spent--some of it, at least--my loose cash would certainly be employed in improving my collection of music and books.'' (unknown)

``And the bulk of your fortune would be laid out in annuities on the authors or their heirs.'' (unknown)

``No, Edward, I should have something else to do with it.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps, then, you would bestow it as a reward on that person who wrote the ablest defence of your favourite maxim, that no one can ever be in love more than once in their life--your opinion on that point is unchanged, I presume?'' (unknown)

``Undoubtedly. At my time of life opinions are tolerably fixed. It is not likely that I should now see or hear any thing to change them.'' (unknown)

``Marianne is as steadfast as ever, you see,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``she (Elinor) is not at all altered.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``She (Elinor) is only grown a little more grave than she (Elinor) was.'' (unknown)

``Nay, Edward,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``you need not reproach me. You are not very gay yourself.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Why should you think so!'' (he)
replied he (Edward), with a sigh.
``But gaiety never was a part of MY character.'' (unknown)

``Nor do I think it a part of Marianne's,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``I should hardly call her (Elinor) a lively girl--she (Elinor) is very earnest, very eager in all she (Elinor) does--sometimes talks a great deal and always with animation--but she (Elinor) is not often really merry.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I believe you are right,'' (he)
he (character) replied,
``and yet I have always set her (Elinor) down as a lively girl.'' (he)

``I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``in a total misapprehension of character in some point or other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or stupid than they really are, and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``But I thought it was right, Elinor,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``to be guided wholly by the opinion of other people. I thought our judgments were given us merely to be subservient to those of neighbours. This has always been your doctrine, I am sure.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``No, Marianne, never. My doctrine has never aimed at the subjection of the understanding. All I have ever attempted to influence has been the behaviour. You must not confound my meaning. I am guilty, I confess, of having often wished you to treat our acquaintance in general with greater attention; but when have I advised you to adopt their sentiments or to conform to their judgment in serious matters?'' (unknown)

``You have not been able to bring your sister over to your plan of general civility,'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
said Edward to Elinor.
``Do you gain no ground?'' (unknown)

``Quite the contrary,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, looking expressively at Marianne.

``My judgment,'' (he)
he (Edward) returned,
``is all on your side of the question; but I am afraid my practice is much more on your sister's. I never wish to offend, but I am so foolishly shy, that I often seem negligent, when I am only kept back by my natural awkwardness. I have frequently thought that I must have been intended by nature to be fond of low company, I am so little at my ease among strangers of gentility!'' (he)

``Marianne has not shyness to excuse any inattention of hers,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.

``She (Elinor) knows her (Elinor) own worth too well for false shame,'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
replied Edward.
``Shyness is only the effect of a sense of inferiority in some way or other. If I could persuade myself that my manners were perfectly easy and graceful, I should not be shy.'' (unknown)

``But you would still be reserved,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``and that is worse.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Edward started--

``Reserved! Am I reserved, Marianne?'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

``Yes, very.'' (unknown)

``I do not understand you,'' (he)
replied he (Edward), colouring.
``Reserved!--how, in what manner? What am I to tell you? What can you suppose?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor looked surprised at his (Edward) emotion; but trying to laugh off the subject, she (Elinor) said to him (Edward),

``Do not you know my sister well enough to understand what she (Elinor) means? Do not you know she (Elinor) calls every one reserved who does not talk as fast, and admire what she (Elinor) admires as rapturously as herself?'' (him)

Edward made no answer. His (Edward) gravity and thoughtfulness returned on him (Edward) in their fullest extent--and he (Edward) sat for some time silent and dull.

CHAPTER 18

Elinor saw, with great uneasiness the low spirits of her (Elinor) friend. His (friend) visit afforded her (Elinor) but a very partial satisfaction, while his (friend) own enjoyment in it appeared so imperfect. It was evident that he (friend) was unhappy; she (Elinor) wished it were equally evident that he (friend) still distinguished her (Elinor) by the same affection which once she (Elinor) had felt no doubt of inspiring; but hitherto the continuance of his (friend) preference seemed very uncertain; and the reservedness of his (friend) manner towards her (Elinor) contradicted one moment what a more animated look had intimated the preceding one.

He (friend) joined her (Elinor) and Marianne in the breakfast-room the next morning before the others were down; and Marianne, who was always eager to promote their happiness as far as she (Marianne) could, soon left them to themselves. But before she (Marianne) was half way upstairs she (Marianne) heard the parlour door open, and, turning round, was astonished to see Edward himself come out.

``I am going into the village to see my horses,'' (he)
said he (Edward),
``as you are not yet ready for breakfast; I shall be back again presently.'' (he)

***

Edward returned to them with fresh admiration of the surrounding country; in his (Edward) walk to the village, he (Edward) had seen many parts of the valley to advantage; and the village itself, in a much higher situation than the cottage, afforded a general view of the whole, which had exceedingly pleased him (Edward). This was a subject which ensured Marianne's attention, and she (Marianne) was beginning to describe her (Marianne) own admiration of these scenes, and to question him (Edward) more minutely on the objects that had particularly struck him (Edward), when Edward interrupted her (Marianne) by saying,

``You must not enquire too far, Marianne--remember I have no knowledge in the picturesque, and I shall offend you by my ignorance and want of taste if we come to particulars. I shall call hills steep, which ought to be bold; surfaces strange and uncouth, which ought to be irregular and rugged; and distant objects out of sight, which ought only to be indistinct through the soft medium of a hazy atmosphere. You must be satisfied with such admiration as I can honestly give. I call it a very fine country--the hills are steep, the woods seem full of fine timber, and the valley looks comfortable and snug--with rich meadows and several neat farm houses scattered here and there. It exactly answers my idea of a fine country, because it unites beauty with utility--and I dare say it is a picturesque one too, because you admire it; I can easily believe it to be full of rocks and promontories, grey moss and brush wood, but these are all lost on me. I know nothing of the picturesque.'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

``I am afraid it is but too true,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne;
``but why should you boast of it?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``I suspect,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``that to avoid one kind of affectation, Edward here falls into another. Because he (Edward) believes many people pretend to more admiration of the beauties of nature than they really feel, and is disgusted with such pretensions, he (Edward) affects greater indifference and less discrimination in viewing them himself than he (Edward) possesses. He (Edward) is fastidious and will have an affectation of his (Edward) own.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``It is very true,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``that admiration of landscape scenery is become a mere jargon. Every body pretends to feel and tries to describe with the taste and elegance of him (Edward) who first defined what picturesque beauty was. I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and meaning.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``I am convinced,'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
said Edward,
``that you really feel all the delight in a fine prospect which you profess to feel. But, in return, your sister must allow me to feel no more than I profess. I like a fine prospect, but not on picturesque principles. I do not like crooked, twisted, blasted trees. I admire them much more if they are tall, straight, and flourishing. I do not like ruined, tattered cottages. I am not fond of nettles or thistles, or heath blossoms. I have more pleasure in a snug farm-house than a watch-tower--and a troop of tidy, happy villages please me better than the finest banditti in the world.'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

Marianne looked with amazement at Edward, with compassion at her (Marianne) sister. Elinor only laughed.

The subject was continued no farther; and Marianne remained thoughtfully silent, till a new object suddenly engaged her (Marianne) attention. She (Marianne) was sitting by Edward, and in taking his (Edward) tea from Mrs. Dashwood, his (Edward) hand passed so directly before her (Dashwood), as to make a ring, with a plait of hair in the centre, very conspicuous on one of his (Edward) fingers.

``I never saw you wear a ring before, Edward,'' (she)
she (Dashwood) cried.
``Is that Fanny's hair? I remember her (Dashwood) promising to give you some. But I should have thought her (Dashwood) hair had been darker.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne spoke inconsiderately what she (Marianne) really felt--but when she (Marianne) saw how much she (Marianne) had pained Edward, her (Marianne) own vexation at her (Marianne) want of thought could not be surpassed by his (Edward). He (Edward) coloured very deeply, and giving a momentary glance at Elinor, replied,

``Yes; it is my sister's hair. The setting always casts a different shade on it, you know.'' (Elinor)

Elinor had met his (Edward) eye, and looked conscious likewise. That the hair was her (Elinor) own, she (Elinor) instantaneously felt as well satisfied as Marianne; the only difference in their conclusions was, that what Marianne considered as a free gift from her (Marianne) sister, Elinor was conscious must have been procured by some theft or contrivance unknown to herself. She (Elinor) was not in a humour, however, to regard it as an affront, and affecting to take no notice of what passed, by instantly talking of something else, she (Elinor) internally resolved henceforward to catch every opportunity of eyeing the hair and of satisfying herself, beyond all doubt, that it was exactly the shade of her (Elinor) own.

Edward's embarrassment lasted some time, and it ended in an absence of mind still more settled. He (Edward) was particularly grave the whole morning. Marianne severely censured herself for what she (Marianne) had said; but her (Marianne) own forgiveness might have been more speedy, had she (Marianne) known how little offence it had given her (Marianne) sister.

Before the middle of the day, they were visited by Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, who, having heard of the arrival of a gentleman at the cottage, came to take a survey of the guest. With the assistance of his (guest) mother-in-law, Sir John was not long in discovering that the name of Ferrars began with an F. and this prepared a future mine of raillery against the devoted Elinor, which nothing but the newness of their acquaintance with Edward could have prevented from being immediately sprung. But, as it was, she (Elinor) only learned, from some very significant looks, how far their penetration, founded on Margaret's instructions, extended.

Sir John never came to the Dashwoods without either inviting them to dine at the park the next day, or to drink tea with them that evening. On the present occasion, for the better entertainment of their visitor, towards whose amusement he (visitor) felt himself bound to contribute, he (visitor) wished to engage them for both.

``You MUST drink tea with us to night,'' (he)
said he (visitor),
``for we shall be quite alone--and tomorrow you must absolutely dine with us, for we shall be a large party.'' (he)

Mrs. Jennings enforced the necessity.

``And who knows but you may raise a dance,'' (she)
said she (Jennings).
``And that will tempt YOU, Miss Marianne.'' (unknown)

``A dance!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne.
``Impossible! Who is to dance?'' (unknown)

``Who! why yourselves, and the Careys, and Whitakers to be sure.--What! you thought nobody could dance because a certain person that shall be nameless is gone!'' (unknown)

``I wish with all my soul,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
cried Sir John,
``that Willoughby were among us again.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

This, and Marianne's blushing, gave new suspicions to Edward.

``And who is Willoughby?'' (he)
said he (Willoughby), in a low voice, to Miss Dashwood, by whom he (Willoughby) was sitting.

She (Dashwood) gave him (Willoughby) a brief reply. Marianne's countenance was more communicative. Edward saw enough to comprehend, not only the meaning of others, but such of Marianne's expressions as had puzzled him (Edward) before; and when their visitors left them, he (Edward) went immediately round her (Marianne), and said, in a whisper,

``I have been guessing. Shall I tell you my guess?'' (her)

``What do you mean?'' (unknown)

``Shall I tell you.'' (unknown)

``Certainly.'' (unknown)

``Well then; I guess that Mr. Willoughby hunts.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne was surprised and confused, yet she (Marianne) could not help smiling at the quiet archness of his (Willoughby) manner, and after a moment's silence, said,

``Oh, Edward! How can you?--But the time will come I hope...I am sure you will like him (Edward).'' (she)

``I do not doubt it,'' (he)
replied he (Edward), rather astonished at her (Marianne) earnestness and warmth; for had he (Edward) not imagined it to be a joke for the good of her (Marianne) acquaintance in general, founded only on a something or a nothing between Mr. Willoughby and herself, he (Willoughby) would not have ventured to mention it.

CHAPTER 19

Edward remained a week at the cottage; he (Edward) was earnestly pressed by Mrs. Dashwood to stay longer; but, as if he (Edward) were bent only on self-mortification, he (Edward) seemed resolved to be gone when his (Edward) enjoyment among his (Edward) friends was at the height. His (Edward) spirits, during the last two or three days, though still very unequal, were greatly improved--he (Edward) grew more and more partial to the house and environs--never spoke of going away without a sigh--declared his (Edward) time to be wholly disengaged--even doubted to what place he (Edward) should go when he (Edward) left them--but still, go he (Edward) must. Never had any week passed so quickly--he (Edward) could hardly believe it to be gone. He (Edward) said so repeatedly; other things he (Edward) said too, which marked the turn of his (Edward) feelings and gave the lie to his (Edward) actions. He (Edward) had no pleasure at Norland; he (Edward) detested being in town; but either to Norland or London, he (Edward) must go. He (Edward) valued their kindness beyond any thing, and his (Edward) greatest happiness was in being with them. Yet, he (Edward) must leave them at the end of a week, in spite of their wishes and his (Edward) own, and without any restraint on his (Edward) time.

Elinor placed all that was astonishing in this way of acting to his (Edward) mother's account; and it was happy for her (Elinor) that he (Edward) had a mother whose character was so imperfectly known to her (Elinor), as to be the general excuse for every thing strange on the part of her (Elinor) son. Disappointed, however, and vexed as she (Elinor) was, and sometimes displeased with his (son) uncertain behaviour to herself, she (Elinor) was very well disposed on the whole to regard his (son) actions with all the candid allowances and generous qualifications, which had been rather more painfully extorted from her (Elinor), for Willoughby's service, by her (Elinor) mother. His (Willoughby) want of spirits, of openness, and of consistency, were most usually attributed to his (Willoughby) want of independence, and his (Willoughby) better knowledge of Mrs. Ferrars's disposition and designs. The shortness of his (Willoughby) visit, the steadiness of his (Willoughby) purpose in leaving them, originated in the same fettered inclination, the same inevitable necessity of temporizing with his (Willoughby) mother. The old well-established grievance of duty against will, parent against child, was the cause of all. She (mother) would have been glad to know when these difficulties were to cease, this opposition was to yield,--when Mrs. Ferrars would be reformed, and her (Ferrars) son be at liberty to be happy. But from such vain wishes she (Ferrars) was forced to turn for comfort to the renewal of her (Ferrars) confidence in Edward's affection, to the remembrance of every mark of regard in look or word which fell from him (Edward) while at Barton, and above all to that flattering proof of it which he (Barton) constantly wore round his (Barton) finger.

``I think, Edward,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood, as they were at breakfast the last morning,
``you would be a happier man if you had any profession to engage your time and give an interest to your plans and actions. Some inconvenience to your friends, indeed, might result from it--you would not be able to give them so much of your time. But -LRB-with a smile-RRB- you would be materially benefited in one particular at least--you would know where to go when you left them.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``I do assure you,'' (he)
he (man) replied,
``that I have long thought on this point, as you think now. It has been, and is, and probably will always be a heavy misfortune to me, that I have had no necessary business to engage me, no profession to give me employment, or afford me any thing like independence. But unfortunately my own nicety, and the nicety of my friends, have made me what I am, an idle, helpless being. We never could agree in our choice of a profession. I always preferred the church, as I still do. But that was not smart enough for my family. They recommended the army. That was a great deal too smart for me. The law was allowed to be genteel enough; many young men, who had chambers in the Temple, made a very good appearance in the first circles, and drove about town in very knowing gigs. But I had no inclination for the law, even in this less abstruse study of it, which my family approved. As for the navy, it had fashion on its side, but I was too old when the subject was first started to enter it--and, at length, as there was no necessity for my having any profession at all, as I might be as dashing and expensive without a red coat on my back as with one, idleness was pronounced on the whole to be most advantageous and honourable, and a young man of eighteen is not in general so earnestly bent on being busy as to resist the solicitations of his (man) friends to do nothing. I was therefore entered at Oxford and have been properly idle ever since.'' (he)

``The consequence of which, I suppose, will be,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood,
``since leisure has not promoted your own happiness, that your sons will be brought up to as many pursuits, employments, professions, and trades as Columella's.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``They will be brought up,'' (he)
said he (man), in a serious accent,
``to be as unlike myself as is possible. In feeling, in action, in condition, in every thing.'' (he)

``Come, come; this is all an effusion of immediate want of spirits, Edward. You are in a melancholy humour, and fancy that any one unlike yourself must be happy. But remember that the pain of parting from friends will be felt by every body at times, whatever be their education or state. Know your own happiness. You want nothing but patience--or give it a more fascinating name, call it hope. Your mother will secure to you, in time, that independence you are so anxious for; it is her (mother) duty, and it will, it must ere long become her (mother) happiness to prevent your whole youth from being wasted in discontent. How much may not a few months do?'' (unknown)

``I think,'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
replied Edward,
``that I may defy many months to produce any good to me.'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

This desponding turn of mind, though it could not be communicated to Mrs. Dashwood, gave additional pain to them all in the parting, which shortly took place, and left an uncomfortable impression on Elinor's feelings especially, which required some trouble and time to subdue. But as it was her (Elinor) determination to subdue it, and to prevent herself from appearing to suffer more than what all her (Elinor) family suffered on his (Edward) going away, she (Elinor) did not adopt the method so judiciously employed by Marianne, on a similar occasion, to augment and fix her (Marianne) sorrow, by seeking silence, solitude and idleness. Their means were as different as their objects, and equally suited to the advancement of each.

Elinor sat down to her (Elinor) drawing-table as soon as he (Edward) was out of the house, busily employed herself the whole day, neither sought nor avoided the mention of his (Edward) name, appeared to interest herself almost as much as ever in the general concerns of the family, and if, by this conduct, she (Elinor) did not lessen her (Elinor) own grief, it was at least prevented from unnecessary increase, and her (Elinor) mother and sisters were spared much solicitude on her (Elinor) account.

Such behaviour as this, so exactly the reverse of her (Elinor) own, appeared no more meritorious to Marianne, than her (Marianne) own had seemed faulty to her (Marianne). The business of self-command she (Marianne) settled very easily;--with strong affections it was impossible, with calm ones it could have no merit. That her (Marianne) sister's affections WERE calm, she (Marianne) dared not deny, though she (Marianne) blushed to acknowledge it; and of the strength of her (Marianne) own, she (Marianne) gave a very striking proof, by still loving and respecting that sister, in spite of this mortifying conviction.

Without shutting herself up from her (sister) family, or leaving the house in determined solitude to avoid them, or lying awake the whole night to indulge meditation, Elinor found every day afforded her (Elinor) leisure enough to think of Edward, and of Edward's behaviour, in every possible variety which the different state of her (Elinor) spirits at different times could produce,--with tenderness, pity, approbation, censure, and doubt. There were moments in abundance, when, if not by the absence of her (Elinor) mother and sisters, at least by the nature of their employments, conversation was forbidden among them, and every effect of solitude was produced. Her (Elinor) mind was inevitably at liberty; her (Elinor) thoughts could not be chained elsewhere; and the past and the future, on a subject so interesting, must be before her (Elinor), must force her (Elinor) attention, and engross her (Elinor) memory, her (Elinor) reflection, and her (Elinor) fancy.

From a reverie of this kind, as she (Elinor) sat at her (Elinor) drawing-table, she (Elinor) was roused one morning, soon after Edward's leaving them, by the arrival of company. She (Elinor) happened to be quite alone. The closing of the little gate, at the entrance of the green court in front of the house, drew her (Elinor) eyes to the window, and she (Elinor) saw a large party walking up to the door. Amongst them were Sir John and Lady Middleton and Mrs. Jennings, but there were two others, a gentleman and lady, who were quite unknown to her (gentleman). She (gentleman) was sitting near the window, and as soon as Sir John perceived her (John), he (party) left the rest of the party to the ceremony of knocking at the door, and stepping across the turf, obliged her (John) to open the casement to speak to him (party), though the space was so short between the door and the window, as to make it hardly possible to speak at one without being heard at the other.

``Well,'' (he)
said he (party),
``we have brought you some strangers. How do you like them?'' (he)

``Hush! they will hear you.'' (unknown)

``Never mind if they do. It is only the Palmers. Charlotte is very pretty, I can tell you. You may see her (Charlotte) if you look this way.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

As Elinor was certain of seeing her (Elinor) in a couple of minutes, without taking that liberty, she (Elinor) begged to be excused.

``Where is Marianne? Has she (Marianne) run away because we are come? I see her (Marianne) instrument is open.'' (unknown)

``She (Marianne) is walking, I believe.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

They were now joined by Mrs. Jennings, who had not patience enough to wait till the door was opened before she (Jennings) told HER story. She (Jennings) came hallooing to the window,

``How do you do, my dear? How does Mrs. Dashwood do? And where are your sisters? What! all alone! you will be glad of a little company to sit with you. I have brought my other son and daughter to see you. Only think of their coming so suddenly! I thought I heard a carriage last night, while we were drinking our tea, but it never entered my head that it could be them. I thought of nothing but whether it might not be Colonel Brandon come back again; so I said to Sir John, I do think I hear a carriage; perhaps it is Colonel Brandon come back again'' (She)
--

Elinor was obliged to turn from her (Elinor), in the middle of her (Elinor) story, to receive the rest of the party; Lady Middleton introduced the two strangers; Mrs. Dashwood and Margaret came down stairs at the same time, and they all sat down to look at one another, while Mrs. Jennings continued her (Jennings) story as she (Jennings) walked through the passage into the parlour, attended by Sir John.

Mrs. Palmer was several years younger than Lady Middleton, and totally unlike her (Middleton) in every respect. She (Middleton) was short and plump, had a very pretty face, and the finest expression of good humour in it that could possibly be. Her (Middleton) manners were by no means so elegant as her (Middleton) sister's, but they were much more prepossessing. She (Middleton) came in with a smile, smiled all the time of her (Middleton) visit, except when she (Middleton) laughed, and smiled when she (Middleton) went away. Her (Middleton) husband was a grave looking young man of five or six and twenty, with an air of more fashion and sense than his (husband) wife, but of less willingness to please or be pleased. He (husband) entered the room with a look of self-consequence, slightly bowed to the ladies, without speaking a word, and, after briefly surveying them and their apartments, took up a newspaper from the table, and continued to read it as long as he (husband) staid.

Mrs. Palmer, on the contrary, who was strongly endowed by nature with a turn for being uniformly civil and happy, was hardly seated before her (Palmer) admiration of the parlour and every thing in it burst forth.

``Well! what a delightful room this is! I never saw anything so charming! Only think, Mama, how it is improved since I was here last! I always thought it such a sweet place, ma'am! -LRB-turning to Mrs. Dashwood-RRB- but you have made it so charming! Only look, sister, how delightful every thing is! How I should like such a house for myself! Should not you, Mr. Palmer?'' (Mr. Palmer)

Mr. Palmer made her (sister) no answer, and did not even raise his (Palmer) eyes from the newspaper.

``Mr. Palmer does not hear me,'' (she)
said she (sister), laughing;
``he (Palmer) never does sometimes. It is so ridiculous!'' (she)

This was quite a new idea to Mrs. Dashwood; she (Dashwood) had never been used to find wit in the inattention of any one, and could not help looking with surprise at them both.

Mrs. Jennings, in the meantime, talked on as loud as she (Jennings) could, and continued her (Jennings) account of their surprise, the evening before, on seeing their friends, without ceasing till every thing was told. Mrs. Palmer laughed heartily at the recollection of their astonishment, and every body agreed, two or three times over, that it had been quite an agreeable surprise.

``You may believe how glad we all were to see them,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
added Mrs. Jennings, leaning forward towards Elinor, and speaking in a low voice as if she (Elinor) meant to be heard by no one else, though they were seated on different sides of the room;
``but, however, I can't help wishing they had not travelled quite so fast, nor made such a long journey of it, for they came all round by London upon account of some business, for you know -LRB-nodding significantly and pointing to her (Elinor) daughter-RRB- it was wrong in her (Elinor) situation. I wanted her (Elinor) to stay at home and rest this morning, but she (Elinor) would come with us; she (Elinor) longed so much to see you all!'' (she)

Mrs. Palmer laughed, and said it would not do her (Palmer) any harm.

``She (Palmer) expects to be confined in February,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
continued Mrs. Jennings.

Lady Middleton could no longer endure such a conversation, and therefore exerted herself to ask Mr. Palmer if there was any news in the paper.

``No, none at all,'' (he)
he (Palmer) replied, and read on.

``Here comes Marianne,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
cried Sir John.
``Now, Palmer, you shall see a monstrous pretty girl.'' (He)

He (Palmer) immediately went into the passage, opened the front door, and ushered her (Palmer) in himself. Mrs. Jennings asked her (Jennings), as soon as she (Jennings) appeared, if she (Jennings) had not been to Allenham; and Mrs. Palmer laughed so heartily at the question, as to show she (Palmer) understood it. Mr. Palmer looked up on her (Palmer) entering the room, stared at her (Palmer) some minutes, and then returned to his (Palmer) newspaper. Mrs. Palmer's eye was now caught by the drawings which hung round the room. She (Palmer) got up to examine them.

``Oh! dear, how beautiful these are! Well! how delightful! Do but look, mama, how sweet! I declare they are quite charming; I could look at them for ever.'' (she)
And then sitting down again, she (Palmer) very soon forgot that there were any such things in the room.

When Lady Middleton rose to go away, Mr. Palmer rose also, laid down the newspaper, stretched himself and looked at them all around.

``My love, have you been asleep?'' (wife)
said his (Palmer) wife, laughing.

He (Palmer) made her (wife) no answer; and only observed, after again examining the room, that it was very low pitched, and that the ceiling was crooked. He (Palmer) then made his (Palmer) bow, and departed with the rest.

Sir John had been very urgent with them all to spend the next day at the park. Mrs. Dashwood, who did not chuse to dine with them oftener than they dined at the cottage, absolutely refused on her (Dashwood) own account; her (Dashwood) daughters might do as they pleased. But they had no curiosity to see how Mr. and Mrs. Palmer ate their dinner, and no expectation of pleasure from them in any other way. They attempted, therefore, likewise, to excuse themselves; the weather was uncertain, and not likely to be good. But Sir John would not be satisfied--the carriage should be sent for them and they must come. Lady Middleton too, though she (Middleton) did not press their mother, pressed them. Mrs. Jennings and Mrs. Palmer joined their entreaties, all seemed equally anxious to avoid a family party; and the young ladies were obliged to yield.

``Why should they ask us?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, as soon as they were gone.
``The rent of this cottage is said to be low; but we have it on very hard terms, if we are to dine at the park whenever any one is staying either with them, or with us.'' (unknown)

``They mean no less to be civil and kind to us now,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``by these frequent invitations, than by those which we received from them a few weeks ago. The alteration is not in them, if their parties are grown tedious and dull. We must look for the change elsewhere.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

CHAPTER 20

As the Miss Dashwoods entered the drawing-room of the park the next day, at one door, Mrs. Palmer came running in at the other, looking as good humoured and merry as before. She (Palmer) took them all most affectionately by the hand, and expressed great delight in seeing them again.

``I am so glad to see you!'' (she)
said she (Palmer), seating herself between Elinor and Marianne,
``for it is so bad a day I was afraid you might not come, which would be a shocking thing, as we go away again tomorrow. We must go, for the Westons come to us next week you know. It was quite a sudden thing our coming at all, and I knew nothing of it till the carriage was coming to the door, and then Mr. Palmer asked me if I would go with him (Palmer) to Barton. He (Palmer) is so droll! He (Palmer) never tells me any thing! I am so sorry we cannot stay longer; however we shall meet again in town very soon, I hope.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

They were obliged to put an end to such an expectation.

``Not go to town!'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)
cried Mrs. Palmer, with a laugh,
``I shall be quite disappointed if you do not. I could get the nicest house in world for you, next door to ours, in Hanover-square. You must come, indeed. I am sure I shall be very happy to chaperon you at any time till I am confined, if Mrs. Dashwood should not like to go into public.'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)

They thanked her (Dashwood); but were obliged to resist all her (Dashwood) entreaties.

``Oh, my love,'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)
cried Mrs. Palmer to her (Palmer) husband, who just then entered the room--
``you must help me to persuade the Miss Dashwoods to go to town this winter.'' (husband)

Her (Palmer) love made no answer; and after slightly bowing to the ladies, began complaining of the weather.

``How horrid all this is!'' (he)
said he (husband).
``Such weather makes every thing and every body disgusting. Dullness is as much produced within doors as without, by rain. It makes one detest all one's acquaintance. What the devil does Sir John mean by not having a billiard room in his (devil) house? How few people know what comfort is! Sir John is as stupid as the weather.'' (unknown)

The rest of the company soon dropt in.

``I am afraid, Miss Marianne,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Sir John,
``you have not been able to take your usual walk to Allenham today.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Marianne looked very grave and said nothing.

``Oh, don't be so sly before us,'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)
said Mrs. Palmer;
``for we know all about it, I assure you; and I admire your taste very much, for I think he (we) is extremely handsome. We do not live a great way from him (we) in the country, you know. Not above ten miles, I dare say.'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)

``Much nearer thirty,'' (husband)
said her (Palmer) husband.

``Ah, well! there is not much difference. I never was at his (husband) house; but they say it is a sweet pretty place.'' (unknown)

``As vile a spot as I ever saw in my life,'' (Mr. Palmer)
said Mr. Palmer.

Marianne remained perfectly silent, though her (Marianne) countenance betrayed her (Marianne) interest in what was said.

``Is it very ugly?'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)
continued Mrs. Palmer--
``then it must be some other place that is so pretty I suppose.'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)

When they were seated in the dining room, Sir John observed with regret that they were only eight all together.

``My dear,'' (he)
said he (Palmer) to his (Palmer) lady,
``it is very provoking that we should be so few. Why did not you ask the Gilberts to come to us today?'' (lady)

``Did not I tell you, Sir John, when you spoke to me about it before, that it could not be done? They dined with us last.'' (unknown)

``You and I, Sir John,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings,
``should not stand upon such ceremony.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``Then you would be very ill-bred,'' (Mr. Palmer)
cried Mr. Palmer.

``My love you contradict every body,'' (wife)
said his (Palmer) wife with her (wife) usual laugh.
``Do you know that you are quite rude?'' (unknown)

``I did not know I contradicted any body in calling your mother ill-bred.'' (unknown)

``Ay, you may abuse me as you please,'' (the lady)
said the good-natured old lady,
``you have taken Charlotte off my hands, and cannot give her (Charlotte) back again. So there I have the whip hand of you.'' (the lady)

Charlotte laughed heartily to think that her (Charlotte) husband could not get rid of her (Charlotte); and exultingly said, she (Charlotte) did not care how cross he (husband) was to her (Charlotte), as they must live together. It was impossible for any one to be more thoroughly good-natured, or more determined to be happy than Mrs. Palmer. The studied indifference, insolence, and discontent of her (Palmer) husband gave her (Palmer) no pain; and when he (husband) scolded or abused her (Palmer), she (Palmer) was highly diverted.

``Mr. Palmer is so droll!'' (she)
said she (Palmer), in a whisper, to Elinor.
``He (Palmer) is always out of humour.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was not inclined, after a little observation, to give him (Palmer) credit for being so genuinely and unaffectedly ill-natured or ill-bred as he (Palmer) wished to appear. His (Palmer) temper might perhaps be a little soured by finding, like many others of his (Palmer) sex, that through some unaccountable bias in favour of beauty, he (Palmer) was the husband of a very silly woman,--but she (woman) knew that this kind of blunder was too common for any sensible man to be lastingly hurt by it.-- It was rather a wish of distinction, she (woman) believed, which produced his (man) contemptuous treatment of every body, and his (man) general abuse of every thing before him (man). It was the desire of appearing superior to other people. The motive was too common to be wondered at; but the means, however they might succeed by establishing his (man) superiority in ill-breeding, were not likely to attach any one to him (man) except his (man) wife.

``Oh, my dear Miss Dashwood,'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)
said Mrs. Palmer soon afterwards,
``I have got such a favour to ask of you and your sister. Will you come and spend some time at Cleveland this Christmas? Now, pray do,--and come while the Westons are with us. You cannot think how happy I shall be! It will be quite delightful!--My love,'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)
applying to her (Palmer) husband,
``don't you long to have the Miss Dashwoods come to Cleveland?'' (husband)

``Certainly,'' (he)
he (husband) replied, with a sneer--
``I came into Devonshire with no other view.'' (he)

``There now,'' (lady)
--said his (husband) lady,
``you see Mr. Palmer expects you; so you cannot refuse to come.'' (lady)

They both eagerly and resolutely declined her (lady) invitation.

``But indeed you must and shall come. I am sure you will like it of all things. The Westons will be with us, and it will be quite delightful. You cannot think what a sweet place Cleveland is; and we are so gay now, for Mr. Palmer is always going about the country canvassing against the election; and so many people came to dine with us that I never saw before, it is quite charming! But, poor fellow! it is very fatiguing to him (fellow)! for he (fellow) is forced to make every body like him (fellow).'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor could hardly keep her (Elinor) countenance as she (Elinor) assented to the hardship of such an obligation.

``How charming it will be,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``when he (fellow) is in Parliament!--won't it? How I shall laugh! It will be so ridiculous to see all his (fellow) letters directed to him (fellow) with an M.P.--But do you know, he (fellow) says, he (fellow) will never frank for me? He (fellow) declares he (fellow) won't. Don't you, Mr. Palmer?'' (Charlotte)

Mr. Palmer took no notice of her (Charlotte).

``He (Palmer) cannot bear writing, you know,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) continued--
``he (Palmer) says it is quite shocking.'' (she)

``No,'' (he)
said he (Palmer),
``I never said any thing so irrational. Don't palm all your abuses of languages upon me.'' (he)

``There now; you see how droll he (Palmer) is. This is always the way with him (Palmer)! Sometimes he (Palmer) won't speak to me for half a day together, and then he (Palmer) comes out with something so droll--all about any thing in the world.'' (She)

She (Charlotte) surprised Elinor very much as they returned into the drawing-room, by asking her (Charlotte) whether she (Charlotte) did not like Mr. Palmer excessively.

``Certainly,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``he (Palmer) seems very agreeable.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Well--I am so glad you do. I thought you would, he (Palmer) is so pleasant; and Mr. Palmer is excessively pleased with you and your sisters I can tell you, and you can't think how disappointed he (Palmer) will be if you don't come to Cleveland.--I can't imagine why you should object to it.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was again obliged to decline her (Elinor) invitation; and by changing the subject, put a stop to her (Elinor) entreaties. She (Elinor) thought it probable that as they lived in the same county, Mrs. Palmer might be able to give some more particular account of Willoughby's general character, than could be gathered from the Middletons' partial acquaintance with him (acquaintance); and she (Palmer) was eager to gain from any one, such a confirmation of his (acquaintance) merits as might remove the possibility of fear from Marianne. She (Marianne) began by inquiring if they saw much of Mr. Willoughby at Cleveland, and whether they were intimately acquainted with him (Willoughby).

``Oh dear, yes; I know him (Willoughby) extremely well,'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)
replied Mrs. Palmer;--
``Not that I ever spoke to him (Willoughby), indeed; but I have seen him (Willoughby) for ever in town. Somehow or other I never happened to be staying at Barton while he (Barton) was at Allenham. Mama saw him (Barton) here once before;--but I was with my uncle at Weymouth. However, I dare say we should have seen a great deal of him (uncle) in Somersetshire, if it had not happened very unluckily that we should never have been in the country together. He (uncle) is very little at Combe, I believe; but if he (uncle) were ever so much there, I do not think Mr. Palmer would visit him (Palmer), for he (Palmer) is in the opposition, you know, and besides it is such a way off. I know why you inquire about him (Palmer), very well; your sister is to marry him (Palmer). I am monstrous glad of it, for then I shall have her (sister) for a neighbour you know.'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)

``Upon my word,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``you know much more of the matter than I do, if you have any reason to expect such a match.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Don't pretend to deny it, because you know it is what every body talks of. I assure you I heard of it in my way through town.'' (unknown)

``My dear Mrs. Palmer!'' (unknown)

``Upon my honour I did.--I met Colonel Brandon Monday morning in Bond-street, just before we left town, and he (Colonel) told me of it directly.'' (unknown)

``You surprise me very much. Colonel Brandon tell you of it! Surely you must be mistaken. To give such intelligence to a person who could not be interested in it, even if it were true, is not what I should expect Colonel Brandon to do.'' (unknown)

``But I do assure you it was so, for all that, and I will tell you how it happened. When we met him (Colonel), he (Colonel) turned back and walked with us; and so we began talking of my brother and sister, and one thing and another, and I said to him (brother), `So, Colonel, there is a new family come to Barton cottage, I hear, and mama sends me word they are very pretty, and that one of them is going to be married to Mr. Willoughby of Combe Magna. Is it true, pray? for of course you must know, as you have been in Devonshire so lately.''' (unknown)

``And what did the Colonel say?'' (unknown)

``Oh--he (Colonel) did not say much; but he (Colonel) looked as if he (Colonel) knew it to be true, so from that moment I set it down as certain. It will be quite delightful, I declare! When is it to take place?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Brandon was very well I hope?'' (unknown)

``Oh! yes, quite well; and so full of your praises, he (Brandon) did nothing but say fine things of you.'' (unknown)

``I am flattered by his (Brandon) commendation. He (Brandon) seems an excellent man; and I think him (Brandon) uncommonly pleasing.'' (unknown)

``So do I.--He (Brandon) is such a charming man, that it is quite a pity he (Brandon) should be so grave and so dull. Mama says HE (Brandon) was in love with your sister too.-- I assure you it was a great compliment if he (Brandon) was, for he (Brandon) hardly ever falls in love with any body.'' (unknown)

``Is Mr. Willoughby much known in your part of Somersetshire?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.

``Oh! yes, extremely well; that is, I do not believe many people are acquainted with him (Willoughby), because Combe Magna is so far off; but they all think him (Magna) extremely agreeable I assure you. Nobody is more liked than Mr. Willoughby wherever he (Willoughby) goes, and so you may tell your sister. She (sister) is a monstrous lucky girl to get him (Willoughby), upon my honour; not but that he (Willoughby) is much more lucky in getting her (sister), because she (sister) is so very handsome and agreeable, that nothing can be good enough for her (sister). However, I don't think her (sister) hardly at all handsomer than you, I assure you; for I think you both excessively pretty, and so does Mr. Palmer too I am sure, though we could not get him (Palmer) to own it last night.'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)

Mrs. Palmer's information respecting Willoughby was not very material; but any testimony in his (Willoughby) favour, however small, was pleasing to her (Palmer).

``I am so glad we are got acquainted at last,'' (Charlotte)
continued Charlotte.--
``And now I hope we shall always be great friends. You can't think how much I longed to see you! It is so delightful that you should live at the cottage! Nothing can be like it, to be sure! And I am so glad your sister is going to be well married! I hope you will be a great deal at Combe Magna. It is a sweet place, by all accounts.'' (unknown)

``You have been long acquainted with Colonel Brandon, have not you?'' (unknown)

``Yes, a great while; ever since my sister married.-- He (Colonel) was a particular friend of Sir John's. I believe,'' (she)
she (John) added in a low voice,
``he (Colonel) would have been very glad to have had me, if he (Colonel) could. Sir John and Lady Middleton wished it very much. But mama did not think the match good enough for me, otherwise Sir John would have mentioned it to the Colonel, and we should have been married immediately.'' (she)

``Did not Colonel Brandon know of Sir John's proposal to your mother before it was made? Had he (Colonel) never owned his (Colonel) affection to yourself?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no; but if mama had not objected to it, I dare say he (Colonel) would have liked it of all things. He (Colonel) had not seen me then above twice, for it was before I left school. However, I am much happier as I am. Mr. Palmer is the kind of man I like.'' (Palmers)

CHAPTER 21

The Palmers returned to Cleveland the next day, and the two families at Barton were again left to entertain each other. But this did not last long; Elinor had hardly got their last visitors out of her (Elinor) head, had hardly done wondering at Charlotte's being so happy without a cause, at Mr. Palmer's acting so simply, with good abilities, and at the strange unsuitableness which often existed between husband and wife, before Sir John's and Mrs. Jennings's active zeal in the cause of society, procured her (John) some other new acquaintance to see and observe.

In a morning's excursion to Exeter, they had met with two young ladies, whom Mrs. Jennings had the satisfaction of discovering to be her (Jennings) relations, and this was enough for Sir John to invite them directly to the park, as soon as their present engagements at Exeter were over. Their engagements at Exeter instantly gave way before such an invitation, and Lady Middleton was thrown into no little alarm on the return of Sir John, by hearing that she (John) was very soon to receive a visit from two girls whom she (John) had never seen in her (John) life, and of whose elegance,--whose tolerable gentility even, she (John) could have no proof; for the assurances of her (John) husband and mother on that subject went for nothing at all. Their being her (John) relations too made it so much the worse; and Mrs. Jennings's attempts at consolation were therefore unfortunately founded, when she (Jennings) advised her (Jennings) daughter not to care about their being so fashionable; because they were all cousins and must put up with one another. As it was impossible, however, now to prevent their coming, Lady Middleton resigned herself to the idea of it, with all the philosophy of a well-bred woman, contenting herself with merely giving her (Middleton) husband a gentle reprimand on the subject five or six times every day.

The young ladies arrived: their appearance was by no means ungenteel or unfashionable. Their dress was very smart, their manners very civil, they were delighted with the house, and in raptures with the furniture, and they happened to be so doatingly fond of children that Lady Middleton's good opinion was engaged in their favour before they had been an hour at the Park. She (Middleton) declared them to be very agreeable girls indeed, which for her (Middleton) ladyship was enthusiastic admiration. Sir John's confidence in his (their) own judgment rose with this animated praise, and he (their) set off directly for the cottage to tell the Miss Dashwoods of the Miss Steeles' arrival, and to assure them of their being the sweetest girls in the world. From such commendation as this, however, there was not much to be learned; Elinor well knew that the sweetest girls in the world were to be met with in every part of England, under every possible variation of form, face, temper and understanding. Sir John wanted the whole family to walk to the Park directly and look at his (their) guests. Benevolent, philanthropic man! It was painful to him (their) even to keep a third cousin to himself.

``Do come now,'' (he)
said he (their)--
``pray come--you must come--I declare you shall come--You can't think how you will like them. Lucy is monstrous pretty, and so good humoured and agreeable! The children are all hanging about her (Lucy) already, as if she (Lucy) was an old acquaintance. And they both long to see you of all things, for they have heard at Exeter that you are the most beautiful creatures in the world; and I have told them it is all very true, and a great deal more. You will be delighted with them I am sure. They have brought the whole coach full of playthings for the children. How can you be so cross as not to come? Why they are your cousins, you know, after a fashion. YOU are my cousins, and they are my wife's, so you must be related.'' (he)

But Sir John could not prevail. He (coach) could only obtain a promise of their calling at the Park within a day or two, and then left them in amazement at their indifference, to walk home and boast anew of their attractions to the Miss Steeles, as he (coach) had been already boasting of the Miss Steeles to them.

When their promised visit to the Park and consequent introduction to these young ladies took place, they found in the appearance of the eldest, who was nearly thirty, with a very plain and not a sensible face, nothing to admire; but in the other, who was not more than two or three and twenty, they acknowledged considerable beauty; her (Steeles) features were pretty, and she (Steeles) had a sharp quick eye, and a smartness of air, which though it did not give actual elegance or grace, gave distinction to her (Steeles) person.-- Their manners were particularly civil, and Elinor soon allowed them credit for some kind of sense, when she (Elinor) saw with what constant and judicious attention they were making themselves agreeable to Lady Middleton. With her (Middleton) children they were in continual raptures, extolling their beauty, courting their notice, and humouring their whims; and such of their time as could be spared from the importunate demands which this politeness made on it, was spent in admiration of whatever her (Middleton) ladyship was doing, if she (Middleton) happened to be doing any thing, or in taking patterns of some elegant new dress, in which her (Middleton) appearance the day before had thrown them into unceasing delight. Fortunately for those who pay their court through such foibles, a fond mother, though, in pursuit of praise for her (mother) children, the most rapacious of human beings, is likewise the most credulous; her (mother) demands are exorbitant; but she (mother) will swallow any thing; and the excessive affection and endurance of the Miss Steeles towards her (mother) offspring were viewed therefore by Lady Middleton without the smallest surprise or distrust. She (Middleton) saw with maternal complacency all the impertinent encroachments and mischievous tricks to which her (Middleton) cousins submitted. She (Middleton) saw their sashes untied, their hair pulled about their ears, their work-bags searched, and their knives and scissors stolen away, and felt no doubt of its being a reciprocal enjoyment. It suggested no other surprise than that Elinor and Marianne should sit so composedly by, without claiming a share in what was passing.

``John is in such spirits today!'' (she)
said she (John), on his (their) taking Miss Steeles's pocket handkerchief, and throwing it out of window--
``He (their) is full of monkey tricks.'' (Miss Steeles/Steeles)

And soon afterwards, on the second boy's violently pinching one of the same lady's fingers, she (lady) fondly observed,

``How playful William is!'' (she)

``And here is my sweet little Annamaria,'' (she)
