she (lady) added, tenderly caressing a little girl of three years old, who had not made a noise for the last two minutes;
``And she (lady) is always so gentle and quiet--Never was there such a quiet little thing!'' (a girl)

But unfortunately in bestowing these embraces, a pin in her (lady) ladyship's head dress slightly scratching the child's neck, produced from this pattern of gentleness such violent screams, as could hardly be outdone by any creature professedly noisy. The mother's consternation was excessive; but it could not surpass the alarm of the Miss Steeles, and every thing was done by all three, in so critical an emergency, which affection could suggest as likely to assuage the agonies of the little sufferer. She (Steeles) was seated in her (Steeles) mother's lap, covered with kisses, her (Steeles) wound bathed with lavender-water, by one of the Miss Steeles, who was on her (Steeles) knees to attend her (Steeles), and her (Steeles) mouth stuffed with sugar plums by the other. With such a reward for her (Steeles) tears, the child was too wise to cease crying. She (Steeles) still screamed and sobbed lustily, kicked her (Steeles) two brothers for offering to touch her (Steeles), and all their united soothings were ineffectual till Lady Middleton luckily remembering that in a scene of similar distress last week, some apricot marmalade had been successfully applied for a bruised temple, the same remedy was eagerly proposed for this unfortunate scratch, and a slight intermission of screams in the young lady on hearing it, gave them reason to hope that it would not be rejected.-- She (lady) was carried out of the room therefore in her (lady) mother's arms, in quest of this medicine, and as the two boys chose to follow, though earnestly entreated by their mother to stay behind, the four young ladies were left in a quietness which the room had not known for many hours.

``Poor little creatures!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Miss Steele, as soon as they were gone.
``It might have been a very sad accident.'' (unknown)

``Yet I hardly know how,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``unless it had been under totally different circumstances. But this is the usual way of heightening alarm, where there is nothing to be alarmed at in reality.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``What a sweet woman Lady Middleton is!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy Steele.

Marianne was silent; it was impossible for her (Marianne) to say what she (Marianne) did not feel, however trivial the occasion; and upon Elinor therefore the whole task of telling lies when politeness required it, always fell. She (Elinor) did her (Elinor) best when thus called on, by speaking of Lady Middleton with more warmth than she (Middleton) felt, though with far less than Miss Lucy.

``And Sir John too,'' (the sister man)
cried the elder sister,
``what a charming man he (man) is!'' (the sister man)

Here too, Miss Dashwood's commendation, being only simple and just, came in without any eclat. She (Dashwood) merely observed that he (man) was perfectly good humoured and friendly.

``And what a charming little family they have! I never saw such fine children in my life.--I declare I quite doat upon them already, and indeed I am always distractedly fond of children.'' (unknown)

``I should guess so,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, with a smile,
``from what I have witnessed this morning.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I have a notion,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy,
``you think the little Middletons rather too much indulged; perhaps they may be the outside of enough; but it is so natural in Lady Middleton; and for my part, I love to see children full of life and spirits; I cannot bear them if they are tame and quiet.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``I confess,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``that while I am at Barton Park, I never think of tame and quiet children with any abhorrence.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

A short pause succeeded this speech, which was first broken by Miss Steele, who seemed very much disposed for conversation, and who now said rather abruptly,

``And how do you like Devonshire, Miss Dashwood? I suppose you were very sorry to leave Sussex.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

In some surprise at the familiarity of this question, or at least of the manner in which it was spoken, Elinor replied that she (Elinor) was.

``Norland is a prodigious beautiful place, is not it?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
added Miss Steele.

``We have heard Sir John admire it excessively,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy, who seemed to think some apology necessary for the freedom of her (Lucy) sister.

``I think every one MUST admire it,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``who ever saw the place; though it is not to be supposed that any one can estimate its beauties as we do.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``And had you a great many smart beaux there? I suppose you have not so many in this part of the world; for my part, I think they are a vast addition always.'' (unknown)

``But why should you think,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy, looking ashamed of her (Lucy) sister,
``that there are not as many genteel young men in Devonshire as Sussex?'' (sister)

``Nay, my dear, I'm sure I don't pretend to say that there an't. I'm sure there's a vast many smart beaux in Exeter; but you know, how could I tell what smart beaux there might be about Norland; and I was only afraid the Miss Dashwoods might find it dull at Barton, if they had not so many as they used to have. But perhaps you young ladies may not care about the beaux, and had as lief be without them as with them. For my part, I think they are vastly agreeable, provided they dress smart and behave civil. But I can't bear to see them dirty and nasty. Now there's Mr. Rose at Exeter, a prodigious smart young man, quite a beau, clerk to Mr. Simpson, you know, and yet if you do but meet him (Simpson) of a morning, he (Simpson) is not fit to be seen.-- I suppose your brother was quite a beau, Miss Dashwood, before he (brother) married, as he (brother) was so rich?'' (unknown)

``Upon my word,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``I cannot tell you, for I do not perfectly comprehend the meaning of the word. But this I can say, that if he (brother) ever was a beau before he (brother) married, he (brother) is one still for there is not the smallest alteration in him (brother).'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Oh! dear! one never thinks of married men's being beaux--they have something else to do.'' (unknown)

``Lord! Anne,'' (sister)
cried her (Anne) sister,
``you can talk of nothing but beaux;--you will make Miss Dashwood believe you think of nothing else.'' (sister)
And then to turn the discourse, she (Dashwood) began admiring the house and the furniture.

This specimen of the Miss Steeles was enough. The vulgar freedom and folly of the eldest left her (Steeles) no recommendation, and as Elinor was not blinded by the beauty, or the shrewd look of the youngest, to her (Elinor) want of real elegance and artlessness, she (Elinor) left the house without any wish of knowing them better.

Not so the Miss Steeles.--They came from Exeter, well provided with admiration for the use of Sir John Middleton, his (Middleton) family, and all his (Middleton) relations, and no niggardly proportion was now dealt out to his (Middleton) fair cousins, whom they declared to be the most beautiful, elegant, accomplished, and agreeable girls they had ever beheld, and with whom they were particularly anxious to be better acquainted.-- And to be better acquainted therefore, Elinor soon found was their inevitable lot, for as Sir John was entirely on the side of the Miss Steeles, their party would be too strong for opposition, and that kind of intimacy must be submitted to, which consists of sitting an hour or two together in the same room almost every day. Sir John could do no more; but he (girls) did not know that any more was required: to be together was, in his (girls) opinion, to be intimate, and while his (girls) continual schemes for their meeting were effectual, he (girls) had not a doubt of their being established friends.

To do him (girls) justice, he (girls) did every thing in his (girls) power to promote their unreserve, by making the Miss Steeles acquainted with whatever he (girls) knew or supposed of his (girls) cousins' situations in the most delicate particulars,--and Elinor had not seen them more than twice, before the eldest of them wished her (Elinor) joy on her (Elinor) sister's having been so lucky as to make a conquest of a very smart beau since she (Elinor) came to Barton.

''`Twill be a fine thing to have her (Elinor) married so young to be sure,'' said she (Elinor),

``and I hear he (Barton) is quite a beau, and prodigious handsome. And I hope you may have as good luck yourself soon,--but perhaps you may have a friend in the corner already.'' (she)

Elinor could not suppose that Sir John would be more nice in proclaiming his (friend) suspicions of her (John) regard for Edward, than he (friend) had been with respect to Marianne; indeed it was rather his (friend) favourite joke of the two, as being somewhat newer and more conjectural; and since Edward's visit, they had never dined together without his (Edward) drinking to her (Marianne) best affections with so much significancy and so many nods and winks, as to excite general attention. The letter F--had been likewise invariably brought forward, and found productive of such countless jokes, that its character as the wittiest letter in the alphabet had been long established with Elinor.

The Miss Steeles, as she (Steeles) expected, had now all the benefit of these jokes, and in the eldest of them they raised a curiosity to know the name of the gentleman alluded to, which, though often impertinently expressed, was perfectly of a piece with her (Steeles) general inquisitiveness into the concerns of their family. But Sir John did not sport long with the curiosity which he (gentleman) delighted to raise, for he (gentleman) had at least as much pleasure in telling the name, as Miss Steele had in hearing it.

``His (gentleman) name is Ferrars,'' (he)
said he (Ferrars), in a very audible whisper;
``but pray do not tell it, for it's a great secret.'' (he)

``Ferrars!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
repeated Miss Steele;
``Mr. Ferrars is the happy man, is he (Ferrars)? What! your sister-in-law's brother, Miss Dashwood? a very agreeable young man to be sure; I know him (man) very well.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``How can you say so, Anne?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Lucy, who generally made an amendment to all her (Lucy) sister's assertions.
``Though we have seen him (man) once or twice at my uncle's, it is rather too much to pretend to know him (uncle) very well.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor heard all this with attention and surprise.

``And who was this uncle? Where did he (uncle) live? How came they acquainted?'' (She)
She (Elinor) wished very much to have the subject continued, though she (Elinor) did not chuse to join in it herself; but nothing more of it was said, and for the first time in her (Elinor) life, she (Elinor) thought Mrs. Jennings deficient either in curiosity after petty information, or in a disposition to communicate it. The manner in which Miss Steele had spoken of Edward, increased her (Steele) curiosity; for it struck her (Steele) as being rather ill-natured, and suggested the suspicion of that lady's knowing, or fancying herself to know something to his (Edward) disadvantage.--But her (lady) curiosity was unavailing, for no farther notice was taken of Mr. Ferrars's name by Miss Steele when alluded to, or even openly mentioned by Sir John.

CHAPTER 22

Marianne, who had never much toleration for any thing like impertinence, vulgarity, inferiority of parts, or even difference of taste from herself, was at this time particularly ill-disposed, from the state of her (Marianne) spirits, to be pleased with the Miss Steeles, or to encourage their advances; and to the invariable coldness of her (Marianne) behaviour towards them, which checked every endeavour at intimacy on their side, Elinor principally attributed that preference of herself which soon became evident in the manners of both, but especially of Lucy, who missed no opportunity of engaging her (Lucy) in conversation, or of striving to improve their acquaintance by an easy and frank communication of her (Lucy) sentiments.

Lucy was naturally clever; her (Lucy) remarks were often just and amusing; and as a companion for half an hour Elinor frequently found her (Elinor) agreeable; but her (Elinor) powers had received no aid from education: she (Elinor) was ignorant and illiterate; and her (Elinor) deficiency of all mental improvement, her (Elinor) want of information in the most common particulars, could not be concealed from Miss Dashwood, in spite of her (Dashwood) constant endeavour to appear to advantage. Elinor saw, and pitied her (Elinor) for, the neglect of abilities which education might have rendered so respectable; but she (Elinor) saw, with less tenderness of feeling, the thorough want of delicacy, of rectitude, and integrity of mind, which her (Elinor) attentions, her (Elinor) assiduities, her (Elinor) flatteries at the Park betrayed; and she (Elinor) could have no lasting satisfaction in the company of a person who joined insincerity with ignorance; whose want of instruction prevented their meeting in conversation on terms of equality, and whose conduct toward others made every shew of attention and deference towards herself perfectly valueless.

``You will think my question an odd one, I dare say,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy to her (Lucy) one day, as they were walking together from the park to the cottage--
``but pray, are you personally acquainted with your sister-in-law's mother, Mrs. Ferrars?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Elinor DID think the question a very odd one, and her (Elinor) countenance expressed it, as she (Elinor) answered that she (Elinor) had never seen Mrs. Ferrars.

``Indeed!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
replied Lucy;
``I wonder at that, for I thought you must have seen her (Lucy) at Norland sometimes. Then, perhaps, you cannot tell me what sort of a woman she (woman) is?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``No,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
returned Elinor, cautious of giving her (Elinor) real opinion of Edward's mother, and not very desirous of satisfying what seemed impertinent curiosity--
``I know nothing of her (Elinor).'' (Edward mother)

``I am sure you think me very strange, for enquiring about her (Elinor) in such a way,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy, eyeing Elinor attentively as she (Elinor) spoke;
``but perhaps there may be reasons--I wish I might venture; but however I hope you will do me the justice of believing that I do not mean to be impertinent.'' (she)

Elinor made her (Elinor) a civil reply, and they walked on for a few minutes in silence. It was broken by Lucy, who renewed the subject again by saying, with some hesitation,

``I cannot bear to have you think me impertinently curious. I am sure I would rather do any thing in the world than be thought so by a person whose good opinion is so well worth having as yours. And I am sure I should not have the smallest fear of trusting YOU; indeed, I should be very glad of your advice how to manage in such an uncomfortable situation as I am; but, however, there is no occasion to trouble YOU. I am sorry you do not happen to know Mrs. Ferrars.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``I am sorry I do NOT,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, in great astonishment,
``if it could be of any use to YOU to know my opinion of her (Elinor). But really I never understood that you were at all connected with that family, and therefore I am a little surprised, I confess, at so serious an inquiry into her (Elinor) character.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I dare say you are, and I am sure I do not at all wonder at it. But if I dared tell you all, you would not be so much surprised. Mrs. Ferrars is certainly nothing to me at present--but the time MAY come--how soon it will come must depend upon herself--when we may be very intimately connected.'' (She)

She (Ferrars) looked down as she (Ferrars) said this, amiably bashful, with only one side glance at her (Ferrars) companion to observe its effect on her (Ferrars).

``Good heavens!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
cried Elinor,
``what do you mean? Are you acquainted with Mr. Robert Ferrars? Can you be?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
And she (Elinor) did not feel much delighted with the idea of such a sister-in-law.

``No,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
replied Lucy,
``not to Mr. ROBERT Ferrars--I never saw him (Ferrars) in my life; but,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
fixing her (Lucy) eyes upon Elinor,
``to his (Ferrars) eldest brother.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

What felt Elinor at that moment? Astonishment, that would have been as painful as it was strong, had not an immediate disbelief of the assertion attended it. She (Elinor) turned towards Lucy in silent amazement, unable to divine the reason or object of such a declaration; and though her (Lucy) complexion varied, she (Lucy) stood firm in incredulity, and felt in no danger of an hysterical fit, or a swoon.

``You may well be surprised,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
continued Lucy;
``for to be sure you could have had no idea of it before; for I dare say he (it) never dropped the smallest hint of it to you or any of your family; because it was always meant to be a great secret, and I am sure has been faithfully kept so by me to this hour. Not a soul of all my relations know of it but Anne, and I never should have mentioned it to you, if I had not felt the greatest dependence in the world upon your secrecy; and I really thought my behaviour in asking so many questions about Mrs. Ferrars must seem so odd, that it ought to be explained. And I do not think Mr. Ferrars can be displeased, when he (Ferrars) knows I have trusted you, because I know he (Ferrars) has the highest opinion in the world of all your family, and looks upon yourself and the other Miss Dashwoods quite as his (Ferrars) own sisters.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
--She (Ferrars) paused.

Elinor for a few moments remained silent. Her (Elinor) astonishment at what she (Elinor) heard was at first too great for words; but at length forcing herself to speak, and to speak cautiously, she (Elinor) said, with calmness of manner, which tolerably well concealed her (Elinor) surprise and solicitude--

``May I ask if your engagement is of long standing?'' (she)

``We have been engaged these four years.'' (unknown)

``Four years!'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor, though greatly shocked, still felt unable to believe it.

``I did not know,'' (she)
said she (Elinor),
``that you were even acquainted till the other day.'' (she)

``Our acquaintance, however, is of many years date. He (acquaintance) was under my uncle's care, you know, a considerable while.'' (unknown)

``Your uncle!'' (unknown)

``Yes; Mr. Pratt. Did you never hear him (Pratt) talk of Mr. Pratt?'' (unknown)

``I think I have,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, with an exertion of spirits, which increased with her (Elinor) increase of emotion.

``He (Pratt) was four years with my uncle, who lives at Longstaple, near Plymouth. It was there our acquaintance begun, for my sister and me was often staying with my uncle, and it was there our engagement was formed, though not till a year after he (uncle) had quitted as a pupil; but he (uncle) was almost always with us afterwards. I was very unwilling to enter into it, as you may imagine, without the knowledge and approbation of his (uncle) mother; but I was too young, and loved him (uncle) too well, to be so prudent as I ought to have been.-- Though you do not know him (uncle) so well as me, Miss Dashwood, you must have seen enough of him (uncle) to be sensible he (uncle) is very capable of making a woman sincerely attached to him (uncle).'' (unknown)

``Certainly,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
answered Elinor, without knowing what she (Elinor) said; but after a moment's reflection, she (Elinor) added, with revived security of Edward's honour and love, and her (Elinor) companion's falsehood--
``Engaged to Mr. Edward Ferrars!--I confess myself so totally surprised at what you tell me, that really--I beg your pardon; but surely there must be some mistake of person or name. We cannot mean the same Mr. Ferrars.'' (companion)

``We can mean no other,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Lucy, smiling.
``Mr. Edward Ferrars, the eldest son of Mrs. Ferrars, of Park Street, and brother of your sister-in-law, Mrs. John Dashwood, is the person I mean; you must allow that I am not likely to be deceived as to the name of the man on who all my happiness depends.'' (unknown)

``It is strange,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, in a most painful perplexity,
``that I should never have heard him (man) even mention your name.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``No; considering our situation, it was not strange. Our first care has been to keep the matter secret.-- You knew nothing of me, or my family, and, therefore, there could be no OCCASION for ever mentioning my name to you; and, as he (man) was always particularly afraid of his (man) sister's suspecting any thing, THAT was reason enough for his (man) not mentioning it.'' (She)

She (sister) was silent.--Elinor's security sunk; but her (Elinor) self-command did not sink with it.

``Four years you have been engaged,'' (she)
said she (Elinor) with a firm voice.

``Yes; and heaven knows how much longer we may have to wait. Poor Edward! It puts him (Edward) quite out of heart.'' (she)
Then taking a small miniature from her (Elinor) pocket, she (Elinor) added,
``To prevent the possibility of mistake, be so good as to look at this face. It does not do him (Edward) justice, to be sure, but yet I think you cannot be deceived as to the person it was drew for.--I have had it above these three years.'' (she)

She (Elinor) put it into her (Elinor) hands as she (Elinor) spoke; and when Elinor saw the painting, whatever other doubts her (Elinor) fear of a too hasty decision, or her (Elinor) wish of detecting falsehood might suffer to linger in her (Elinor) mind, she (Elinor) could have none of its being Edward's face. She (Elinor) returned it almost instantly, acknowledging the likeness.

``I have never been able,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
continued Lucy,
``to give him (Edward) my picture in return, which I am very much vexed at, for he (Edward) has been always so anxious to get it! But I am determined to set for it the very first opportunity.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``You are quite in the right,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor calmly. They then proceeded a few paces in silence. Lucy spoke first.

``I am sure,'' (she)
said she (Lucy),
``I have no doubt in the world of your faithfully keeping this secret, because you must know of what importance it is to us, not to have it reach his (Edward) mother; for she (mother) would never approve of it, I dare say. I shall have no fortune, and I fancy she (mother) is an exceeding proud woman.'' (she)

``I certainly did not seek your confidence,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``but you do me no more than justice in imagining that I may be depended on. Your secret is safe with me; but pardon me if I express some surprise at so unnecessary a communication. You must at least have felt that my being acquainted with it could not add to its safety.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

As she (Elinor) said this, she (Elinor) looked earnestly at Lucy, hoping to discover something in her (Lucy) countenance; perhaps the falsehood of the greatest part of what she (Lucy) had been saying; but Lucy's countenance suffered no change.

``I was afraid you would think I was taking a great liberty with you,'' (she)
said she (Lucy),
``in telling you all this. I have not known you long to be sure, personally at least, but I have known you and all your family by description a great while; and as soon as I saw you, I felt almost as if you was an old acquaintance. Besides in the present case, I really thought some explanation was due to you after my making such particular inquiries about Edward's mother; and I am so unfortunate, that I have not a creature whose advice I can ask. Anne is the only person that knows of it, and she (Anne) has no judgment at all; indeed, she (Anne) does me a great deal more harm than good, for I am in constant fear of her (Anne) betraying me. She (Anne) does not know how to hold her (Anne) tongue, as you must perceive, and I am sure I was in the greatest fright in the world t`other day, when Edward's name was mentioned by Sir John, lest she (John) should out with it all. You can't think how much I go through in my mind from it altogether. I only wonder that I am alive after what I have suffered for Edward's sake these last four years. Every thing in such suspense and uncertainty; and seeing him (Edward) so seldom--we can hardly meet above twice a-year. I am sure I wonder my heart is not quite broke.'' (she)

Here she (John) took out her (John) handkerchief; but Elinor did not feel very compassionate.

``Sometimes.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
continued Lucy, after wiping her (Lucy) eyes,
``I think whether it would not be better for us both to break off the matter entirely.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
As she (Lucy) said this, she (Lucy) looked directly at her (Lucy) companion.
``But then at other times I have not resolution enough for it.-- I cannot bear the thoughts of making him (companion) so miserable, as I know the very mention of such a thing would do. And on my own account too--so dear as he (companion) is to me--I don't think I could be equal to it. What would you advise me to do in such a case, Miss Dashwood? What would you do yourself?'' (unknown)

``Pardon me,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, startled by the question;
``but I can give you no advice under such circumstances. Your own judgment must direct you.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``To be sure,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
continued Lucy, after a few minutes silence on both sides,
``his (companion) mother must provide for him (companion) sometime or other; but poor Edward is so cast down by it! Did you not think him (Edward) dreadful low-spirited when he (Edward) was at Barton? He (Edward) was so miserable when he (Edward) left us at Longstaple, to go to you, that I was afraid you would think him (Edward) quite ill.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``Did he (Edward) come from your uncle's, then, when he (Edward) visited us?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes; he (Edward) had been staying a fortnight with us. Did you think he (Edward) came directly from town?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, most feelingly sensible of every fresh circumstance in favour of Lucy's veracity;
``I remember he (Edward) told us, that he (Edward) had been staying a fortnight with some friends near Plymouth.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
She (Lucy) remembered too, her (Lucy) own surprise at the time, at his (Edward) mentioning nothing farther of those friends, at his (Edward) total silence with respect even to their names.

``Did not you think him (Edward) sadly out of spirits?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
repeated Lucy.

``We did, indeed, particularly so when he (Edward) first arrived.'' (unknown)

``I begged him (Edward) to exert himself for fear you should suspect what was the matter; but it made him (Edward) so melancholy, not being able to stay more than a fortnight with us, and seeing me so much affected.-- Poor fellow!--I am afraid it is just the same with him (fellow) now; for he (fellow) writes in wretched spirits. I heard from him (fellow) just before I left Exeter;'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
taking a letter from her (Lucy) pocket and carelessly showing the direction to Elinor.
``You know his (fellow) hand, I dare say, a charming one it is; but that is not written so well as usual.--He (fellow) was tired, I dare say, for he (fellow) had just filled the sheet to me as full as possible.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor saw that it WAS his (fellow) hand, and she (Elinor) could doubt no longer. This picture, she (Elinor) had allowed herself to believe, might have been accidentally obtained; it might not have been Edward's gift; but a correspondence between them by letter, could subsist only under a positive engagement, could be authorised by nothing else; for a few moments, she (Elinor) was almost overcome--her (Elinor) heart sunk within her (Elinor), and she (Elinor) could hardly stand; but exertion was indispensably necessary; and she (Elinor) struggled so resolutely against the oppression of her (Elinor) feelings, that her (Elinor) success was speedy, and for the time complete.

``Writing to each other,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy, returning the letter into her (Lucy) pocket,
``is the only comfort we have in such long separations. Yes, I have one other comfort in his (Elinor) picture, but poor Edward has not even THAT. If he (Edward) had but my picture, he (Edward) says he (Edward) should be easy. I gave him (Edward) a lock of my hair set in a ring when he (Edward) was at Longstaple last, and that was some comfort to him (Edward), he (Edward) said, but not equal to a picture. Perhaps you might notice the ring when you saw him (Edward)?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``I did,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, with a composure of voice, under which was concealed an emotion and distress beyond any thing she (Elinor) had ever felt before. She (Elinor) was mortified, shocked, confounded.

Fortunately for her (Elinor), they had now reached the cottage, and the conversation could be continued no farther. After sitting with them a few minutes, the Miss Steeles returned to the Park, and Elinor was then at liberty to think and be wretched.

-LSB-At this point in the first and second editions, Volume 1 ends.-RSB-

CHAPTER 23

However small Elinor's general dependence on Lucy's veracity might be, it was impossible for her (Lucy) on serious reflection to suspect it in the present case, where no temptation could be answerable to the folly of inventing a falsehood of such a description. What Lucy had asserted to be true, therefore, Elinor could not, dared not longer doubt; supported as it was too on every side by such probabilities and proofs, and contradicted by nothing but her (Elinor) own wishes. Their opportunity of acquaintance in the house of Mr. Pratt was a foundation for the rest, at once indisputable and alarming; and Edward's visit near Plymouth, his (Edward) melancholy state of mind, his (Edward) dissatisfaction at his (Edward) own prospects, his (Edward) uncertain behaviour towards herself, the intimate knowledge of the Miss Steeles as to Norland and their family connections, which had often surprised her (Steeles), the picture, the letter, the ring, formed altogether such a body of evidence, as overcame every fear of condemning him (Edward) unfairly, and established as a fact, which no partiality could set aside, his (Edward) ill-treatment of herself.--Her (Steeles) resentment of such behaviour, her (Steeles) indignation at having been its dupe, for a short time made her (Steeles) feel only for herself; but other ideas, other considerations, soon arose. Had Edward been intentionally deceiving her (Steeles)? Had he (Edward) feigned a regard for her (Steeles) which he (Edward) did not feel? Was his (Edward) engagement to Lucy an engagement of the heart? No; whatever it might once have been, she (Lucy) could not believe it such at present. His (Edward) affection was all her (Lucy) own. She (Lucy) could not be deceived in that. Her (Lucy) mother, sisters, Fanny, all had been conscious of his (Edward) regard for her (Lucy) at Norland; it was not an illusion of her (Lucy) own vanity. He (Edward) certainly loved her (Lucy). What a softener of the heart was this persuasion! How much could it not tempt her (Lucy) to forgive! He (Edward) had been blamable, highly blamable, in remaining at Norland after he (Edward) first felt her (Lucy) influence over him (Edward) to be more than it ought to be. In that, he (Edward) could not be defended; but if he (Edward) had injured her (Lucy), how much more had he (Edward) injured himself; if her (Lucy) case were pitiable, his (Edward) was hopeless. His (Edward) imprudence had made her (Lucy) miserable for a while; but it seemed to have deprived himself of all chance of ever being otherwise. She (Lucy) might in time regain tranquillity; but HE (Edward), what had he (Edward) to look forward to? Could he (Edward) ever be tolerably happy with Lucy Steele; could he (Edward), were his (Edward) affection for herself out of the question, with his (Edward) integrity, his (Edward) delicacy, and well-informed mind, be satisfied with a wife like her (wife)--illiterate, artful, and selfish?

The youthful infatuation of nineteen would naturally blind him (Edward) to every thing but her (wife) beauty and good nature; but the four succeeding years--years, which if rationally spent, give such improvement to the understanding, must have opened his (Edward) eyes to her (wife) defects of education, while the same period of time, spent on her (wife) side in inferior society and more frivolous pursuits, had perhaps robbed her (wife) of that simplicity which might once have given an interesting character to her (wife) beauty.

If in the supposition of his (character) seeking to marry herself, his (character) difficulties from his (character) mother had seemed great, how much greater were they now likely to be, when the object of his (character) engagement was undoubtedly inferior in connections, and probably inferior in fortune to herself. These difficulties, indeed, with a heart so alienated from Lucy, might not press very hard upon his (character) patience; but melancholy was the state of the person by whom the expectation of family opposition and unkindness, could be felt as a relief!

As these considerations occurred to her (Lucy) in painful succession, she (Lucy) wept for him (character), more than for herself. Supported by the conviction of having done nothing to merit her (Lucy) present unhappiness, and consoled by the belief that Edward had done nothing to forfeit her (Lucy) esteem, she (Lucy) thought she (Lucy) could even now, under the first smart of the heavy blow, command herself enough to guard every suspicion of the truth from her (Lucy) mother and sisters. And so well was she (Lucy) able to answer her (Lucy) own expectations, that when she (Lucy) joined them at dinner only two hours after she (Lucy) had first suffered the extinction of all her (Lucy) dearest hopes, no one would have supposed from the appearance of the sisters, that Elinor was mourning in secret over obstacles which must divide her (Elinor) for ever from the object of her (Elinor) love, and that Marianne was internally dwelling on the perfections of a man, of whose whole heart she (Marianne) felt thoroughly possessed, and whom she (Marianne) expected to see in every carriage which drove near their house.

The necessity of concealing from her (Marianne) mother and Marianne, what had been entrusted in confidence to herself, though it obliged her (Marianne) to unceasing exertion, was no aggravation of Elinor's distress. On the contrary it was a relief to her (Elinor), to be spared the communication of what would give such affliction to them, and to be saved likewise from hearing that condemnation of Edward, which would probably flow from the excess of their partial affection for herself, and which was more than she (Elinor) felt equal to support.

From their counsel, or their conversation, she (Elinor) knew she (Elinor) could receive no assistance, their tenderness and sorrow must add to her (Elinor) distress, while her (Elinor) self-command would neither receive encouragement from their example nor from their praise. She (Elinor) was stronger alone, and her (Elinor) own good sense so well supported her (Elinor), that her (Elinor) firmness was as unshaken, her (Elinor) appearance of cheerfulness as invariable, as with regrets so poignant and so fresh, it was possible for them to be.

Much as she (Elinor) had suffered from her (Elinor) first conversation with Lucy on the subject, she (Elinor) soon felt an earnest wish of renewing it; and this for more reasons than one. She (Elinor) wanted to hear many particulars of their engagement repeated again, she (Elinor) wanted more clearly to understand what Lucy really felt for Edward, whether there were any sincerity in her (Lucy) declaration of tender regard for him (Edward), and she (Lucy) particularly wanted to convince Lucy, by her (Lucy) readiness to enter on the matter again, and her (Lucy) calmness in conversing on it, that she (Lucy) was no otherwise interested in it than as a friend, which she (Lucy) very much feared her (Lucy) involuntary agitation, in their morning discourse, must have left at least doubtful. That Lucy was disposed to be jealous of her (Lucy) appeared very probable: it was plain that Edward had always spoken highly in her (Lucy) praise, not merely from Lucy's assertion, but from her (Lucy) venturing to trust her (Lucy) on so short a personal acquaintance, with a secret so confessedly and evidently important. And even Sir John's joking intelligence must have had some weight. But indeed, while Elinor remained so well assured within herself of being really beloved by Edward, it required no other consideration of probabilities to make it natural that Lucy should be jealous; and that she (Lucy) was so, her (Lucy) very confidence was a proof. What other reason for the disclosure of the affair could there be, but that Elinor might be informed by it of Lucy's superior claims on Edward, and be taught to avoid him (Edward) in future? She (Lucy) had little difficulty in understanding thus much of her (Lucy) rival's intentions, and while she (Lucy) was firmly resolved to act by her (Lucy) as every principle of honour and honesty directed, to combat her (Lucy) own affection for Edward and to see him (Edward) as little as possible; she (Lucy) could not deny herself the comfort of endeavouring to convince Lucy that her (Lucy) heart was unwounded. And as she (Lucy) could now have nothing more painful to hear on the subject than had already been told, she (Lucy) did not mistrust her (Lucy) own ability of going through a repetition of particulars with composure.

But it was not immediately that an opportunity of doing so could be commanded, though Lucy was as well disposed as herself to take advantage of any that occurred; for the weather was not often fine enough to allow of their joining in a walk, where they might most easily separate themselves from the others; and though they met at least every other evening either at the park or cottage, and chiefly at the former, they could not be supposed to meet for the sake of conversation. Such a thought would never enter either Sir John or Lady Middleton's head; and therefore very little leisure was ever given for a general chat, and none at all for particular discourse. They met for the sake of eating, drinking, and laughing together, playing at cards, or consequences, or any other game that was sufficiently noisy.

One or two meetings of this kind had taken place, without affording Elinor any chance of engaging Lucy in private, when Sir John called at the cottage one morning, to beg, in the name of charity, that they would all dine with Lady Middleton that day, as he (Lucy) was obliged to attend the club at Exeter, and she (Middleton) would otherwise be quite alone, except her (Middleton) mother and the two Miss Steeles. Elinor, who foresaw a fairer opening for the point she (Elinor) had in view, in such a party as this was likely to be, more at liberty among themselves under the tranquil and well-bred direction of Lady Middleton than when her (Middleton) husband united them together in one noisy purpose, immediately accepted the invitation; Margaret, with her (Margaret) mother's permission, was equally compliant, and Marianne, though always unwilling to join any of their parties, was persuaded by her (Marianne) mother, who could not bear to have her (Marianne) seclude herself from any chance of amusement, to go likewise.

The young ladies went, and Lady Middleton was happily preserved from the frightful solitude which had threatened her (Middleton). The insipidity of the meeting was exactly such as Elinor had expected; it produced not one novelty of thought or expression, and nothing could be less interesting than the whole of their discourse both in the dining parlour and drawing room: to the latter, the children accompanied them, and while they remained there, she (Elinor) was too well convinced of the impossibility of engaging Lucy's attention to attempt it. They quitted it only with the removal of the tea-things. The card-table was then placed, and Elinor began to wonder at herself for having ever entertained a hope of finding time for conversation at the park. They all rose up in preparation for a round game.

``I am glad,'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)
said Lady Middleton to Lucy,
``you are not going to finish poor little Annamaria's basket this evening; for I am sure it must hurt your eyes to work filigree by candlelight. And we will make the dear little love some amends for her (Middleton) disappointment to-morrow, and then I hope she (Middleton) will not much mind it.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

This hint was enough, Lucy recollected herself instantly and replied,

``Indeed you are very much mistaken, Lady Middleton; I am only waiting to know whether you can make your party without me, or I should have been at my filigree already. I would not disappoint the little angel for all the world: and if you want me at the card-table now, I am resolved to finish the basket after supper.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``You are very good, I hope it won't hurt your eyes--will you ring the bell for some working candles? My poor little girl would be sadly disappointed, I know, if the basket was not finished tomorrow, for though I told her (girl) it certainly would not, I am sure she (girl) depends upon having it done.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Lucy directly drew her (Lucy) work table near her (Lucy) and reseated herself with an alacrity and cheerfulness which seemed to infer that she (Lucy) could taste no greater delight than in making a filigree basket for a spoilt child.

Lady Middleton proposed a rubber of Casino to the others. No one made any objection but Marianne, who with her (Marianne) usual inattention to the forms of general civility, exclaimed,

``Your Ladyship will have the goodness to excuse ME--you know I detest cards. I shall go to the piano-forte; I have not touched it since it was tuned.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
And without farther ceremony, she (Marianne) turned away and walked to the instrument.

Lady Middleton looked as if she (Middleton) thanked heaven that SHE had never made so rude a speech.

``Marianne can never keep long from that instrument you know, ma'am,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, endeavouring to smooth away the offence;
``and I do not much wonder at it; for it is the very best toned piano-forte I ever heard.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

The remaining five were now to draw their cards.

``Perhaps,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
continued Elinor,
``if I should happen to cut out, I may be of some use to Miss Lucy Steele, in rolling her (Steele) papers for her (Steele); and there is so much still to be done to the basket, that it must be impossible I think for her (Steele) labour singly, to finish it this evening. I should like the work exceedingly, if she (Steele) would allow me a share in it.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Indeed I shall be very much obliged to you for your help,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Lucy,
``for I find there is more to be done to it than I thought there was; and it would be a shocking thing to disappoint dear Annamaria after all.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``Oh! that would be terrible, indeed,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Miss Steele--
``Dear little soul, how I do love her (Steele)!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``You are very kind,'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)
said Lady Middleton to Elinor;
``and as you really like the work, perhaps you will be as well pleased not to cut in till another rubber, or will you take your chance now?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor joyfully profited by the first of these proposals, and thus by a little of that address which Marianne could never condescend to practise, gained her (Marianne) own end, and pleased Lady Middleton at the same time. Lucy made room for her (Lucy) with ready attention, and the two fair rivals were thus seated side by side at the same table, and, with the utmost harmony, engaged in forwarding the same work. The pianoforte at which Marianne, wrapped up in her (Marianne) own music and her (Marianne) own thoughts, had by this time forgotten that any body was in the room besides herself, was luckily so near them that Miss Dashwood now judged she (Dashwood) might safely, under the shelter of its noise, introduce the interesting subject, without any risk of being heard at the card-table.

CHAPTER 24

In a firm, though cautious tone, Elinor thus began.

``I should be undeserving of the confidence you have honoured me with, if I felt no desire for its continuance, or no farther curiosity on its subject. I will not apologize therefore for bringing it forward again.'' (unknown)

``Thank you,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Lucy warmly,
``for breaking the ice; you have set my heart at ease by it; for I was somehow or other afraid I had offended you by what I told you that Monday.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``Offended me! How could you suppose so? Believe me,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
and Elinor spoke it with the truest sincerity,
``nothing could be farther from my intention than to give you such an idea. Could you have a motive for the trust, that was not honourable and flattering to me?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``And yet I do assure you,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
replied Lucy, her (Lucy) little sharp eyes full of meaning,
``there seemed to me to be a coldness and displeasure in your manner that made me quite uncomfortable. I felt sure that you was angry with me; and have been quarrelling with myself ever since, for having took such a liberty as to trouble you with my affairs. But I am very glad to find it was only my own fancy, and that you really do not blame me. If you knew what a consolation it was to me to relieve my heart speaking to you of what I am always thinking of every moment of my life, your compassion would make you overlook every thing else I am sure.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``Indeed, I can easily believe that it was a very great relief to you, to acknowledge your situation to me, and be assured that you shall never have reason to repent it. Your case is a very unfortunate one; you seem to me to be surrounded with difficulties, and you will have need of all your mutual affection to support you under them. Mr. Ferrars, I believe, is entirely dependent on his (Ferrars) mother.'' (unknown)

``He (Ferrars) has only two thousand pounds of his (Ferrars) own; it would be madness to marry upon that, though for my own part, I could give up every prospect of more without a sigh. I have been always used to a very small income, and could struggle with any poverty for him (Ferrars); but I love him (Ferrars) too well to be the selfish means of robbing him (Ferrars), perhaps, of all that his (Ferrars) mother might give him (Ferrars) if he (Ferrars) married to please her (mother). We must wait, it may be for many years. With almost every other man in the world, it would be an alarming prospect; but Edward's affection and constancy nothing can deprive me of I know.'' (unknown)

``That conviction must be every thing to you; and he (Edward) is undoubtedly supported by the same trust in your's. If the strength of your reciprocal attachment had failed, as between many people, and under many circumstances it naturally would during a four years' engagement, your situation would have been pitiable, indeed.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Lucy here looked up; but Elinor was careful in guarding her (Elinor) countenance from every expression that could give her (Elinor) words a suspicious tendency.

``Edward's love for me,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy,
``has been pretty well put to the test, by our long, very long absence since we were first engaged, and it has stood the trial so well, that I should be unpardonable to doubt it now. I can safely say that he (Edward) has never gave me one moment's alarm on that account from the first.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Elinor hardly knew whether to smile or sigh at this assertion.

Lucy went on.

``I am rather of a jealous temper too by nature, and from our different situations in life, from his (Edward) being so much more in the world than me, and our continual separation, I was enough inclined for suspicion, to have found out the truth in an instant, if there had been the slightest alteration in his (Edward) behaviour to me when we met, or any lowness of spirits that I could not account for, or if he (Edward) had talked more of one lady than another, or seemed in any respect less happy at Longstaple than he (Edward) used to be. I do not mean to say that I am particularly observant or quick-sighted in general, but in such a case I am sure I could not be deceived.'' (unknown)

``All this,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
thought Elinor,
``is very pretty; but it can impose upon neither of us.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``But what,'' (she)
said she (Elinor) after a short silence,
``are your views? or have you none but that of waiting for Mrs. Ferrars's death, which is a melancholy and shocking extremity?--Is her (Ferrars) son determined to submit to this, and to all the tediousness of the many years of suspense in which it may involve you, rather than run the risk of her (Ferrars) displeasure for a while by owning the truth?'' (she)

``If we could be certain that it would be only for a while! But Mrs. Ferrars is a very headstrong proud woman, and in her (Ferrars) first fit of anger upon hearing it, would very likely secure every thing to Robert, and the idea of that, for Edward's sake, frightens away all my inclination for hasty measures.'' (unknown)

``And for your own sake too, or you are carrying your disinterestedness beyond reason.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Lucy looked at Elinor again, and was silent.

``Do you know Mr. Robert Ferrars?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
asked Elinor.

``Not at all--I never saw him (Ferrars); but I fancy he (Ferrars) is very unlike his (Ferrars) brother--silly and a great coxcomb.'' (unknown)

``A great coxcomb!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
repeated Miss Steele, whose ear had caught those words by a sudden pause in Marianne's music.--
``Oh, they are talking of their favourite beaux, I dare say.'' (unknown)

``No sister,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Lucy,
``you are mistaken there, our favourite beaux are NOT great coxcombs.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``I can answer for it that Miss Dashwood's is not,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings, laughing heartily;
``for he (Ferrars) is one of the modestest, prettiest behaved young men I ever saw; but as for Lucy, she (Lucy) is such a sly little creature, there is no finding out who SHE likes.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``Oh,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Miss Steele, looking significantly round at them,
``I dare say Lucy's beau is quite as modest and pretty behaved as Miss Dashwood's.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Elinor blushed in spite of herself. Lucy bit her (Lucy) lip, and looked angrily at her (Lucy) sister. A mutual silence took place for some time. Lucy first put an end to it by saying in a lower tone, though Marianne was then giving them the powerful protection of a very magnificent concerto--

``I will honestly tell you of one scheme which has lately come into my head, for bringing matters to bear; indeed I am bound to let you into the secret, for you are a party concerned. I dare say you have seen enough of Edward to know that he (Edward) would prefer the church to every other profession; now my plan is that he (Edward) should take orders as soon as he (Edward) can, and then through your interest, which I am sure you would be kind enough to use out of friendship for him (Edward), and I hope out of some regard to me, your brother might be persuaded to give him (brother) Norland living; which I understand is a very good one, and the present incumbent not likely to live a great while. That would be enough for us to marry upon, and we might trust to time and chance for the rest.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``I should always be happy,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``to show any mark of my esteem and friendship for Mr. Ferrars; but do you not perceive that my interest on such an occasion would be perfectly unnecessary? He (Ferrars) is brother to Mrs. John Dashwood--THAT must be recommendation enough to her (Dashwood) husband.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``But Mrs. John Dashwood would not much approve of Edward's going into orders.'' (unknown)

``Then I rather suspect that my interest would do very little.'' (unknown)

They were again silent for many minutes. At length Lucy exclaimed with a deep sigh,

``I believe it would be the wisest way to put an end to the business at once by dissolving the engagement. We seem so beset with difficulties on every side, that though it would make us miserable for a time, we should be happier perhaps in the end. But you will not give me your advice, Miss Dashwood?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``No,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
answered Elinor, with a smile, which concealed very agitated feelings,
``on such a subject I certainly will not. You know very well that my opinion would have no weight with you, unless it were on the side of your wishes.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Indeed you wrong me,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
replied Lucy, with great solemnity;
``I know nobody of whose judgment I think so highly as I do of yours; and I do really believe, that if you was to say to me, 'I advise you by all means to put an end to your engagement with Edward Ferrars, it will be more for the happiness of both of you,' I should resolve upon doing it immediately.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Elinor blushed for the insincerity of Edward's future wife, and replied,

``This compliment would effectually frighten me from giving any opinion on the subject had I formed one. It raises my influence much too high; the power of dividing two people so tenderly attached is too much for an indifferent person.'' (Edward wife)

'''Tis because you are an indifferent person,'' said Lucy, with some pique, and laying a particular stress on those words,

``that your judgment might justly have such weight with me. If you could be supposed to be biased in any respect by your own feelings, your opinion would not be worth having.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Elinor thought it wisest to make no answer to this, lest they might provoke each other to an unsuitable increase of ease and unreserve; and was even partly determined never to mention the subject again. Another pause therefore of many minutes' duration, succeeded this speech, and Lucy was still the first to end it.

``Shall you be in town this winter, Miss Dashwood?'' (she)
said she (Dashwood) with all her (Dashwood) accustomary complacency.

``Certainly not.'' (unknown)

``I am sorry for that,'' (unknown)
returned the other, while her (Dashwood) eyes brightened at the information,
``it would have gave me such pleasure to meet you there! But I dare say you will go for all that. To be sure, your brother and sister will ask you to come to them.'' (unknown)

``It will not be in my power to accept their invitation if they do.'' (unknown)

``How unlucky that is! I had quite depended upon meeting you there. Anne and me are to go the latter end of January to some relations who have been wanting us to visit them these several years! But I only go for the sake of seeing Edward. He (Edward) will be there in February, otherwise London would have no charms for me; I have not spirits for it.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was soon called to the card-table by the conclusion of the first rubber, and the confidential discourse of the two ladies was therefore at an end, to which both of them submitted without any reluctance, for nothing had been said on either side to make them dislike each other less than they had done before; and Elinor sat down to the card table with the melancholy persuasion that Edward was not only without affection for the person who was to be his (Edward) wife; but that he (Edward) had not even the chance of being tolerably happy in marriage, which sincere affection on HER side would have given, for self-interest alone could induce a woman to keep a man to an engagement, of which she (woman) seemed so thoroughly aware that he (man) was weary.

From this time the subject was never revived by Elinor, and when entered on by Lucy, who seldom missed an opportunity of introducing it, and was particularly careful to inform her (Lucy) confidante, of her (Lucy) happiness whenever she (Lucy) received a letter from Edward, it was treated by the former with calmness and caution, and dismissed as soon as civility would allow; for she (Lucy) felt such conversations to be an indulgence which Lucy did not deserve, and which were dangerous to herself.

The visit of the Miss Steeles at Barton Park was lengthened far beyond what the first invitation implied. Their favour increased; they could not be spared; Sir John would not hear of their going; and in spite of their numerous and long arranged engagements in Exeter, in spite of the absolute necessity of returning to fulfill them immediately, which was in full force at the end of every week, they were prevailed on to stay nearly two months at the park, and to assist in the due celebration of that festival which requires a more than ordinary share of private balls and large dinners to proclaim its importance.

CHAPTER 25

Though Mrs. Jennings was in the habit of spending a large portion of the year at the houses of her (Jennings) children and friends, she (Jennings) was not without a settled habitation of her (Jennings) own. Since the death of her (Jennings) husband, who had traded with success in a less elegant part of the town, she (Jennings) had resided every winter in a house in one of the streets near Portman Square. Towards this home, she (Jennings) began on the approach of January to turn her (Jennings) thoughts, and thither she (Jennings) one day abruptly, and very unexpectedly by them, asked the elder Misses Dashwood to accompany her (Dashwood). Elinor, without observing the varying complexion of her (Elinor) sister, and the animated look which spoke no indifference to the plan, immediately gave a grateful but absolute denial for both, in which she (Elinor) believed herself to be speaking their united inclinations. The reason alleged was their determined resolution of not leaving their mother at that time of the year. Mrs. Jennings received the refusal with some surprise, and repeated her (Jennings) invitation immediately.

``Oh, Lord! I am sure your mother can spare you very well, and I DO beg you will favour me with your company, for I've quite set my heart upon it. Don't fancy that you will be any inconvenience to me, for I shan't put myself at all out of my way for you. It will only be sending Betty by the coach, and I hope I can afford THAT. We three shall be able to go very well in my chaise; and when we are in town, if you do not like to go wherever I do, well and good, you may always go with one of my daughters. I am sure your mother will not object to it; for I have had such good luck in getting my own children off my hands that she (mother) will think me a very fit person to have the charge of you; and if I don't get one of you at least well married before I have done with you, it shall not be my fault. I shall speak a good word for you to all the young men, you may depend upon it.'' (unknown)

``I have a notion,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Sir John,
``that Miss Marianne would not object to such a scheme, if her (Marianne) elder sister would come into it. It is very hard indeed that she (Marianne) should not have a little pleasure, because Miss Dashwood does not wish it. So I would advise you two, to set off for town, when you are tired of Barton, without saying a word to Miss Dashwood about it.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``Nay,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings,
``I am sure I shall be monstrous glad of Miss Marianne's company, whether Miss Dashwood will go or not, only the more the merrier say I, and I thought it would be more comfortable for them to be together; because, if they got tired of me, they might talk to one another, and laugh at my old ways behind my back. But one or the other, if not both of them, I must have. Lord bless me! how do you think I can live poking by myself, I who have been always used till this winter to have Charlotte with me. Come, Miss Marianne, let us strike hands upon the bargain, and if Miss Dashwood will change her (Dashwood) mind by and bye, why so much the better.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``I thank you, ma'am, sincerely thank you,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, with warmth:
``your invitation has insured my gratitude for ever, and it would give me such happiness, yes, almost the greatest happiness I am capable of, to be able to accept it. But my mother, my dearest, kindest mother,--I feel the justice of what Elinor has urged, and if she (Elinor) were to be made less happy, less comfortable by our absence--Oh! no, nothing should tempt me to leave her (Elinor). It should not, must not be a struggle.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Mrs. Jennings repeated her (Jennings) assurance that Mrs. Dashwood could spare them perfectly well; and Elinor, who now understood her (Elinor) sister, and saw to what indifference to almost every thing else she (Elinor) was carried by her (Elinor) eagerness to be with Willoughby again, made no farther direct opposition to the plan, and merely referred it to her (Elinor) mother's decision, from whom however she (Elinor) scarcely expected to receive any support in her (Elinor) endeavour to prevent a visit, which she (Elinor) could not approve of for Marianne, and which on her (Marianne) own account she (Marianne) had particular reasons to avoid. Whatever Marianne was desirous of, her (Marianne) mother would be eager to promote--she (Marianne) could not expect to influence the latter to cautiousness of conduct in an affair respecting which she (Marianne) had never been able to inspire her (Marianne) with distrust; and she (Marianne) dared not explain the motive of her (Marianne) own disinclination for going to London. That Marianne, fastidious as she (Marianne) was, thoroughly acquainted with Mrs. Jennings' manners, and invariably disgusted by them, should overlook every inconvenience of that kind, should disregard whatever must be most wounding to her (Marianne) irritable feelings, in her (Marianne) pursuit of one object, was such a proof, so strong, so full, of the importance of that object to her (Marianne), as Elinor, in spite of all that had passed, was not prepared to witness.

On being informed of the invitation, Mrs. Dashwood, persuaded that such an excursion would be productive of much amusement to both her (Dashwood) daughters, and perceiving through all her (Dashwood) affectionate attention to herself, how much the heart of Marianne was in it, would not hear of their declining the offer upon HER account; insisted on their both accepting it directly; and then began to foresee, with her (Marianne) usual cheerfulness, a variety of advantages that would accrue to them all, from this separation.

``I am delighted with the plan,'' (she)
she (Marianne) cried,
``it is exactly what I could wish. Margaret and I shall be as much benefited by it as yourselves. When you and the Middletons are gone, we shall go on so quietly and happily together with our books and our music! You will find Margaret so improved when you come back again! I have a little plan of alteration for your bedrooms too, which may now be performed without any inconvenience to any one. It is very right that you SHOULD go to town; I would have every young woman of your condition in life acquainted with the manners and amusements of London. You will be under the care of a motherly good sort of woman, of whose kindness to you I can have no doubt. And in all probability you will see your brother, and whatever may be his (brother) faults, or the faults of his (brother) wife, when I consider whose son he (brother) is, I cannot bear to have you so wholly estranged from each other.'' (she)

``Though with your usual anxiety for our happiness,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``you have been obviating every impediment to the present scheme which occurred to you, there is still one objection which, in my opinion, cannot be so easily removed.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Marianne's countenance sunk.

``And what,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood,
``is my dear prudent Elinor going to suggest? What formidable obstacle is she (Elinor) now to bring forward? Do let me hear a word about the expense of it.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``My objection is this; though I think very well of Mrs. Jennings's heart, she (Jennings) is not a woman whose society can afford us pleasure, or whose protection will give us consequence.'' (unknown)

``That is very true,'' (mother)
replied her (Jennings) mother,
``but of her (Jennings) society, separately from that of other people, you will scarcely have any thing at all, and you will almost always appear in public with Lady Middleton.'' (mother)

``If Elinor is frightened away by her (Elinor) dislike of Mrs. Jennings,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``at least it need not prevent MY accepting her (Marianne) invitation. I have no such scruples, and I am sure I could put up with every unpleasantness of that kind with very little effort.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Elinor could not help smiling at this display of indifference towards the manners of a person, to whom she (Elinor) had often had difficulty in persuading Marianne to behave with tolerable politeness; and resolved within herself, that if her (Marianne) sister persisted in going, she (Marianne) would go likewise, as she (Marianne) did not think it proper that Marianne should be left to the sole guidance of her (Marianne) own judgment, or that Mrs. Jennings should be abandoned to the mercy of Marianne for all the comfort of her (Marianne) domestic hours. To this determination she (Marianne) was the more easily reconciled, by recollecting that Edward Ferrars, by Lucy's account, was not to be in town before February; and that their visit, without any unreasonable abridgement, might be previously finished.

``I will have you BOTH go,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood;
``these objections are nonsensical. You will have much pleasure in being in London, and especially in being together; and if Elinor would ever condescend to anticipate enjoyment, she (Elinor) would foresee it there from a variety of sources; she (Elinor) would, perhaps, expect some from improving her (Elinor) acquaintance with her (Elinor) sister-in-law's family.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Elinor had often wished for an opportunity of attempting to weaken her (Elinor) mother's dependence on the attachment of Edward and herself, that the shock might be less when the whole truth were revealed, and now on this attack, though almost hopeless of success, she (Elinor) forced herself to begin her (Elinor) design by saying, as calmly as she (Elinor) could,

``I like Edward Ferrars very much, and shall always be glad to see him (Ferrars); but as to the rest of the family, it is a matter of perfect indifference to me, whether I am ever known to them or not.'' (she)

Mrs. Dashwood smiled, and said nothing. Marianne lifted up her (Marianne) eyes in astonishment, and Elinor conjectured that she (Elinor) might as well have held her (Elinor) tongue.

After very little farther discourse, it was finally settled that the invitation should be fully accepted. Mrs. Jennings received the information with a great deal of joy, and many assurances of kindness and care; nor was it a matter of pleasure merely to her (Jennings). Sir John was delighted; for to a man, whose prevailing anxiety was the dread of being alone, the acquisition of two, to the number of inhabitants in London, was something. Even Lady Middleton took the trouble of being delighted, which was putting herself rather out of her (Middleton) way; and as for the Miss Steeles, especially Lucy, they had never been so happy in their lives as this intelligence made them.

Elinor submitted to the arrangement which counteracted her (Elinor) wishes with less reluctance than she (Elinor) had expected to feel. With regard to herself, it was now a matter of unconcern whether she (Elinor) went to town or not, and when she (Elinor) saw her (Elinor) mother so thoroughly pleased with the plan, and her (Elinor) sister exhilarated by it in look, voice, and manner, restored to all her (Elinor) usual animation, and elevated to more than her (Elinor) usual gaiety, she (Elinor) could not be dissatisfied with the cause, and would hardly allow herself to distrust the consequence.

Marianne's joy was almost a degree beyond happiness, so great was the perturbation of her (Marianne) spirits and her (Marianne) impatience to be gone. Her (Marianne) unwillingness to quit her (Marianne) mother was her (Marianne) only restorative to calmness; and at the moment of parting her (Marianne) grief on that score was excessive. Her (Marianne) mother's affliction was hardly less, and Elinor was the only one of the three, who seemed to consider the separation as any thing short of eternal.

Their departure took place in the first week in January. The Middletons were to follow in about a week. The Miss Steeles kept their station at the park, and were to quit it only with the rest of the family.

CHAPTER 26

Elinor could not find herself in the carriage with Mrs. Jennings, and beginning a journey to London under her (Elinor) protection, and as her (Elinor) guest, without wondering at her (Elinor) own situation, so short had their acquaintance with that lady been, so wholly unsuited were they in age and disposition, and so many had been her (lady) objections against such a measure only a few days before! But these objections had all, with that happy ardour of youth which Marianne and her (Marianne) mother equally shared, been overcome or overlooked; and Elinor, in spite of every occasional doubt of Willoughby's constancy, could not witness the rapture of delightful expectation which filled the whole soul and beamed in the eyes of Marianne, without feeling how blank was her (Marianne) own prospect, how cheerless her (Marianne) own state of mind in the comparison, and how gladly she (Marianne) would engage in the solicitude of Marianne's situation to have the same animating object in view, the same possibility of hope. A short, a very short time however must now decide what Willoughby's intentions were; in all probability he (Willoughby) was already in town. Marianne's eagerness to be gone declared her (Marianne) dependence on finding him (Willoughby) there; and Elinor was resolved not only upon gaining every new light as to his (Willoughby) character which her (Elinor) own observation or the intelligence of others could give her (Elinor), but likewise upon watching his (Willoughby) behaviour to her (Elinor) sister with such zealous attention, as to ascertain what he (Willoughby) was and what he (Willoughby) meant, before many meetings had taken place. Should the result of her (Elinor) observations be unfavourable, she (Elinor) was determined at all events to open the eyes of her (Elinor) sister; should it be otherwise, her (Elinor) exertions would be of a different nature--she (Elinor) must then learn to avoid every selfish comparison, and banish every regret which might lessen her (Elinor) satisfaction in the happiness of Marianne.

They were three days on their journey, and Marianne's behaviour as they travelled was a happy specimen of what future complaisance and companionableness to Mrs. Jennings might be expected to be. She (Jennings) sat in silence almost all the way, wrapt in her (Jennings) own meditations, and scarcely ever voluntarily speaking, except when any object of picturesque beauty within their view drew from her (Jennings) an exclamation of delight exclusively addressed to her (Jennings) sister. To atone for this conduct therefore, Elinor took immediate possession of the post of civility which she (Elinor) had assigned herself, behaved with the greatest attention to Mrs. Jennings, talked with her (Jennings), laughed with her (Jennings), and listened to her (Jennings) whenever she (Jennings) could; and Mrs. Jennings on her (Jennings) side treated them both with all possible kindness, was solicitous on every occasion for their ease and enjoyment, and only disturbed that she (Jennings) could not make them choose their own dinners at the inn, nor extort a confession of their preferring salmon to cod, or boiled fowls to veal cutlets. They reached town by three o'clock the third day, glad to be released, after such a journey, from the confinement of a carriage, and ready to enjoy all the luxury of a good fire.

The house was handsome, and handsomely fitted up, and the young ladies were immediately put in possession of a very comfortable apartment. It had formerly been Charlotte's, and over the mantelpiece still hung a landscape in coloured silks of her (Charlotte) performance, in proof of her (Charlotte) having spent seven years at a great school in town to some effect.

As dinner was not to be ready in less than two hours from their arrival, Elinor determined to employ the interval in writing to her (Elinor) mother, and sat down for that purpose. In a few moments Marianne did the same.

``I am writing home, Marianne,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``had not you better defer your letter for a day or two?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I am NOT going to write to my mother,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
replied Marianne, hastily, and as if wishing to avoid any farther inquiry. Elinor said no more; it immediately struck her (Elinor) that she (Elinor) must then be writing to Willoughby; and the conclusion which as instantly followed was, that, however mysteriously they might wish to conduct the affair, they must be engaged. This conviction, though not entirely satisfactory, gave her (Elinor) pleasure, and she (Elinor) continued her (Elinor) letter with greater alacrity. Marianne's was finished in a very few minutes; in length it could be no more than a note; it was then folded up, sealed, and directed with eager rapidity. Elinor thought she (Elinor) could distinguish a large W in the direction; and no sooner was it complete than Marianne, ringing the bell, requested the footman who answered it to get that letter conveyed for her (Marianne) to the two-penny post. This decided the matter at once.

Her (Marianne) spirits still continued very high; but there was a flutter in them which prevented their giving much pleasure to her (Marianne) sister, and this agitation increased as the evening drew on. She (Marianne) could scarcely eat any dinner, and when they afterwards returned to the drawing room, seemed anxiously listening to the sound of every carriage.

It was a great satisfaction to Elinor that Mrs. Jennings, by being much engaged in her (Jennings) own room, could see little of what was passing. The tea things were brought in, and already had Marianne been disappointed more than once by a rap at a neighbouring door, when a loud one was suddenly heard which could not be mistaken for one at any other house, Elinor felt secure of its announcing Willoughby's approach, and Marianne, starting up, moved towards the door. Every thing was silent; this could not be borne many seconds; she (Marianne) opened the door, advanced a few steps towards the stairs, and after listening half a minute, returned into the room in all the agitation which a conviction of having heard him (Willoughby) would naturally produce; in the ecstasy of her (Marianne) feelings at that instant she (Marianne) could not help exclaiming,

``Oh, Elinor, it is Willoughby, indeed it is!'' (she)
and seemed almost ready to throw herself into his (Willoughby) arms, when Colonel Brandon appeared.

It was too great a shock to be borne with calmness, and she (Brandon) immediately left the room. Elinor was disappointed too; but at the same time her (Elinor) regard for Colonel Brandon ensured his (Colonel) welcome with her (Elinor); and she (Elinor) felt particularly hurt that a man so partial to her (Elinor) sister should perceive that she (Elinor) experienced nothing but grief and disappointment in seeing him (man). She (Elinor) instantly saw that it was not unnoticed by him (man), that he (man) even observed Marianne as she (Marianne) quitted the room, with such astonishment and concern, as hardly left him (man) the recollection of what civility demanded towards herself.

``Is your sister ill?'' (he)
said he (man).

Elinor answered in some distress that she (Elinor) was, and then talked of head-aches, low spirits, and over fatigues; and of every thing to which she (Elinor) could decently attribute her (Elinor) sister's behaviour.

He (man) heard her (Elinor) with the most earnest attention, but seeming to recollect himself, said no more on the subject, and began directly to speak of his (man) pleasure at seeing them in London, making the usual inquiries about their journey, and the friends they had left behind.

In this calm kind of way, with very little interest on either side, they continued to talk, both of them out of spirits, and the thoughts of both engaged elsewhere. Elinor wished very much to ask whether Willoughby were then in town, but she (Elinor) was afraid of giving him (Willoughby) pain by any enquiry after his (Willoughby) rival; and at length, by way of saying something, she (Elinor) asked if he (Willoughby) had been in London ever since she (Elinor) had seen him (Willoughby) last.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Willoughby) replied, with some embarrassment,
``almost ever since; I have been once or twice at Delaford for a few days, but it has never been in my power to return to Barton.'' (he)

This, and the manner in which it was said, immediately brought back to her (Elinor) remembrance all the circumstances of his (Barton) quitting that place, with the uneasiness and suspicions they had caused to Mrs. Jennings, and she (Jennings) was fearful that her (Jennings) question had implied much more curiosity on the subject than she (Jennings) had ever felt.
