Mrs. Jennings soon came in.

``Oh! Colonel,'' (she)
said she (Jennings), with her (Jennings) usual noisy cheerfulness,
``I am monstrous glad to see you--sorry I could not come before--beg your pardon, but I have been forced to look about me a little, and settle my matters; for it is a long while since I have been at home, and you know one has always a world of little odd things to do after one has been away for any time; and then I have had Cartwright to settle with-- Lord, I have been as busy as a bee ever since dinner! But pray, Colonel, how came you to conjure out that I should be in town today?'' (she)

``I had the pleasure of hearing it at Mr. Palmer's, where I have been dining.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you did; well, and how do they all do at their house? How does Charlotte do? I warrant you she (Charlotte) is a fine size by this time.'' (unknown)

``Mrs. Palmer appeared quite well, and I am commissioned to tell you, that you will certainly see her (Palmer) to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Ay, to be sure, I thought as much. Well, Colonel, I have brought two young ladies with me, you see--that is, you see but one of them now, but there is another somewhere. Your friend, Miss Marianne, too--which you will not be sorry to hear. I do not know what you and Mr. Willoughby will do between you about her (Marianne). Ay, it is a fine thing to be young and handsome. Well! I was young once, but I never was very handsome--worse luck for me. However, I got a very good husband, and I don't know what the greatest beauty can do more. Ah! poor man! he (man) has been dead these eight years and better. But Colonel, where have you been to since we parted? And how does your business go on? Come, come, let's have no secrets among friends.'' (He)

He (Colonel) replied with his (Colonel) accustomary mildness to all her (your) inquiries, but without satisfying her (your) in any. Elinor now began to make the tea, and Marianne was obliged to appear again.

After her (Marianne) entrance, Colonel Brandon became more thoughtful and silent than he (Colonel) had been before, and Mrs. Jennings could not prevail on him (Colonel) to stay long. No other visitor appeared that evening, and the ladies were unanimous in agreeing to go early to bed.

Marianne rose the next morning with recovered spirits and happy looks. The disappointment of the evening before seemed forgotten in the expectation of what was to happen that day. They had not long finished their breakfast before Mrs. Palmer's barouche stopped at the door, and in a few minutes she (Palmer) came laughing into the room: so delighted to see them all, that it was hard to say whether she (Palmer) received most pleasure from meeting her (Palmer) mother or the Miss Dashwoods again. So surprised at their coming to town, though it was what she (Palmer) had rather expected all along; so angry at their accepting her (Palmer) mother's invitation after having declined her (Palmer) own, though at the same time she (Palmer) would never have forgiven them if they had not come!

``Mr. Palmer will be so happy to see you,'' (she)
said she (Palmer);
``What do you think he (Palmer) said when he (Palmer) heard of your coming with Mama? I forget what it was now, but it was something so droll!'' (she)

After an hour or two spent in what her (Mama) mother called comfortable chat, or in other words, in every variety of inquiry concerning all their acquaintance on Mrs. Jennings's side, and in laughter without cause on Mrs. Palmer's, it was proposed by the latter that they should all accompany her (Palmer) to some shops where she (Palmer) had business that morning, to which Mrs. Jennings and Elinor readily consented, as having likewise some purchases to make themselves; and Marianne, though declining it at first was induced to go likewise.

Wherever they went, she (Marianne) was evidently always on the watch. In Bond Street especially, where much of their business lay, her (Marianne) eyes were in constant inquiry; and in whatever shop the party were engaged, her (Marianne) mind was equally abstracted from every thing actually before them, from all that interested and occupied the others. Restless and dissatisfied every where, her (Marianne) sister could never obtain her (Marianne) opinion of any article of purchase, however it might equally concern them both: she (Marianne) received no pleasure from anything; was only impatient to be at home again, and could with difficulty govern her (Marianne) vexation at the tediousness of Mrs. Palmer, whose eye was caught by every thing pretty, expensive, or new; who was wild to buy all, could determine on none, and dawdled away her (Palmer) time in rapture and indecision.

It was late in the morning before they returned home; and no sooner had they entered the house than Marianne flew eagerly up stairs, and when Elinor followed, she (Elinor) found her (Elinor) turning from the table with a sorrowful countenance, which declared that no Willoughby had been there.

``Has no letter been left here for me since we went out?'' (she)
said she (Elinor) to the footman who then entered with the parcels. She (Elinor) was answered in the negative.
``Are you quite sure of it?'' (she)
she (Elinor) replied.
``Are you certain that no servant, no porter has left any letter or note?'' (The man)

The man replied that none had.

``How very odd!'' (she)
said she (Elinor), in a low and disappointed voice, as she (Elinor) turned away to the window.

``How odd, indeed!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
repeated Elinor within herself, regarding her (Elinor) sister with uneasiness.
``If she (Elinor) had not known him (man) to be in town she (Elinor) would not have written to him (man), as she (Elinor) did; she (Elinor) would have written to Combe Magna; and if he (Magna) is in town, how odd that he (Magna) should neither come nor write! Oh! my dear mother, you must be wrong in permitting an engagement between a daughter so young, a man so little known, to be carried on in so doubtful, so mysterious a manner! I long to inquire; and how will MY interference be borne.'' (She)

She (daughter) determined, after some consideration, that if appearances continued many days longer as unpleasant as they now were, she (daughter) would represent in the strongest manner to her (daughter) mother the necessity of some serious enquiry into the affair.

Mrs. Palmer and two elderly ladies of Mrs. Jennings's intimate acquaintance, whom she (Jennings) had met and invited in the morning, dined with them. The former left them soon after tea to fulfill her (Jennings) evening engagements; and Elinor was obliged to assist in making a whist table for the others. Marianne was of no use on these occasions, as she (Marianne) would never learn the game; but though her (Marianne) time was therefore at her (Marianne) own disposal, the evening was by no means more productive of pleasure to her (Marianne) than to Elinor, for it was spent in all the anxiety of expectation and the pain of disappointment. She (Marianne) sometimes endeavoured for a few minutes to read; but the book was soon thrown aside, and she (Marianne) returned to the more interesting employment of walking backwards and forwards across the room, pausing for a moment whenever she (Marianne) came to the window, in hopes of distinguishing the long-expected rap.

CHAPTER 27

``If this open weather holds much longer,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings, when they met at breakfast the following morning,
``Sir John will not like leaving Barton next week; 'tis a sad thing for sportsmen to lose a day's pleasure. Poor souls! I always pity them when they do; they seem to take it so much to heart.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``That is true,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne, in a cheerful voice, and walking to the window as she (Marianne) spoke, to examine the day.
``I had not thought of that. This weather will keep many sportsmen in the country.'' (all spirits)

It was a lucky recollection, all her (Marianne) good spirits were restored by it.

``It is charming weather for THEM indeed,'' (she)
she (Marianne) continued, as she (Marianne) sat down to the breakfast table with a happy countenance.
``How much they must enjoy it! But'' (unknown)
-LRB-with a little return of anxiety-RRB-
``it cannot be expected to last long. At this time of the year, and after such a series of rain, we shall certainly have very little more of it. Frosts will soon set in, and in all probability with severity. In another day or two perhaps; this extreme mildness can hardly last longer--nay, perhaps it may freeze tonight!'' (unknown)

``At any rate,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, wishing to prevent Mrs. Jennings from seeing her (Elinor) sister's thoughts as clearly as she (Elinor) did,
``I dare say we shall have Sir John and Lady Middleton in town by the end of next week.'' (she)

``Ay, my dear, I'll warrant you we do. Mary always has her (Mary) own way.'' (unknown)

``And now,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
silently conjectured Elinor,
``she (Elinor) will write to Combe by this day's post.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

But if she (Elinor) DID, the letter was written and sent away with a privacy which eluded all her (Elinor) watchfulness to ascertain the fact. Whatever the truth of it might be, and far as Elinor was from feeling thorough contentment about it, yet while she (Elinor) saw Marianne in spirits, she (Elinor) could not be very uncomfortable herself. And Marianne was in spirits; happy in the mildness of the weather, and still happier in her (Marianne) expectation of a frost.

The morning was chiefly spent in leaving cards at the houses of Mrs. Jennings's acquaintance to inform them of her (Jennings) being in town; and Marianne was all the time busy in observing the direction of the wind, watching the variations of the sky and imagining an alteration in the air.

``Don't you find it colder than it was in the morning, Elinor? There seems to me a very decided difference. I can hardly keep my hands warm even in my muff. It was not so yesterday, I think. The clouds seem parting too, the sun will be out in a moment, and we shall have a clear afternoon.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was alternately diverted and pained; but Marianne persevered, and saw every night in the brightness of the fire, and every morning in the appearance of the atmosphere, the certain symptoms of approaching frost.

The Miss Dashwoods had no greater reason to be dissatisfied with Mrs. Jennings's style of living, and set of acquaintance, than with her (Jennings) behaviour to themselves, which was invariably kind. Every thing in her (Jennings) household arrangements was conducted on the most liberal plan, and excepting a few old city friends, whom, to Lady Middleton's regret, she (Middleton) had never dropped, she (Middleton) visited no one to whom an introduction could at all discompose the feelings of her (Middleton) young companions. Pleased to find herself more comfortably situated in that particular than she (Middleton) had expected, Elinor was very willing to compound for the want of much real enjoyment from any of their evening parties, which, whether at home or abroad, formed only for cards, could have little to amuse her (Elinor).

Colonel Brandon, who had a general invitation to the house, was with them almost every day; he (Colonel) came to look at Marianne and talk to Elinor, who often derived more satisfaction from conversing with him (Colonel) than from any other daily occurrence, but who saw at the same time with much concern his (Colonel) continued regard for her (Elinor) sister. She (Elinor) feared it was a strengthening regard. It grieved her (Elinor) to see the earnestness with which he (Colonel) often watched Marianne, and his (Colonel) spirits were certainly worse than when at Barton.

About a week after their arrival, it became certain that Willoughby was also arrived. His (Willoughby) card was on the table when they came in from the morning's drive.

``Good God!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``he (God) has been here while we were out.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
Elinor, rejoiced to be assured of his (God) being in London, now ventured to say,
``Depend upon it, he (God) will call again tomorrow.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
But Marianne seemed hardly to hear her (Marianne), and on Mrs. Jennings's entrance, escaped with the precious card.

This event, while it raised the spirits of Elinor, restored to those of her (Elinor) sister all, and more than all, their former agitation. From this moment her (Elinor) mind was never quiet; the expectation of seeing him (God) every hour of the day, made her (Elinor) unfit for any thing. She (Elinor) insisted on being left behind, the next morning, when the others went out.

Elinor's thoughts were full of what might be passing in Berkeley Street during their absence; but a moment's glance at her (Elinor) sister when they returned was enough to inform her (Elinor), that Willoughby had paid no second visit there. A note was just then brought in, and laid on the table.

``For me!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne, stepping hastily forward.

``No, ma'am, for my mistress.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

But Marianne, not convinced, took it instantly up.

``It is indeed for Mrs. Jennings; how provoking!'' (unknown)

``You are expecting a letter, then?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, unable to be longer silent.

``Yes, a little--not much.'' (unknown)

After a short pause.

``You have no confidence in me, Marianne.'' (unknown)

``Nay, Elinor, this reproach from YOU--you who have confidence in no one!'' (unknown)

``Me!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
returned Elinor in some confusion;
``indeed, Marianne, I have nothing to tell.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Nor I,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
answered Marianne with energy,
``our situations then are alike. We have neither of us any thing to tell; you, because you do not communicate, and I, because I conceal nothing.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Elinor, distressed by this charge of reserve in herself, which she (Elinor) was not at liberty to do away, knew not how, under such circumstances, to press for greater openness in Marianne.

Mrs. Jennings soon appeared, and the note being given her (Jennings), she (Jennings) read it aloud. It was from Lady Middleton, announcing their arrival in Conduit Street the night before, and requesting the company of her (Middleton) mother and cousins the following evening. Business on Sir John's part, and a violent cold on her (John) own, prevented their calling in Berkeley Street. The invitation was accepted; but when the hour of appointment drew near, necessary as it was in common civility to Mrs. Jennings, that they should both attend her (Jennings) on such a visit, Elinor had some difficulty in persuading her (Elinor) sister to go, for still she (Elinor) had seen nothing of Willoughby; and therefore was not more indisposed for amusement abroad, than unwilling to run the risk of his (Willoughby) calling again in her (Elinor) absence.

Elinor found, when the evening was over, that disposition is not materially altered by a change of abode, for although scarcely settled in town, Sir John had contrived to collect around him (Willoughby), nearly twenty young people, and to amuse them with a ball. This was an affair, however, of which Lady Middleton did not approve. In the country, an unpremeditated dance was very allowable; but in London, where the reputation of elegance was more important and less easily attained, it was risking too much for the gratification of a few girls, to have it known that Lady Middleton had given a small dance of eight or nine couple, with two violins, and a mere side-board collation.

Mr. and Mrs. Palmer were of the party; from the former, whom they had not seen before since their arrival in town, as he (Middleton) was careful to avoid the appearance of any attention to his (Middleton) mother-in-law, and therefore never came near her (mother-in-law), they received no mark of recognition on their entrance. He (Middleton) looked at them slightly, without seeming to know who they were, and merely nodded to Mrs. Jennings from the other side of the room. Marianne gave one glance round the apartment as she (Marianne) entered: it was enough--HE (Middleton) was not there--and she (Marianne) sat down, equally ill-disposed to receive or communicate pleasure. After they had been assembled about an hour, Mr. Palmer sauntered towards the Miss Dashwoods to express his (Palmer) surprise on seeing them in town, though Colonel Brandon had been first informed of their arrival at his (Colonel) house, and he (Colonel) had himself said something very droll on hearing that they were to come.

``I thought you were both in Devonshire,'' (he)
said he (Colonel).

``Did you?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor.

``When do you go back again?'' (unknown)

``I do not know.'' (unknown)
And thus ended their discourse.

Never had Marianne been so unwilling to dance in her (Marianne) life, as she (Marianne) was that evening, and never so much fatigued by the exercise. She (Marianne) complained of it as they returned to Berkeley Street.

``Aye, aye,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings,
``we know the reason of all that very well; if a certain person who shall be nameless, had been there, you would not have been a bit tired: and to say the truth it was not very pretty of him (Marianne) not to give you the meeting when he (Marianne) was invited.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``Invited!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne.

``So my daughter Middleton told me, for it seems Sir John met him (Marianne) somewhere in the street this morning.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
Marianne said no more, but looked exceedingly hurt. Impatient in this situation to be doing something that might lead to her (Marianne) sister's relief, Elinor resolved to write the next morning to her (Marianne) mother, and hoped by awakening her (Marianne) fears for the health of Marianne, to procure those inquiries which had been so long delayed; and she (Marianne) was still more eagerly bent on this measure by perceiving after breakfast on the morrow, that Marianne was again writing to Willoughby, for she (Marianne) could not suppose it to be to any other person.

About the middle of the day, Mrs. Jennings went out by herself on business, and Elinor began her (Elinor) letter directly, while Marianne, too restless for employment, too anxious for conversation, walked from one window to the other, or sat down by the fire in melancholy meditation. Elinor was very earnest in her (Elinor) application to her (Elinor) mother, relating all that had passed, her (Elinor) suspicions of Willoughby's inconstancy, urging her (Elinor) by every plea of duty and affection to demand from Marianne an account of her (Marianne) real situation with respect to him (Willoughby).

Her (Marianne) letter was scarcely finished, when a rap foretold a visitor, and Colonel Brandon was announced. Marianne, who had seen him (Colonel) from the window, and who hated company of any kind, left the room before he (Colonel) entered it. He (Colonel) looked more than usually grave, and though expressing satisfaction at finding Miss Dashwood alone, as if he (Colonel) had somewhat in particular to tell her (Dashwood), sat for some time without saying a word. Elinor, persuaded that he (Colonel) had some communication to make in which her (Elinor) sister was concerned, impatiently expected its opening. It was not the first time of her (Elinor) feeling the same kind of conviction; for, more than once before, beginning with the observation of

``your sister looks unwell to-day,'' (he)
or
``your sister seems out of spirits,'' (he)
he (Colonel) had appeared on the point, either of disclosing, or of inquiring, something particular about her (sister). After a pause of several minutes, their silence was broken, by his (Colonel) asking her (sister) in a voice of some agitation, when he (Colonel) was to congratulate her (sister) on the acquisition of a brother? Elinor was not prepared for such a question, and having no answer ready, was obliged to adopt the simple and common expedient, of asking what he (Colonel) meant? He (Colonel) tried to smile as he (Colonel) replied,
``your sister's engagement to Mr. Willoughby is very generally known.'' (he)

``It cannot be generally known,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
returned Elinor,
``for her (Elinor) own family do not know it.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

He (Willoughby) looked surprised and said,

``I beg your pardon, I am afraid my inquiry has been impertinent; but I had not supposed any secrecy intended, as they openly correspond, and their marriage is universally talked of.'' (He)

``How can that be? By whom can you have heard it mentioned?'' (unknown)

``By many--by some of whom you know nothing, by others with whom you are most intimate, Mrs. Jennings, Mrs. Palmer, and the Middletons. But still I might not have believed it, for where the mind is perhaps rather unwilling to be convinced, it will always find something to support its doubts, if I had not, when the servant let me in today, accidentally seen a letter in his (servant) hand, directed to Mr. Willoughby in your sister's writing. I came to inquire, but I was convinced before I could ask the question. Is every thing finally settled? Is it impossible to-? But I have no right, and I could have no chance of succeeding. Excuse me, Miss Dashwood. I believe I have been wrong in saying so much, but I hardly know what to do, and on your prudence I have the strongest dependence. Tell me that it is all absolutely resolved on, that any attempt, that in short concealment, if concealment be possible, is all that remains.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

These words, which conveyed to Elinor a direct avowal of his (I) love for her (Elinor) sister, affected her (Elinor) very much. She (Elinor) was not immediately able to say anything, and even when her (Elinor) spirits were recovered, she (Elinor) debated for a short time, on the answer it would be most proper to give. The real state of things between Willoughby and her (Elinor) sister was so little known to herself, that in endeavouring to explain it, she (Elinor) might be as liable to say too much as too little. Yet as she (Elinor) was convinced that Marianne's affection for Willoughby, could leave no hope of Colonel Brandon's success, whatever the event of that affection might be, and at the same time wished to shield her (Brandon) conduct from censure, she (Brandon) thought it most prudent and kind, after some consideration, to say more than she (Brandon) really knew or believed. She (Brandon) acknowledged, therefore, that though she (Brandon) had never been informed by themselves of the terms on which they stood with each other, of their mutual affection she (Brandon) had no doubt, and of their correspondence she (Brandon) was not astonished to hear.

He (Colonel) listened to her (Brandon) with silent attention, and on her (Brandon) ceasing to speak, rose directly from his (Colonel) seat, and after saying in a voice of emotion,

``to your sister I wish all imaginable happiness; to Willoughby that he (Willoughby) may endeavour to deserve her (sister),'' (He)
--took leave, and went away.

Elinor derived no comfortable feelings from this conversation, to lessen the uneasiness of her (Elinor) mind on other points; she (Elinor) was left, on the contrary, with a melancholy impression of Colonel Brandon's unhappiness, and was prevented even from wishing it removed, by her (Brandon) anxiety for the very event that must confirm it.

CHAPTER 28

Nothing occurred during the next three or four days, to make Elinor regret what she (Elinor) had done, in applying to her (Elinor) mother; for Willoughby neither came nor wrote. They were engaged about the end of that time to attend Lady Middleton to a party, from which Mrs. Jennings was kept away by the indisposition of her (Jennings) youngest daughter; and for this party, Marianne, wholly dispirited, careless of her (Marianne) appearance, and seeming equally indifferent whether she (Marianne) went or staid, prepared, without one look of hope or one expression of pleasure. She (Marianne) sat by the drawing-room fire after tea, till the moment of Lady Middleton's arrival, without once stirring from her (Middleton) seat, or altering her (Middleton) attitude, lost in her (Middleton) own thoughts, and insensible of her (Middleton) sister's presence; and when at last they were told that Lady Middleton waited for them at the door, she (Middleton) started as if she (Middleton) had forgotten that any one was expected.

They arrived in due time at the place of destination, and as soon as the string of carriages before them would allow, alighted, ascended the stairs, heard their names announced from one landing-place to another in an audible voice, and entered a room splendidly lit up, quite full of company, and insufferably hot. When they had paid their tribute of politeness by curtsying to the lady of the house, they were permitted to mingle in the crowd, and take their share of the heat and inconvenience, to which their arrival must necessarily add. After some time spent in saying little or doing less, Lady Middleton sat down to Cassino, and as Marianne was not in spirits for moving about, she (Marianne) and Elinor luckily succeeding to chairs, placed themselves at no great distance from the table.

They had not remained in this manner long, before Elinor perceived Willoughby, standing within a few yards of them, in earnest conversation with a very fashionable looking young woman. She (woman) soon caught his (Willoughby) eye, and he (Willoughby) immediately bowed, but without attempting to speak to her (woman), or to approach Marianne, though he (Willoughby) could not but see her (Marianne); and then continued his (Willoughby) discourse with the same lady. Elinor turned involuntarily to Marianne, to see whether it could be unobserved by her (Elinor). At that moment she (Elinor) first perceived him (Willoughby), and her (Elinor) whole countenance glowing with sudden delight, she (Elinor) would have moved towards him (Willoughby) instantly, had not her (Elinor) sister caught hold of her (Elinor).

``Good heavens!'' (she)
she (Elinor) exclaimed,
``he (Willoughby) is there--he (Willoughby) is there--Oh! why does he (Willoughby) not look at me? why cannot I speak to him (Willoughby)?'' (she)

``Pray, pray be composed,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
cried Elinor,
``and do not betray what you feel to every body present. Perhaps he (Willoughby) has not observed you yet.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

This however was more than she (Elinor) could believe herself; and to be composed at such a moment was not only beyond the reach of Marianne, it was beyond her (Marianne) wish. She (Marianne) sat in an agony of impatience which affected every feature.

At last he (Willoughby) turned round again, and regarded them both; she (Marianne) started up, and pronouncing his (Willoughby) name in a tone of affection, held out her (Marianne) hand to him (Willoughby). He (Willoughby) approached, and addressing himself rather to Elinor than Marianne, as if wishing to avoid her (Marianne) eye, and determined not to observe her (Marianne) attitude, inquired in a hurried manner after Mrs. Dashwood, and asked how long they had been in town. Elinor was robbed of all presence of mind by such an address, and was unable to say a word. But the feelings of her (Elinor) sister were instantly expressed. Her (Elinor) face was crimsoned over, and she (Elinor) exclaimed, in a voice of the greatest emotion,

``Good God! Willoughby, what is the meaning of this? Have you not received my letters? Will you not shake hands with me?'' (she)

He (Willoughby) could not then avoid it, but her (Elinor) touch seemed painful to him (Willoughby), and he (Willoughby) held her (Elinor) hand only for a moment. During all this time he (Willoughby) was evidently struggling for composure. Elinor watched his (Willoughby) countenance and saw its expression becoming more tranquil. After a moment's pause, he (Willoughby) spoke with calmness.

``I did myself the honour of calling in Berkeley Street last Tuesday, and very much regretted that I was not fortunate enough to find yourselves and Mrs. Jennings at home. My card was not lost, I hope.'' (unknown)

``But have you not received my notes?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne in the wildest anxiety.
``Here is some mistake I am sure--some dreadful mistake. What can be the meaning of it? Tell me, Willoughby; for heaven's sake tell me, what is the matter?'' (He)

He (Willoughby) made no reply; his (Willoughby) complexion changed and all his (Willoughby) embarrassment returned; but as if, on catching the eye of the young lady with whom he (Willoughby) had been previously talking, he (Willoughby) felt the necessity of instant exertion, he (Willoughby) recovered himself again, and after saying,

``Yes, I had the pleasure of receiving the information of your arrival in town, which you were so good as to send me,'' (he)
turned hastily away with a slight bow and joined his (Willoughby) friend.

Marianne, now looking dreadfully white, and unable to stand, sunk into her (Marianne) chair, and Elinor, expecting every moment to see her (Elinor) faint, tried to screen her (Elinor) from the observation of others, while reviving her (Elinor) with lavender water.

``Go to him (Willoughby), Elinor,'' (she)
she (Elinor) cried, as soon as she (Elinor) could speak,
``and force him (Willoughby) to come to me. Tell him (Willoughby) I must see him (Willoughby) again--must speak to him (Willoughby) instantly.-- I cannot rest--I shall not have a moment's peace till this is explained--some dreadful misapprehension or other.-- Oh go to him (Willoughby) this moment.'' (she)

``How can that be done? No, my dearest Marianne, you must wait. This is not the place for explanations. Wait only till tomorrow.'' (she)

With difficulty however could she (Marianne) prevent her (Marianne) from following him (Willoughby) herself; and to persuade her (Marianne) to check her (Marianne) agitation, to wait, at least, with the appearance of composure, till she (Marianne) might speak to him (Willoughby) with more privacy and more effect, was impossible; for Marianne continued incessantly to give way in a low voice to the misery of her (Marianne) feelings, by exclamations of wretchedness. In a short time Elinor saw Willoughby quit the room by the door towards the staircase, and telling Marianne that he (Willoughby) was gone, urged the impossibility of speaking to him (Willoughby) again that evening, as a fresh argument for her (Marianne) to be calm. She (Marianne) instantly begged her (Marianne) sister would entreat Lady Middleton to take them home, as she (Marianne) was too miserable to stay a minute longer.

Lady Middleton, though in the middle of a rubber, on being informed that Marianne was unwell, was too polite to object for a moment to her (Marianne) wish of going away, and making over her (Marianne) cards to a friend, they departed as soon the carriage could be found. Scarcely a word was spoken during their return to Berkeley Street. Marianne was in a silent agony, too much oppressed even for tears; but as Mrs. Jennings was luckily not come home, they could go directly to their own room, where hartshorn restored her (Jennings) a little to herself. She (Jennings) was soon undressed and in bed, and as she (Jennings) seemed desirous of being alone, her (Jennings) sister then left her (Jennings), and while she (Jennings) waited the return of Mrs. Jennings, had leisure enough for thinking over the past.

That some kind of engagement had subsisted between Willoughby and Marianne she (Marianne) could not doubt, and that Willoughby was weary of it, seemed equally clear; for however Marianne might still feed her (Marianne) own wishes, SHE could not attribute such behaviour to mistake or misapprehension of any kind. Nothing but a thorough change of sentiment could account for it. Her (Marianne) indignation would have been still stronger than it was, had she (Marianne) not witnessed that embarrassment which seemed to speak a consciousness of his (Willoughby) own misconduct, and prevented her (Marianne) from believing him (Willoughby) so unprincipled as to have been sporting with the affections of her (Marianne) sister from the first, without any design that would bear investigation. Absence might have weakened his (Willoughby) regard, and convenience might have determined him (Willoughby) to overcome it, but that such a regard had formerly existed she (Marianne) could not bring herself to doubt.

As for Marianne, on the pangs which so unhappy a meeting must already have given her (Marianne), and on those still more severe which might await her (Marianne) in its probable consequence, she (Marianne) could not reflect without the deepest concern. Her (Marianne) own situation gained in the comparison; for while she (Marianne) could ESTEEM Edward as much as ever, however they might be divided in future, her (Marianne) mind might be always supported. But every circumstance that could embitter such an evil seemed uniting to heighten the misery of Marianne in a final separation from Willoughby--in an immediate and irreconcilable rupture with him (Willoughby).

CHAPTER 29

Before the house-maid had lit their fire the next day, or the sun gained any power over a cold, gloomy morning in January, Marianne, only half dressed, was kneeling against one of the window-seats for the sake of all the little light she (Marianne) could command from it, and writing as fast as a continual flow of tears would permit her (Marianne). In this situation, Elinor, roused from sleep by her (Elinor) agitation and sobs, first perceived her (Elinor); and after observing her (Elinor) for a few moments with silent anxiety, said, in a tone of the most considerate gentleness,

``Marianne, may I ask-?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``No, Elinor,'' (she)
she (Elinor) replied,
``ask nothing; you will soon know all.'' (she)

The sort of desperate calmness with which this was said, lasted no longer than while she (Elinor) spoke, and was immediately followed by a return of the same excessive affliction. It was some minutes before she (Elinor) could go on with her (Elinor) letter, and the frequent bursts of grief which still obliged her (Elinor), at intervals, to withhold her (Elinor) pen, were proofs enough of her (Elinor) feeling how more than probable it was that she (Elinor) was writing for the last time to Willoughby.

Elinor paid her (Elinor) every quiet and unobtrusive attention in her (Elinor) power; and she (Elinor) would have tried to sooth and tranquilize her (Elinor) still more, had not Marianne entreated her (Marianne), with all the eagerness of the most nervous irritability, not to speak to her (Marianne) for the world. In such circumstances, it was better for both that they should not be long together; and the restless state of Marianne's mind not only prevented her (Marianne) from remaining in the room a moment after she (Marianne) was dressed, but requiring at once solitude and continual change of place, made her (Marianne) wander about the house till breakfast time, avoiding the sight of every body.

At breakfast she (Marianne) neither ate, nor attempted to eat any thing; and Elinor's attention was then all employed, not in urging her (Elinor), not in pitying her (Elinor), nor in appearing to regard her (Elinor), but in endeavouring to engage Mrs. Jennings's notice entirely to herself.

As this was a favourite meal with Mrs. Jennings, it lasted a considerable time, and they were just setting themselves, after it, round the common working table, when a letter was delivered to Marianne, which she (Marianne) eagerly caught from the servant, and, turning of a death-like paleness, instantly ran out of the room. Elinor, who saw as plainly by this, as if she (Elinor) had seen the direction, that it must come from Willoughby, felt immediately such a sickness at heart as made her (Elinor) hardly able to hold up her (Elinor) head, and sat in such a general tremour as made her (Elinor) fear it impossible to escape Mrs. Jennings's notice. That good lady, however, saw only that Marianne had received a letter from Willoughby, which appeared to her (Marianne) a very good joke, and which she (Marianne) treated accordingly, by hoping, with a laugh, that she (Marianne) would find it to her (Marianne) liking. Of Elinor's distress, she (Elinor) was too busily employed in measuring lengths of worsted for her (Elinor) rug, to see any thing at all; and calmly continuing her (Elinor) talk, as soon as Marianne disappeared, she (Marianne) said,

``Upon my word, I never saw a young woman so desperately in love in my life! MY girls were nothing to her (MY), and yet they used to be foolish enough; but as for Miss Marianne, she (Marianne) is quite an altered creature. I hope, from the bottom of my heart, he (Marianne) won't keep her (Marianne) waiting much longer, for it is quite grievous to see her (Marianne) look so ill and forlorn. Pray, when are they to be married?'' (she)

Elinor, though never less disposed to speak than at that moment, obliged herself to answer such an attack as this, and, therefore, trying to smile, replied,

``And have you really, Ma'am, talked yourself into a persuasion of my sister's being engaged to Mr. Willoughby? I thought it had been only a joke, but so serious a question seems to imply more; and I must beg, therefore, that you will not deceive yourself any longer. I do assure you that nothing would surprise me more than to hear of their being going to be married.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``For shame, for shame, Miss Dashwood! how can you talk so? Don't we all know that it must be a match, that they were over head and ears in love with each other from the first moment they met? Did not I see them together in Devonshire every day, and all day long; and did not I know that your sister came to town with me on purpose to buy wedding clothes? Come, come, this won't do. Because you are so sly about it yourself, you think nobody else has any senses; but it is no such thing, I can tell you, for it has been known all over town this ever so long. I tell every body of it and so does Charlotte.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, Ma'am,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, very seriously,
``you are mistaken. Indeed, you are doing a very unkind thing in spreading the report, and you will find that you have though you will not believe me now.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Mrs. Jennings laughed again, but Elinor had not spirits to say more, and eager at all events to know what Willoughby had written, hurried away to their room, where, on opening the door, she (Elinor) saw Marianne stretched on the bed, almost choked by grief, one letter in her (Marianne) hand, and two or three others laying by her (Marianne). Elinor drew near, but without saying a word; and seating herself on the bed, took her (Elinor) hand, kissed her (Elinor) affectionately several times, and then gave way to a burst of tears, which at first was scarcely less violent than Marianne's. The latter, though unable to speak, seemed to feel all the tenderness of this behaviour, and after some time thus spent in joint affliction, she (Marianne) put all the letters into Elinor's hands; and then covering her (Elinor) face with her (Elinor) handkerchief, almost screamed with agony. Elinor, who knew that such grief, shocking as it was to witness it, must have its course, watched by her (Elinor) till this excess of suffering had somewhat spent itself, and then turning eagerly to Willoughby's letter, read as follows:

``Bond Street, January. ``MY DEAR MADAM,

``I have just had the honour of receiving your letter, for which I beg to return my sincere acknowledgments. I am much concerned to find there was anything in my behaviour last night that did not meet your approbation; and though I am quite at a loss to discover in what point I could be so unfortunate as to offend you, I entreat your forgiveness of what I can assure you to have been perfectly unintentional. I shall never reflect on my former acquaintance with your family in Devonshire without the most grateful pleasure, and flatter myself it will not be broken by any mistake or misapprehension of my actions. My esteem for your whole family is very sincere; but if I have been so unfortunate as to give rise to a belief of more than I felt, or meant to express, I shall reproach myself for not having been more guarded in my professions of that esteem. That I should ever have meant more you will allow to be impossible, when you understand that my affections have been long engaged elsewhere, and it will not be many weeks, I believe, before this engagement is fulfilled. It is with great regret that I obey your commands in returning the letters with which I have been honoured from you, and the lock of hair, which you so obligingly bestowed on me.

``I am, dear Madam, ``Your most obedient ``humble servant,

``JOHN WILLOUGHBY.'' (servant WILLOUGHBY)

With what indignation such a letter as this must be read by Miss Dashwood, may be imagined. Though aware, before she (Dashwood) began it, that it must bring a confession of his (servant) inconstancy, and confirm their separation for ever, she (Dashwood) was not aware that such language could be suffered to announce it; nor could she (Dashwood) have supposed Willoughby capable of departing so far from the appearance of every honourable and delicate feeling--so far from the common decorum of a gentleman, as to send a letter so impudently cruel: a letter which, instead of bringing with his (gentleman) desire of a release any professions of regret, acknowledged no breach of faith, denied all peculiar affection whatever--a letter of which every line was an insult, and which proclaimed its writer to be deep in hardened villainy.

She (Dashwood) paused over it for some time with indignant astonishment; then read it again and again; but every perusal only served to increase her (Dashwood) abhorrence of the man, and so bitter were her (Dashwood) feelings against him (man), that she (Dashwood) dared not trust herself to speak, lest she (Dashwood) might wound Marianne still deeper by treating their disengagement, not as a loss to her (Dashwood) of any possible good but as an escape from the worst and most irremediable of all evils, a connection, for life, with an unprincipled man, as a deliverance the most real, a blessing the most important.

In her (Dashwood) earnest meditations on the contents of the letter, on the depravity of that mind which could dictate it, and probably, on the very different mind of a very different person, who had no other connection whatever with the affair than what her (Dashwood) heart gave him (man) with every thing that passed, Elinor forgot the immediate distress of her (Elinor) sister, forgot that she (Elinor) had three letters on her (Elinor) lap yet unread, and so entirely forgot how long she (Elinor) had been in the room, that when on hearing a carriage drive up to the door, she (Elinor) went to the window to see who could be coming so unreasonably early, she (Elinor) was all astonishment to perceive Mrs. Jennings's chariot, which she (Jennings) knew had not been ordered till one. Determined not to quit Marianne, though hopeless of contributing, at present, to her (Marianne) ease, she (Marianne) hurried away to excuse herself from attending Mrs. Jennings, on account of her (Jennings) sister being indisposed. Mrs. Jennings, with a thoroughly good-humoured concern for its cause, admitted the excuse most readily, and Elinor, after seeing her (Elinor) safe off, returned to Marianne, whom she (Marianne) found attempting to rise from the bed, and whom she (Marianne) reached just in time to prevent her (Marianne) from falling on the floor, faint and giddy from a long want of proper rest and food; for it was many days since she (Marianne) had any appetite, and many nights since she (Marianne) had really slept; and now, when her (Marianne) mind was no longer supported by the fever of suspense, the consequence of all this was felt in an aching head, a weakened stomach, and a general nervous faintness. A glass of wine, which Elinor procured for her (Elinor) directly, made her (Elinor) more comfortable, and she (Elinor) was at last able to express some sense of her (Elinor) kindness, by saying,

``Poor Elinor! how unhappy I make you!'' (she)

``I only wish,'' (sister)
replied her (Elinor) sister,
``there were any thing I COULD do, which might be of comfort to you.'' (sister)

This, as every thing else would have been, was too much for Marianne, who could only exclaim, in the anguish of her (Marianne) heart,

``Oh! Elinor, I am miserable, indeed,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
before her (Elinor) voice was entirely lost in sobs.

Elinor could no longer witness this torrent of unresisted grief in silence.

``Exert yourself, dear Marianne,'' (she)
she (Marianne) cried,
``if you would not kill yourself and all who love you. Think of your mother; think of her (mother) misery while YOU suffer: for her (mother) sake you must exert yourself.'' (she)

``I cannot, I cannot,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne;
``leave me, leave me, if I distress you; leave me, hate me, forget me! but do not torture me so. Oh! how easy for those, who have no sorrow of their own to talk of exertion! Happy, happy Elinor, YOU cannot have an idea of what I suffer.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Do you call ME happy, Marianne? Ah! if you knew!--And can you believe me to be so, while I see you so wretched!'' (unknown)

``Forgive me, forgive me,'' (sister)
throwing her (Marianne) arms round her (Marianne) sister's neck;
``I know you feel for me; I know what a heart you have; but yet you are--you must be happy; Edward loves you--what, oh what, can do away such happiness as that?'' (sister)

``Many, many circumstances,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, solemnly.

``No, no, no,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne wildly,
``he (Edward) loves you, and only you. You CAN have no grief.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``I can have no pleasure while I see you in this state.'' (unknown)

``And you will never see me otherwise. Mine is a misery which nothing can do away.'' (unknown)

``You must not talk so, Marianne. Have you no comforts? no friends? Is your loss such as leaves no opening for consolation? Much as you suffer now, think of what you would have suffered if the discovery of his (Edward) character had been delayed to a later period--if your engagement had been carried on for months and months, as it might have been, before he (Edward) chose to put an end to it. Every additional day of unhappy confidence, on your side, would have made the blow more dreadful.'' (unknown)

``Engagement!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``there has been no engagement.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``No engagement!'' (unknown)

``No, he (Edward) is not so unworthy as you believe him (Edward). He (Edward) has broken no faith with me.'' (unknown)

``But he (Edward) told you that he (Edward) loved you.'' (unknown)

``Yes--no--never absolutely. It was every day implied, but never professedly declared. Sometimes I thought it had been--but it never was.'' (unknown)

``Yet you wrote to him (Edward)?'' (unknown)
--

``Yes--could that be wrong after all that had passed?-- But I cannot talk.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor said no more, and turning again to the three letters which now raised a much stronger curiosity than before, directly ran over the contents of all. The first, which was what her (Elinor) sister had sent him (Edward) on their arrival in town, was to this effect.

Berkeley Street, January.

``How surprised you will be, Willoughby, on receiving this; and I think you will feel something more than surprise, when you know that I am in town. An opportunity of coming hither, though with Mrs. Jennings, was a temptation we could not resist. I wish you may receive this in time to come here to-night, but I will not depend on it. At any rate I shall expect you to-morrow. For the present, adieu.

``M.D.'' (Middletons)

Her (Jennings) second note, which had been written on the morning after the dance at the Middletons', was in these words:--

``I cannot express my disappointment in having missed you the day before yesterday, nor my astonishment at not having received any answer to a note which I sent you above a week ago. I have been expecting to hear from you, and still more to see you, every hour of the day. Pray call again as soon as possible, and explain the reason of my having expected this in vain. You had better come earlier another time, because we are generally out by one. We were last night at Lady Middleton's, where there was a dance. I have been told that you were asked to be of the party. But could it be so? You must be very much altered indeed since we parted, if that could be the case, and you not there. But I will not suppose this possible, and I hope very soon to receive your personal assurance of its being otherwise.

``M.D.'' (him)

The contents of her (Middleton) last note to him (we) were these:--

``What am I to imagine, Willoughby, by your behaviour last night? Again I demand an explanation of it. I was prepared to meet you with the pleasure which our separation naturally produced, with the familiarity which our intimacy at Barton appeared to me to justify. I was repulsed indeed! I have passed a wretched night in endeavouring to excuse a conduct which can scarcely be called less than insulting; but though I have not yet been able to form any reasonable apology for your behaviour, I am perfectly ready to hear your justification of it. You have perhaps been misinformed, or purposely deceived, in something concerning me, which may have lowered me in your opinion. Tell me what it is, explain the grounds on which you acted, and I shall be satisfied, in being able to satisfy you. It would grieve me indeed to be obliged to think ill of you; but if I am to do it, if I am to learn that you are not what we have hitherto believed you, that your regard for us all was insincere, that your behaviour to me was intended only to deceive, let it be told as soon as possible. My feelings are at present in a state of dreadful indecision; I wish to acquit you, but certainty on either side will be ease to what I now suffer. If your sentiments are no longer what they were, you will return my notes, and the lock of my hair which is in your possession.

``M.D.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

That such letters, so full of affection and confidence, could have been so answered, Elinor, for Willoughby's sake, would have been unwilling to believe. But her (Elinor) condemnation of him (Willoughby) did not blind her (Elinor) to the impropriety of their having been written at all; and she (Elinor) was silently grieving over the imprudence which had hazarded such unsolicited proofs of tenderness, not warranted by anything preceding, and most severely condemned by the event, when Marianne, perceiving that she (Marianne) had finished the letters, observed to her (Marianne) that they contained nothing but what any one would have written in the same situation.

``I felt myself,'' (she)
she (Marianne) added,
``to be as solemnly engaged to him (Willoughby), as if the strictest legal covenant had bound us to each other.'' (she)

``I can believe it,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``but unfortunately he (Willoughby) did not feel the same.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``He (Willoughby) DID feel the same, Elinor--for weeks and weeks he (Willoughby) felt it. I know he (Willoughby) did. Whatever may have changed him (Willoughby) now, -LRB-and nothing but the blackest art employed against me can have done it-RRB-, I was once as dear to him (Willoughby) as my own soul could wish. This lock of hair, which now he (Willoughby) can so readily give up, was begged of me with the most earnest supplication. Had you seen his (Willoughby) look, his (Willoughby) manner, had you heard his (Willoughby) voice at that moment! Have you forgot the last evening of our being together at Barton? The morning that we parted too! When he (Barton) told me that it might be many weeks before we met again--his (Barton) distress--can I ever forget his (Barton) distress?'' (she)

For a moment or two she (Willoughby) could say no more; but when this emotion had passed away, she (Willoughby) added, in a firmer tone,

``Elinor, I have been cruelly used; but not by Willoughby.'' (she)

``Dearest Marianne, who but himself? By whom can he (Willoughby) have been instigated?'' (unknown)

``By all the world, rather than by his (Willoughby) own heart. I could rather believe every creature of my acquaintance leagued together to ruin me in his (Willoughby) opinion, than believe his (Willoughby) nature capable of such cruelty. This woman of whom he (Willoughby) writes--whoever she (woman) be--or any one, in short, but your own dear self, mama, and Edward, may have been so barbarous to bely me. Beyond you three, is there a creature in the world whom I would not rather suspect of evil than Willoughby, whose heart I know so well?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor would not contend, and only replied,

``Whoever may have been so detestably your enemy, let them be cheated of their malignant triumph, my dear sister, by seeing how nobly the consciousness of your own innocence and good intentions supports your spirits. It is a reasonable and laudable pride which resists such malevolence.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``No, no,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne,
``misery such as mine has no pride. I care not who knows that I am wretched. The triumph of seeing me so may be open to all the world. Elinor, Elinor, they who suffer little may be proud and independent as they like--may resist insult, or return mortification--but I cannot. I must feel--I must be wretched--and they are welcome to enjoy the consciousness of it that can.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``But for my mother's sake and mine--'' (unknown)

``I would do more than for my own. But to appear happy when I am so miserable--Oh! who can require it?'' (unknown)

Again they were both silent. Elinor was employed in walking thoughtfully from the fire to the window, from the window to the fire, without knowing that she (Elinor) received warmth from one, or discerning objects through the other; and Marianne, seated at the foot of the bed, with her (Marianne) head leaning against one of its posts, again took up Willoughby's letter, and, after shuddering over every sentence, exclaimed--

``It is too much! Oh, Willoughby, Willoughby, could this be yours! Cruel, cruel--nothing can acquit you. Elinor, nothing can. Whatever he (Willoughby) might have heard against me--ought he (Willoughby) not to have suspended his (Willoughby) belief? ought he (Willoughby) not to have told me of it, to have given me the power of clearing myself? `The lock of hair, -LRB-repeating it from the letter,-RRB- which you so obligingly bestowed on me'--That is unpardonable. Willoughby, where was your heart when you wrote those words? Oh, barbarously insolent!--Elinor, can he (Willoughby) be justified?'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

``No, Marianne, in no possible way.'' (unknown)

``And yet this woman--who knows what her (woman) art may have been?--how long it may have been premeditated, and how deeply contrived by her (woman)!--Who is she (woman)?--Who can she (woman) be?--Whom did I ever hear him (Willoughby) talk of as young and attractive among his (Willoughby) female acquaintance?--Oh! no one, no one--he (Willoughby) talked to me only of myself.'' (unknown)

Another pause ensued; Marianne was greatly agitated, and it ended thus.

``Elinor, I must go home. I must go and comfort mama. Can not we be gone to-morrow?'' (unknown)

``To-morrow, Marianne!'' (unknown)

``Yes, why should I stay here? I came only for Willoughby's sake--and now who cares for me? Who regards me?'' (unknown)

``It would be impossible to go to-morrow. We owe Mrs. Jennings much more than civility; and civility of the commonest kind must prevent such a hasty removal as that.'' (unknown)

``Well then, another day or two, perhaps; but I cannot stay here long, I cannot stay to endure the questions and remarks of all these people. The Middletons and Palmers--how am I to bear their pity? The pity of such a woman as Lady Middleton! Oh, what would HE (Palmers) say to that!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor advised her (Elinor) to lie down again, and for a moment she (Elinor) did so; but no attitude could give her (Elinor) ease; and in restless pain of mind and body she (Elinor) moved from one posture to another, till growing more and more hysterical, her (Elinor) sister could with difficulty keep her (Elinor) on the bed at all, and for some time was fearful of being constrained to call for assistance. Some lavender drops, however, which she (Elinor) was at length persuaded to take, were of use; and from that time till Mrs. Jennings returned, she (Jennings) continued on the bed quiet and motionless.

CHAPTER 30

Mrs. Jennings came immediately to their room on her (Jennings) return, and without waiting to have her (Jennings) request of admittance answered, opened the door and walked in with a look of real concern.

``How do you do my dear?'' (she)
--said she (Jennings) in a voice of great compassion to Marianne, who turned away her (Marianne) face without attempting to answer.

``How is she (Marianne), Miss Dashwood?--Poor thing! she (Dashwood) looks very bad.-- No wonder. Ay, it is but too true. He (Jennings) is to be married very soon--a good-for-nothing fellow! I have no patience with him (Jennings). Mrs. Taylor told me of it half an hour ago, and she (Taylor) was told it by a particular friend of Miss Grey herself, else I am sure I should not have believed it; and I was almost ready to sink as it was. Well, said I, all I can say is, that if this be true, he (friend) has used a young lady of my acquaintance abominably ill, and I wish with all my soul his (friend) wife may plague his (friend) heart out. And so I shall always say, my dear, you may depend on it. I have no notion of men's going on in this way; and if ever I meet him (friend) again, I will give him (friend) such a dressing as he (friend) has not had this many a day. But there is one comfort, my dear Miss Marianne; he (friend) is not the only young man in the world worth having; and with your pretty face you will never want admirers. Well, poor thing! I won't disturb her (Marianne) any longer, for she (Marianne) had better have her (Marianne) cry out at once and have done with. The Parrys and Sandersons luckily are coming tonight you know, and that will amuse her (Marianne).'' (She)

She (Marianne) then went away, walking on tiptoe out of the room, as if she (Marianne) supposed her (Marianne) young friend's affliction could be increased by noise.

Marianne, to the surprise of her (Marianne) sister, determined on dining with them. Elinor even advised her (Elinor) against it. But

``no, she (Elinor) would go down; she (Elinor) could bear it very well, and the bustle about her (Elinor) would be less.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
Elinor, pleased to have her (Elinor) governed for a moment by such a motive, though believing it hardly possible that she (Elinor) could sit out the dinner, said no more; and adjusting her (Elinor) dress for her (Elinor) as well as she (Elinor) could, while Marianne still remained on the bed, was ready to assist her (Marianne) into the dining room as soon as they were summoned to it.

When there, though looking most wretchedly, she (Marianne) ate more and was calmer than her (Marianne) sister had expected. Had she (Marianne) tried to speak, or had she (Marianne) been conscious of half Mrs. Jennings's well-meant but ill-judged attentions to her (Marianne), this calmness could not have been maintained; but not a syllable escaped her (Marianne) lips; and the abstraction of her (Marianne) thoughts preserved her (Marianne) in ignorance of every thing that was passing before her (Marianne).

Elinor, who did justice to Mrs. Jennings's kindness, though its effusions were often distressing, and sometimes almost ridiculous, made her (Jennings) those acknowledgments, and returned her (Jennings) those civilities, which her (Jennings) sister could not make or return for herself. Their good friend saw that Marianne was unhappy, and felt that every thing was due to her (Marianne) which might make her (Marianne) at all less so. She (Marianne) treated her (Marianne) therefore, with all the indulgent fondness of a parent towards a favourite child on the last day of its holidays. Marianne was to have the best place by the fire, was to be tempted to eat by every delicacy in the house, and to be amused by the relation of all the news of the day. Had not Elinor, in the sad countenance of her (Elinor) sister, seen a check to all mirth, she (Elinor) could have been entertained by Mrs. Jennings's endeavours to cure a disappointment in love, by a variety of sweetmeats and olives, and a good fire. As soon, however, as the consciousness of all this was forced by continual repetition on Marianne, she (Marianne) could stay no longer. With a hasty exclamation of Misery, and a sign to her (Marianne) sister not to follow her (Marianne), she (Marianne) directly got up and hurried out of the room.

``Poor soul!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings, as soon as she (Jennings) was gone,
``how it grieves me to see her (Jennings)! And I declare if she (Jennings) is not gone away without finishing her (Jennings) wine! And the dried cherries too! Lord! nothing seems to do her (Jennings) any good. I am sure if I knew of any thing she (Jennings) would like, I would send all over the town for it. Well, it is the oddest thing to me, that a man should use such a pretty girl so ill! But when there is plenty of money on one side, and next to none on the other, Lord bless you! they care no more about such things!--'' (she)

``The lady then--Miss Grey I think you called her (Grey)--is very rich?'' (unknown)

``Fifty thousand pounds, my dear. Did you ever see her (Grey)? a smart, stylish girl they say, but not handsome. I remember her (girl) aunt very well, Biddy Henshawe; she (girl) married a very wealthy man. But the family are all rich together. Fifty thousand pounds! and by all accounts, it won't come before it's wanted; for they say he (man) is all to pieces. No wonder! dashing about with his (man) curricle and hunters! Well, it don't signify talking; but when a young man, be who he (man) will, comes and makes love to a pretty girl, and promises marriage, he (man) has no business to fly off from his (man) word only because he (man) grows poor, and a richer girl is ready to have him (man). Why don't he (man), in such a case, sell his (man) horses, let his (man) house, turn off his (man) servants, and make a thorough reform at once? I warrant you, Miss Marianne would have been ready to wait till matters came round. But that won't do now-a-days; nothing in the way of pleasure can ever be given up by the young men of this age.'' (unknown)

``Do you know what kind of a girl Miss Grey is? Is she (Grey) said to be amiable?'' (unknown)

``I never heard any harm of her (Grey); indeed I hardly ever heard her (Grey) mentioned; except that Mrs. Taylor did say this morning, that one day Miss Walker hinted to her (Walker), that she (Walker) believed Mr. and Mrs. Ellison would not be sorry to have Miss Grey married, for she (Grey) and Mrs. Ellison could never agree.'' (unknown)
--

``And who are the Ellisons?'' (unknown)

``Her (Grey) guardians, my dear. But now she (Grey) is of age and may choose for herself; and a pretty choice she (Grey) has made!--What now,'' (unknown)
after pausing a moment--
``your poor sister is gone to her (sister) own room, I suppose, to moan by herself. Is there nothing one can get to comfort her (sister)? Poor dear, it seems quite cruel to let her (sister) be alone. Well, by-and-by we shall have a few friends, and that will amuse her (sister) a little. What shall we play at? She (sister) hates whist I know; but is there no round game she (sister) cares for?'' (unknown)

``Dear ma'am, this kindness is quite unnecessary. Marianne, I dare say, will not leave her (Marianne) room again this evening. I shall persuade her (Marianne) if I can to go early to bed, for I am sure she (Marianne) wants rest.'' (unknown)

``Aye, I believe that will be best for her (Marianne). Let her (Marianne) name her (Marianne) own supper, and go to bed. Lord! no wonder she (Marianne) has been looking so bad and so cast down this last week or two, for this matter I suppose has been hanging over her (Marianne) head as long as that. And so the letter that came today finished it! Poor soul! I am sure if I had had a notion of it, I would not have joked her (Marianne) about it for all my money. But then you know, how should I guess such a thing? I made sure of its being nothing but a common love letter, and you know young people like to be laughed at about them. Lord! how concerned Sir John and my daughters will be when they hear it! If I had my senses about me I might have called in Conduit Street in my way home, and told them of it. But I shall see them tomorrow.'' (unknown)

``It would be unnecessary I am sure, for you to caution Mrs. Palmer and Sir John against ever naming Mr. Willoughby, or making the slightest allusion to what has passed, before my sister. Their own good-nature must point out to them the real cruelty of appearing to know any thing about it when she (sister) is present; and the less that may ever be said to myself on the subject, the more my feelings will be spared, as you my dear madam will easily believe.'' (unknown)

``Oh! Lord! yes, that I do indeed. It must be terrible for you to hear it talked of; and as for your sister, I am sure I would not mention a word about it to her (sister) for the world. You saw I did not all dinner time. No more would Sir John, nor my daughters, for they are all very thoughtful and considerate; especially if I give them a hint, as I certainly will. For my part, I think the less that is said about such things, the better, the sooner 'tis blown over and forgot. And what does talking ever do you know?'' (unknown)

``In this affair it can only do harm; more so perhaps than in many cases of a similar kind, for it has been attended by circumstances which, for the sake of every one concerned in it, make it unfit to become the public conversation. I must do THIS justice to Mr. Willoughby--he (Willoughby) has broken no positive engagement with my sister.'' (unknown)

``Law, my dear! Don't pretend to defend him (Willoughby). No positive engagement indeed! after taking her (sister) all over Allenham House, and fixing on the very rooms they were to live in hereafter!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor, for her (Elinor) sister's sake, could not press the subject farther, and she (Elinor) hoped it was not required of her (Elinor) for Willoughby's; since, though Marianne might lose much, he (Willoughby) could gain very little by the enforcement of the real truth. After a short silence on both sides, Mrs. Jennings, with all her (Jennings) natural hilarity, burst forth again.

``Well, my dear, 'tis a true saying about an ill-wind, for it will be all the better for Colonel Brandon. He (Colonel) will have her (Brandon) at last; aye, that he (Colonel) will. Mind me, now, if they an't married by Mid-summer. Lord! how he (Lord)'ll chuckle over this news! I hope he (Lord) will come tonight. It will be all to one a better match for your sister. Two thousand a year without debt or drawback--except the little love-child, indeed; aye, I had forgot her (sister); but she (sister) may be `prenticed out at a small cost, and then what does it signify? Delaford is a nice place, I can tell you; exactly what I call a nice old fashioned place, full of comforts and conveniences; quite shut in with great garden walls that are covered with the best fruit-trees in the country; and such a mulberry tree in one corner! Lord! how Charlotte and I did stuff the only time we were there! Then, there is a dove-cote, some delightful stew-ponds, and a very pretty canal; and every thing, in short, that one could wish for; and, moreover, it is close to the church, and only a quarter of a mile from the turnpike-road, so 'tis never dull, for if you only go and sit up in an old yew arbour behind the house, you may see all the carriages that pass along. Oh! 'tis a nice place! A butcher hard by in the village, and the parsonage-house within a stone's throw. To my fancy, a thousand times prettier than Barton Park, where they are forced to send three miles for their meat, and have not a neighbour nearer than your mother. Well, I shall spirit up the Colonel as soon as I can. One shoulder of mutton, you know, drives another down. If we CAN but put Willoughby out of her (mother) head!'' (unknown)

``Ay, if we can do THAT, Ma'am,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``we shall do very well with or without Colonel Brandon.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
And then rising, she (Brandon) went away to join Marianne, whom she (Brandon) found, as she (Brandon) expected, in her (Brandon) own room, leaning, in silent misery, over the small remains of a fire, which, till Elinor's entrance, had been her (Elinor) only light.

``You had better leave me,'' (sister)
was all the notice that her (Elinor) sister received from her (Elinor).

``I will leave you,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``if you will go to bed.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
But this, from the momentary perverseness of impatient suffering, she (Elinor) at first refused to do. Her (Elinor) sister's earnest, though gentle persuasion, however, soon softened her (Elinor) to compliance, and Elinor saw her (Elinor) lay her (Elinor) aching head on the pillow, and as she (Elinor) hoped, in a way to get some quiet rest before she (Elinor) left her (Elinor).

In the drawing-room, whither she (Elinor) then repaired, she (Elinor) was soon joined by Mrs. Jennings, with a wine-glass, full of something, in her (Elinor) hand.

``My dear,'' (she)
said she (Elinor), entering,
``I have just recollected that I have some of the finest old Constantia wine in the house that ever was tasted, so I have brought a glass of it for your sister. My poor husband! how fond he (husband) was of it! Whenever he (husband) had a touch of his (husband) old colicky gout, he (husband) said it did him (husband) more good than any thing else in the world. Do take it to your sister.'' (she)

``Dear Ma'am,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, smiling at the difference of the complaints for which it was recommended,
``how good you are! But I have just left Marianne in bed, and, I hope, almost asleep; and as I think nothing will be of so much service to her (Marianne) as rest, if you will give me leave, I will drink the wine myself.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Mrs. Jennings, though regretting that she (Jennings) had not been five minutes earlier, was satisfied with the compromise; and Elinor, as she (Elinor) swallowed the chief of it, reflected, that though its effects on a colicky gout were, at present, of little importance to her (Elinor), its healing powers, on a disappointed heart might be as reasonably tried on herself as on her (Elinor) sister.

Colonel Brandon came in while the party were at tea, and by his (Colonel) manner of looking round the room for Marianne, Elinor immediately fancied that he (Colonel) neither expected nor wished to see her (Elinor) there, and, in short, that he (Colonel) was already aware of what occasioned her (Elinor) absence. Mrs. Jennings was not struck by the same thought; for soon after his (Colonel) entrance, she (Jennings) walked across the room to the tea-table where Elinor presided, and whispered--

``The Colonel looks as grave as ever you see. He (Colonel) knows nothing of it; do tell him (Colonel), my dear.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

He (Colonel) shortly afterwards drew a chair close to hers, and, with a look which perfectly assured her (Elinor) of his (Colonel) good information, inquired after her (Elinor) sister.

``Marianne is not well,'' (she)
said she (Marianne).
``She (Marianne) has been indisposed all day, and we have persuaded her (Marianne) to go to bed.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps, then,'' (he)
he (Colonel) hesitatingly replied,
``what I heard this morning may be--there may be more truth in it than I could believe possible at first.'' (he)

``What did you hear?'' (unknown)

``That a gentleman, whom I had reason to think--in short, that a man, whom I KNEW to be engaged--but how shall I tell you? If you know it already, as surely you must, I may be spared.'' (unknown)

``You mean,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
answered Elinor, with forced calmness,
``Mr. Willoughby's marriage with Miss Grey. Yes, we DO know it all. This seems to have been a day of general elucidation, for this very morning first unfolded it to us. Mr. Willoughby is unfathomable! Where did you hear it?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``In a stationer's shop in Pall Mall, where I had business. Two ladies were waiting for their carriage, and one of them was giving the other an account of the intended match, in a voice so little attempting concealment, that it was impossible for me not to hear all. The name of Willoughby, John Willoughby, frequently repeated, first caught my attention; and what followed was a positive assertion that every thing was now finally settled respecting his (Willoughby) marriage with Miss Grey--it was no longer to be a secret--it would take place even within a few weeks, with many particulars of preparations and other matters. One thing, especially, I remember, because it served to identify the man still more:--as soon as the ceremony was over, they were to go to Combe Magna, his (Magna) seat in Somersetshire. My astonishment!--but it would be impossible to describe what I felt. The communicative lady I learnt, on inquiry, for I stayed in the shop till they were gone, was a Mrs. Ellison, and that, as I have been since informed, is the name of Miss Grey's guardian.'' (unknown)

``It is. But have you likewise heard that Miss Grey has fifty thousand pounds? In that, if in any thing, we may find an explanation.'' (unknown)

``It may be so; but Willoughby is capable--at least I think'' (he)
--he (Willoughby) stopped a moment; then added in a voice which seemed to distrust itself,
``And your sister--how did she (sister)--'' (he)

``Her (sister) sufferings have been very severe. I have only to hope that they may be proportionately short. It has been, it is a most cruel affliction. Till yesterday, I believe, she (sister) never doubted his (Willoughby) regard; and even now, perhaps--but I am almost convinced that he (Willoughby) never was really attached to her (sister). He (Willoughby) has been very deceitful! and, in some points, there seems a hardness of heart about him (Willoughby).'' (he)

``Ah!'' (Colonel)
said Colonel Brandon,
``there is, indeed! But your sister does not--I think you said so--she (sister) does not consider quite as you do?'' (Brandon/Mrs. Brandon)

``You know her (sister) disposition, and may believe how eagerly she (sister) would still justify him (Colonel) if she (sister) could.'' (He)

He (Colonel) made no answer; and soon afterwards, by the removal of the tea-things, and the arrangement of the card parties, the subject was necessarily dropped. Mrs. Jennings, who had watched them with pleasure while they were talking, and who expected to see the effect of Miss Dashwood's communication, in such an instantaneous gaiety on Colonel Brandon's side, as might have become a man in the bloom of youth, of hope and happiness, saw him (man), with amazement, remain the whole evening more serious and thoughtful than usual.

CHAPTER 31

From a night of more sleep than she (Brandon) had expected, Marianne awoke the next morning to the same consciousness of misery in which she (Brandon) had closed her (Brandon) eyes.

Elinor encouraged her (Elinor) as much as possible to talk of what she (Elinor) felt; and before breakfast was ready, they had gone through the subject again and again; and with the same steady conviction and affectionate counsel on Elinor's side, the same impetuous feelings and varying opinions on Marianne's, as before. Sometimes she (Marianne) could believe Willoughby to be as unfortunate and as innocent as herself, and at others, lost every consolation in the impossibility of acquitting him (Willoughby). At one moment she (Marianne) was absolutely indifferent to the observation of all the world, at another she (Marianne) would seclude herself from it for ever, and at a third could resist it with energy. In one thing, however, she (Marianne) was uniform, when it came to the point, in avoiding, where it was possible, the presence of Mrs. Jennings, and in a determined silence when obliged to endure it. Her (Jennings) heart was hardened against the belief of Mrs. Jennings's entering into her (Jennings) sorrows with any compassion.

``No, no, no, it cannot be,'' (she)
she (Jennings) cried;
``she (Jennings) cannot feel. Her (Jennings) kindness is not sympathy; her (Jennings) good-nature is not tenderness. All that she (Jennings) wants is gossip, and she (Jennings) only likes me now because I supply it.'' (she)

Elinor had not needed this to be assured of the injustice to which her (Elinor) sister was often led in her (Elinor) opinion of others, by the irritable refinement of her (Elinor) own mind, and the too great importance placed by her (Elinor) on the delicacies of a strong sensibility, and the graces of a polished manner. Like half the rest of the world, if more than half there be that are clever and good, Marianne, with excellent abilities and an excellent disposition, was neither reasonable nor candid. She (Marianne) expected from other people the same opinions and feelings as her (Marianne) own, and she (Marianne) judged of their motives by the immediate effect of their actions on herself. Thus a circumstance occurred, while the sisters were together in their own room after breakfast, which sunk the heart of Mrs. Jennings still lower in her (Jennings) estimation; because, through her (Jennings) own weakness, it chanced to prove a source of fresh pain to herself, though Mrs. Jennings was governed in it by an impulse of the utmost goodwill.

With a letter in her (Jennings) outstretched hand, and countenance gaily smiling, from the persuasion of bringing comfort, she (Jennings) entered their room, saying,

``Now, my dear, I bring you something that I am sure will do you good.'' (she)

Marianne heard enough. In one moment her (Marianne) imagination placed before her (Marianne) a letter from Willoughby, full of tenderness and contrition, explanatory of all that had passed, satisfactory, convincing; and instantly followed by Willoughby himself, rushing eagerly into the room to inforce, at her (Marianne) feet, by the eloquence of his (Willoughby) eyes, the assurances of his (Willoughby) letter. The work of one moment was destroyed by the next.
