The hand writing of her (Marianne) mother, never till then unwelcome, was before her (Marianne); and, in the acuteness of the disappointment which followed such an ecstasy of more than hope, she (Marianne) felt as if, till that instant, she (Marianne) had never suffered.

The cruelty of Mrs. Jennings no language, within her (Jennings) reach in her (Jennings) moments of happiest eloquence, could have expressed; and now she (Jennings) could reproach her (Jennings) only by the tears which streamed from her (Jennings) eyes with passionate violence--a reproach, however, so entirely lost on its object, that after many expressions of pity, she (Jennings) withdrew, still referring her (Jennings) to the letter of comfort. But the letter, when she (Jennings) was calm enough to read it, brought little comfort. Willoughby filled every page. Her (Jennings) mother, still confident of their engagement, and relying as warmly as ever on his (Willoughby) constancy, had only been roused by Elinor's application, to intreat from Marianne greater openness towards them both; and this, with such tenderness towards her (Marianne), such affection for Willoughby, and such a conviction of their future happiness in each other, that she (Marianne) wept with agony through the whole of it.

All her (Marianne) impatience to be at home again now returned; her (Marianne) mother was dearer to her (Marianne) than ever; dearer through the very excess of her (Marianne) mistaken confidence in Willoughby, and she (Marianne) was wildly urgent to be gone. Elinor, unable herself to determine whether it were better for Marianne to be in London or at Barton, offered no counsel of her (Marianne) own except of patience till their mother's wishes could be known; and at length she (Marianne) obtained her (Marianne) sister's consent to wait for that knowledge.

Mrs. Jennings left them earlier than usual; for she (Jennings) could not be easy till the Middletons and Palmers were able to grieve as much as herself; and positively refusing Elinor's offered attendance, went out alone for the rest of the morning. Elinor, with a very heavy heart, aware of the pain she (Elinor) was going to communicate, and perceiving, by Marianne's letter, how ill she (Marianne) had succeeded in laying any foundation for it, then sat down to write her (Marianne) mother an account of what had passed, and entreat her (Marianne) directions for the future; while Marianne, who came into the drawing-room on Mrs. Jennings's going away, remained fixed at the table where Elinor wrote, watching the advancement of her (Elinor) pen, grieving over her (Elinor) for the hardship of such a task, and grieving still more fondly over its effect on her (Elinor) mother.

In this manner they had continued about a quarter of an hour, when Marianne, whose nerves could not then bear any sudden noise, was startled by a rap at the door.

``Who can this be?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
cried Elinor.
``So early too! I thought we HAD been safe.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne moved to the window--

``It is Colonel Brandon!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said she (Brandon), with vexation.
``We are never safe from HIM.'' (unknown)

``He (Colonel) will not come in, as Mrs. Jennings is from home.'' (unknown)

``I will not trust to THAT,'' (unknown)
retreating to her (Jennings) own room.
``A man who has nothing to do with his (man) own time has no conscience in his (man) intrusion on that of others.'' (unknown)

The event proved her (Jennings) conjecture right, though it was founded on injustice and error; for Colonel Brandon DID come in; and Elinor, who was convinced that solicitude for Marianne brought him (Colonel) thither, and who saw THAT solicitude in his (Colonel) disturbed and melancholy look, and in his (Colonel) anxious though brief inquiry after her (Marianne), could not forgive her (Marianne) sister for esteeming him (Colonel) so lightly.

``I met Mrs. Jennings in Bond Street,'' (he)
said he (Bond), after the first salutation,
``and she (Jennings) encouraged me to come on; and I was the more easily encouraged, because I thought it probable that I might find you alone, which I was very desirous of doing. My object--my wish--my sole wish in desiring it--I hope, I believe it is--is to be a means of giving comfort;--no, I must not say comfort--not present comfort--but conviction, lasting conviction to your sister's mind. My regard for her (sister), for yourself, for your mother--will you allow me to prove it, by relating some circumstances which nothing but a VERY sincere regard--nothing but an earnest desire of being useful--I think I am justified--though where so many hours have been spent in convincing myself that I am right, is there not some reason to fear I may be wrong?'' (he)
He (sister) stopped.

``I understand you,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.
``You have something to tell me of Mr. Willoughby, that will open his (Willoughby) character farther. Your telling it will be the greatest act of friendship that can be shewn Marianne. MY gratitude will be insured immediately by any information tending to that end, and HERS must be gained by it in time. Pray, pray let me hear it.'' (unknown)

``You shall; and, to be brief, when I quitted Barton last October,--but this will give you no idea--I must go farther back. You will find me a very awkward narrator, Miss Dashwood; I hardly know where to begin. A short account of myself, I believe, will be necessary, and it SHALL be a short one. On such a subject,'' (He)
sighing heavily,
``can I have little temptation to be diffuse.'' (He)

He (narrator) stopt a moment for recollection, and then, with another sigh, went on.

``You have probably entirely forgotten a conversation---LRB-it is not to be supposed that it could make any impression on you-RRB---a conversation between us one evening at Barton Park--it was the evening of a dance--in which I alluded to a lady I had once known, as resembling, in some measure, your sister Marianne.'' (unknown)

``Indeed,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
answered Elinor,
``I have NOT forgotten it.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
He (Barton) looked pleased by this remembrance, and added,

``If I am not deceived by the uncertainty, the partiality of tender recollection, there is a very strong resemblance between them, as well in mind as person. The same warmth of heart, the same eagerness of fancy and spirits. This lady was one of my nearest relations, an orphan from her (lady) infancy, and under the guardianship of my father. Our ages were nearly the same, and from our earliest years we were playfellows and friends. I cannot remember the time when I did not love Eliza; and my affection for her (Eliza), as we grew up, was such, as perhaps, judging from my present forlorn and cheerless gravity, you might think me incapable of having ever felt. Hers, for me, was, I believe, fervent as the attachment of your sister to Mr. Willoughby and it was, though from a different cause, no less unfortunate. At seventeen she (sister) was lost to me for ever. She (sister) was married--married against her (sister) inclination to my brother. Her (sister) fortune was large, and our family estate much encumbered. And this, I fear, is all that can be said for the conduct of one, who was at once her (sister) uncle and guardian. My brother did not deserve her (sister); he (brother) did not even love her (sister). I had hoped that her (sister) regard for me would support her (sister) under any difficulty, and for some time it did; but at last the misery of her (sister) situation, for she (sister) experienced great unkindness, overcame all her (sister) resolution, and though she (sister) had promised me that nothing--but how blindly I relate! I have never told you how this was brought on. We were within a few hours of eloping together for Scotland. The treachery, or the folly, of my cousin's maid betrayed us. I was banished to the house of a relation far distant, and she (maid) was allowed no liberty, no society, no amusement, till my father's point was gained. I had depended on her (maid) fortitude too far, and the blow was a severe one--but had her (maid) marriage been happy, so young as I then was, a few months must have reconciled me to it, or at least I should not have now to lament it. This however was not the case. My brother had no regard for her (maid); his (brother) pleasures were not what they ought to have been, and from the first he (brother) treated her (maid) unkindly. The consequence of this, upon a mind so young, so lively, so inexperienced as Mrs. Brandon's, was but too natural. She (Brandon) resigned herself at first to all the misery of her (Brandon) situation; and happy had it been if she (Brandon) had not lived to overcome those regrets which the remembrance of me occasioned. But can we wonder that, with such a husband to provoke inconstancy, and without a friend to advise or restrain her (Brandon) -LRB-for my father lived only a few months after their marriage, and I was with my regiment in the East Indies-RRB- she (Brandon) should fall? Had I remained in England, perhaps--but I meant to promote the happiness of both by removing from her (Brandon) for years, and for that purpose had procured my exchange. The shock which her (Brandon) marriage had given me,'' (He)
he (father) continued, in a voice of great agitation,
``was of trifling weight--was nothing to what I felt when I heard, about two years afterwards, of her (Brandon) divorce. It was THAT which threw this gloom,--even now the recollection of what I suffered--'' (he)

He (father) could say no more, and rising hastily walked for a few minutes about the room. Elinor, affected by his (father) relation, and still more by his (father) distress, could not speak. He (father) saw her (Elinor) concern, and coming to her (Elinor), took her (Elinor) hand, pressed it, and kissed it with grateful respect. A few minutes more of silent exertion enabled him (father) to proceed with composure.

``It was nearly three years after this unhappy period before I returned to England. My first care, when I DID arrive, was of course to seek for her (Elinor); but the search was as fruitless as it was melancholy. I could not trace her (Elinor) beyond her (Elinor) first seducer, and there was every reason to fear that she (Elinor) had removed from him (father) only to sink deeper in a life of sin. Her (Elinor) legal allowance was not adequate to her (Elinor) fortune, nor sufficient for her (Elinor) comfortable maintenance, and I learnt from my brother that the power of receiving it had been made over some months before to another person. He (brother) imagined, and calmly could he (brother) imagine it, that her (Elinor) extravagance, and consequent distress, had obliged her (Elinor) to dispose of it for some immediate relief. At last, however, and after I had been six months in England, I DID find her (Elinor). Regard for a former servant of my own, who had since fallen into misfortune, carried me to visit him (servant) in a spunging-house, where he (servant) was confined for debt; and there, in the same house, under a similar confinement, was my unfortunate sister. So altered--so faded--worn down by acute suffering of every kind! hardly could I believe the melancholy and sickly figure before me, to be the remains of the lovely, blooming, healthful girl, on whom I had once doted. What I endured in so beholding her (girl)--but I have no right to wound your feelings by attempting to describe it--I have pained you too much already. That she (girl) was, to all appearance, in the last stage of a consumption, was--yes, in such a situation it was my greatest comfort. Life could do nothing for her (girl), beyond giving time for a better preparation for death; and that was given. I saw her (girl) placed in comfortable lodgings, and under proper attendants; I visited her (girl) every day during the rest of her (girl) short life: I was with her (girl) in her (girl) last moments.'' (he)

Again he (girl) stopped to recover himself; and Elinor spoke her (Elinor) feelings in an exclamation of tender concern, at the fate of his (girl) unfortunate friend.

``Your sister, I hope, cannot be offended,'' (he)
said he (girl),
``by the resemblance I have fancied between her (sister) and my poor disgraced relation. Their fates, their fortunes, cannot be the same; and had the natural sweet disposition of the one been guarded by a firmer mind, or a happier marriage, she (sister) might have been all that you will live to see the other be. But to what does all this lead? I seem to have been distressing you for nothing. Ah! Miss Dashwood--a subject such as this--untouched for fourteen years--it is dangerous to handle it at all! I WILL be more collected--more concise. She (Dashwood) left to my care her (Dashwood) only child, a little girl, the offspring of her (Dashwood) first guilty connection, who was then about three years old. She (Dashwood) loved the child, and had always kept it with her (Dashwood). It was a valued, a precious trust to me; and gladly would I have discharged it in the strictest sense, by watching over her (Dashwood) education myself, had the nature of our situations allowed it; but I had no family, no home; and my little Eliza was therefore placed at school. I saw her (Eliza) there whenever I could, and after the death of my brother, -LRB-which happened about five years ago, and which left to me the possession of the family property,-RRB- she (Eliza) visited me at Delaford. I called her (Eliza) a distant relation; but I am well aware that I have in general been suspected of a much nearer connection with her (Eliza). It is now three years ago -LRB-she (Eliza) had just reached her (Eliza) fourteenth year,-RRB- that I removed her (Eliza) from school, to place her (Eliza) under the care of a very respectable woman, residing in Dorsetshire, who had the charge of four or five other girls of about the same time of life; and for two years I had every reason to be pleased with her (Eliza) situation. But last February, almost a twelvemonth back, she (Eliza) suddenly disappeared. I had allowed her (Eliza), -LRB-imprudently, as it has since turned out,-RRB- at her (Eliza) earnest desire, to go to Bath with one of her (Eliza) young friends, who was attending her (Eliza) father there for his (father) health. I knew him (father) to be a very good sort of man, and I thought well of his (father) daughter--better than she (daughter) deserved, for, with a most obstinate and ill-judged secrecy, she (daughter) would tell nothing, would give no clue, though she (daughter) certainly knew all. He (father), her (daughter) father, a well-meaning, but not a quick-sighted man, could really, I believe, give no information; for he (man) had been generally confined to the house, while the girls were ranging over the town and making what acquaintance they chose; and he (acquaintance) tried to convince me, as thoroughly as he (acquaintance) was convinced himself, of his (acquaintance) daughter's being entirely unconcerned in the business. In short, I could learn nothing but that she (daughter) was gone; all the rest, for eight long months, was left to conjecture. What I thought, what I feared, may be imagined; and what I suffered too.'' (he)

``Good heavens!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
cried Elinor,
``could it be--could Willoughby!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
--

``The first news that reached me of her (Elinor),'' (he)
he (Willoughby) continued,
``came in a letter from herself, last October. It was forwarded to me from Delaford, and I received it on the very morning of our intended party to Whitwell; and this was the reason of my leaving Barton so suddenly, which I am sure must at the time have appeared strange to every body, and which I believe gave offence to some. Little did Mr. Willoughby imagine, I suppose, when his (Willoughby) looks censured me for incivility in breaking up the party, that I was called away to the relief of one whom he (Willoughby) had made poor and miserable; but HAD he (Willoughby) known it, what would it have availed? Would he (Willoughby) have been less gay or less happy in the smiles of your sister? No, he (Willoughby) had already done that, which no man who CAN feel for another would do. He (man) had left the girl whose youth and innocence he (man) had seduced, in a situation of the utmost distress, with no creditable home, no help, no friends, ignorant of his (man) address! He (man) had left her (girl), promising to return; he (man) neither returned, nor wrote, nor relieved her (girl).'' (he)

``This is beyond every thing!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
exclaimed Elinor.

``His (man) character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him (man) as ever, and on being assured that she (sister) was to marry him (man): guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister--but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him (man). But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his (man) designs on her (sister). Whatever they may have been, however, she (sister) may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her (sister) own condition, when she (sister) compares it with that of my poor Eliza, when she (Eliza) considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her (Eliza) to herself, with an affection for him (man) so strong, still as strong as her (Eliza) own, and with a mind tormented by self-reproach, which must attend her (Eliza) through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her (Eliza). She (Eliza) will feel her (Eliza) own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her (Eliza) friend by them. Concern for her (Eliza) unhappiness, and respect for her (Eliza) fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her (Eliza) what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her (Eliza) regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor's thanks followed this speech with grateful earnestness; attended too with the assurance of her (Elinor) expecting material advantage to Marianne, from the communication of what had passed.

``I have been more pained,'' (she)
said she (Elinor),
``by her (Elinor) endeavors to acquit him (Elinor) than by all the rest; for it irritates her (Elinor) mind more than the most perfect conviction of his (Elinor) unworthiness can do. Now, though at first she (Elinor) will suffer much, I am sure she (Elinor) will soon become easier. Have you,'' (she)
she (Elinor) continued, after a short silence,
``ever seen Mr. Willoughby since you left him (Willoughby) at Barton?'' (she)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Barton) replied gravely,
``once I have. One meeting was unavoidable.'' (he)

Elinor, startled by his (Barton) manner, looked at him (Barton) anxiously, saying,

``What? have you met him (Barton) to--'' (him)

``I could meet him (Barton) no other way. Eliza had confessed to me, though most reluctantly, the name of her (Eliza) lover; and when he (lover) returned to town, which was within a fortnight after myself, we met by appointment, he (lover) to defend, I to punish his (lover) conduct. We returned unwounded, and the meeting, therefore, never got abroad.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor sighed over the fancied necessity of this; but to a man and a soldier she (Elinor) presumed not to censure it.

``Such,'' (Colonel)
said Colonel Brandon, after a pause,
``has been the unhappy resemblance between the fate of mother and daughter! and so imperfectly have I discharged my trust!'' (Brandon/Mrs. Brandon)

``Is she (daughter) still in town?'' (unknown)

``No; as soon as she (daughter) recovered from her (daughter) lying-in, for I found her (daughter) near her (daughter) delivery, I removed her (daughter) and her (daughter) child into the country, and there she (daughter) remains.'' (he)

Recollecting, soon afterwards, that he (Colonel) was probably dividing Elinor from her (Elinor) sister, he (Colonel) put an end to his (Colonel) visit, receiving from her (Elinor) again the same grateful acknowledgments, and leaving her (Elinor) full of compassion and esteem for him (Colonel).

CHAPTER 32

When the particulars of this conversation were repeated by Miss Dashwood to her (Dashwood) sister, as they very soon were, the effect on her (Dashwood) was not entirely such as the former had hoped to see. Not that Marianne appeared to distrust the truth of any part of it, for she (Marianne) listened to it all with the most steady and submissive attention, made neither objection nor remark, attempted no vindication of Willoughby, and seemed to shew by her (Marianne) tears that she (Marianne) felt it to be impossible. But though this behaviour assured Elinor that the conviction of this guilt WAS carried home to her (Elinor) mind, though she (Elinor) saw with satisfaction the effect of it, in her (Elinor) no longer avoiding Colonel Brandon when he (Colonel) called, in her (Elinor) speaking to him (Colonel), even voluntarily speaking, with a kind of compassionate respect, and though she (Elinor) saw her (Elinor) spirits less violently irritated than before, she (Elinor) did not see her (Elinor) less wretched. Her (Elinor) mind did become settled, but it was settled in a gloomy dejection. She (Elinor) felt the loss of Willoughby's character yet more heavily than she (Elinor) had felt the loss of his (Willoughby) heart; his (Willoughby) seduction and desertion of Miss Williams, the misery of that poor girl, and the doubt of what his (Willoughby) designs might ONCE have been on herself, preyed altogether so much on her (Williams) spirits, that she (Williams) could not bring herself to speak of what she (Williams) felt even to Elinor; and, brooding over her (Elinor) sorrows in silence, gave more pain to her (Elinor) sister than could have been communicated by the most open and most frequent confession of them.

To give the feelings or the language of Mrs. Dashwood on receiving and answering Elinor's letter would be only to give a repetition of what her (Elinor) daughters had already felt and said; of a disappointment hardly less painful than Marianne's, and an indignation even greater than Elinor's. Long letters from her (Elinor), quickly succeeding each other, arrived to tell all that she (Elinor) suffered and thought; to express her (Elinor) anxious solicitude for Marianne, and entreat she (Elinor) would bear up with fortitude under this misfortune. Bad indeed must the nature of Marianne's affliction be, when her (Marianne) mother could talk of fortitude! mortifying and humiliating must be the origin of those regrets, which SHE could wish her (Marianne) not to indulge!

Against the interest of her (Marianne) own individual comfort, Mrs. Dashwood had determined that it would be better for Marianne to be any where, at that time, than at Barton, where every thing within her (Marianne) view would be bringing back the past in the strongest and most afflicting manner, by constantly placing Willoughby before her (Marianne), such as she (Marianne) had always seen him (Willoughby) there. She (Marianne) recommended it to her (Marianne) daughters, therefore, by all means not to shorten their visit to Mrs. Jennings; the length of which, though never exactly fixed, had been expected by all to comprise at least five or six weeks. A variety of occupations, of objects, and of company, which could not be procured at Barton, would be inevitable there, and might yet, she (Jennings) hoped, cheat Marianne, at times, into some interest beyond herself, and even into some amusement, much as the ideas of both might now be spurned by her (Marianne).

From all danger of seeing Willoughby again, her (Marianne) mother considered her (Marianne) to be at least equally safe in town as in the country, since his (Willoughby) acquaintance must now be dropped by all who called themselves her (Marianne) friends. Design could never bring them in each other's way: negligence could never leave them exposed to a surprise; and chance had less in its favour in the crowd of London than even in the retirement of Barton, where it might force him (Barton) before her (Marianne) while paying that visit at Allenham on his (Barton) marriage, which Mrs. Dashwood, from foreseeing at first as a probable event, had brought herself to expect as a certain one.

She (Dashwood) had yet another reason for wishing her (Dashwood) children to remain where they were; a letter from her (Dashwood) son-in-law had told her (Dashwood) that he (son-in-law) and his (son-in-law) wife were to be in town before the middle of February, and she (Dashwood) judged it right that they should sometimes see their brother.

Marianne had promised to be guided by her (Marianne) mother's opinion, and she (Marianne) submitted to it therefore without opposition, though it proved perfectly different from what she (Marianne) wished and expected, though she (Marianne) felt it to be entirely wrong, formed on mistaken grounds, and that by requiring her (Marianne) longer continuance in London it deprived her (Marianne) of the only possible alleviation of her (Marianne) wretchedness, the personal sympathy of her (Marianne) mother, and doomed her (Marianne) to such society and such scenes as must prevent her (Marianne) ever knowing a moment's rest.

But it was a matter of great consolation to her (Marianne), that what brought evil to herself would bring good to her (Marianne) sister; and Elinor, on the other hand, suspecting that it would not be in her (Elinor) power to avoid Edward entirely, comforted herself by thinking, that though their longer stay would therefore militate against her (Elinor) own happiness, it would be better for Marianne than an immediate return into Devonshire.

Her (Marianne) carefulness in guarding her (Marianne) sister from ever hearing Willoughby's name mentioned, was not thrown away. Marianne, though without knowing it herself, reaped all its advantage; for neither Mrs. Jennings, nor Sir John, nor even Mrs. Palmer herself, ever spoke of him (Willoughby) before her (Palmer). Elinor wished that the same forbearance could have extended towards herself, but that was impossible, and she (Elinor) was obliged to listen day after day to the indignation of them all.

Sir John, could not have thought it possible.

``A man of whom he (man) had always had such reason to think well! Such a good-natured fellow! He (fellow) did not believe there was a bolder rider in England! It was an unaccountable business. He (rider) wished him (rider) at the devil with all his (rider) heart. He (rider) would not speak another word to him (rider), meet him (rider) where he (rider) might, for all the world! No, not if it were to be by the side of Barton covert, and they were kept watching for two hours together. Such a scoundrel of a fellow! such a deceitful dog! It was only the last time they met that he (fellow) had offered him (fellow) one of Folly's puppies! and this was the end of it!'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)

Mrs. Palmer, in her (Palmer) way, was equally angry.

``She (Palmer) was determined to drop his (fellow) acquaintance immediately, and she (Palmer) was very thankful that she (Palmer) had never been acquainted with him (fellow) at all. She (Palmer) wished with all her (Palmer) heart Combe Magna was not so near Cleveland; but it did not signify, for it was a great deal too far off to visit; she (Palmer) hated him (Magna) so much that she (Palmer) was resolved never to mention his (Magna) name again, and she (Palmer) should tell everybody she (Palmer) saw, how good-for-nothing he (Magna) was.'' (Mrs. Palmer/Palmer)

The rest of Mrs. Palmer's sympathy was shewn in procuring all the particulars in her (Palmer) power of the approaching marriage, and communicating them to Elinor. She (Elinor) could soon tell at what coachmaker's the new carriage was building, by what painter Mr. Willoughby's portrait was drawn, and at what warehouse Miss Grey's clothes might be seen.

The calm and polite unconcern of Lady Middleton on the occasion was a happy relief to Elinor's spirits, oppressed as they often were by the clamorous kindness of the others. It was a great comfort to her (Elinor) to be sure of exciting no interest in ONE person at least among their circle of friends: a great comfort to know that there was ONE who would meet her (Elinor) without feeling any curiosity after particulars, or any anxiety for her (Elinor) sister's health.

Every qualification is raised at times, by the circumstances of the moment, to more than its real value; and she (Elinor) was sometimes worried down by officious condolence to rate good-breeding as more indispensable to comfort than good-nature.

Lady Middleton expressed her (Middleton) sense of the affair about once every day, or twice, if the subject occurred very often, by saying,

``It is very shocking, indeed!'' (Lady Middleton/Middleton)
and by the means of this continual though gentle vent, was able not only to see the Miss Dashwoods from the first without the smallest emotion, but very soon to see them without recollecting a word of the matter; and having thus supported the dignity of her (Middleton) own sex, and spoken her (Middleton) decided censure of what was wrong in the other, she (Middleton) thought herself at liberty to attend to the interest of her (Middleton) own assemblies, and therefore determined -LRB-though rather against the opinion of Sir John-RRB- that as Mrs. Willoughby would at once be a woman of elegance and fortune, to leave her (Willoughby) card with her (Willoughby) as soon as she (Willoughby) married.

Colonel Brandon's delicate, unobtrusive enquiries were never unwelcome to Miss Dashwood. He (Colonel) had abundantly earned the privilege of intimate discussion of her (Dashwood) sister's disappointment, by the friendly zeal with which he (Colonel) had endeavoured to soften it, and they always conversed with confidence. His (Colonel) chief reward for the painful exertion of disclosing past sorrows and present humiliations, was given in the pitying eye with which Marianne sometimes observed him (Colonel), and the gentleness of her (Marianne) voice whenever -LRB-though it did not often happen-RRB- she (Marianne) was obliged, or could oblige herself to speak to him (Colonel). THESE assured him (Colonel) that his (Colonel) exertion had produced an increase of good-will towards himself, and THESE gave Elinor hopes of its being farther augmented hereafter; but Mrs. Jennings, who knew nothing of all this, who knew only that the Colonel continued as grave as ever, and that she (Jennings) could neither prevail on him (Colonel) to make the offer himself, nor commission her (Jennings) to make it for him (Colonel), began, at the end of two days, to think that, instead of Midsummer, they would not be married till Michaelmas, and by the end of a week that it would not be a match at all. The good understanding between the Colonel and Miss Dashwood seemed rather to declare that the honours of the mulberry-tree, the canal, and the yew arbour, would all be made over to HER; and Mrs. Jennings had, for some time ceased to think at all of Mrs. Ferrars.

Early in February, within a fortnight from the receipt of Willoughby's letter, Elinor had the painful office of informing her (Elinor) sister that he (Willoughby) was married. She (Elinor) had taken care to have the intelligence conveyed to herself, as soon as it was known that the ceremony was over, as she (Elinor) was desirous that Marianne should not receive the first notice of it from the public papers, which she (Marianne) saw her (Marianne) eagerly examining every morning.

She (Marianne) received the news with resolute composure; made no observation on it, and at first shed no tears; but after a short time they would burst out, and for the rest of the day, she (Marianne) was in a state hardly less pitiable than when she (Marianne) first learnt to expect the event.

The Willoughbys left town as soon as they were married; and Elinor now hoped, as there could be no danger of her (Elinor) seeing either of them, to prevail on her (Elinor) sister, who had never yet left the house since the blow first fell, to go out again by degrees as she (Elinor) had done before.

About this time the two Miss Steeles, lately arrived at their cousin's house in Bartlett's Buildings, Holburn, presented themselves again before their more grand relations in Conduit and Berkeley Streets; and were welcomed by them all with great cordiality.

Elinor only was sorry to see them. Their presence always gave her (Elinor) pain, and she (Elinor) hardly knew how to make a very gracious return to the overpowering delight of Lucy in finding her (Lucy) STILL in town.

``I should have been quite disappointed if I had not found you here STILL,'' (she)
said she (Lucy) repeatedly, with a strong emphasis on the word.
``But I always thought I SHOULD. I was almost sure you would not leave London yet awhile; though you TOLD me, you know, at Barton, that you should not stay above a MONTH. But I thought, at the time, that you would most likely change your mind when it came to the point. It would have been such a great pity to have went away before your brother and sister came. And now to be sure you will be in no hurry to be gone. I am amazingly glad you did not keep to YOUR WORD.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor perfectly understood her (Elinor), and was forced to use all her (Elinor) self-command to make it appear that she (Elinor) did NOT.

``Well, my dear,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings,
``and how did you travel?'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``Not in the stage, I assure you,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
replied Miss Steele, with quick exultation;
``we came post all the way, and had a very smart beau to attend us. Dr. Davies was coming to town, and so we thought we'd join him (Davies) in a post-chaise; and he (Davies) behaved very genteelly, and paid ten or twelve shillings more than we did.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``Oh, oh!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings;
``very pretty, indeed! and the Doctor is a single man, I warrant you.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``There now,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Miss Steele, affectedly simpering,
``everybody laughs at me so about the Doctor, and I cannot think why. My cousins say they are sure I have made a conquest; but for my part I declare I never think about him (Doctor) from one hour's end to another. `Lord! here comes your beau, Nancy,' my cousin said t`other day, when she (Nancy) saw him (cousin) crossing the street to the house. My beau, indeed! said I--I cannot think who you mean. The Doctor is no beau of mine.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``Aye, aye, that is very pretty talking--but it won't do--the Doctor is the man, I see.'' (unknown)

``No, indeed!'' (cousin)
replied her (Nancy) cousin, with affected earnestness,
``and I beg you will contradict it, if you ever hear it talked of.'' (cousin)

Mrs. Jennings directly gave her (Jennings) the gratifying assurance that she (Jennings) certainly would NOT, and Miss Steele was made completely happy.

``I suppose you will go and stay with your brother and sister, Miss Dashwood, when they come to town,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy, returning, after a cessation of hostile hints, to the charge.

``No, I do not think we shall.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, I dare say you will.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor would not humour her (Elinor) by farther opposition.

``What a charming thing it is that Mrs. Dashwood can spare you both for so long a time together!'' (unknown)

``Long a time, indeed!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
interposed Mrs. Jennings.
``Why, their visit is but just begun!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Lucy was silenced.

``I am sorry we cannot see your sister, Miss Dashwood,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Miss Steele.
``I am sorry she (Steele) is not well--'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
for Marianne had left the room on their arrival.

``You are very good. My sister will be equally sorry to miss the pleasure of seeing you; but she (sister) has been very much plagued lately with nervous head-aches, which make her (sister) unfit for company or conversation.'' (unknown)

``Oh, dear, that is a great pity! but such old friends as Lucy and me!--I think she (Lucy) might see US; and I am sure we would not speak a word.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor, with great civility, declined the proposal. Her (Elinor) sister was perhaps laid down upon the bed, or in her (Elinor) dressing gown, and therefore not able to come to them.

``Oh, if that's all,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Miss Steele,
``we can just as well go and see HER.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

Elinor began to find this impertinence too much for her (Elinor) temper; but she (Elinor) was saved the trouble of checking it, by Lucy's sharp reprimand, which now, as on many occasions, though it did not give much sweetness to the manners of one sister, was of advantage in governing those of the other.

CHAPTER 33

After some opposition, Marianne yielded to her (Marianne) sister's entreaties, and consented to go out with her (Marianne) and Mrs. Jennings one morning for half an hour. She (Jennings) expressly conditioned, however, for paying no visits, and would do no more than accompany them to Gray's in Sackville Street, where Elinor was carrying on a negotiation for the exchange of a few old-fashioned jewels of her (Elinor) mother.

When they stopped at the door, Mrs. Jennings recollected that there was a lady at the other end of the street on whom she (Jennings) ought to call; and as she (Jennings) had no business at Gray's, it was resolved, that while her (Jennings) young friends transacted their's, she (Jennings) should pay her (Jennings) visit and return for them.

On ascending the stairs, the Miss Dashwoods found so many people before them in the room, that there was not a person at liberty to tend to their orders; and they were obliged to wait. All that could be done was, to sit down at that end of the counter which seemed to promise the quickest succession; one gentleman only was standing there, and it is probable that Elinor was not without hope of exciting his (gentleman) politeness to a quicker despatch. But the correctness of his (gentleman) eye, and the delicacy of his (gentleman) taste, proved to be beyond his (gentleman) politeness. He (gentleman) was giving orders for a toothpick-case for himself, and till its size, shape, and ornaments were determined, all of which, after examining and debating for a quarter of an hour over every toothpick-case in the shop, were finally arranged by his (gentleman) own inventive fancy, he (gentleman) had no leisure to bestow any other attention on the two ladies, than what was comprised in three or four very broad stares; a kind of notice which served to imprint on Elinor the remembrance of a person and face, of strong, natural, sterling insignificance, though adorned in the first style of fashion.

Marianne was spared from the troublesome feelings of contempt and resentment, on this impertinent examination of their features, and on the puppyism of his (gentleman) manner in deciding on all the different horrors of the different toothpick-cases presented to his (gentleman) inspection, by remaining unconscious of it all; for she (Marianne) was as well able to collect her (Marianne) thoughts within herself, and be as ignorant of what was passing around her (Marianne), in Mr. Gray's shop, as in her (Marianne) own bedroom.

At last the affair was decided. The ivory, the gold, and the pearls, all received their appointment, and the gentleman having named the last day on which his (gentleman) existence could be continued without the possession of the toothpick-case, drew on his (gentleman) gloves with leisurely care, and bestowing another glance on the Miss Dashwoods, but such a one as seemed rather to demand than express admiration, walked off with a happy air of real conceit and affected indifference.

Elinor lost no time in bringing her (Elinor) business forward, was on the point of concluding it, when another gentleman presented himself at her (Elinor) side. She (Elinor) turned her (Elinor) eyes towards his (gentleman) face, and found him (gentleman) with some surprise to be her (Elinor) brother.

Their affection and pleasure in meeting was just enough to make a very creditable appearance in Mr. Gray's shop. John Dashwood was really far from being sorry to see his (Gray) sisters again; it rather gave them satisfaction; and his (Gray) inquiries after their mother were respectful and attentive.

Elinor found that he (Gray) and Fanny had been in town two days.

``I wished very much to call upon you yesterday,'' (he)
said he (Gray),
``but it was impossible, for we were obliged to take Harry to see the wild beasts at Exeter Exchange; and we spent the rest of the day with Mrs. Ferrars. Harry was vastly pleased. THIS morning I had fully intended to call on you, if I could possibly find a spare half hour, but one has always so much to do on first coming to town. I am come here to bespeak Fanny a seal. But tomorrow I think I shall certainly be able to call in Berkeley Street, and be introduced to your friend Mrs. Jennings. I understand she (Jennings) is a woman of very good fortune. And the Middletons too, you must introduce me to THEM. As my mother-in-law's relations, I shall be happy to show them every respect. They are excellent neighbours to you in the country, I understand.'' (he)

``Excellent indeed. Their attention to our comfort, their friendliness in every particular, is more than I can express.'' (unknown)

``I am extremely glad to hear it, upon my word; extremely glad indeed. But so it ought to be; they are people of large fortune, they are related to you, and every civility and accommodation that can serve to make your situation pleasant might be reasonably expected. And so you are most comfortably settled in your little cottage and want for nothing! Edward brought us a most charming account of the place: the most complete thing of its kind, he (Edward) said, that ever was, and you all seemed to enjoy it beyond any thing. It was a great satisfaction to us to hear it, I assure you.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor did feel a little ashamed of her (Elinor) brother; and was not sorry to be spared the necessity of answering him (brother), by the arrival of Mrs. Jennings's servant, who came to tell her (Jennings) that his (servant) mistress waited for them at the door.

Mr. Dashwood attended them down stairs, was introduced to Mrs. Jennings at the door of her (Jennings) carriage, and repeating his (Dashwood) hope of being able to call on them the next day, took leave.

His (Dashwood) visit was duly paid. He (Dashwood) came with a pretence at an apology from their sister-in-law, for not coming too;

``but she (sister-in-law) was so much engaged with her (sister-in-law) mother, that really she (sister-in-law) had no leisure for going any where.'' (sister-in-law)
Mrs. Jennings, however, assured him (Dashwood) directly, that she (Jennings) should not stand upon ceremony, for they were all cousins, or something like it, and she (Jennings) should certainly wait on Mrs. John Dashwood very soon, and bring her (Dashwood) sisters to see her (Dashwood). His (Dashwood) manners to THEM, though calm, were perfectly kind; to Mrs. Jennings, most attentively civil; and on Colonel Brandon's coming in soon after himself, he (Colonel) eyed him (Colonel) with a curiosity which seemed to say, that he (Colonel) only wanted to know him (Colonel) to be rich, to be equally civil to HIM.

After staying with them half an hour, he (Colonel) asked Elinor to walk with him (Colonel) to Conduit Street, and introduce him (Colonel) to Sir John and Lady Middleton. The weather was remarkably fine, and she (Middleton) readily consented. As soon as they were out of the house, his (Colonel) enquiries began.

``Who is Colonel Brandon? Is he (Colonel) a man of fortune?'' (unknown)

``Yes; he (Colonel) has very good property in Dorsetshire.'' (unknown)

``I am glad of it. He (Colonel) seems a most gentlemanlike man; and I think, Elinor, I may congratulate you on the prospect of a very respectable establishment in life.'' (unknown)

``Me, brother! what do you mean?'' (unknown)

``He (brother) likes you. I observed him (brother) narrowly, and am convinced of it. What is the amount of his (brother) fortune?'' (unknown)

``I believe about two thousand a year.'' (unknown)

``Two thousand a-year;'' (he)
and then working himself up to a pitch of enthusiastic generosity, he (brother) added,
``Elinor, I wish with all my heart it were TWICE as much, for your sake.'' (he)

``Indeed I believe you,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor;
``but I am very sure that Colonel Brandon has not the smallest wish of marrying ME.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``You are mistaken, Elinor; you are very much mistaken. A very little trouble on your side secures him (Colonel). Perhaps just at present he (Colonel) may be undecided; the smallness of your fortune may make him (Colonel) hang back; his (Colonel) friends may all advise him (Colonel) against it. But some of those little attentions and encouragements which ladies can so easily give will fix him (Colonel), in spite of himself. And there can be no reason why you should not try for him (Colonel). It is not to be supposed that any prior attachment on your side--in short, you know as to an attachment of that kind, it is quite out of the question, the objections are insurmountable--you have too much sense not to see all that. Colonel Brandon must be the man; and no civility shall be wanting on my part to make him (Colonel) pleased with you and your family. It is a match that must give universal satisfaction. In short, it is a kind of thing that'' (unknown)
--lowering his (Colonel) voice to an important whisper--
``will be exceedingly welcome to ALL PARTIES.'' (he)
Recollecting himself, however, he (Colonel) added,
``That is, I mean to say--your friends are all truly anxious to see you well settled; Fanny particularly, for she (Fanny) has your interest very much at heart, I assure you. And her (Fanny) mother too, Mrs. Ferrars, a very good-natured woman, I am sure it would give her (Fanny) great pleasure; she (Fanny) said as much the other day.'' (he)

Elinor would not vouchsafe any answer.

``It would be something remarkable, now,'' (he)
he (Colonel) continued,
``something droll, if Fanny should have a brother and I a sister settling at the same time. And yet it is not very unlikely.'' (he)

``Is Mr. Edward Ferrars,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, with resolution,
``going to be married?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``It is not actually settled, but there is such a thing in agitation. He (Ferrars) has a most excellent mother. Mrs. Ferrars, with the utmost liberality, will come forward, and settle on him (Ferrars) a thousand a year, if the match takes place. The lady is the Hon. Miss Morton, only daughter of the late Lord Morton, with thirty thousand pounds. A very desirable connection on both sides, and I have not a doubt of its taking place in time. A thousand a-year is a great deal for a mother to give away, to make over for ever; but Mrs. Ferrars has a noble spirit. To give you another instance of her (Ferrars) liberality:--The other day, as soon as we came to town, aware that money could not be very plenty with us just now, she (Ferrars) put bank-notes into Fanny's hands to the amount of two hundred pounds. And extremely acceptable it is, for we must live at a great expense while we are here.'' (He)

He (Fanny) paused for her (Ferrars) assent and compassion; and she (Ferrars) forced herself to say,

``Your expenses both in town and country must certainly be considerable; but your income is a large one.'' (she)

``Not so large, I dare say, as many people suppose. I do not mean to complain, however; it is undoubtedly a comfortable one, and I hope will in time be better. The enclosure of Norland Common, now carrying on, is a most serious drain. And then I have made a little purchase within this half year; East Kingham Farm, you must remember the place, where old Gibson used to live. The land was so very desirable for me in every respect, so immediately adjoining my own property, that I felt it my duty to buy it. I could not have answered it to my conscience to let it fall into any other hands. A man must pay for his (man) convenience; and it HAS cost me a vast deal of money.'' (unknown)

``More than you think it really and intrinsically worth.'' (unknown)

``Why, I hope not that. I might have sold it again, the next day, for more than I gave: but, with regard to the purchase-money, I might have been very unfortunate indeed; for the stocks were at that time so low, that if I had not happened to have the necessary sum in my banker's hands, I must have sold out to very great loss.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor could only smile.

``Other great and inevitable expenses too we have had on first coming to Norland. Our respected father, as you well know, bequeathed all the Stanhill effects that remained at Norland -LRB-and very valuable they were-RRB- to your mother. Far be it from me to repine at his (father) doing so; he (father) had an undoubted right to dispose of his (father) own property as he (father) chose, but, in consequence of it, we have been obliged to make large purchases of linen, china, &c. to supply the place of what was taken away. You may guess, after all these expenses, how very far we must be from being rich, and how acceptable Mrs. Ferrars's kindness is.'' (unknown)

``Certainly,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``and assisted by her (Elinor) liberality, I hope you may yet live to be in easy circumstances.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Another year or two may do much towards it,'' (he)
he (Elinor) gravely replied;
``but however there is still a great deal to be done. There is not a stone laid of Fanny's green-house, and nothing but the plan of the flower-garden marked out.'' (he)

``Where is the green-house to be?'' (unknown)

``Upon the knoll behind the house. The old walnut trees are all come down to make room for it. It will be a very fine object from many parts of the park, and the flower-garden will slope down just before it, and be exceedingly pretty. We have cleared away all the old thorns that grew in patches over the brow.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor kept her (Elinor) concern and her (Elinor) censure to herself; and was very thankful that Marianne was not present, to share the provocation.

Having now said enough to make his (Marianne) poverty clear, and to do away the necessity of buying a pair of ear-rings for each of his (Marianne) sisters, in his (Marianne) next visit at Gray's his (Marianne) thoughts took a cheerfuller turn, and he (Marianne) began to congratulate Elinor on having such a friend as Mrs. Jennings.

``She (Jennings) seems a most valuable woman indeed--Her (Jennings) house, her (Jennings) style of living, all bespeak an exceeding good income; and it is an acquaintance that has not only been of great use to you hitherto, but in the end may prove materially advantageous.--Her (Jennings) inviting you to town is certainly a vast thing in your favour; and indeed, it speaks altogether so great a regard for you, that in all probability when she (Jennings) dies you will not be forgotten.-- She (Jennings) must have a great deal to leave.'' (unknown)

``Nothing at all, I should rather suppose; for she (Jennings) has only her (Jennings) jointure, which will descend to her (Jennings) children.'' (unknown)

``But it is not to be imagined that she (Jennings) lives up to her (Jennings) income. Few people of common prudence will do THAT; and whatever she (Jennings) saves, she (Jennings) will be able to dispose of.'' (unknown)

``And do you not think it more likely that she (Jennings) should leave it to her (Jennings) daughters, than to us?'' (unknown)

``Her (Jennings) daughters are both exceedingly well married, and therefore I cannot perceive the necessity of her (Jennings) remembering them farther. Whereas, in my opinion, by her (Jennings) taking so much notice of you, and treating you in this kind of way, she (Jennings) has given you a sort of claim on her (Jennings) future consideration, which a conscientious woman would not disregard. Nothing can be kinder than her (Jennings) behaviour; and she (Jennings) can hardly do all this, without being aware of the expectation it raises.'' (unknown)

``But she (Jennings) raises none in those most concerned. Indeed, brother, your anxiety for our welfare and prosperity carries you too far.'' (unknown)

``Why, to be sure,'' (he)
said he (brother), seeming to recollect himself,
``people have little, have very little in their power. But, my dear Elinor, what is the matter with Marianne?-- she (Marianne) looks very unwell, has lost her (Marianne) colour, and is grown quite thin. Is she (Marianne) ill?'' (he)

``She (Marianne) is not well, she (Marianne) has had a nervous complaint on her (Marianne) for several weeks.'' (unknown)

``I am sorry for that. At her (Marianne) time of life, any thing of an illness destroys the bloom for ever! Hers has been a very short one! She (Marianne) was as handsome a girl last September, as I ever saw; and as likely to attract the man. There was something in her (Marianne) style of beauty, to please them particularly. I remember Fanny used to say that she (Fanny) would marry sooner and better than you did; not but what she (Fanny) is exceedingly fond of YOU, but so it happened to strike her (Fanny). She (Fanny) will be mistaken, however. I question whether Marianne NOW, will marry a man worth more than five or six hundred a-year, at the utmost, and I am very much deceived if YOU do not do better. Dorsetshire! I know very little of Dorsetshire; but, my dear Elinor, I shall be exceedingly glad to know more of it; and I think I can answer for your having Fanny and myself among the earliest and best pleased of your visitors.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor tried very seriously to convince him (man) that there was no likelihood of her (Elinor) marrying Colonel Brandon; but it was an expectation of too much pleasure to himself to be relinquished, and he (Colonel) was really resolved on seeking an intimacy with that gentleman, and promoting the marriage by every possible attention. He (Colonel) had just compunction enough for having done nothing for his (Colonel) sisters himself, to be exceedingly anxious that everybody else should do a great deal; and an offer from Colonel Brandon, or a legacy from Mrs. Jennings, was the easiest means of atoning for his (Colonel) own neglect.

They were lucky enough to find Lady Middleton at home, and Sir John came in before their visit ended. Abundance of civilities passed on all sides. Sir John was ready to like anybody, and though Mr. Dashwood did not seem to know much about horses, he (Dashwood) soon set him (Dashwood) down as a very good-natured fellow: while Lady Middleton saw enough of fashion in his (Dashwood) appearance to think his (Dashwood) acquaintance worth having; and Mr. Dashwood went away delighted with both.

``I shall have a charming account to carry to Fanny,'' (he)
said he (Dashwood), as he (Dashwood) walked back with his (Dashwood) sister.
``Lady Middleton is really a most elegant woman! Such a woman as I am sure Fanny will be glad to know. And Mrs. Jennings too, an exceedingly well-behaved woman, though not so elegant as her (woman) daughter. Your sister need not have any scruple even of visiting HER, which, to say the truth, has been a little the case, and very naturally; for we only knew that Mrs. Jennings was the widow of a man who had got all his (man) money in a low way; and Fanny and Mrs. Ferrars were both strongly prepossessed, that neither she (Ferrars) nor her (Ferrars) daughters were such kind of women as Fanny would like to associate with. But now I can carry her (Fanny) a most satisfactory account of both.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

CHAPTER 34

Mrs. John Dashwood had so much confidence in her (Dashwood) husband's judgment, that she (Dashwood) waited the very next day both on Mrs. Jennings and her (Jennings) daughter; and her (Jennings) confidence was rewarded by finding even the former, even the woman with whom her (woman) sisters were staying, by no means unworthy her (woman) notice; and as for Lady Middleton, she (Middleton) found her (Middleton) one of the most charming women in the world!

Lady Middleton was equally pleased with Mrs. Dashwood. There was a kind of cold hearted selfishness on both sides, which mutually attracted them; and they sympathised with each other in an insipid propriety of demeanor, and a general want of understanding.

The same manners, however, which recommended Mrs. John Dashwood to the good opinion of Lady Middleton did not suit the fancy of Mrs. Jennings, and to HER she (Jennings) appeared nothing more than a little proud-looking woman of uncordial address, who met her (woman) husband's sisters without any affection, and almost without having anything to say to them; for of the quarter of an hour bestowed on Berkeley Street, she (woman) sat at least seven minutes and a half in silence.

Elinor wanted very much to know, though she (Elinor) did not chuse to ask, whether Edward was then in town; but nothing would have induced Fanny voluntarily to mention his (Edward) name before her (Fanny), till able to tell her (Fanny) that his (Edward) marriage with Miss Morton was resolved on, or till her (Fanny) husband's expectations on Colonel Brandon were answered; because she (Fanny) believed them still so very much attached to each other, that they could not be too sedulously divided in word and deed on every occasion. The intelligence however, which SHE would not give, soon flowed from another quarter. Lucy came very shortly to claim Elinor's compassion on being unable to see Edward, though he (Edward) had arrived in town with Mr. and Mrs. Dashwood. He (Edward) dared not come to Bartlett's Buildings for fear of detection, and though their mutual impatience to meet, was not to be told, they could do nothing at present but write.

Edward assured them himself of his (Edward) being in town, within a very short time, by twice calling in Berkeley Street. Twice was his (Edward) card found on the table, when they returned from their morning's engagements. Elinor was pleased that he (Edward) had called; and still more pleased that she (Elinor) had missed him (Edward).

The Dashwoods were so prodigiously delighted with the Middletons, that, though not much in the habit of giving anything, they determined to give them--a dinner; and soon after their acquaintance began, invited them to dine in Harley Street, where they had taken a very good house for three months. Their sisters and Mrs. Jennings were invited likewise, and John Dashwood was careful to secure Colonel Brandon, who, always glad to be where the Miss Dashwoods were, received his (Colonel) eager civilities with some surprise, but much more pleasure. They were to meet Mrs. Ferrars; but Elinor could not learn whether her (Elinor) sons were to be of the party. The expectation of seeing HER, however, was enough to make her (Elinor) interested in the engagement; for though she (Elinor) could now meet Edward's mother without that strong anxiety which had once promised to attend such an introduction, though she (Elinor) could now see her (Elinor) with perfect indifference as to her (Elinor) opinion of herself, her (Elinor) desire of being in company with Mrs. Ferrars, her (Ferrars) curiosity to know what she (Ferrars) was like, was as lively as ever.

The interest with which she (Ferrars) thus anticipated the party, was soon afterwards increased, more powerfully than pleasantly, by her (Ferrars) hearing that the Miss Steeles were also to be at it.

So well had they recommended themselves to Lady Middleton, so agreeable had their assiduities made them to her (Middleton), that though Lucy was certainly not so elegant, and her (Lucy) sister not even genteel, she (Lucy) was as ready as Sir John to ask them to spend a week or two in Conduit Street; and it happened to be particularly convenient to the Miss Steeles, as soon as the Dashwoods' invitation was known, that their visit should begin a few days before the party took place.

Their claims to the notice of Mrs. John Dashwood, as the nieces of the gentleman who for many years had had the care of her (Dashwood) brother, might not have done much, however, towards procuring them seats at her (Dashwood) table; but as Lady Middleton's guests they must be welcome; and Lucy, who had long wanted to be personally known to the family, to have a nearer view of their characters and her (Lucy) own difficulties, and to have an opportunity of endeavouring to please them, had seldom been happier in her (Lucy) life, than she (Lucy) was on receiving Mrs. John Dashwood's card.

On Elinor its effect was very different. She (Elinor) began immediately to determine, that Edward who lived with his (Edward) mother, must be asked as his (Edward) mother was, to a party given by his (Edward) sister; and to see him (Edward) for the first time, after all that passed, in the company of Lucy!--she (Lucy) hardly knew how she (Lucy) could bear it!

These apprehensions, perhaps, were not founded entirely on reason, and certainly not at all on truth. They were relieved however, not by her (Lucy) own recollection, but by the good will of Lucy, who believed herself to be inflicting a severe disappointment when she (Lucy) told her (Lucy) that Edward certainly would not be in Harley Street on Tuesday, and even hoped to be carrying the pain still farther by persuading her (Lucy) that he (Edward) was kept away by the extreme affection for herself, which he (Edward) could not conceal when they were together.

The important Tuesday came that was to introduce the two young ladies to this formidable mother-in-law.

``Pity me, dear Miss Dashwood!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Lucy, as they walked up the stairs together--for the Middletons arrived so directly after Mrs. Jennings, that they all followed the servant at the same time--
``There is nobody here but you, that can feel for me.--I declare I can hardly stand. Good gracious!--In a moment I shall see the person that all my happiness depends on--that is to be my mother!'' (the servant)
--

Elinor could have given her (Elinor) immediate relief by suggesting the possibility of its being Miss Morton's mother, rather than her (mother) own, whom they were about to behold; but instead of doing that, she (mother) assured her (mother), and with great sincerity, that she (mother) did pity her (mother)--to the utter amazement of Lucy, who, though really uncomfortable herself, hoped at least to be an object of irrepressible envy to Elinor.

Mrs. Ferrars was a little, thin woman, upright, even to formality, in her (Ferrars) figure, and serious, even to sourness, in her (Ferrars) aspect. Her (Ferrars) complexion was sallow; and her (Ferrars) features small, without beauty, and naturally without expression; but a lucky contraction of the brow had rescued her (Ferrars) countenance from the disgrace of insipidity, by giving it the strong characters of pride and ill nature. She (Ferrars) was not a woman of many words; for, unlike people in general, she (Ferrars) proportioned them to the number of her (Ferrars) ideas; and of the few syllables that did escape her (Ferrars), not one fell to the share of Miss Dashwood, whom she (Dashwood) eyed with the spirited determination of disliking her (Dashwood) at all events.

Elinor could not NOW be made unhappy by this behaviour.-- A few months ago it would have hurt her (Elinor) exceedingly; but it was not in Mrs. Ferrars' power to distress her (Ferrars) by it now;--and the difference of her (Ferrars) manners to the Miss Steeles, a difference which seemed purposely made to humble her (Ferrars) more, only amused her (Ferrars). She (Ferrars) could not but smile to see the graciousness of both mother and daughter towards the very person-- for Lucy was particularly distinguished--whom of all others, had they known as much as she (Lucy) did, they would have been most anxious to mortify; while she (Lucy) herself, who had comparatively no power to wound them, sat pointedly slighted by both. But while she (Lucy) smiled at a graciousness so misapplied, she (Lucy) could not reflect on the mean-spirited folly from which it sprung, nor observe the studied attentions with which the Miss Steeles courted its continuance, without thoroughly despising them all four.

Lucy was all exultation on being so honorably distinguished; and Miss Steele wanted only to be teazed about Dr. Davies to be perfectly happy.

The dinner was a grand one, the servants were numerous, and every thing bespoke the Mistress's inclination for show, and the Master's ability to support it. In spite of the improvements and additions which were making to the Norland estate, and in spite of its owner having once been within some thousand pounds of being obliged to sell out at a loss, nothing gave any symptom of that indigence which he (owner) had tried to infer from it;--no poverty of any kind, except of conversation, appeared--but there, the deficiency was considerable. John Dashwood had not much to say for himself that was worth hearing, and his (owner) wife had still less. But there was no peculiar disgrace in this; for it was very much the case with the chief of their visitors, who almost all laboured under one or other of these disqualifications for being agreeable--Want of sense, either natural or improved--want of elegance--want of spirits--or want of temper.

When the ladies withdrew to the drawing-room after dinner, this poverty was particularly evident, for the gentlemen HAD supplied the discourse with some variety--the variety of politics, inclosing land, and breaking horses--but then it was all over; and one subject only engaged the ladies till coffee came in, which was the comparative heights of Harry Dashwood, and Lady Middleton's second son William, who were nearly of the same age.

Had both the children been there, the affair might have been determined too easily by measuring them at once; but as Harry only was present, it was all conjectural assertion on both sides; and every body had a right to be equally positive in their opinion, and to repeat it over and over again as often as they liked.

The parties stood thus:

The two mothers, though each really convinced that her (Middleton) own son was the tallest, politely decided in favour of the other.

The two grandmothers, with not less partiality, but more sincerity, were equally earnest in support of their own descendant.

Lucy, who was hardly less anxious to please one parent than the other, thought the boys were both remarkably tall for their age, and could not conceive that there could be the smallest difference in the world between them; and Miss Steele, with yet greater address gave it, as fast as she (Steele) could, in favour of each.

Elinor, having once delivered her (Elinor) opinion on William's side, by which she (Elinor) offended Mrs. Ferrars and Fanny still more, did not see the necessity of enforcing it by any farther assertion; and Marianne, when called on for hers, offended them all, by declaring that she (Marianne) had no opinion to give, as she (Marianne) had never thought about it.

Before her (Marianne) removing from Norland, Elinor had painted a very pretty pair of screens for her (Elinor) sister-in-law, which being now just mounted and brought home, ornamented her (Elinor) present drawing room; and these screens, catching the eye of John Dashwood on his (Elinor) following the other gentlemen into the room, were officiously handed by him (Elinor) to Colonel Brandon for his (Colonel) admiration.

``These are done by my eldest sister,'' (he)
said he (Colonel);
``and you, as a man of taste, will, I dare say, be pleased with them. I do not know whether you have ever happened to see any of her (sister) performances before, but she (sister) is in general reckoned to draw extremely well.'' (he)

The Colonel, though disclaiming all pretensions to connoisseurship, warmly admired the screens, as he (Colonel) would have done any thing painted by Miss Dashwood; and on the curiosity of the others being of course excited, they were handed round for general inspection. Mrs. Ferrars, not aware of their being Elinor's work, particularly requested to look at them; and after they had received gratifying testimony of Lady Middletons's approbation, Fanny presented them to her (Fanny) mother, considerately informing her (Fanny), at the same time, that they were done by Miss Dashwood.

``Hum'' (Mrs. Ferrars/Robert/Mrs. Robert Ferrars)
--said Mrs. Ferrars--
``very pretty,'' (Mrs. Ferrars/Robert/Mrs. Robert Ferrars)
--and without regarding them at all, returned them to her (Ferrars) daughter.

Perhaps Fanny thought for a moment that her (Fanny) mother had been quite rude enough,--for, colouring a little, she (Fanny) immediately said,

``They are very pretty, ma'am--an't they?'' (she)
But then again, the dread of having been too civil, too encouraging herself, probably came over her (Fanny), for she (Fanny) presently added,

``Do you not think they are something in Miss Morton's style of painting, Ma'am?--She (Morton) DOES paint most delightfully!--How beautifully her (Morton) last landscape is done!'' (she)

``Beautifully indeed! But SHE does every thing well.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne could not bear this.--She (Marianne) was already greatly displeased with Mrs. Ferrars; and such ill-timed praise of another, at Elinor's expense, though she (Elinor) had not any notion of what was principally meant by it, provoked her (Elinor) immediately to say with warmth,

``This is admiration of a very particular kind!--what is Miss Morton to us?--who knows, or who cares, for her (Morton)?--it is Elinor of whom WE think and speak.'' (she)

And so saying, she (Elinor) took the screens out of her (Elinor) sister-in-law's hands, to admire them herself as they ought to be admired.

Mrs. Ferrars looked exceedingly angry, and drawing herself up more stiffly than ever, pronounced in retort this bitter philippic,

``Miss Morton is Lord Morton's daughter.'' (Mrs. Ferrars/Robert/Mrs. Robert Ferrars)

Fanny looked very angry too, and her (Fanny) husband was all in a fright at his (husband) sister's audacity. Elinor was much more hurt by Marianne's warmth than she (Elinor) had been by what produced it; but Colonel Brandon's eyes, as they were fixed on Marianne, declared that he (Colonel) noticed only what was amiable in it, the affectionate heart which could not bear to see a sister slighted in the smallest point.

Marianne's feelings did not stop here. The cold insolence of Mrs. Ferrars's general behaviour to her (Ferrars) sister, seemed, to her (Ferrars), to foretell such difficulties and distresses to Elinor, as her (Elinor) own wounded heart taught her (Elinor) to think of with horror; and urged by a strong impulse of affectionate sensibility, she (Elinor) moved after a moment, to her (Elinor) sister's chair, and putting one arm round her (Elinor) neck, and one cheek close to hers, said in a low, but eager, voice,

``Dear, dear Elinor, don't mind them. Don't let them make YOU unhappy.'' (sister)

She (Elinor) could say no more; her (Elinor) spirits were quite overcome, and hiding her (Elinor) face on Elinor's shoulder, she (Elinor) burst into tears. Every body's attention was called, and almost every body was concerned.--Colonel Brandon rose up and went to them without knowing what he (Colonel) did.--Mrs. Jennings, with a very intelligent

``Ah! poor dear,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
immediately gave her (Jennings) her (Jennings) salts; and Sir John felt so desperately enraged against the author of this nervous distress, that he (author) instantly changed his (author) seat to one close by Lucy Steele, and gave her (Steele), in a whisper, a brief account of the whole shocking affair.

In a few minutes, however, Marianne was recovered enough to put an end to the bustle, and sit down among the rest; though her (Marianne) spirits retained the impression of what had passed, the whole evening.

``Poor Marianne!'' (brother)
said her (Marianne) brother to Colonel Brandon, in a low voice, as soon as he (Colonel) could secure his (Colonel) attention,--
``She (Marianne) has not such good health as her (Marianne) sister,--she (Marianne) is very nervous,--she (Marianne) has not Elinor's constitution;--and one must allow that there is something very trying to a young woman who HAS BEEN a beauty in the loss of her (woman) personal attractions. You would not think it perhaps, but Marianne WAS remarkably handsome a few months ago; quite as handsome as Elinor.-- Now you see it is all gone.'' (he)

CHAPTER 35

Elinor's curiosity to see Mrs. Ferrars was satisfied.-- She (Elinor) had found in her (Elinor) every thing that could tend to make a farther connection between the families undesirable.-- She (Elinor) had seen enough of her (Elinor) pride, her (Elinor) meanness, and her (Elinor) determined prejudice against herself, to comprehend all the difficulties that must have perplexed the engagement, and retarded the marriage, of Edward and herself, had he (Edward) been otherwise free;--and she (Elinor) had seen almost enough to be thankful for her (Elinor) OWN sake, that one greater obstacle preserved her (Elinor) from suffering under any other of Mrs. Ferrars's creation, preserved her (Ferrars) from all dependence upon her (Ferrars) caprice, or any solicitude for her (Ferrars) good opinion. Or at least, if she (Ferrars) did not bring herself quite to rejoice in Edward's being fettered to Lucy, she (Lucy) determined, that had Lucy been more amiable, she (Lucy) OUGHT to have rejoiced.

She (Lucy) wondered that Lucy's spirits could be so very much elevated by the civility of Mrs. Ferrars;--that her (Ferrars) interest and her (Ferrars) vanity should so very much blind her (Ferrars) as to make the attention which seemed only paid her (Ferrars) because she (Ferrars) was NOT ELINOR, appear a compliment to herself--or to allow her (ELINOR) to derive encouragement from a preference only given her (ELINOR), because her (ELINOR) real situation was unknown. But that it was so, had not only been declared by Lucy's eyes at the time, but was declared over again the next morning more openly, for at her (Lucy) particular desire, Lady Middleton set her (Middleton) down in Berkeley Street on the chance of seeing Elinor alone, to tell her (Elinor) how happy she (Elinor) was.

The chance proved a lucky one, for a message from Mrs. Palmer soon after she (Palmer) arrived, carried Mrs. Jennings away.

``My dear friend,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Lucy, as soon as they were by themselves,
``I come to talk to you of my happiness. Could anything be so flattering as Mrs. Ferrars's way of treating me yesterday? So exceeding affable as she (Ferrars) was!--You know how I dreaded the thoughts of seeing her (Ferrars);--but the very moment I was introduced, there was such an affability in her (Ferrars) behaviour as really should seem to say, she (Ferrars) had quite took a fancy to me. Now was not it so?-- You saw it all; and was not you quite struck with it?'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

``She (Ferrars) was certainly very civil to you.'' (unknown)

``Civil!--Did you see nothing but only civility?-- I saw a vast deal more. Such kindness as fell to the share of nobody but me!--No pride, no hauteur, and your sister just the same--all sweetness and affability!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor wished to talk of something else, but Lucy still pressed her (Lucy) to own that she (Lucy) had reason for her (Lucy) happiness; and Elinor was obliged to go on.--

``Undoubtedly, if they had known your engagement,'' (she)
said she (Elinor),
``nothing could be more flattering than their treatment of you;--but as that was not the case'' (she)
--

``I guessed you would say so,'' (she)
--replied Lucy quickly--
``but there was no reason in the world why Mrs. Ferrars should seem to like me, if she (Ferrars) did not, and her (Ferrars) liking me is every thing. You shan't talk me out of my satisfaction. I am sure it will all end well, and there will be no difficulties at all, to what I used to think. Mrs. Ferrars is a charming woman, and so is your sister. They are both delightful women, indeed!--I wonder I should never hear you say how agreeable Mrs. Dashwood was!'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)

To this Elinor had no answer to make, and did not attempt any.

``Are you ill, Miss Dashwood?--you seem low--you don't speak;--sure you an't well.'' (unknown)

``I never was in better health.'' (unknown)

``I am glad of it with all my heart; but really you did not look it. I should be sorry to have YOU ill; you, that have been the greatest comfort to me in the world!--Heaven knows what I should have done without your friendship.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
--

Elinor tried to make a civil answer, though doubting her (Elinor) own success. But it seemed to satisfy Lucy, for she (Lucy) directly replied,

``Indeed I am perfectly convinced of your regard for me, and next to Edward's love, it is the greatest comfort I have.--Poor Edward!--But now there is one good thing, we shall be able to meet, and meet pretty often, for Lady Middleton's delighted with Mrs. Dashwood, so we shall be a good deal in Harley Street, I dare say, and Edward spends half his (Edward) time with his (Edward) sister--besides, Lady Middleton and Mrs. Ferrars will visit now;--and Mrs. Ferrars and your sister were both so good to say more than once, they should always be glad to see me.-- They are such charming women!--I am sure if ever you tell your sister what I think of her (sister), you cannot speak too high.'' (she)

But Elinor would not give her (Elinor) any encouragement to hope that she (Elinor) SHOULD tell her (Elinor) sister. Lucy continued.

``I am sure I should have seen it in a moment, if Mrs. Ferrars had took a dislike to me. If she (Ferrars) had only made me a formal courtesy, for instance, without saying a word, and never after had took any notice of me, and never looked at me in a pleasant way--you know what I mean--if I had been treated in that forbidding sort of way, I should have gave it all up in despair. I could not have stood it. For where she (Ferrars) DOES dislike, I know it is most violent.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was prevented from making any reply to this civil triumph, by the door's being thrown open, the servant's announcing Mr. Ferrars, and Edward's immediately walking in.

It was a very awkward moment; and the countenance of each shewed that it was so.
