They all looked exceedingly foolish; and Edward seemed to have as great an inclination to walk out of the room again, as to advance farther into it. The very circumstance, in its unpleasantest form, which they would each have been most anxious to avoid, had fallen on them.--They were not only all three together, but were together without the relief of any other person. The ladies recovered themselves first. It was not Lucy's business to put herself forward, and the appearance of secrecy must still be kept up. She (Lucy) could therefore only LOOK her (Lucy) tenderness, and after slightly addressing him (themselves), said no more.

But Elinor had more to do; and so anxious was she (Elinor), for his (themselves) sake and her (Elinor) own, to do it well, that she (Elinor) forced herself, after a moment's recollection, to welcome him (themselves), with a look and manner that were almost easy, and almost open; and another struggle, another effort still improved them. She (Elinor) would not allow the presence of Lucy, nor the consciousness of some injustice towards herself, to deter her (Lucy) from saying that she (Lucy) was happy to see him (themselves), and that she (Lucy) had very much regretted being from home, when he (themselves) called before in Berkeley Street. She (Lucy) would not be frightened from paying him (themselves) those attentions which, as a friend and almost a relation, were his (friend) due, by the observant eyes of Lucy, though she (Lucy) soon perceived them to be narrowly watching her (Lucy).

Her (Lucy) manners gave some re-assurance to Edward, and he (Edward) had courage enough to sit down; but his (Edward) embarrassment still exceeded that of the ladies in a proportion, which the case rendered reasonable, though his (Edward) sex might make it rare; for his (Edward) heart had not the indifference of Lucy's, nor could his (Edward) conscience have quite the ease of Elinor's.

Lucy, with a demure and settled air, seemed determined to make no contribution to the comfort of the others, and would not say a word; and almost every thing that WAS said, proceeded from Elinor, who was obliged to volunteer all the information about her (Elinor) mother's health, their coming to town, &c. which Edward ought to have inquired about, but never did.

Her (Elinor) exertions did not stop here; for she (Elinor) soon afterwards felt herself so heroically disposed as to determine, under pretence of fetching Marianne, to leave the others by themselves; and she (Marianne) really did it, and THAT in the handsomest manner, for she (Marianne) loitered away several minutes on the landing-place, with the most high-minded fortitude, before she (Marianne) went to her (Marianne) sister. When that was once done, however, it was time for the raptures of Edward to cease; for Marianne's joy hurried her (Marianne) into the drawing-room immediately. Her (Marianne) pleasure in seeing him (Edward) was like every other of her (Marianne) feelings, strong in itself, and strongly spoken. She (Marianne) met him (Edward) with a hand that would be taken, and a voice that expressed the affection of a sister.

``Dear Edward!'' (she)
she (sister) cried,
``this is a moment of great happiness!--This would almost make amends for every thing?'' (she)

Edward tried to return her (sister) kindness as it deserved, but before such witnesses he (Edward) dared not say half what he (Edward) really felt. Again they all sat down, and for a moment or two all were silent; while Marianne was looking with the most speaking tenderness, sometimes at Edward and sometimes at Elinor, regretting only that their delight in each other should be checked by Lucy's unwelcome presence. Edward was the first to speak, and it was to notice Marianne's altered looks, and express his (Edward) fear of her (Marianne) not finding London agree with her (Marianne).

``Oh, don't think of me!'' (she)
she (Marianne) replied with spirited earnestness, though her (Marianne) eyes were filled with tears as she (Marianne) spoke,
``don't think of MY health. Elinor is well, you see. That must be enough for us both.'' (she)

This remark was not calculated to make Edward or Elinor more easy, nor to conciliate the good will of Lucy, who looked up at Marianne with no very benignant expression.

``Do you like London?'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
said Edward, willing to say any thing that might introduce another subject.

``Not at all. I expected much pleasure in it, but I have found none. The sight of you, Edward, is the only comfort it has afforded; and thank Heaven! you are what you always were!'' (She)

She (Marianne) paused--no one spoke.

``I think, Elinor,'' (she)
she (Elinor) presently added,
``we must employ Edward to take care of us in our return to Barton. In a week or two, I suppose, we shall be going; and, I trust, Edward will not be very unwilling to accept the charge.'' (she)

Poor Edward muttered something, but what it was, nobody knew, not even himself. But Marianne, who saw his (Edward) agitation, and could easily trace it to whatever cause best pleased herself, was perfectly satisfied, and soon talked of something else.

``We spent such a day, Edward, in Harley Street yesterday! So dull, so wretchedly dull!--But I have much to say to you on that head, which cannot be said now.'' (she)

And with this admirable discretion did she (Marianne) defer the assurance of her (Marianne) finding their mutual relatives more disagreeable than ever, and of her (Marianne) being particularly disgusted with his (Edward) mother, till they were more in private.

``But why were you not there, Edward?--Why did you not come?'' (unknown)

``I was engaged elsewhere.'' (unknown)

``Engaged! But what was that, when such friends were to be met?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps, Miss Marianne,'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
cried Lucy, eager to take some revenge on her (Marianne),
``you think young men never stand upon engagements, if they have no mind to keep them, little as well as great.'' (her)

Elinor was very angry, but Marianne seemed entirely insensible of the sting; for she (Marianne) calmly replied,

``Not so, indeed; for, seriously speaking, I am very sure that conscience only kept Edward from Harley Street. And I really believe he (Edward) HAS the most delicate conscience in the world; the most scrupulous in performing every engagement, however minute, and however it may make against his (Edward) interest or pleasure. He (Edward) is the most fearful of giving pain, of wounding expectation, and the most incapable of being selfish, of any body I ever saw. Edward, it is so, and I will say it. What! are you never to hear yourself praised!--Then you must be no friend of mine; for those who will accept of my love and esteem, must submit to my open commendation.'' (she)

The nature of her (it) commendation, in the present case, however, happened to be particularly ill-suited to the feelings of two thirds of her (it) auditors, and was so very unexhilarating to Edward, that he (Edward) very soon got up to go away.

``Going so soon!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne;
``my dear Edward, this must not be.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

And drawing him (Edward) a little aside, she (Marianne) whispered her (Marianne) persuasion that Lucy could not stay much longer. But even this encouragement failed, for he (Edward) would go; and Lucy, who would have outstaid him (Edward), had his (Edward) visit lasted two hours, soon afterwards went away.

``What can bring her (Lucy) here so often?'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, on her (Marianne) leaving them.
``Could not she (Marianne) see that we wanted her (Marianne) gone!--how teazing to Edward!'' (unknown)

``Why so?--we were all his (Edward) friends, and Lucy has been the longest known to him (Edward) of any. It is but natural that he (Edward) should like to see her (Lucy) as well as ourselves.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne looked at her (Marianne) steadily, and said,

``You know, Elinor, that this is a kind of talking which I cannot bear. If you only hope to have your assertion contradicted, as I must suppose to be the case, you ought to recollect that I am the last person in the world to do it. I cannot descend to be tricked out of assurances, that are not really wanted.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

She (Elinor) then left the room; and Elinor dared not follow her (Elinor) to say more, for bound as she (Elinor) was by her (Elinor) promise of secrecy to Lucy, she (Lucy) could give no information that would convince Marianne; and painful as the consequences of her (Marianne) still continuing in an error might be, she (Marianne) was obliged to submit to it. All that she (Marianne) could hope, was that Edward would not often expose her (Marianne) or himself to the distress of hearing Marianne's mistaken warmth, nor to the repetition of any other part of the pain that had attended their recent meeting--and this she (Marianne) had every reason to expect.

CHAPTER 36

Within a few days after this meeting, the newspapers announced to the world, that the lady of Thomas Palmer, Esq. was safely delivered of a son and heir; a very interesting and satisfactory paragraph, at least to all those intimate connections who knew it before.

This event, highly important to Mrs. Jennings's happiness, produced a temporary alteration in the disposal of her (Jennings) time, and influenced, in a like degree, the engagements of her (Jennings) young friends; for as she (Jennings) wished to be as much as possible with Charlotte, she (Charlotte) went thither every morning as soon as she (Charlotte) was dressed, and did not return till late in the evening; and the Miss Dashwoods, at the particular request of the Middletons, spent the whole of every day in Conduit Street. For their own comfort they would much rather have remained, at least all the morning, in Mrs. Jennings's house; but it was not a thing to be urged against the wishes of everybody. Their hours were therefore made over to Lady Middleton and the two Miss Steeles, by whom their company, in fact was as little valued, as it was professedly sought.

They had too much sense to be desirable companions to the former; and by the latter they were considered with a jealous eye, as intruding on THEIR ground, and sharing the kindness which they wanted to monopolize. Though nothing could be more polite than Lady Middleton's behaviour to Elinor and Marianne, she (Marianne) did not really like them at all. Because they neither flattered herself nor her (Marianne) children, she (Marianne) could not believe them good-natured; and because they were fond of reading, she (Marianne) fancied them satirical: perhaps without exactly knowing what it was to be satirical; but THAT did not signify. It was censure in common use, and easily given.

Their presence was a restraint both on her (Marianne) and on Lucy. It checked the idleness of one, and the business of the other. Lady Middleton was ashamed of doing nothing before them, and the flattery which Lucy was proud to think of and administer at other times, she (Lucy) feared they would despise her (Lucy) for offering. Miss Steele was the least discomposed of the three, by their presence; and it was in their power to reconcile her (Steele) to it entirely. Would either of them only have given her (Steele) a full and minute account of the whole affair between Marianne and Mr. Willoughby, she (Marianne) would have thought herself amply rewarded for the sacrifice of the best place by the fire after dinner, which their arrival occasioned. But this conciliation was not granted; for though she (Marianne) often threw out expressions of pity for her (Marianne) sister to Elinor, and more than once dropt a reflection on the inconstancy of beaux before Marianne, no effect was produced, but a look of indifference from the former, or of disgust in the latter. An effort even yet lighter might have made her (Marianne) their friend. Would they only have laughed at her (Marianne) about the Doctor! But so little were they, anymore than the others, inclined to oblige her (Marianne), that if Sir John dined from home, she (John) might spend a whole day without hearing any other raillery on the subject, than what she (John) was kind enough to bestow on herself.

All these jealousies and discontents, however, were so totally unsuspected by Mrs. Jennings, that she (Jennings) thought it a delightful thing for the girls to be together; and generally congratulated her (Jennings) young friends every night, on having escaped the company of a stupid old woman so long. She (woman) joined them sometimes at Sir John's, sometimes at her (woman) own house; but wherever it was, she (woman) always came in excellent spirits, full of delight and importance, attributing Charlotte's well doing to her (Charlotte) own care, and ready to give so exact, so minute a detail of her (Charlotte) situation, as only Miss Steele had curiosity enough to desire. One thing DID disturb her (Steele); and of that she (Steele) made her (Steele) daily complaint. Mr. Palmer maintained the common, but unfatherly opinion among his (Palmer) sex, of all infants being alike; and though she (Steele) could plainly perceive, at different times, the most striking resemblance between this baby and every one of his (Palmer) relations on both sides, there was no convincing his (Palmer) father of it; no persuading him (Palmer) to believe that it was not exactly like every other baby of the same age; nor could he (Palmer) even be brought to acknowledge the simple proposition of its being the finest child in the world.

I come now to the relation of a misfortune, which about this time befell Mrs. John Dashwood. It so happened that while her (Dashwood) two sisters with Mrs. Jennings were first calling on her (Dashwood) in Harley Street, another of her (Dashwood) acquaintance had dropt in--a circumstance in itself not apparently likely to produce evil to her (Dashwood). But while the imaginations of other people will carry them away to form wrong judgments of our conduct, and to decide on it by slight appearances, one's happiness must in some measure be always at the mercy of chance. In the present instance, this last-arrived lady allowed her (lady) fancy to so far outrun truth and probability, that on merely hearing the name of the Miss Dashwoods, and understanding them to be Mr. Dashwood's sisters, she (lady) immediately concluded them to be staying in Harley Street; and this misconstruction produced within a day or two afterwards, cards of invitation for them as well as for their brother and sister, to a small musical party at her (sister) house. The consequence of which was, that Mrs. John Dashwood was obliged to submit not only to the exceedingly great inconvenience of sending her (Dashwood) carriage for the Miss Dashwoods, but, what was still worse, must be subject to all the unpleasantness of appearing to treat them with attention: and who could tell that they might not expect to go out with her (Dashwood) a second time? The power of disappointing them, it was true, must always be hers. But that was not enough; for when people are determined on a mode of conduct which they know to be wrong, they feel injured by the expectation of any thing better from them.

Marianne had now been brought by degrees, so much into the habit of going out every day, that it was become a matter of indifference to her (Marianne), whether she (Marianne) went or not: and she (Marianne) prepared quietly and mechanically for every evening's engagement, though without expecting the smallest amusement from any, and very often without knowing, till the last moment, where it was to take her (Marianne).

To her (Marianne) dress and appearance she (Marianne) was grown so perfectly indifferent, as not to bestow half the consideration on it, during the whole of her (Marianne) toilet, which it received from Miss Steele in the first five minutes of their being together, when it was finished. Nothing escaped HER minute observation and general curiosity; she (Steele) saw every thing, and asked every thing; was never easy till she (Steele) knew the price of every part of Marianne's dress; could have guessed the number of her (Marianne) gowns altogether with better judgment than Marianne herself, and was not without hopes of finding out before they parted, how much her (Marianne) washing cost per week, and how much she (Marianne) had every year to spend upon herself. The impertinence of these kind of scrutinies, moreover, was generally concluded with a compliment, which though meant as its douceur, was considered by Marianne as the greatest impertinence of all; for after undergoing an examination into the value and make of her (Marianne) gown, the colour of her (Marianne) shoes, and the arrangement of her (Marianne) hair, she (Marianne) was almost sure of being told that upon

``her (Marianne) word she (Marianne) looked vastly smart, and she (Marianne) dared to say she (Marianne) would make a great many conquests.'' (she)

With such encouragement as this, was she (Marianne) dismissed on the present occasion, to her (Marianne) brother's carriage; which they were ready to enter five minutes after it stopped at the door, a punctuality not very agreeable to their sister-in-law, who had preceded them to the house of her (sister-in-law) acquaintance, and was there hoping for some delay on their part that might inconvenience either herself or her (sister-in-law) coachman.

The events of this evening were not very remarkable. The party, like other musical parties, comprehended a great many people who had real taste for the performance, and a great many more who had none at all; and the performers themselves were, as usual, in their own estimation, and that of their immediate friends, the first private performers in England.

As Elinor was neither musical, nor affecting to be so, she (Elinor) made no scruple of turning her (Elinor) eyes from the grand pianoforte, whenever it suited her (Elinor), and unrestrained even by the presence of a harp, and violoncello, would fix them at pleasure on any other object in the room. In one of these excursive glances she (Elinor) perceived among a group of young men, the very he (performers), who had given them a lecture on toothpick-cases at Gray's. She (Elinor) perceived him (Gray) soon afterwards looking at herself, and speaking familiarly to her (Elinor) brother; and had just determined to find out his (brother) name from the latter, when they both came towards her (Elinor), and Mr. Dashwood introduced him (Dashwood) to her (Elinor) as Mr. Robert Ferrars.

He (Ferrars) addressed her (Elinor) with easy civility, and twisted his (Ferrars) head into a bow which assured her (Elinor) as plainly as words could have done, that he (Ferrars) was exactly the coxcomb she (Elinor) had heard him (Ferrars) described to be by Lucy. Happy had it been for her (Lucy), if her (Lucy) regard for Edward had depended less on his (Edward) own merit, than on the merit of his (Edward) nearest relations! For then his (Edward) brother's bow must have given the finishing stroke to what the ill-humour of his (Edward) mother and sister would have begun. But while she (sister) wondered at the difference of the two young men, she (sister) did not find that the emptiness of conceit of the one, put her (sister) out of all charity with the modesty and worth of the other. Why they WERE different, Robert exclaimed to her (Robert) himself in the course of a quarter of an hour's conversation; for, talking of his (Edward) brother, and lamenting the extreme GAUCHERIE which he (Edward) really believed kept him (Edward) from mixing in proper society, he (Edward) candidly and generously attributed it much less to any natural deficiency, than to the misfortune of a private education; while he (Edward) himself, though probably without any particular, any material superiority by nature, merely from the advantage of a public school, was as well fitted to mix in the world as any other man.

``Upon my soul,'' (he)
he (man) added,
``I believe it is nothing more; and so I often tell my mother, when she (mother) is grieving about it. `My dear Madam,' I always say to her (mother), `you must make yourself easy. The evil is now irremediable, and it has been entirely your own doing. Why would you be persuaded by my uncle, Sir Robert, against your own judgment, to place Edward under private tuition, at the most critical time of his (Edward) life? If you had only sent him (Edward) to Westminster as well as myself, instead of sending him (Edward) to Mr. Pratt's, all this would have been prevented.' This is the way in which I always consider the matter, and my mother is perfectly convinced of her (mother) error.'' (he)

Elinor would not oppose his (Pratt) opinion, because, whatever might be her (Elinor) general estimation of the advantage of a public school, she (Elinor) could not think of Edward's abode in Mr. Pratt's family, with any satisfaction.

``You reside in Devonshire, I think,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
--was his (Pratt) next observation,
``in a cottage near Dawlish.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor set him (Pratt) right as to its situation; and it seemed rather surprising to him (Pratt) that anybody could live in Devonshire, without living near Dawlish. He (Pratt) bestowed his (Pratt) hearty approbation however on their species of house.

``For my own part,'' (he)
said he (Pratt), ``I am excessively fond of a cottage; there is always so much comfort, so much elegance about them. And I protest, if I had any money to spare, I should buy a little land and build one myself, within a short distance of London, where I might drive myself down at any time, and collect a few friends about me, and be happy. I advise every body who is going to build, to build a cottage. My friend Lord Courtland came to me the other day on purpose to ask my advice, and laid before me three different plans of Bonomi's. I was to decide on the best of them. `My dear Courtland,' said I, immediately throwing them all into the fire, `do not adopt either of them, but by all means build a cottage.' And that I fancy, will be the end of it.

``Some people imagine that there can be no accommodations, no space in a cottage; but this is all a mistake. I was last month at my friend Elliott's, near Dartford. Lady Elliott wished to give a dance. `But how can it be done?' said she (Elliott); `my dear Ferrars, do tell me how it is to be managed. There is not a room in this cottage that will hold ten couple, and where can the supper be?' I immediately saw that there could be no difficulty in it, so I said, `My dear Lady Elliott, do not be uneasy. The dining parlour will admit eighteen couple with ease; card-tables may be placed in the drawing-room; the library may be open for tea and other refreshments; and let the supper be set out in the saloon.' Lady Elliott was delighted with the thought. We measured the dining-room, and found it would hold exactly eighteen couple, and the affair was arranged precisely after my plan. So that, in fact, you see, if people do but know how to set about it, every comfort may be as well enjoyed in a cottage as in the most spacious dwelling.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor agreed to it all, for she (Elinor) did not think he (it) deserved the compliment of rational opposition.

As John Dashwood had no more pleasure in music than his (it) eldest sister, his (it) mind was equally at liberty to fix on any thing else; and a thought struck him (it) during the evening, which he (it) communicated to his (it) wife, for her (wife) approbation, when they got home. The consideration of Mrs. Dennison's mistake, in supposing his (it) sisters their guests, had suggested the propriety of their being really invited to become such, while Mrs. Jennings's engagements kept her (Jennings) from home. The expense would be nothing, the inconvenience not more; and it was altogether an attention which the delicacy of his (it) conscience pointed out to be requisite to its complete enfranchisement from his (it) promise to his (it) father. Fanny was startled at the proposal.

``I do not see how it can be done,'' (she)
said she (Fanny),
``without affronting Lady Middleton, for they spend every day with her (Fanny); otherwise I should be exceedingly glad to do it. You know I am always ready to pay them any attention in my power, as my taking them out this evening shews. But they are Lady Middleton's visitors. How can I ask them away from her (Middleton)?'' (she)

Her (Middleton) husband, but with great humility, did not see the force of her (Middleton) objection.

``They had already spent a week in this manner in Conduit Street, and Lady Middleton could not be displeased at their giving the same number of days to such near relations.'' (Fanny)

Fanny paused a moment, and then, with fresh vigor, said,

``My love I would ask them with all my heart, if it was in my power. But I had just settled within myself to ask the Miss Steeles to spend a few days with us. They are very well behaved, good kind of girls; and I think the attention is due to them, as their uncle did so very well by Edward. We can ask your sisters some other year, you know; but the Miss Steeles may not be in town any more. I am sure you will like them; indeed, you DO like them, you know, very much already, and so does my mother; and they are such favourites with Harry!'' (Fanny)

Mr. Dashwood was convinced. He (Dashwood) saw the necessity of inviting the Miss Steeles immediately, and his (Dashwood) conscience was pacified by the resolution of inviting his (Dashwood) sisters another year; at the same time, however, slyly suspecting that another year would make the invitation needless, by bringing Elinor to town as Colonel Brandon's wife, and Marianne as THEIR visitor.

Fanny, rejoicing in her (Fanny) escape, and proud of the ready wit that had procured it, wrote the next morning to Lucy, to request her (Lucy) company and her (Lucy) sister's, for some days, in Harley Street, as soon as Lady Middleton could spare them. This was enough to make Lucy really and reasonably happy. Mrs. Dashwood seemed actually working for her (Dashwood), herself; cherishing all her (Dashwood) hopes, and promoting all her (Dashwood) views! Such an opportunity of being with Edward and his (Edward) family was, above all things, the most material to her (Dashwood) interest, and such an invitation the most gratifying to her (Dashwood) feelings! It was an advantage that could not be too gratefully acknowledged, nor too speedily made use of; and the visit to Lady Middleton, which had not before had any precise limits, was instantly discovered to have been always meant to end in two days' time.

When the note was shown to Elinor, as it was within ten minutes after its arrival, it gave her (Elinor), for the first time, some share in the expectations of Lucy; for such a mark of uncommon kindness, vouchsafed on so short an acquaintance, seemed to declare that the good-will towards her (Lucy) arose from something more than merely malice against herself; and might be brought, by time and address, to do every thing that Lucy wished. Her (Lucy) flattery had already subdued the pride of Lady Middleton, and made an entry into the close heart of Mrs. John Dashwood; and these were effects that laid open the probability of greater.

The Miss Steeles removed to Harley Street, and all that reached Elinor of their influence there, strengthened her (Elinor) expectation of the event. Sir John, who called on them more than once, brought home such accounts of the favour they were in, as must be universally striking. Mrs. Dashwood had never been so much pleased with any young women in her (Dashwood) life, as she (Dashwood) was with them; had given each of them a needle book made by some emigrant; called Lucy by her (Lucy) Christian name; and did not know whether she (Lucy) should ever be able to part with them.

-LSB-At this point in the first and second editions, Volume II ended.-RSB-

CHAPTER 37

Mrs. Palmer was so well at the end of a fortnight, that her (Palmer) mother felt it no longer necessary to give up the whole of her (Palmer) time to her (Palmer); and, contenting herself with visiting her (Palmer) once or twice a day, returned from that period to her (Palmer) own home, and her (Palmer) own habits, in which she (Palmer) found the Miss Dashwoods very ready to resume their former share.

About the third or fourth morning after their being thus resettled in Berkeley Street, Mrs. Jennings, on returning from her (Jennings) ordinary visit to Mrs. Palmer, entered the drawing-room, where Elinor was sitting by herself, with an air of such hurrying importance as prepared her (Elinor) to hear something wonderful; and giving her (Elinor) time only to form that idea, began directly to justify it, by saying,

``Lord! my dear Miss Dashwood! have you heard the news?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``No, ma'am. What is it?'' (unknown)

``Something so strange! But you shall hear it all.-- When I got to Mr. Palmer's, I found Charlotte quite in a fuss about the child. She (Charlotte) was sure it was very ill--it cried, and fretted, and was all over pimples. So I looked at it directly, and, `Lord! my dear,' says I, `it is nothing in the world, but the red gum--' and nurse said just the same. But Charlotte, she (Charlotte) would not be satisfied, so Mr. Donavan was sent for; and luckily he (Donavan) happened to just come in from Harley Street, so he (Donavan) stepped over directly, and as soon as ever Mama, he (Donavan) said just as we did, that it was nothing in the world but the red gum, and then Charlotte was easy. And so, just as he (Donavan) was going away again, it came into my head, I am sure I do not know how I happened to think of it, but it came into my head to ask him (Donavan) if there was any news. So upon that, he (Donavan) smirked, and simpered, and looked grave, and seemed to know something or other, and at last he (Donavan) said in a whisper, `For fear any unpleasant report should reach the young ladies under your care as to their sister's indisposition, I think it advisable to say, that I believe there is no great reason for alarm; I hope Mrs. Dashwood will do very well.''' (unknown)

``What! is Fanny ill?'' (unknown)

``That is exactly what I said, my dear. `Lord!' says I, `is Mrs. Dashwood ill?' So then it all came out; and the long and the short of the matter, by all I can learn, seems to be this. Mr. Edward Ferrars, the very young man I used to joke with you about -LRB-but however, as it turns out, I am monstrous glad there was never any thing in it-RRB-, Mr. Edward Ferrars, it seems, has been engaged above this twelvemonth to my cousin Lucy!--There's for you, my dear!--And not a creature knowing a syllable of the matter, except Nancy!--Could you have believed such a thing possible?-- There is no great wonder in their liking one another; but that matters should be brought so forward between them, and nobody suspect it!--THAT is strange!--I never happened to see them together, or I am sure I should have found it out directly. Well, and so this was kept a great secret, for fear of Mrs. Ferrars, and neither she (Ferrars) nor your brother or sister suspected a word of the matter;--till this very morning, poor Nancy, who, you know, is a well-meaning creature, but no conjurer, popt it all out. `Lord!' thinks she (Nancy) to herself, `they are all so fond of Lucy, to be sure they will make no difficulty about it;' and so, away she (Lucy) went to your sister, who was sitting all alone at her (Lucy) carpet-work, little suspecting what was to come--for she (Lucy) had just been saying to your brother, only five minutes before, that she (Lucy) thought to make a match between Edward and some Lord's daughter or other, I forget who. So you may think what a blow it was to all her (Lucy) vanity and pride. She (Lucy) fell into violent hysterics immediately, with such screams as reached your brother's ears, as he (brother) was sitting in his (brother) own dressing-room down stairs, thinking about writing a letter to his (brother) steward in the country. So up he (brother) flew directly, and a terrible scene took place, for Lucy was come to them by that time, little dreaming what was going on. Poor soul! I pity HER. And I must say, I think she (Lucy) was used very hardly; for your sister scolded like any fury, and soon drove her (Lucy) into a fainting fit. Nancy, she (Nancy) fell upon her (Nancy) knees, and cried bitterly; and your brother, he (brother) walked about the room, and said he (brother) did not know what to do. Mrs. Dashwood declared they should not stay a minute longer in the house, and your brother was forced to go down upon HIS (brother) knees too, to persuade her (Dashwood) to let them stay till they had packed up their clothes. THEN she (Dashwood) fell into hysterics again, and he (brother) was so frightened that he (brother) would send for Mr. Donavan, and Mr. Donavan found the house in all this uproar. The carriage was at the door ready to take my poor cousins away, and they were just stepping in as he (Donavan) came off; poor Lucy in such a condition, he (Donavan) says, she (Lucy) could hardly walk; and Nancy, she (Nancy) was almost as bad. I declare, I have no patience with your sister; and I hope, with all my heart, it will be a match in spite of her (sister). Lord! what a taking poor Mr. Edward will be in when he (Edward) hears of it! To have his (Edward) love used so scornfully! for they say he (Edward) is monstrous fond of her (sister), as well he (Edward) may. I should not wonder, if he (Edward) was to be in the greatest passion!--and Mr. Donavan thinks just the same. He (Donavan) and I had a great deal of talk about it; and the best of all is, that he (Donavan) is gone back again to Harley Street, that he (Donavan) may be within call when Mrs. Ferrars is told of it, for she (Ferrars) was sent for as soon as ever my cousins left the house, for your sister was sure SHE would be in hysterics too; and so she (sister) may, for what I care. I have no pity for either of them. I have no notion of people's making such a to-do about money and greatness. There is no reason on earth why Mr. Edward and Lucy should not marry; for I am sure Mrs. Ferrars may afford to do very well by her (Ferrars) son, and though Lucy has next to nothing herself, she (Lucy) knows better than any body how to make the most of every thing; I dare say, if Mrs. Ferrars would only allow him (son) five hundred a-year, she (Ferrars) would make as good an appearance with it as any body else would with eight. Lord! how snug they might live in such another cottage as yours--or a little bigger--with two maids, and two men; and I believe I could help them to a housemaid, for my Betty has a sister out of place, that would fit them exactly.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

Here Mrs. Jennings ceased, and as Elinor had had time enough to collect her (Elinor) thoughts, she (Elinor) was able to give such an answer, and make such observations, as the subject might naturally be supposed to produce. Happy to find that she (Elinor) was not suspected of any extraordinary interest in it; that Mrs. Jennings -LRB-as she (Jennings) had of late often hoped might be the case-RRB- had ceased to imagine her (Jennings) at all attached to Edward; and happy above all the rest, in the absence of Marianne, she (Marianne) felt very well able to speak of the affair without embarrassment, and to give her (Marianne) judgment, as she (Marianne) believed, with impartiality on the conduct of every one concerned in it.

She (Marianne) could hardly determine what her (Marianne) own expectation of its event really was; though she (Marianne) earnestly tried to drive away the notion of its being possible to end otherwise at last, than in the marriage of Edward and Lucy. What Mrs. Ferrars would say and do, though there could not be a doubt of its nature, she (Ferrars) was anxious to hear; and still more anxious to know how Edward would conduct himself. For HIM she (Ferrars) felt much compassion;--for Lucy very little--and it cost her (Lucy) some pains to procure that little;--for the rest of the party none at all.

As Mrs. Jennings could talk on no other subject, Elinor soon saw the necessity of preparing Marianne for its discussion. No time was to be lost in undeceiving her (Elinor), in making her (Elinor) acquainted with the real truth, and in endeavouring to bring her (Elinor) to hear it talked of by others, without betraying that she (Elinor) felt any uneasiness for her (Elinor) sister, or any resentment against Edward.

Elinor's office was a painful one.--She (Elinor) was going to remove what she (Elinor) really believed to be her (Elinor) sister's chief consolation,--to give such particulars of Edward as she (Elinor) feared would ruin him (Edward) for ever in her (Elinor) good opinion,-and to make Marianne, by a resemblance in their situations, which to HER fancy would seem strong, feel all her (Elinor) own disappointment over again. But unwelcome as such a task must be, it was necessary to be done, and Elinor therefore hastened to perform it.

She (Elinor) was very far from wishing to dwell on her (Elinor) own feelings, or to represent herself as suffering much, any otherwise than as the self-command she (Elinor) had practised since her (Elinor) first knowledge of Edward's engagement, might suggest a hint of what was practicable to Marianne. Her (Marianne) narration was clear and simple; and though it could not be given without emotion, it was not accompanied by violent agitation, nor impetuous grief.--THAT belonged rather to the hearer, for Marianne listened with horror, and cried excessively. Elinor was to be the comforter of others in her (Elinor) own distresses, no less than in theirs; and all the comfort that could be given by assurances of her (Elinor) own composure of mind, and a very earnest vindication of Edward from every charge but of imprudence, was readily offered.

But Marianne for some time would give credit to neither. Edward seemed a second Willoughby; and acknowledging as Elinor did, that she (Elinor) HAD loved him (Edward) most sincerely, could she (Elinor) feel less than herself! As for Lucy Steele, she (Steele) considered her (Steele) so totally unamiable, so absolutely incapable of attaching a sensible man, that she (Steele) could not be persuaded at first to believe, and afterwards to pardon, any former affection of Edward for her (Steele). She (Steele) would not even admit it to have been natural; and Elinor left her (Elinor) to be convinced that it was so, by that which only could convince her (Elinor), a better knowledge of mankind.

Her (Elinor) first communication had reached no farther than to state the fact of the engagement, and the length of time it had existed.--Marianne's feelings had then broken in, and put an end to all regularity of detail; and for some time all that could be done was to soothe her (Marianne) distress, lessen her (Marianne) alarms, and combat her (Marianne) resentment. The first question on her (Marianne) side, which led to farther particulars, was,--

``How long has this been known to you, Elinor? has he (Marianne) written to you?'' (unknown)

``I have known it these four months. When Lucy first came to Barton Park last November, she (Lucy) told me in confidence of her (Lucy) engagement.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

At these words, Marianne's eyes expressed the astonishment which her (Marianne) lips could not utter. After a pause of wonder, she (Marianne) exclaimed--

``Four months!--Have you known of this four months?'' (she)

Elinor confirmed it.

``What!--while attending me in all my misery, has this been on your heart?--And I have reproached you for being happy!'' (unknown)
--

``It was not fit that you should then know how much I was the reverse!'' (unknown)

``Four months!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--cried Marianne again.--
``So calm!--so cheerful!--how have you been supported?'' (unknown)
--

``By feeling that I was doing my duty.--My promise to Lucy, obliged me to be secret. I owed it to her (Lucy), therefore, to avoid giving any hint of the truth; and I owed it to my family and friends, not to create in them a solicitude about me, which it could not be in my power to satisfy.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne seemed much struck.

``I have very often wished to undeceive yourself and my mother,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
added Elinor;
``and once or twice I have attempted it;--but without betraying my trust, I never could have convinced you.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Four months!--and yet you loved him (it)!'' (unknown)
--

``Yes. But I did not love only him (it);--and while the comfort of others was dear to me, I was glad to spare them from knowing how much I felt. Now, I can think and speak of it with little emotion. I would not have you suffer on my account; for I assure you I no longer suffer materially myself. I have many things to support me. I am not conscious of having provoked the disappointment by any imprudence of my own, I have borne it as much as possible without spreading it farther. I acquit Edward of essential misconduct. I wish him (Edward) very happy; and I am so sure of his (Edward) always doing his (Edward) duty, that though now he (Edward) may harbour some regret, in the end he (Edward) must become so. Lucy does not want sense, and that is the foundation on which every thing good may be built.--And after all, Marianne, after all that is bewitching in the idea of a single and constant attachment, and all that can be said of one's happiness depending entirely on any particular person, it is not meant--it is not fit--it is not possible that it should be so.-- Edward will marry Lucy; he (Edward) will marry a woman superior in person and understanding to half her (Lucy) sex; and time and habit will teach him (Edward) to forget that he (Edward) ever thought another superior to HER.'' (unknown)
--

``If such is your way of thinking,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``if the loss of what is most valued is so easily to be made up by something else, your resolution, your self-command, are, perhaps, a little less to be wondered at.--They are brought more within my comprehension.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``I understand you.--You do not suppose that I have ever felt much.--For four months, Marianne, I have had all this hanging on my mind, without being at liberty to speak of it to a single creature; knowing that it would make you and my mother most unhappy whenever it were explained to you, yet unable to prepare you for it in the least.-- It was told me,--it was in a manner forced on me by the very person herself, whose prior engagement ruined all my prospects; and told me, as I thought, with triumph.-- This person's suspicions, therefore, I have had to oppose, by endeavouring to appear indifferent where I have been most deeply interested;--and it has not been only once;--I have had her (mother) hopes and exultation to listen to again and again.-- I have known myself to be divided from Edward for ever, without hearing one circumstance that could make me less desire the connection.--Nothing has proved him (Edward) unworthy; nor has anything declared him (Edward) indifferent to me.-- I have had to contend against the unkindness of his (Edward) sister, and the insolence of his (Edward) mother; and have suffered the punishment of an attachment, without enjoying its advantages.-- And all this has been going on at a time, when, as you know too well, it has not been my only unhappiness.-- If you can think me capable of ever feeling--surely you may suppose that I have suffered NOW. The composure of mind with which I have brought myself at present to consider the matter, the consolation that I have been willing to admit, have been the effect of constant and painful exertion;--they did not spring up of themselves;--they did not occur to relieve my spirits at first.-- No, Marianne.--THEN, if I had not been bound to silence, perhaps nothing could have kept me entirely--not even what I owed to my dearest friends--from openly shewing that I was VERY unhappy.'' (-- Marianne)
--

Marianne was quite subdued.--

``Oh! Elinor,'' (she)
she (Elinor) cried,
``you have made me hate myself for ever.--How barbarous have I been to you!--you, who have been my only comfort, who have borne with me in all my misery, who have seemed to be only suffering for me!--Is this my gratitude?--Is this the only return I can make you?--Because your merit cries out upon myself, I have been trying to do it away.'' (she)

The tenderest caresses followed this confession. In such a frame of mind as she (Elinor) was now in, Elinor had no difficulty in obtaining from her (Elinor) whatever promise she (Elinor) required; and at her (Elinor) request, Marianne engaged never to speak of the affair to any one with the least appearance of bitterness;--to meet Lucy without betraying the smallest increase of dislike to her (Lucy);--and even to see Edward himself, if chance should bring them together, without any diminution of her (Lucy) usual cordiality.-- These were great concessions;--but where Marianne felt that she (Marianne) had injured, no reparation could be too much for her (Marianne) to make.

She (Marianne) performed her (Marianne) promise of being discreet, to admiration.--She (Marianne) attended to all that Mrs. Jennings had to say upon the subject, with an unchanging complexion, dissented from her (Jennings) in nothing, and was heard three times to say,

``Yes, ma'am.'' (Mrs. Jennings)
--She (Jennings) listened to her (Jennings) praise of Lucy with only moving from one chair to another, and when Mrs. Jennings talked of Edward's affection, it cost her (Jennings) only a spasm in her (Jennings) throat.--Such advances towards heroism in her (Jennings) sister, made Elinor feel equal to any thing herself.

The next morning brought a farther trial of it, in a visit from their brother, who came with a most serious aspect to talk over the dreadful affair, and bring them news of his (brother) wife.

``You have heard, I suppose,'' (he)
said he (brother) with great solemnity, as soon as he (brother) was seated,
``of the very shocking discovery that took place under our roof yesterday.'' (he)

They all looked their assent; it seemed too awful a moment for speech.

``Your sister,'' (he)
he (brother) continued,
``has suffered dreadfully. Mrs. Ferrars too--in short it has been a scene of such complicated distress--but I will hope that the storm may be weathered without our being any of us quite overcome. Poor Fanny! she (Fanny) was in hysterics all yesterday. But I would not alarm you too much. Donavan says there is nothing materially to be apprehended; her (Fanny) constitution is a good one, and her (Fanny) resolution equal to any thing. She (Fanny) has borne it all, with the fortitude of an angel! She (Fanny) says she (Fanny) never shall think well of anybody again; and one cannot wonder at it, after being so deceived!--meeting with such ingratitude, where so much kindness had been shewn, so much confidence had been placed! It was quite out of the benevolence of her (Fanny) heart, that she (Fanny) had asked these young women to her (Fanny) house; merely because she (Fanny) thought they deserved some attention, were harmless, well-behaved girls, and would be pleasant companions; for otherwise we both wished very much to have invited you and Marianne to be with us, while your kind friend there, was attending her (Marianne) daughter. And now to be so rewarded! 'I wish, with all my heart,' says poor Fanny in her (Fanny) affectionate way, `that we had asked your sisters instead of them.''' (he)

Here he (friend) stopped to be thanked; which being done, he (friend) went on.

``What poor Mrs. Ferrars suffered, when first Fanny broke it to her (Fanny), is not to be described. While she (Fanny) with the truest affection had been planning a most eligible connection for him (friend), was it to be supposed that he (friend) could be all the time secretly engaged to another person!--such a suspicion could never have entered her (Fanny) head! If she (Fanny) suspected ANY prepossession elsewhere, it could not be in THAT quarter. `THERE, to be sure,' said she (Fanny), 'I might have thought myself safe.' She (Fanny) was quite in an agony. We consulted together, however, as to what should be done, and at last she (Fanny) determined to send for Edward. He (Edward) came. But I am sorry to relate what ensued. All that Mrs. Ferrars could say to make him (Edward) put an end to the engagement, assisted too as you may well suppose by my arguments, and Fanny's entreaties, was of no avail. Duty, affection, every thing was disregarded. I never thought Edward so stubborn, so unfeeling before. His (Edward) mother explained to him (Edward) her (mother) liberal designs, in case of his (Edward) marrying Miss Morton; told him (Edward) she (mother) would settle on him (Edward) the Norfolk estate, which, clear of land-tax, brings in a good thousand a-year; offered even, when matters grew desperate, to make it twelve hundred; and in opposition to this, if he (Edward) still persisted in this low connection, represented to him (Edward) the certain penury that must attend the match. His (Edward) own two thousand pounds she (mother) protested should be his (Edward) all; she (mother) would never see him (Edward) again; and so far would she (mother) be from affording him (Edward) the smallest assistance, that if he (Edward) were to enter into any profession with a view of better support, she (mother) would do all in her (mother) power to prevent him (Edward) advancing in it.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Here Marianne, in an ecstasy of indignation, clapped her (Marianne) hands together, and cried,

``Gracious God! can this be possible!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Well may you wonder, Marianne,'' (brother)
replied her (Marianne) brother,
``at the obstinacy which could resist such arguments as these. Your exclamation is very natural.'' (brother)

Marianne was going to retort, but she (Marianne) remembered her (Marianne) promises, and forbore.

``All this, however,'' (he)
he (brother) continued,
``was urged in vain. Edward said very little; but what he (Edward) did say, was in the most determined manner. Nothing should prevail on him (Edward) to give up his (Edward) engagement. He (Edward) would stand to it, cost him (Edward) what it might.'' (he)

``Then,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings with blunt sincerity, no longer able to be silent,
``he (Edward) has acted like an honest man! I beg your pardon, Mr. Dashwood, but if he (Dashwood) had done otherwise, I should have thought him (Dashwood) a rascal. I have some little concern in the business, as well as yourself, for Lucy Steele is my cousin, and I believe there is not a better kind of girl in the world, nor one who more deserves a good husband.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

John Dashwood was greatly astonished; but his (husband) nature was calm, not open to provocation, and he (husband) never wished to offend anybody, especially anybody of good fortune. He (husband) therefore replied, without any resentment,

``I would by no means speak disrespectfully of any relation of yours, madam. Miss Lucy Steele is, I dare say, a very deserving young woman, but in the present case you know, the connection must be impossible. And to have entered into a secret engagement with a young man under her (Steele) uncle's care, the son of a woman especially of such very large fortune as Mrs. Ferrars, is perhaps, altogether a little extraordinary. In short, I do not mean to reflect upon the behaviour of any person whom you have a regard for, Mrs. Jennings. We all wish her (Jennings) extremely happy; and Mrs. Ferrars's conduct throughout the whole, has been such as every conscientious, good mother, in like circumstances, would adopt. It has been dignified and liberal. Edward has drawn his (Edward) own lot, and I fear it will be a bad one.'' (He)

Marianne sighed out her (Marianne) similar apprehension; and Elinor's heart wrung for the feelings of Edward, while braving his (Edward) mother's threats, for a woman who could not reward him (Edward).

``Well, sir,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings,
``and how did it end?'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``I am sorry to say, ma'am, in a most unhappy rupture:-- Edward is dismissed for ever from his (Edward) mother's notice. He (Edward) left her (mother) house yesterday, but where he (Edward) is gone, or whether he (Edward) is still in town, I do not know; for WE of course can make no inquiry.'' (unknown)

``Poor young man!--and what is to become of him (man)?'' (unknown)

``What, indeed, ma'am! It is a melancholy consideration. Born to the prospect of such affluence! I cannot conceive a situation more deplorable. The interest of two thousand pounds--how can a man live on it?--and when to that is added the recollection, that he (man) might, but for his (man) own folly, within three months have been in the receipt of two thousand, five hundred a-year -LRB-for Miss Morton has thirty thousand pounds,-RRB- I cannot picture to myself a more wretched condition. We must all feel for him (man); and the more so, because it is totally out of our power to assist him (man).'' (unknown)

``Poor young man!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings,
``I am sure he (man) should be very welcome to bed and board at my house; and so I would tell him (man) if I could see him (man). It is not fit that he (man) should be living about at his (man) own charge now, at lodgings and taverns.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

Elinor's heart thanked her (Elinor) for such kindness towards Edward, though she (Elinor) could not forbear smiling at the form of it.

``If he (Edward) would only have done as well by himself,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said John Dashwood,
``as all his (Edward) friends were disposed to do by him (Edward), he (Edward) might now have been in his (Edward) proper situation, and would have wanted for nothing. But as it is, it must be out of anybody's power to assist him (Edward). And there is one thing more preparing against him (Edward), which must be worse than all--his (Edward) mother has determined, with a very natural kind of spirit, to settle THAT estate upon Robert immediately, which might have been Edward's, on proper conditions. I left her (Robert) this morning with her (Robert) lawyer, talking over the business.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``Well!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings,
``that is HER revenge. Everybody has a way of their own. But I don't think mine would be, to make one son independent, because another had plagued me.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

Marianne got up and walked about the room.

``Can anything be more galling to the spirit of a man,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
continued John,
``than to see his (man) younger brother in possession of an estate which might have been his (man) own? Poor Edward! I feel for him (Edward) sincerely.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

A few minutes more spent in the same kind of effusion, concluded his (Edward) visit; and with repeated assurances to his (Edward) sisters that he (Edward) really believed there was no material danger in Fanny's indisposition, and that they need not therefore be very uneasy about it, he (Edward) went away; leaving the three ladies unanimous in their sentiments on the present occasion, as far at least as it regarded Mrs. Ferrars's conduct, the Dashwoods', and Edward's.

Marianne's indignation burst forth as soon as he (Edward) quitted the room; and as her (Marianne) vehemence made reserve impossible in Elinor, and unnecessary in Mrs. Jennings, they all joined in a very spirited critique upon the party.

CHAPTER 38

Mrs. Jennings was very warm in her (Jennings) praise of Edward's conduct, but only Elinor and Marianne understood its true merit. THEY only knew how little he (Edward) had had to tempt him (Edward) to be disobedient, and how small was the consolation, beyond the consciousness of doing right, that could remain to him (Edward) in the loss of friends and fortune. Elinor gloried in his (Edward) integrity; and Marianne forgave all his (Edward) offences in compassion for his (Edward) punishment. But though confidence between them was, by this public discovery, restored to its proper state, it was not a subject on which either of them were fond of dwelling when alone. Elinor avoided it upon principle, as tending to fix still more upon her (Elinor) thoughts, by the too warm, too positive assurances of Marianne, that belief of Edward's continued affection for herself which she (Marianne) rather wished to do away; and Marianne's courage soon failed her (Marianne), in trying to converse upon a topic which always left her (Marianne) more dissatisfied with herself than ever, by the comparison it necessarily produced between Elinor's conduct and her (Elinor) own.

She (Elinor) felt all the force of that comparison; but not as her (Elinor) sister had hoped, to urge her (Elinor) to exertion now; she (Elinor) felt it with all the pain of continual self-reproach, regretted most bitterly that she (Elinor) had never exerted herself before; but it brought only the torture of penitence, without the hope of amendment. Her (Elinor) mind was so much weakened that she (Elinor) still fancied present exertion impossible, and therefore it only dispirited her (Elinor) more.

Nothing new was heard by them, for a day or two afterwards, of affairs in Harley Street, or Bartlett's Buildings. But though so much of the matter was known to them already, that Mrs. Jennings might have had enough to do in spreading that knowledge farther, without seeking after more, she (Jennings) had resolved from the first to pay a visit of comfort and inquiry to her (Jennings) cousins as soon as she (Jennings) could; and nothing but the hindrance of more visitors than usual, had prevented her (Jennings) going to them within that time.

The third day succeeding their knowledge of the particulars, was so fine, so beautiful a Sunday as to draw many to Kensington Gardens, though it was only the second week in March. Mrs. Jennings and Elinor were of the number; but Marianne, who knew that the Willoughbys were again in town, and had a constant dread of meeting them, chose rather to stay at home, than venture into so public a place.

An intimate acquaintance of Mrs. Jennings joined them soon after they entered the Gardens, and Elinor was not sorry that by her (Elinor) continuing with them, and engaging all Mrs. Jennings's conversation, she (Jennings) was herself left to quiet reflection. She (Jennings) saw nothing of the Willoughbys, nothing of Edward, and for some time nothing of anybody who could by any chance whether grave or gay, be interesting to her (Jennings). But at last she (Jennings) found herself with some surprise, accosted by Miss Steele, who, though looking rather shy, expressed great satisfaction in meeting them, and on receiving encouragement from the particular kindness of Mrs. Jennings, left her (Jennings) own party for a short time, to join their's. Mrs. Jennings immediately whispered to Elinor,

``Get it all out of her (Jennings), my dear. She (Jennings) will tell you any thing if you ask. You see I cannot leave Mrs. Clarke.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

It was lucky, however, for Mrs. Jennings's curiosity and Elinor's too, that she (Elinor) would tell any thing WITHOUT being asked; for nothing would otherwise have been learnt.

``I am so glad to meet you;'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
said Miss Steele, taking her (Steele) familiarly by the arm--
``for I wanted to see you of all things in the world.'' (Lucy/Miss Steele/Lucy Steele)
And then lowering her (Steele) voice,
``I suppose Mrs. Jennings has heard all about it. Is she (Jennings) angry?'' (unknown)

``Not at all, I believe, with you.'' (unknown)

``That is a good thing. And Lady Middleton, is SHE angry?'' (unknown)

``I cannot suppose it possible that she (Middleton) should.'' (unknown)

``I am monstrous glad of it. Good gracious! I have had such a time of it! I never saw Lucy in such a rage in my life. She (Lucy) vowed at first she (Lucy) would never trim me up a new bonnet, nor do any thing else for me again, so long as she (Lucy) lived; but now she (Lucy) is quite come to, and we are as good friends as ever. Look, she (Lucy) made me this bow to my hat, and put in the feather last night. There now, YOU are going to laugh at me too. But why should not I wear pink ribbons? I do not care if it IS the Doctor's favourite colour. I am sure, for my part, I should never have known he (Doctor) DID like it better than any other colour, if he (Doctor) had not happened to say so. My cousins have been so plaguing me! I declare sometimes I do not know which way to look before them.'' (She)

She (it) had wandered away to a subject on which Elinor had nothing to say, and therefore soon judged it expedient to find her (Elinor) way back again to the first.

``Well, but Miss Dashwood,'' (unknown)
speaking triumphantly,
``people may say what they chuse about Mr. Ferrars's declaring he (Ferrars) would not have Lucy, for it is no such thing I can tell you; and it is quite a shame for such ill-natured reports to be spread abroad. Whatever Lucy might think about it herself, you know, it was no business of other people to set it down for certain.'' (unknown)

``I never heard any thing of the kind hinted at before, I assure you,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.

``Oh, did not you? But it WAS said, I know, very well, and by more than one; for Miss Godby told Miss Sparks, that nobody in their senses could expect Mr. Ferrars to give up a woman like Miss Morton, with thirty thousand pounds to her (Morton) fortune, for Lucy Steele that had nothing at all; and I had it from Miss Sparks myself. And besides that, my cousin Richard said himself, that when it came to the point he (Richard) was afraid Mr. Ferrars would be off; and when Edward did not come near us for three days, I could not tell what to think myself; and I believe in my heart Lucy gave it up all for lost; for we came away from your brother's Wednesday, and we saw nothing of him (brother) not all Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, and did not know what was become of him (brother). Once Lucy thought to write to him (brother), but then her (Lucy) spirits rose against that. However this morning he (brother) came just as we came home from church; and then it all came out, how he (brother) had been sent for Wednesday to Harley Street, and been talked to by his (brother) mother and all of them, and how he (brother) had declared before them all that he (brother) loved nobody but Lucy, and nobody but Lucy would he (brother) have. And how he (brother) had been so worried by what passed, that as soon as he (brother) had went away from his (brother) mother's house, he (brother) had got upon his (brother) horse, and rid into the country, some where or other; and how he (brother) had stayed about at an inn all Thursday and Friday, on purpose to get the better of it. And after thinking it all over and over again, he (brother) said, it seemed to him (brother) as if, now he (brother) had no fortune, and no nothing at all, it would be quite unkind to keep her (mother) on to the engagement, because it must be for her (mother) loss, for he (brother) had nothing but two thousand pounds, and no hope of any thing else; and if he (brother) was to go into orders, as he (brother) had some thoughts, he (brother) could get nothing but a curacy, and how was they to live upon that?--He (brother) could not bear to think of her (mother) doing no better, and so he (brother) begged, if she (mother) had the least mind for it, to put an end to the matter directly, and leave him (brother) shift for himself. I heard him (brother) say all this as plain as could possibly be. And it was entirely for HER sake, and upon HER account, that he (brother) said a word about being off, and not upon his (brother) own. I will take my oath he (brother) never dropt a syllable of being tired of her (mother), or of wishing to marry Miss Morton, or any thing like it. But, to be sure, Lucy would not give ear to such kind of talking; so she (Lucy) told him (brother) directly -LRB-with a great deal about sweet and love, you know, and all that--Oh, la! one can't repeat such kind of things you know-RRB---she (Lucy) told him (brother) directly, she (Lucy) had not the least mind in the world to be off, for she (Lucy) could live with him (brother) upon a trifle, and how little so ever he (brother) might have, she (Lucy) should be very glad to have it all, you know, or something of the kind. So then he (brother) was monstrous happy, and talked on some time about what they should do, and they agreed he (brother) should take orders directly, and they must wait to be married till he (brother) got a living. And just then I could not hear any more, for my cousin called from below to tell me Mrs. Richardson was come in her (Richardson) coach, and would take one of us to Kensington Gardens; so I was forced to go into the room and interrupt them, to ask Lucy if she (Lucy) would like to go, but she (Lucy) did not care to leave Edward; so I just run up stairs and put on a pair of silk stockings and came off with the Richardsons.'' (unknown)

``I do not understand what you mean by interrupting them,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor;
``you were all in the same room together, were not you?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``No, indeed, not us. La! Miss Dashwood, do you think people make love when any body else is by? Oh, for shame!--To be sure you must know better than that. -LRB-Laughing affectedly.-RRB---No, no; they were shut up in the drawing-room together, and all I heard was only by listening at the door.'' (unknown)

``How!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
cried Elinor;
``have you been repeating to me what you only learnt yourself by listening at the door? I am sorry I did not know it before; for I certainly would not have suffered you to give me particulars of a conversation which you ought not to have known yourself. How could you behave so unfairly by your sister?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Oh, la! there is nothing in THAT. I only stood at the door, and heard what I could. And I am sure Lucy would have done just the same by me; for a year or two back, when Martha Sharpe and I had so many secrets together, she (Martha) never made any bones of hiding in a closet, or behind a chimney-board, on purpose to hear what we said.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor tried to talk of something else; but Miss Steele could not be kept beyond a couple of minutes, from what was uppermost in her (Steele) mind.

``Edward talks of going to Oxford soon,'' (she)
said she (Steele);
``but now he (Edward) is lodging at No. --, Pall Mall. What an ill-natured woman his (Edward) mother is, an't she (mother)? And your brother and sister were not very kind! However, I shan't say anything against them to YOU; and to be sure they did send us home in their own chariot, which was more than I looked for. And for my part, I was all in a fright for fear your sister should ask us for the huswifes she (sister) had gave us a day or two before; but, however, nothing was said about them, and I took care to keep mine out of sight. Edward have got some business at Oxford, he (Edward) says; so he (Edward) must go there for a time; and after THAT, as soon as he (Edward) can light upon a Bishop, he (Edward) will be ordained. I wonder what curacy he (Edward) will get!--Good gracious! -LRB-giggling as she (sister) spoke-RRB- I'd lay my life I know what my cousins will say, when they hear of it. They will tell me I should write to the Doctor, to get Edward the curacy of his (Edward) new living. I know they will; but I am sure I would not do such a thing for all the world.-- `La!' I shall say directly, 'I wonder how you could think of such a thing? I write to the Doctor, indeed!''' (she)

``Well,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``it is a comfort to be prepared against the worst. You have got your answer ready.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Miss Steele was going to reply on the same subject, but the approach of her (Steele) own party made another more necessary.

``Oh, la! here come the Richardsons. I had a vast deal more to say to you, but I must not stay away from them not any longer. I assure you they are very genteel people. He (Doctor) makes a monstrous deal of money, and they keep their own coach. I have not time to speak to Mrs. Jennings about it myself, but pray tell her (Jennings) I am quite happy to hear she (Jennings) is not in anger against us, and Lady Middleton the same; and if anything should happen to take you and your sister away, and Mrs. Jennings should want company, I am sure we should be very glad to come and stay with her (Jennings) for as long a time as she (Jennings) likes. I suppose Lady Middleton won't ask us any more this bout. Good-by; I am sorry Miss Marianne was not here. Remember me kindly to her (Marianne). La! if you have not got your spotted muslin on!--I wonder you was not afraid of its being torn.'' (unknown)

Such was her (Marianne) parting concern; for after this, she (Marianne) had time only to pay her (Marianne) farewell compliments to Mrs. Jennings, before her (Jennings) company was claimed by Mrs. Richardson; and Elinor was left in possession of knowledge which might feed her (Elinor) powers of reflection some time, though she (Elinor) had learnt very little more than what had been already foreseen and foreplanned in her (Elinor) own mind. Edward's marriage with Lucy was as firmly determined on, and the time of its taking place remained as absolutely uncertain, as she (Lucy) had concluded it would be;--every thing depended, exactly after her (Lucy) expectation, on his (Edward) getting that preferment, of which, at present, there seemed not the smallest chance.

As soon as they returned to the carriage, Mrs. Jennings was eager for information; but as Elinor wished to spread as little as possible intelligence that had in the first place been so unfairly obtained, she (Elinor) confined herself to the brief repetition of such simple particulars, as she (Elinor) felt assured that Lucy, for the sake of her (Lucy) own consequence, would choose to have known. The continuance of their engagement, and the means that were able to be taken for promoting its end, was all her (Lucy) communication; and this produced from Mrs. Jennings the following natural remark.

``Wait for his (Lucy) having a living!--ay, we all know how THAT will end:--they will wait a twelvemonth, and finding no good comes of it, will set down upon a curacy of fifty pounds a-year, with the interest of his (Lucy) two thousand pounds, and what little matter Mr. Steele and Mr. Pratt can give her (Jennings).--Then they will have a child every year! and Lord help 'em! how poor they will be!--I must see what I can give them towards furnishing their house. Two maids and two men, indeed!--as I talked of t`other day.--No, no, they must get a stout girl of all works.-- Betty's sister would never do for them NOW.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

The next morning brought Elinor a letter by the two-penny post from Lucy herself. It was as follows:

``Bartlett's Building, March.

``I hope my dear Miss Dashwood will excuse the liberty I take of writing to her (Dashwood); but I know your friendship for me will make you pleased to hear such a good account of myself and my dear Edward, after all the troubles we have went through lately, therefore will make no more apologies, but proceed to say that, thank God! though we have suffered dreadfully, we are both quite well now, and as happy as we must always be in one another's love. We have had great trials, and great persecutions, but however, at the same time, gratefully acknowledge many friends, yourself not the least among them, whose great kindness I shall always thankfully remember, as will Edward too, who I have told of it. I am sure you will be glad to hear, as likewise dear Mrs. Jennings, I spent two happy hours with him (Edward) yesterday afternoon, he (Edward) would not hear of our parting, though earnestly did I, as I thought my duty required, urge him (Edward) to it for prudence sake, and would have parted for ever on the spot, would he (Edward) consent to it; but he (Edward) said it should never be, he (Edward) did not regard his (Edward) mother's anger, while he (Edward) could have my affections; our prospects are not very bright, to be sure, but we must wait, and hope for the best; he (Edward) will be ordained shortly; and should it ever be in your power to recommend him (Edward) to any body that has a living to bestow, am very sure you will not forget us, and dear Mrs. Jennings too, trust she (Jennings) will speak a good word for us to Sir John, or Mr. Palmer, or any friend that may be able to assist us.--Poor Anne was much to blame for what she (Anne) did, but she (Anne) did it for the best, so I say nothing; hope Mrs. Jennings won't think it too much trouble to give us a call, should she (Jennings) come this way any morning, `twould be a great kindness, and my cousins would be proud to know her (Jennings).--My paper reminds me to conclude; and begging to be most gratefully and respectfully remembered to her (Jennings), and to Sir John, and Lady Middleton, and the dear children, when you chance to see them, and love to Miss Marianne,

``I am, &c.'' (Miss Marianne)

As soon as Elinor had finished it, she (Elinor) performed what she (Elinor) concluded to be its writer's real design, by placing it in the hands of Mrs. Jennings, who read it aloud with many comments of satisfaction and praise.

``Very well indeed!--how prettily she (Jennings) writes!--aye, that was quite proper to let him (writer) be off if he (writer) would. That was just like Lucy.--Poor soul! I wish I COULD get him (writer) a living, with all my heart.--She (Lucy) calls me dear Mrs. Jennings, you see. She (Jennings) is a good-hearted girl as ever lived.--Very well upon my word. That sentence is very prettily turned. Yes, yes, I will go and see her (Jennings), sure enough. How attentive she (Jennings) is, to think of every body!--Thank you, my dear, for shewing it me. It is as pretty a letter as ever I saw, and does Lucy's head and heart great credit.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

CHAPTER 39

The Miss Dashwoods had now been rather more than two months in town, and Marianne's impatience to be gone increased every day. She (Marianne) sighed for the air, the liberty, the quiet of the country; and fancied that if any place could give her (Marianne) ease, Barton must do it. Elinor was hardly less anxious than herself for their removal, and only so much less bent on its being effected immediately, as that she (Elinor) was conscious of the difficulties of so long a journey, which Marianne could not be brought to acknowledge. She (Marianne) began, however, seriously to turn her (Marianne) thoughts towards its accomplishment, and had already mentioned their wishes to their kind hostess, who resisted them with all the eloquence of her (hostess) good-will, when a plan was suggested, which, though detaining them from home yet a few weeks longer, appeared to Elinor altogether much more eligible than any other. The Palmers were to remove to Cleveland about the end of March, for the Easter holidays; and Mrs. Jennings, with both her (Jennings) friends, received a very warm invitation from Charlotte to go with them. This would not, in itself, have been sufficient for the delicacy of Miss Dashwood;--but it was inforced with so much real politeness by Mr. Palmer himself, as, joined to the very great amendment of his (Palmer) manners towards them since her (Dashwood) sister had been known to be unhappy, induced her (Dashwood) to accept it with pleasure.

When she (Dashwood) told Marianne what she (Dashwood) had done, however, her (Dashwood) first reply was not very auspicious.

``Cleveland!'' (she)
--she (Dashwood) cried, with great agitation.
``No, I cannot go to Cleveland.'' (unknown)
--

``You forget,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor gently,
``that its situation is not...that it is not in the neighbourhood of...'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``But it is in Somersetshire.--I cannot go into Somersetshire.--There, where I looked forward to going...No, Elinor, you cannot expect me to go there.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor would not argue upon the propriety of overcoming such feelings;--she (Elinor) only endeavoured to counteract them by working on others;--represented it, therefore, as a measure which would fix the time of her (Elinor) returning to that dear mother, whom she (Elinor) so much wished to see, in a more eligible, more comfortable manner, than any other plan could do, and perhaps without any greater delay. From Cleveland, which was within a few miles of Bristol, the distance to Barton was not beyond one day, though a long day's journey; and their mother's servant might easily come there to attend them down; and as there could be no occasion of their staying above a week at Cleveland, they might now be at home in little more than three weeks' time. As Marianne's affection for her (Marianne) mother was sincere, it must triumph with little difficulty, over the imaginary evils she (Marianne) had started.

Mrs. Jennings was so far from being weary of her (Jennings) guests, that she (Jennings) pressed them very earnestly to return with her (Jennings) again from Cleveland. Elinor was grateful for the attention, but it could not alter her (Elinor) design; and their mother's concurrence being readily gained, every thing relative to their return was arranged as far as it could be;--and Marianne found some relief in drawing up a statement of the hours that were yet to divide her (Marianne) from Barton.

``Ah! Colonel, I do not know what you and I shall do without the Miss Dashwoods;'' (Mrs. Jennings)
--was Mrs. Jennings's address to him (Colonel) when he (Colonel) first called on her (Jennings), after their leaving her (Jennings) was settled--
``for they are quite resolved upon going home from the Palmers;--and how forlorn we shall be, when I come back!--Lord! we shall sit and gape at one another as dull as two cats.'' (her)

Perhaps Mrs. Jennings was in hopes, by this vigorous sketch of their future ennui, to provoke him (Lord) to make that offer, which might give himself an escape from it;--and if so, she (Jennings) had soon afterwards good reason to think her (Jennings) object gained; for, on Elinor's moving to the window to take more expeditiously the dimensions of a print, which she (Elinor) was going to copy for her (Elinor) friend, he (friend) followed her (Elinor) to it with a look of particular meaning, and conversed with her (Elinor) there for several minutes.
