The effect of his (friend) discourse on the lady too, could not escape her (Elinor) observation, for though she (Elinor) was too honorable to listen, and had even changed her (Elinor) seat, on purpose that she (Elinor) might NOT hear, to one close by the piano forte on which Marianne was playing, she (Marianne) could not keep herself from seeing that Elinor changed colour, attended with agitation, and was too intent on what he (friend) said to pursue her (Elinor) employment.-- Still farther in confirmation of her (Elinor) hopes, in the interval of Marianne's turning from one lesson to another, some words of the Colonel's inevitably reached her (Marianne) ear, in which he (Colonel) seemed to be apologising for the badness of his (Colonel) house. This set the matter beyond a doubt. She (Marianne) wondered, indeed, at his (Colonel) thinking it necessary to do so; but supposed it to be the proper etiquette. What Elinor said in reply she (Elinor) could not distinguish, but judged from the motion of her (Elinor) lips, that she (Elinor) did not think THAT any material objection;--and Mrs. Jennings commended her (Jennings) in her (Jennings) heart for being so honest. They then talked on for a few minutes longer without her (Jennings) catching a syllable, when another lucky stop in Marianne's performance brought her (Jennings) these words in the Colonel's calm voice,--

``I am afraid it cannot take place very soon.'' (the Colonel)

Astonished and shocked at so unlover-like a speech, she (Jennings) was almost ready to cry out,

``Lord! what should hinder it?'' (she)
--but checking her (Jennings) desire, confined herself to this silent ejaculation.

``This is very strange!--sure he (Lord) need not wait to be older.'' (the Colonel)

This delay on the Colonel's side, however, did not seem to offend or mortify his (Colonel) fair companion in the least, for on their breaking up the conference soon afterwards, and moving different ways, Mrs. Jennings very plainly heard Elinor say, and with a voice which shewed her (Elinor) to feel what she (Elinor) said,

``I shall always think myself very much obliged to you.'' (she)

Mrs. Jennings was delighted with her (Jennings) gratitude, and only wondered that after hearing such a sentence, the Colonel should be able to take leave of them, as he (Colonel) immediately did, with the utmost sang-froid, and go away without making her (Jennings) any reply!--She (Jennings) had not thought her (Jennings) old friend could have made so indifferent a suitor.

What had really passed between them was to this effect.

``I have heard,'' (he)
said he (friend), with great compassion,
``of the injustice your friend Mr. Ferrars has suffered from his (Ferrars) family; for if I understand the matter right, he (Ferrars) has been entirely cast off by them for persevering in his (Ferrars) engagement with a very deserving young woman.-- Have I been rightly informed?--Is it so?--'' (he)

Elinor told him (Ferrars) that it was.

``The cruelty, the impolitic cruelty,'' (he)
--he (Ferrars) replied, with great feeling,--
``of dividing, or attempting to divide, two young people long attached to each other, is terrible.-- Mrs. Ferrars does not know what she (Ferrars) may be doing--what she (Ferrars) may drive her (Ferrars) son to. I have seen Mr. Ferrars two or three times in Harley Street, and am much pleased with him (Ferrars). He (Ferrars) is not a young man with whom one can be intimately acquainted in a short time, but I have seen enough of him (Ferrars) to wish him (Ferrars) well for his (Ferrars) own sake, and as a friend of yours, I wish it still more. I understand that he (Ferrars) intends to take orders. Will you be so good as to tell him (Ferrars) that the living of Delaford, now just vacant, as I am informed by this day's post, is his (Ferrars), if he (Ferrars) think it worth his (Ferrars) acceptance--but THAT, perhaps, so unfortunately circumstanced as he (Ferrars) is now, it may be nonsense to appear to doubt; I only wish it were more valuable.-- It is a rectory, but a small one; the late incumbent, I believe, did not make more than 200 L per annum, and though it is certainly capable of improvement, I fear, not to such an amount as to afford him (Ferrars) a very comfortable income. Such as it is, however, my pleasure in presenting him (Ferrars) to it, will be very great. Pray assure him (Ferrars) of it.'' (he)

Elinor's astonishment at this commission could hardly have been greater, had the Colonel been really making her (Elinor) an offer of his (Colonel) hand. The preferment, which only two days before she (Elinor) had considered as hopeless for Edward, was already provided to enable him (Edward) to marry;--and SHE, of all people in the world, was fixed on to bestow it!--Her (Elinor) emotion was such as Mrs. Jennings had attributed to a very different cause;--but whatever minor feelings less pure, less pleasing, might have a share in that emotion, her (Elinor) esteem for the general benevolence, and her (Elinor) gratitude for the particular friendship, which together prompted Colonel Brandon to this act, were strongly felt, and warmly expressed. She (Brandon) thanked him (Colonel) for it with all her (Brandon) heart, spoke of Edward's principles and disposition with that praise which she (Brandon) knew them to deserve; and promised to undertake the commission with pleasure, if it were really his (Edward) wish to put off so agreeable an office to another. But at the same time, she (Brandon) could not help thinking that no one could so well perform it as himself. It was an office in short, from which, unwilling to give Edward the pain of receiving an obligation from HER, she (Brandon) would have been very glad to be spared herself;-- but Colonel Brandon, on motives of equal delicacy, declining it likewise, still seemed so desirous of its being given through her (Brandon) means, that she (Brandon) would not on any account make farther opposition. Edward, she (Brandon) believed, was still in town, and fortunately she (Brandon) had heard his (Edward) address from Miss Steele. She (Steele) could undertake therefore to inform him (Edward) of it, in the course of the day. After this had been settled, Colonel Brandon began to talk of his (Colonel) own advantage in securing so respectable and agreeable a neighbour, and THEN it was that he (Colonel) mentioned with regret, that the house was small and indifferent;--an evil which Elinor, as Mrs. Jennings had supposed her (Jennings) to do, made very light of, at least as far as regarded its size.

``The smallness of the house,'' (she)
said she (Jennings),
``I cannot imagine any inconvenience to them, for it will be in proportion to their family and income.'' (she)

By which the Colonel was surprised to find that SHE was considering Mr. Ferrars's marriage as the certain consequence of the presentation; for he (Colonel) did not suppose it possible that Delaford living could supply such an income, as anybody in his (Colonel) style of life would venture to settle on--and he (Colonel) said so.

``This little rectory CAN do no more than make Mr. Ferrars comfortable as a bachelor; it cannot enable him (Ferrars) to marry. I am sorry to say that my patronage ends with this; and my interest is hardly more extensive. If, however, by an unforeseen chance it should be in my power to serve him (Ferrars) farther, I must think very differently of him (Ferrars) from what I now do, if I am not as ready to be useful to him (Ferrars) then as I sincerely wish I could be at present. What I am now doing indeed, seems nothing at all, since it can advance him (Ferrars) so little towards what must be his (Ferrars) principal, his (Ferrars) only object of happiness. His (Ferrars) marriage must still be a distant good;--at least, I am afraid it cannot take place very soon.--'' (Mrs. Jennings)

Such was the sentence which, when misunderstood, so justly offended the delicate feelings of Mrs. Jennings; but after this narration of what really passed between Colonel Brandon and Elinor, while they stood at the window, the gratitude expressed by the latter on their parting, may perhaps appear in general, not less reasonably excited, nor less properly worded than if it had arisen from an offer of marriage.

CHAPTER 40

``Well, Miss Dashwood,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings, sagaciously smiling, as soon as the gentleman had withdrawn,
``I do not ask you what the Colonel has been saying to you; for though, upon my honour, I TRIED to keep out of hearing, I could not help catching enough to understand his (Colonel) business. And I assure you I never was better pleased in my life, and I wish you joy of it with all my heart.'' (the gentleman)

``Thank you, ma'am,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor.
``It is a matter of great joy to me; and I feel the goodness of Colonel Brandon most sensibly. There are not many men who would act as he (Colonel) has done. Few people who have so compassionate a heart! I never was more astonished in my life.'' (unknown)

``Lord! my dear, you are very modest. I an't the least astonished at it in the world, for I have often thought of late, there was nothing more likely to happen.'' (unknown)

``You judged from your knowledge of the Colonel's general benevolence; but at least you could not foresee that the opportunity would so very soon occur.'' (unknown)

``Opportunity!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
repeated Mrs. Jennings--
``Oh! as to that, when a man has once made up his (man) mind to such a thing, somehow or other he (man) will soon find an opportunity. Well, my dear, I wish you joy of it again and again; and if ever there was a happy couple in the world, I think I shall soon know where to look for them.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``You mean to go to Delaford after them I suppose,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, with a faint smile.

``Aye, my dear, that I do, indeed. And as to the house being a bad one, I do not know what the Colonel would be at, for it is as good a one as ever I saw.'' (unknown)

``He (Colonel) spoke of its being out of repair.'' (unknown)

``Well, and whose fault is that? why don't he (Colonel) repair it?--who should do it but himself?'' (the servant)

They were interrupted by the servant's coming in to announce the carriage being at the door; and Mrs. Jennings immediately preparing to go, said,--

``Well, my dear, I must be gone before I have had half my talk out. But, however, we may have it all over in the evening; for we shall be quite alone. I do not ask you to go with me, for I dare say your mind is too full of the matter to care for company; and besides, you must long to tell your sister all about it.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

Marianne had left the room before the conversation began.

``Certainly, ma'am, I shall tell Marianne of it; but I shall not mention it at present to any body else.'' (unknown)

``Oh! very well,'' (Mrs. Jennings)
said Mrs. Jennings rather disappointed.
``Then you would not have me tell it to Lucy, for I think of going as far as Holborn to-day.'' (unknown)

``No, ma'am, not even Lucy if you please. One day's delay will not be very material; and till I have written to Mr. Ferrars, I think it ought not to be mentioned to any body else. I shall do THAT directly. It is of importance that no time should be lost with him (Ferrars), for he (Ferrars) will of course have much to do relative to his (Ferrars) ordination.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

This speech at first puzzled Mrs. Jennings exceedingly. Why Mr. Ferrars was to have been written to about it in such a hurry, she (Jennings) could not immediately comprehend. A few moments' reflection, however, produced a very happy idea, and she (Jennings) exclaimed;--

``Oh, ho!--I understand you. Mr. Ferrars is to be the man. Well, so much the better for him (Ferrars). Ay, to be sure, he (Ferrars) must be ordained in readiness; and I am very glad to find things are so forward between you. But, my dear, is not this rather out of character? Should not the Colonel write himself?--sure, he (Colonel) is the proper person.'' (she)

Elinor did not quite understand the beginning of Mrs. Jennings's speech, neither did she (Jennings) think it worth inquiring into; and therefore only replied to its conclusion.

``Colonel Brandon is so delicate a man, that he (Colonel) rather wished any one to announce his (Colonel) intentions to Mr. Ferrars than himself.'' (unknown)

``And so YOU are forced to do it. Well THAT is an odd kind of delicacy! However, I will not disturb you -LRB-seeing her (Brandon) preparing to write.-RRB- You know your own concerns best. So goodby, my dear. I have not heard of any thing to please me so well since Charlotte was brought to bed.'' (she)

And away she (Charlotte) went; but returning again in a moment,

``I have just been thinking of Betty's sister, my dear. I should be very glad to get her (Betty) so good a mistress. But whether she (Betty) would do for a lady's maid, I am sure I can't tell. She (Betty) is an excellent housemaid, and works very well at her (Betty) needle. However, you will think of all that at your leisure.'' (she)

``Certainly, ma'am,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor, not hearing much of what she (Elinor) said, and more anxious to be alone, than to be mistress of the subject.

How she (mistress) should begin--how she (mistress) should express herself in her (mistress) note to Edward, was now all her (mistress) concern. The particular circumstances between them made a difficulty of that which to any other person would have been the easiest thing in the world; but she (mistress) equally feared to say too much or too little, and sat deliberating over her (mistress) paper, with the pen in her (mistress) hand, till broken in on by the entrance of Edward himself.

He (Edward) had met Mrs. Jennings at the door in her (Jennings) way to the carriage, as he (Edward) came to leave his (Edward) farewell card; and she (Jennings), after apologising for not returning herself, had obliged him (Edward) to enter, by saying that Miss Dashwood was above, and wanted to speak with him (Edward) on very particular business.

Elinor had just been congratulating herself, in the midst of her (Elinor) perplexity, that however difficult it might be to express herself properly by letter, it was at least preferable to giving the information by word of mouth, when her (Elinor) visitor entered, to force her (Elinor) upon this greatest exertion of all. Her (Elinor) astonishment and confusion were very great on his (visitor) so sudden appearance. She (Elinor) had not seen him (visitor) before since his (visitor) engagement became public, and therefore not since his (visitor) knowing her (Elinor) to be acquainted with it; which, with the consciousness of what she (Elinor) had been thinking of, and what she (Elinor) had to tell him (visitor), made her (Elinor) feel particularly uncomfortable for some minutes. He (visitor) too was much distressed; and they sat down together in a most promising state of embarrassment.--Whether he (visitor) had asked her (Elinor) pardon for his (visitor) intrusion on first coming into the room, he (visitor) could not recollect; but determining to be on the safe side, he (visitor) made his (visitor) apology in form as soon as he (visitor) could say any thing, after taking a chair.

``Mrs. Jennings told me,'' (he)
said he (visitor),
``that you wished to speak with me, at least I understood her (Jennings) so--or I certainly should not have intruded on you in such a manner; though at the same time, I should have been extremely sorry to leave London without seeing you and your sister; especially as it will most likely be some time--it is not probable that I should soon have the pleasure of meeting you again. I go to Oxford tomorrow.'' (he)

``You would not have gone, however,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, recovering herself, and determined to get over what she (Elinor) so much dreaded as soon as possible,
``without receiving our good wishes, even if we had not been able to give them in person. Mrs. Jennings was quite right in what she (Jennings) said. I have something of consequence to inform you of, which I was on the point of communicating by paper. I am charged with a most agreeable office -LRB-breathing rather faster than usual as she (Jennings) spoke.-RRB- Colonel Brandon, who was here only ten minutes ago, has desired me to say, that understanding you mean to take orders, he (Colonel) has great pleasure in offering you the living of Delaford now just vacant, and only wishes it were more valuable. Allow me to congratulate you on having so respectable and well-judging a friend, and to join in his (friend) wish that the living--it is about two hundred a-year--were much more considerable, and such as might better enable you to--as might be more than a temporary accommodation to yourself--such, in short, as might establish all your views of happiness.'' (she)

What Edward felt, as he (Edward) could not say it himself, it cannot be expected that any one else should say for him (Edward). He (Edward) LOOKED all the astonishment which such unexpected, such unthought-of information could not fail of exciting; but he (Edward) said only these two words,

``Colonel Brandon!'' (he)

``Yes,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
continued Elinor, gathering more resolution, as some of the worst was over,
``Colonel Brandon means it as a testimony of his (Colonel) concern for what has lately passed--for the cruel situation in which the unjustifiable conduct of your family has placed you--a concern which I am sure Marianne, myself, and all your friends, must share; and likewise as a proof of his (Colonel) high esteem for your general character, and his (Colonel) particular approbation of your behaviour on the present occasion.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Colonel Brandon give ME a living!--Can it be possible?'' (unknown)

``The unkindness of your own relations has made you astonished to find friendship any where.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (he)
replied he (Colonel), with sudden consciousness,
``not to find it in YOU; for I cannot be ignorant that to you, to your goodness, I owe it all.--I feel it--I would express it if I could--but, as you well know, I am no orator.'' (he)

``You are very much mistaken. I do assure you that you owe it entirely, at least almost entirely, to your own merit, and Colonel Brandon's discernment of it. I have had no hand in it. I did not even know, till I understood his (Colonel) design, that the living was vacant; nor had it ever occurred to me that he (Colonel) might have had such a living in his (Colonel) gift. As a friend of mine, of my family, he (Colonel) may, perhaps--indeed I know he (Colonel) HAS, still greater pleasure in bestowing it; but, upon my word, you owe nothing to my solicitation.'' (her)

Truth obliged her (Brandon) to acknowledge some small share in the action, but she (Brandon) was at the same time so unwilling to appear as the benefactress of Edward, that she (Brandon) acknowledged it with hesitation; which probably contributed to fix that suspicion in his (Edward) mind which had recently entered it. For a short time he (Edward) sat deep in thought, after Elinor had ceased to speak;--at last, and as if it were rather an effort, he (Edward) said,

``Colonel Brandon seems a man of great worth and respectability. I have always heard him (Colonel) spoken of as such, and your brother I know esteems him (Colonel) highly. He (Colonel) is undoubtedly a sensible man, and in his (Colonel) manners perfectly the gentleman.'' (he)

``Indeed,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``I believe that you will find him (Colonel), on farther acquaintance, all that you have heard him (Colonel) to be, and as you will be such very near neighbours -LRB-for I understand the parsonage is almost close to the mansion-house,-RRB- it is particularly important that he (Colonel) SHOULD be all this.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Edward made no answer; but when she (Elinor) had turned away her (Elinor) head, gave her (Elinor) a look so serious, so earnest, so uncheerful, as seemed to say, that he (Edward) might hereafter wish the distance between the parsonage and the mansion-house much greater.

``Colonel Brandon, I think, lodges in St. James Street,'' (he)
said he (James), soon afterwards, rising from his (James) chair.

Elinor told him (James) the number of the house.

``I must hurry away then, to give him (James) those thanks which you will not allow me to give YOU; to assure him (James) that he (James) has made me a very--an exceedingly happy man.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor did not offer to detain him (James); and they parted, with a very earnest assurance on HER side of her (Elinor) unceasing good wishes for his (James) happiness in every change of situation that might befall him (James); on HIS (James), with rather an attempt to return the same good will, than the power of expressing it.

``When I see him (James) again,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor to herself, as the door shut him (James) out,
``I shall see him (James) the husband of Lucy.'' (him)

And with this pleasing anticipation, she (Lucy) sat down to reconsider the past, recall the words and endeavour to comprehend all the feelings of Edward; and, of course, to reflect on her (Lucy) own with discontent.

When Mrs. Jennings came home, though she (Jennings) returned from seeing people whom she (Jennings) had never seen before, and of whom therefore she (Jennings) must have a great deal to say, her (Jennings) mind was so much more occupied by the important secret in her (Jennings) possession, than by anything else, that she (Jennings) reverted to it again as soon as Elinor appeared.

``Well, my dear,'' (she)
she (Elinor) cried,
``I sent you up the young man. Did not I do right?--And I suppose you had no great difficulty--You did not find him (man) very unwilling to accept your proposal?'' (she)

``No, ma'am; THAT was not very likely.'' (unknown)

``Well, and how soon will he (man) be ready?--For it seems all to depend upon that.'' (unknown)

``Really,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``I know so little of these kind of forms, that I can hardly even conjecture as to the time, or the preparation necessary; but I suppose two or three months will complete his (man) ordination.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Two or three months!'' (Mrs. Jennings)
cried Mrs. Jennings;
``Lord! my dear, how calmly you talk of it; and can the Colonel wait two or three months! Lord bless me!--I am sure it would put ME quite out of patience!--And though one would be very glad to do a kindness by poor Mr. Ferrars, I do think it is not worth while to wait two or three months for him (Ferrars). Sure somebody else might be found that would do as well; somebody that is in orders already.'' (Mrs. Jennings)

``My dear ma'am,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``what can you be thinking of?-- Why, Colonel Brandon's only object is to be of use to Mr. Ferrars.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Lord bless you, my dear!--Sure you do not mean to persuade me that the Colonel only marries you for the sake of giving ten guineas to Mr. Ferrars!'' (unknown)

The deception could not continue after this; and an explanation immediately took place, by which both gained considerable amusement for the moment, without any material loss of happiness to either, for Mrs. Jennings only exchanged one form of delight for another, and still without forfeiting her (Jennings) expectation of the first.

``Aye, aye, the parsonage is but a small one,'' (she)
said she (Jennings), after the first ebullition of surprise and satisfaction was over,
``and very likely MAY be out of repair; but to hear a man apologising, as I thought, for a house that to my knowledge has five sitting rooms on the ground-floor, and I think the housekeeper told me could make up fifteen beds!--and to you too, that had been used to live in Barton cottage!-- It seems quite ridiculous. But, my dear, we must touch up the Colonel to do some thing to the parsonage, and make it comfortable for them, before Lucy goes to it.'' (she)

``But Colonel Brandon does not seem to have any idea of the living's being enough to allow them to marry.'' (unknown)

``The Colonel is a ninny, my dear; because he (Colonel) has two thousand a-year himself, he (Colonel) thinks that nobody else can marry on less. Take my word for it, that, if I am alive, I shall be paying a visit at Delaford Parsonage before Michaelmas; and I am sure I shan't go if Lucy an't there.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was quite of her (Elinor) opinion, as to the probability of their not waiting for any thing more.

CHAPTER 41

Edward, having carried his (Edward) thanks to Colonel Brandon, proceeded with his (Colonel) happiness to Lucy; and such was the excess of it by the time he (Colonel) reached Bartlett's Buildings, that she (Lucy) was able to assure Mrs. Jennings, who called on her (Jennings) again the next day with her (Jennings) congratulations, that she (Jennings) had never seen him (Colonel) in such spirits before in her (Jennings) life.

Her (Jennings) own happiness, and her (Jennings) own spirits, were at least very certain; and she (Jennings) joined Mrs. Jennings most heartily in her (Jennings) expectation of their being all comfortably together in Delaford Parsonage before Michaelmas. So far was she (Jennings), at the same time, from any backwardness to give Elinor that credit which Edward WOULD give her (Elinor), that she (Elinor) spoke of her (Elinor) friendship for them both with the most grateful warmth, was ready to own all their obligation to her (Elinor), and openly declared that no exertion for their good on Miss Dashwood's part, either present or future, would ever surprise her (Dashwood), for she (Dashwood) believed her (Dashwood) capable of doing any thing in the world for those she (Dashwood) really valued. As for Colonel Brandon, she (Brandon) was not only ready to worship him (Colonel) as a saint, but was moreover truly anxious that he (Colonel) should be treated as one in all worldly concerns; anxious that his (Colonel) tithes should be raised to the utmost; and scarcely resolved to avail herself, at Delaford, as far as she (Brandon) possibly could, of his (Colonel) servants, his (Colonel) carriage, his (Colonel) cows, and his (Colonel) poultry.

It was now above a week since John Dashwood had called in Berkeley Street, and as since that time no notice had been taken by them of his (Colonel) wife's indisposition, beyond one verbal enquiry, Elinor began to feel it necessary to pay her (Elinor) a visit.--This was an obligation, however, which not only opposed her (Elinor) own inclination, but which had not the assistance of any encouragement from her (Elinor) companions. Marianne, not contented with absolutely refusing to go herself, was very urgent to prevent her (Marianne) sister's going at all; and Mrs. Jennings, though her (Jennings) carriage was always at Elinor's service, so very much disliked Mrs. John Dashwood, that not even her (Dashwood) curiosity to see how she (Dashwood) looked after the late discovery, nor her (Dashwood) strong desire to affront her (Dashwood) by taking Edward's part, could overcome her (Dashwood) unwillingness to be in her (Dashwood) company again. The consequence was, that Elinor set out by herself to pay a visit, for which no one could really have less inclination, and to run the risk of a tete-a-tete with a woman, whom neither of the others had so much reason to dislike.

Mrs. Dashwood was denied; but before the carriage could turn from the house, her (Dashwood) husband accidentally came out. He (husband) expressed great pleasure in meeting Elinor, told her (Elinor) that he (husband) had been just going to call in Berkeley Street, and, assuring her (Elinor) that Fanny would be very glad to see her (Fanny), invited her (Fanny) to come in.

They walked up stairs in to the drawing-room.--Nobody was there.

``Fanny is in her (Fanny) own room, I suppose,'' (he)
said he (husband):--
``I will go to her (Fanny) presently, for I am sure she (Fanny) will not have the least objection in the world to seeing YOU.-- Very far from it, indeed. NOW especially there cannot be--but however, you and Marianne were always great favourites.--Why would not Marianne come?'' (he)
--

Elinor made what excuse she (Elinor) could for her (Elinor).

``I am not sorry to see you alone,'' (he)
he (husband) replied,
``for I have a good deal to say to you. This living of Colonel Brandon's--can it be true?--has he (Colonel) really given it to Edward?--I heard it yesterday by chance, and was coming to you on purpose to enquire farther about it.'' (he)

``It is perfectly true.--Colonel Brandon has given the living of Delaford to Edward.'' (unknown)

``Really!--Well, this is very astonishing!--no relationship!--no connection between them!--and now that livings fetch such a price!--what was the value of this?'' (unknown)

``About two hundred a year.'' (unknown)

``Very well--and for the next presentation to a living of that value--supposing the late incumbent to have been old and sickly, and likely to vacate it soon--he (Edward) might have got I dare say--fourteen hundred pounds. And how came he (Edward) not to have settled that matter before this person's death?--NOW indeed it would be too late to sell it, but a man of Colonel Brandon's sense!--I wonder he (Colonel) should be so improvident in a point of such common, such natural, concern!--Well, I am convinced that there is a vast deal of inconsistency in almost every human character. I suppose, however--on recollection--that the case may probably be THIS. Edward is only to hold the living till the person to whom the Colonel has really sold the presentation, is old enough to take it.--Aye, aye, that is the fact, depend upon it.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor contradicted it, however, very positively; and by relating that she (Elinor) had herself been employed in conveying the offer from Colonel Brandon to Edward, and, therefore, must understand the terms on which it was given, obliged him (Edward) to submit to her (Brandon) authority.

``It is truly astonishing!'' (he)
--he (Edward) cried, after hearing what she (Brandon) said--
``what could be the Colonel's motive?'' (she)

``A very simple one--to be of use to Mr. Ferrars.'' (unknown)

``Well, well; whatever Colonel Brandon may be, Edward is a very lucky man.--You will not mention the matter to Fanny, however, for though I have broke it to her (Fanny), and she (Fanny) bears it vastly well,--she (Fanny) will not like to hear it much talked of.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor had some difficulty here to refrain from observing, that she (Elinor) thought Fanny might have borne with composure, an acquisition of wealth to her (Fanny) brother, by which neither she (Fanny) nor her (Fanny) child could be possibly impoverished.

``Mrs. Ferrars,'' (he)
added he (brother), lowering his (brother) voice to the tone becoming so important a subject,
``knows nothing about it at present, and I believe it will be best to keep it entirely concealed from her (Ferrars) as long as may be.-- When the marriage takes place, I fear she (Ferrars) must hear of it all.'' (he)

``But why should such precaution be used?--Though it is not to be supposed that Mrs. Ferrars can have the smallest satisfaction in knowing that her (Ferrars) son has money enough to live upon,--for THAT must be quite out of the question; yet why, upon her (Ferrars) late behaviour, is she (Ferrars) supposed to feel at all?--She (Ferrars) has done with her (Ferrars) son, she (Ferrars) cast him (son) off for ever, and has made all those over whom she (Ferrars) had any influence, cast him (son) off likewise. Surely, after doing so, she (Ferrars) cannot be imagined liable to any impression of sorrow or of joy on his (son) account--she (Ferrars) cannot be interested in any thing that befalls him (son).-- She (Ferrars) would not be so weak as to throw away the comfort of a child, and yet retain the anxiety of a parent!'' (unknown)

``Ah! Elinor,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said John,
``your reasoning is very good, but it is founded on ignorance of human nature. When Edward's unhappy match takes place, depend upon it his (Edward) mother will feel as much as if she (mother) had never discarded him (Edward); and, therefore every circumstance that may accelerate that dreadful event, must be concealed from her (mother) as much as possible. Mrs. Ferrars can never forget that Edward is her (Ferrars) son.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

``You surprise me; I should think it must nearly have escaped her (Ferrars) memory by THIS time.'' (unknown)

``You wrong her (Ferrars) exceedingly. Mrs. Ferrars is one of the most affectionate mothers in the world.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was silent.

``We think NOW,'' (Mr. Dashwood/Mr. Henry Dashwood)
--said Mr. Dashwood, after a short pause,
``of ROBERT'S marrying Miss Morton.'' (Mr. Dashwood/Mr. Henry Dashwood)

Elinor, smiling at the grave and decisive importance of her (Elinor) brother's tone, calmly replied,

``The lady, I suppose, has no choice in the affair.'' (brother)

``Choice!--how do you mean?'' (unknown)

``I only mean that I suppose, from your manner of speaking, it must be the same to Miss Morton whether she (Morton) marry Edward or Robert.'' (unknown)

``Certainly, there can be no difference; for Robert will now to all intents and purposes be considered as the eldest son;--and as to any thing else, they are both very agreeable young men: I do not know that one is superior to the other.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor said no more, and John was also for a short time silent.--His (son) reflections ended thus.

``Of ONE thing, my dear sister,'' (unknown)
kindly taking her (sister) hand, and speaking in an awful whisper,--
``I may assure you;--and I WILL do it, because I know it must gratify you. I have good reason to think--indeed I have it from the best authority, or I should not repeat it, for otherwise it would be very wrong to say any thing about it--but I have it from the very best authority--not that I ever precisely heard Mrs. Ferrars say it herself--but her (Ferrars) daughter DID, and I have it from her (Ferrars)--That in short, whatever objections there might be against a certain--a certain connection--you understand me--it would have been far preferable to her (Ferrars), it would not have given her (Ferrars) half the vexation that THIS does. I was exceedingly pleased to hear that Mrs. Ferrars considered it in that light--a very gratifying circumstance you know to us all. `It would have been beyond comparison,' she (Ferrars) said, `the least evil of the two, and she (Ferrars) would be glad to compound NOW for nothing worse.' But however, all that is quite out of the question--not to be thought of or mentioned--as to any attachment you know--it never could be--all that is gone by. But I thought I would just tell you of this, because I knew how much it must please you. Not that you have any reason to regret, my dear Elinor. There is no doubt of your doing exceedingly well--quite as well, or better, perhaps, all things considered. Has Colonel Brandon been with you lately?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor had heard enough, if not to gratify her (Elinor) vanity, and raise her (Elinor) self-importance, to agitate her (Elinor) nerves and fill her (Elinor) mind;--and she (Elinor) was therefore glad to be spared from the necessity of saying much in reply herself, and from the danger of hearing any thing more from her (Elinor) brother, by the entrance of Mr. Robert Ferrars. After a few moments' chat, John Dashwood, recollecting that Fanny was yet uninformed of her (Fanny) sister's being there, quitted the room in quest of her (Fanny); and Elinor was left to improve her (Elinor) acquaintance with Robert, who, by the gay unconcern, the happy self-complacency of his (acquaintance) manner while enjoying so unfair a division of his (acquaintance) mother's love and liberality, to the prejudice of his (acquaintance) banished brother, earned only by his (acquaintance) own dissipated course of life, and that brother's integrity, was confirming her (mother) most unfavourable opinion of his (acquaintance) head and heart.

They had scarcely been two minutes by themselves, before he (acquaintance) began to speak of Edward; for he (acquaintance), too, had heard of the living, and was very inquisitive on the subject. Elinor repeated the particulars of it, as she (Elinor) had given them to John; and their effect on Robert, though very different, was not less striking than it had been on HIM. He (acquaintance) laughed most immoderately. The idea of Edward's being a clergyman, and living in a small parsonage-house, diverted him (Edward) beyond measure;--and when to that was added the fanciful imagery of Edward reading prayers in a white surplice, and publishing the banns of marriage between John Smith and Mary Brown, he (Smith) could conceive nothing more ridiculous.

Elinor, while she (Elinor) waited in silence and immovable gravity, the conclusion of such folly, could not restrain her (Elinor) eyes from being fixed on him (Smith) with a look that spoke all the contempt it excited. It was a look, however, very well bestowed, for it relieved her (Elinor) own feelings, and gave no intelligence to him (Smith). He (Smith) was recalled from wit to wisdom, not by any reproof of hers, but by his (Smith) own sensibility.

``We may treat it as a joke,'' (he)
said he (Smith), at last, recovering from the affected laugh which had considerably lengthened out the genuine gaiety of the moment--
``but, upon my soul, it is a most serious business. Poor Edward! he (Edward) is ruined for ever. I am extremely sorry for it--for I know him (Edward) to be a very good-hearted creature; as well-meaning a fellow perhaps, as any in the world. You must not judge of him (Edward), Miss Dashwood, from YOUR slight acquaintance.--Poor Edward!--His (Edward) manners are certainly not the happiest in nature.--But we are not all born, you know, with the same powers,--the same address.-- Poor fellow!--to see him (fellow) in a circle of strangers!--to be sure it was pitiable enough!--but upon my soul, I believe he (fellow) has as good a heart as any in the kingdom; and I declare and protest to you I never was so shocked in my life, as when it all burst forth. I could not believe it.-- My mother was the first person who told me of it; and I, feeling myself called on to act with resolution, immediately said to her (mother), `My dear madam, I do not know what you may intend to do on the occasion, but as for myself, I must say, that if Edward does marry this young woman, I never will see him (Edward) again.' That was what I said immediately.-- I was most uncommonly shocked, indeed!--Poor Edward!--he (Edward) has done for himself completely--shut himself out for ever from all decent society!--but, as I directly said to my mother, I am not in the least surprised at it; from his (Edward) style of education, it was always to be expected. My poor mother was half frantic.'' (he)

``Have you ever seen the lady?'' (unknown)

``Yes; once, while she (lady) was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her (lady). The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.-- I remember her (lady) perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him (Edward) myself, and dissuade him (Edward) from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier--I think it is most probable--that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. `My dear fellow,' I should have said, `consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He (Edward) must be starved, you know;--that is certain; absolutely starved.'' (He)

He (Edward) had just settled this point with great composure, when the entrance of Mrs. John Dashwood put an end to the subject. But though SHE never spoke of it out of her (Dashwood) own family, Elinor could see its influence on her (Elinor) mind, in the something like confusion of countenance with which she (Elinor) entered, and an attempt at cordiality in her (Elinor) behaviour to herself. She (Elinor) even proceeded so far as to be concerned to find that Elinor and her (Elinor) sister were so soon to leave town, as she (Elinor) had hoped to see more of them;--an exertion in which her (Elinor) husband, who attended her (Elinor) into the room, and hung enamoured over her (Elinor) accents, seemed to distinguish every thing that was most affectionate and graceful.

CHAPTER 42

One other short call in Harley Street, in which Elinor received her (Elinor) brother's congratulations on their travelling so far towards Barton without any expense, and on Colonel Brandon's being to follow them to Cleveland in a day or two, completed the intercourse of the brother and sisters in town;--and a faint invitation from Fanny, to come to Norland whenever it should happen to be in their way, which of all things was the most unlikely to occur, with a more warm, though less public, assurance, from John to Elinor, of the promptitude with which he (brother) should come to see her (Elinor) at Delaford, was all that foretold any meeting in the country.

It amused her (Elinor) to observe that all her (Elinor) friends seemed determined to send her (Elinor) to Delaford;--a place, in which, of all others, she (Elinor) would now least chuse to visit, or wish to reside; for not only was it considered as her (Elinor) future home by her (Elinor) brother and Mrs. Jennings, but even Lucy, when they parted, gave her (Lucy) a pressing invitation to visit her (Lucy) there.

Very early in April, and tolerably early in the day, the two parties from Hanover Square and Berkeley Street set out from their respective homes, to meet, by appointment, on the road. For the convenience of Charlotte and her (Charlotte) child, they were to be more than two days on their journey, and Mr. Palmer, travelling more expeditiously with Colonel Brandon, was to join them at Cleveland soon after their arrival.

Marianne, few as had been her (Marianne) hours of comfort in London, and eager as she (Marianne) had long been to quit it, could not, when it came to the point, bid adieu to the house in which she (Marianne) had for the last time enjoyed those hopes, and that confidence, in Willoughby, which were now extinguished for ever, without great pain. Nor could she (Marianne) leave the place in which Willoughby remained, busy in new engagements, and new schemes, in which SHE could have no share, without shedding many tears.

Elinor's satisfaction, at the moment of removal, was more positive. She (Elinor) had no such object for her (Elinor) lingering thoughts to fix on, she (Elinor) left no creature behind, from whom it would give her (Elinor) a moment's regret to be divided for ever, she (Elinor) was pleased to be free herself from the persecution of Lucy's friendship, she (Lucy) was grateful for bringing her (Lucy) sister away unseen by Willoughby since his (Willoughby) marriage, and she (Lucy) looked forward with hope to what a few months of tranquility at Barton might do towards restoring Marianne's peace of mind, and confirming her (Marianne) own.

Their journey was safely performed. The second day brought them into the cherished, or the prohibited, county of Somerset, for as such was it dwelt on by turns in Marianne's imagination; and in the forenoon of the third they drove up to Cleveland.

Cleveland was a spacious, modern-built house, situated on a sloping lawn. It had no park, but the pleasure-grounds were tolerably extensive; and like every other place of the same degree of importance, it had its open shrubbery, and closer wood walk, a road of smooth gravel winding round a plantation, led to the front, the lawn was dotted over with timber, the house itself was under the guardianship of the fir, the mountain-ash, and the acacia, and a thick screen of them altogether, interspersed with tall Lombardy poplars, shut out the offices.

Marianne entered the house with a heart swelling with emotion from the consciousness of being only eighty miles from Barton, and not thirty from Combe Magna; and before she (Marianne) had been five minutes within its walls, while the others were busily helping Charlotte to show her (Charlotte) child to the housekeeper, she (Charlotte) quitted it again, stealing away through the winding shrubberies, now just beginning to be in beauty, to gain a distant eminence; where, from its Grecian temple, her (Charlotte) eye, wandering over a wide tract of country to the south-east, could fondly rest on the farthest ridge of hills in the horizon, and fancy that from their summits Combe Magna might be seen.

In such moments of precious, invaluable misery, she (Charlotte) rejoiced in tears of agony to be at Cleveland; and as she (Charlotte) returned by a different circuit to the house, feeling all the happy privilege of country liberty, of wandering from place to place in free and luxurious solitude, she (Charlotte) resolved to spend almost every hour of every day while she (Charlotte) remained with the Palmers, in the indulgence of such solitary rambles.

She (Charlotte) returned just in time to join the others as they quitted the house, on an excursion through its more immediate premises; and the rest of the morning was easily whiled away, in lounging round the kitchen garden, examining the bloom upon its walls, and listening to the gardener's lamentations upon blights, in dawdling through the green-house, where the loss of her (Charlotte) favourite plants, unwarily exposed, and nipped by the lingering frost, raised the laughter of Charlotte,--and in visiting her (Charlotte) poultry-yard, where, in the disappointed hopes of her (Charlotte) dairy-maid, by hens forsaking their nests, or being stolen by a fox, or in the rapid decrease of a promising young brood, she (Charlotte) found fresh sources of merriment.

The morning was fine and dry, and Marianne, in her (Marianne) plan of employment abroad, had not calculated for any change of weather during their stay at Cleveland. With great surprise therefore, did she (Marianne) find herself prevented by a settled rain from going out again after dinner. She (Marianne) had depended on a twilight walk to the Grecian temple, and perhaps all over the grounds, and an evening merely cold or damp would not have deterred her (Marianne) from it; but a heavy and settled rain even SHE could not fancy dry or pleasant weather for walking.

Their party was small, and the hours passed quietly away. Mrs. Palmer had her (Palmer) child, and Mrs. Jennings her (Palmer) carpet-work; they talked of the friends they had left behind, arranged Lady Middleton's engagements, and wondered whether Mr. Palmer and Colonel Brandon would get farther than Reading that night. Elinor, however little concerned in it, joined in their discourse; and Marianne, who had the knack of finding her (Marianne) way in every house to the library, however it might be avoided by the family in general, soon procured herself a book.

Nothing was wanting on Mrs. Palmer's side that constant and friendly good humour could do, to make them feel themselves welcome. The openness and heartiness of her (Palmer) manner more than atoned for that want of recollection and elegance which made her (Palmer) often deficient in the forms of politeness; her (Palmer) kindness, recommended by so pretty a face, was engaging; her (Palmer) folly, though evident was not disgusting, because it was not conceited; and Elinor could have forgiven every thing but her (Elinor) laugh.

The two gentlemen arrived the next day to a very late dinner, affording a pleasant enlargement of the party, and a very welcome variety to their conversation, which a long morning of the same continued rain had reduced very low.

Elinor had seen so little of Mr. Palmer, and in that little had seen so much variety in his (Palmer) address to her (Elinor) sister and herself, that she (Elinor) knew not what to expect to find him (Palmer) in his (Palmer) own family. She (Elinor) found him (Palmer), however, perfectly the gentleman in his (Palmer) behaviour to all his (Palmer) visitors, and only occasionally rude to his (Palmer) wife and her (wife) mother; she (wife) found him (Palmer) very capable of being a pleasant companion, and only prevented from being so always, by too great an aptitude to fancy himself as much superior to people in general, as he (Palmer) must feel himself to be to Mrs. Jennings and Charlotte. For the rest of his (Palmer) character and habits, they were marked, as far as Elinor could perceive, with no traits at all unusual in his (Palmer) sex and time of life. He (Palmer) was nice in his (Palmer) eating, uncertain in his (Palmer) hours; fond of his (Palmer) child, though affecting to slight it; and idled away the mornings at billiards, which ought to have been devoted to business. She (Elinor) liked him (Palmer), however, upon the whole, much better than she (Elinor) had expected, and in her (Elinor) heart was not sorry that she (Elinor) could like him (Palmer) no more;--not sorry to be driven by the observation of his (Palmer) Epicurism, his (Palmer) selfishness, and his (Palmer) conceit, to rest with complacency on the remembrance of Edward's generous temper, simple taste, and diffident feelings.

Of Edward, or at least of some of his (Edward) concerns, she (Elinor) now received intelligence from Colonel Brandon, who had been into Dorsetshire lately; and who, treating her (Brandon) at once as the disinterested friend of Mr. Ferrars, and the kind of confidant of himself, talked to her (Brandon) a great deal of the parsonage at Delaford, described its deficiencies, and told her (Brandon) what he (Ferrars) meant to do himself towards removing them.--His (Ferrars) behaviour to her (Brandon) in this, as well as in every other particular, his (Ferrars) open pleasure in meeting her (Brandon) after an absence of only ten days, his (Ferrars) readiness to converse with her (Brandon), and his (Ferrars) deference for her (Brandon) opinion, might very well justify Mrs. Jennings's persuasion of his (Ferrars) attachment, and would have been enough, perhaps, had not Elinor still, as from the first, believed Marianne his (Ferrars) real favourite, to make her (Marianne) suspect it herself. But as it was, such a notion had scarcely ever entered her (Marianne) head, except by Mrs. Jennings's suggestion; and she (Marianne) could not help believing herself the nicest observer of the two;--she (Marianne) watched his (Ferrars) eyes, while Mrs. Jennings thought only of his (Ferrars) behaviour;--and while his (Ferrars) looks of anxious solicitude on Marianne's feeling, in her (Marianne) head and throat, the beginning of a heavy cold, because unexpressed by words, entirely escaped the latter lady's observation;--SHE could discover in them the quick feelings, and needless alarm of a lover.

Two delightful twilight walks on the third and fourth evenings of her (lady) being there, not merely on the dry gravel of the shrubbery, but all over the grounds, and especially in the most distant parts of them, where there was something more of wildness than in the rest, where the trees were the oldest, and the grass was the longest and wettest, had--assisted by the still greater imprudence of sitting in her (lady) wet shoes and stockings--given Marianne a cold so violent as, though for a day or two trifled with or denied, would force itself by increasing ailments on the concern of every body, and the notice of herself. Prescriptions poured in from all quarters, and as usual, were all declined. Though heavy and feverish, with a pain in her (Marianne) limbs, and a cough, and a sore throat, a good night's rest was to cure her (Marianne) entirely; and it was with difficulty that Elinor prevailed on her (Elinor), when she (Elinor) went to bed, to try one or two of the simplest of the remedies.

CHAPTER 43

Marianne got up the next morning at her (Marianne) usual time; to every inquiry replied that she (Marianne) was better, and tried to prove herself so, by engaging in her (Marianne) accustomary employments. But a day spent in sitting shivering over the fire with a book in her (Marianne) hand, which she (Marianne) was unable to read, or in lying, weary and languid, on a sofa, did not speak much in favour of her (Marianne) amendment; and when, at last, she (Marianne) went early to bed, more and more indisposed, Colonel Brandon was only astonished at her (Brandon) sister's composure, who, though attending and nursing her (Brandon) the whole day, against Marianne's inclination, and forcing proper medicines on her (Marianne) at night, trusted, like Marianne, to the certainty and efficacy of sleep, and felt no real alarm.

A very restless and feverish night, however, disappointed the expectation of both; and when Marianne, after persisting in rising, confessed herself unable to sit up, and returned voluntarily to her (Marianne) bed, Elinor was very ready to adopt Mrs. Jennings's advice, of sending for the Palmers' apothecary.

He (Palmers) came, examined his (Palmers) patient, and though encouraging Miss Dashwood to expect that a very few days would restore her (Dashwood) sister to health, yet, by pronouncing her (Dashwood) disorder to have a putrid tendency, and allowing the word

``infection'' (sister)
to pass his (Palmers) lips, gave instant alarm to Mrs. Palmer, on her (Palmer) baby's account. Mrs. Jennings, who had been inclined from the first to think Marianne's complaint more serious than Elinor, now looked very grave on Mr. Harris's report, and confirming Charlotte's fears and caution, urged the necessity of her (Charlotte) immediate removal with her (Charlotte) infant; and Mr. Palmer, though treating their apprehensions as idle, found the anxiety and importunity of his (Palmer) wife too great to be withstood. Her (wife) departure, therefore, was fixed on; and within an hour after Mr. Harris's arrival, she (wife) set off, with her (wife) little boy and his (boy) nurse, for the house of a near relation of Mr. Palmer's, who lived a few miles on the other side of Bath; whither her (wife) husband promised, at her (wife) earnest entreaty, to join her (wife) in a day or two; and whither she (wife) was almost equally urgent with her (wife) mother to accompany her (wife). Mrs. Jennings, however, with a kindness of heart which made Elinor really love her (Elinor), declared her (Elinor) resolution of not stirring from Cleveland as long as Marianne remained ill, and of endeavouring, by her (Marianne) own attentive care, to supply to her (Marianne) the place of the mother she (Marianne) had taken her (Marianne) from; and Elinor found her (Elinor) on every occasion a most willing and active helpmate, desirous to share in all her (Elinor) fatigues, and often by her (Elinor) better experience in nursing, of material use.

Poor Marianne, languid and low from the nature of her (Marianne) malady, and feeling herself universally ill, could no longer hope that tomorrow would find her (Marianne) recovered; and the idea of what tomorrow would have produced, but for this unlucky illness, made every ailment severe; for on that day they were to have begun their journey home; and, attended the whole way by a servant of Mrs. Jennings, were to have taken their mother by surprise on the following forenoon. The little she (Jennings) said was all in lamentation of this inevitable delay; though Elinor tried to raise her (Elinor) spirits, and make her (Elinor) believe, as she (Elinor) THEN really believed herself, that it would be a very short one.

The next day produced little or no alteration in the state of the patient; she (Elinor) certainly was not better, and, except that there was no amendment, did not appear worse. Their party was now farther reduced; for Mr. Palmer, though very unwilling to go as well from real humanity and good-nature, as from a dislike of appearing to be frightened away by his (Palmer) wife, was persuaded at last by Colonel Brandon to perform his (Colonel) promise of following her (Brandon); and while he (Colonel) was preparing to go, Colonel Brandon himself, with a much greater exertion, began to talk of going likewise.--Here, however, the kindness of Mrs. Jennings interposed most acceptably; for to send the Colonel away while his (Colonel) love was in so much uneasiness on her (Jennings) sister's account, would be to deprive them both, she (Jennings) thought, of every comfort; and therefore telling him (Colonel) at once that his (Colonel) stay at Cleveland was necessary to herself, that she (Jennings) should want him (Colonel) to play at piquet of an evening, while Miss Dashwood was above with her (Dashwood) sister, &c. she (Dashwood) urged him (Colonel) so strongly to remain, that he (Colonel), who was gratifying the first wish of his (Colonel) own heart by a compliance, could not long even affect to demur; especially as Mrs. Jennings's entreaty was warmly seconded by Mr. Palmer, who seemed to feel a relief to himself, in leaving behind him (Palmer) a person so well able to assist or advise Miss Dashwood in any emergence.

Marianne was, of course, kept in ignorance of all these arrangements. She (Marianne) knew not that she (Marianne) had been the means of sending the owners of Cleveland away, in about seven days from the time of their arrival. It gave her (Marianne) no surprise that she (Marianne) saw nothing of Mrs. Palmer; and as it gave her (Palmer) likewise no concern, she (Palmer) never mentioned her (Palmer) name.

Two days passed away from the time of Mr. Palmer's departure, and her (Palmer) situation continued, with little variation, the same. Mr. Harris, who attended her (Palmer) every day, still talked boldly of a speedy recovery, and Miss Dashwood was equally sanguine; but the expectation of the others was by no means so cheerful. Mrs. Jennings had determined very early in the seizure that Marianne would never get over it, and Colonel Brandon, who was chiefly of use in listening to Mrs. Jennings's forebodings, was not in a state of mind to resist their influence. He (Colonel) tried to reason himself out of fears, which the different judgment of the apothecary seemed to render absurd; but the many hours of each day in which he (Colonel) was left entirely alone, were but too favourable for the admission of every melancholy idea, and he (Colonel) could not expel from his (Colonel) mind the persuasion that he (Colonel) should see Marianne no more.

On the morning of the third day however, the gloomy anticipations of both were almost done away; for when Mr. Harris arrived, he (Harris) declared his (Harris) patient materially better. Her (Marianne) pulse was much stronger, and every symptom more favourable than on the preceding visit. Elinor, confirmed in every pleasant hope, was all cheerfulness; rejoicing that in her (Elinor) letters to her (Elinor) mother, she (Elinor) had pursued her (Elinor) own judgment rather than her (Elinor) friend's, in making very light of the indisposition which delayed them at Cleveland; and almost fixing on the time when Marianne would be able to travel.

But the day did not close so auspiciously as it began.-- Towards the evening Marianne became ill again, growing more heavy, restless, and uncomfortable than before. Her (Marianne) sister, however, still sanguine, was willing to attribute the change to nothing more than the fatigue of having sat up to have her (Marianne) bed made; and carefully administering the cordials prescribed, saw her (Marianne), with satisfaction, sink at last into a slumber, from which she (Marianne) expected the most beneficial effects. Her (Marianne) sleep, though not so quiet as Elinor wished to see it, lasted a considerable time; and anxious to observe the result of it herself, she (Elinor) resolved to sit with her (Elinor) during the whole of it. Mrs. Jennings, knowing nothing of any change in the patient, went unusually early to bed; her (Jennings) maid, who was one of the principal nurses, was recreating herself in the housekeeper's room, and Elinor remained alone with Marianne.

The repose of the latter became more and more disturbed; and her (Marianne) sister, who watched, with unremitting attention her (Marianne) continual change of posture, and heard the frequent but inarticulate sounds of complaint which passed her (Marianne) lips, was almost wishing to rouse her (Marianne) from so painful a slumber, when Marianne, suddenly awakened by some accidental noise in the house, started hastily up, and, with feverish wildness, cried out,--

``Is mama coming?--'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Not yet,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried the other, concealing her (mama) terror, and assisting Marianne to lie down again,
``but she (Marianne) will be here, I hope, before it is long. It is a great way, you know, from hence to Barton.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``But she (Marianne) must not go round by London,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
cried Marianne, in the same hurried manner.
``I shall never see her (Marianne), if she (Marianne) goes by London.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor perceived with alarm that she (Elinor) was not quite herself, and, while attempting to soothe her (Elinor), eagerly felt her (Elinor) pulse. It was lower and quicker than ever! and Marianne, still talking wildly of mama, her (Marianne) alarm increased so rapidly, as to determine her (Marianne) on sending instantly for Mr. Harris, and despatching a messenger to Barton for her (Marianne) mother. To consult with Colonel Brandon on the best means of effecting the latter, was a thought which immediately followed the resolution of its performance; and as soon she (Brandon) had rung up the maid to take her (Brandon) place by her (Brandon) sister, she (Brandon) hastened down to the drawing-room, where she (Brandon) knew he (Colonel) was generally to be found at a much later hour than the present.

It was no time for hesitation. Her (Brandon) fears and her (Brandon) difficulties were immediately before him (Colonel). Her (Brandon) fears, he (Colonel) had no courage, no confidence to attempt the removal of:--he (Colonel) listened to them in silent despondence;--but her (Brandon) difficulties were instantly obviated, for with a readiness that seemed to speak the occasion, and the service pre-arranged in his (Colonel) mind, he (Colonel) offered himself as the messenger who should fetch Mrs. Dashwood. Elinor made no resistance that was not easily overcome. She (Elinor) thanked him (Colonel) with brief, though fervent gratitude, and while he (Colonel) went to hurry off his (Colonel) servant with a message to Mr. Harris, and an order for post-horses directly, she (Elinor) wrote a few lines to her (Elinor) mother.

The comfort of such a friend at that moment as Colonel Brandon--or such a companion for her (Brandon) mother,--how gratefully was it felt!--a companion whose judgment would guide, whose attendance must relieve, and whose friendship might soothe her (Brandon)!--as far as the shock of such a summons COULD be lessened to her (Brandon), his (companion) presence, his (companion) manners, his (companion) assistance, would lessen it.

HE (companion), meanwhile, whatever he (companion) might feel, acted with all the firmness of a collected mind, made every necessary arrangement with the utmost despatch, and calculated with exactness the time in which she (Brandon) might look for his (companion) return. Not a moment was lost in delay of any kind. The horses arrived, even before they were expected, and Colonel Brandon only pressing her (Brandon) hand with a look of solemnity, and a few words spoken too low to reach her (Brandon) ear, hurried into the carriage. It was then about twelve o'clock, and she (Brandon) returned to her (Brandon) sister's apartment to wait for the arrival of the apothecary, and to watch by her (Brandon) the rest of the night. It was a night of almost equal suffering to both. Hour after hour passed away in sleepless pain and delirium on Marianne's side, and in the most cruel anxiety on Elinor's, before Mr. Harris appeared. Her (Elinor) apprehensions once raised, paid by their excess for all her (Elinor) former security; and the servant who sat up with her (Elinor), for she (Elinor) would not allow Mrs. Jennings to be called, only tortured her (Jennings) more, by hints of what her (Jennings) mistress had always thought.

Marianne's ideas were still, at intervals, fixed incoherently on her (Jennings) mother, and whenever she (Jennings) mentioned her (Jennings) name, it gave a pang to the heart of poor Elinor, who, reproaching herself for having trifled with so many days of illness, and wretched for some immediate relief, fancied that all relief might soon be in vain, that every thing had been delayed too long, and pictured to herself her (Elinor) suffering mother arriving too late to see this darling child, or to see her (Elinor) rational.

She (Elinor) was on the point of sending again for Mr. Harris, or if HE (Harris) could not come, for some other advice, when the former--but not till after five o'clock--arrived. His (Harris) opinion, however, made some little amends for his (Harris) delay, for though acknowledging a very unexpected and unpleasant alteration in his (Harris) patient, he (Harris) would not allow the danger to be material, and talked of the relief which a fresh mode of treatment must procure, with a confidence which, in a lesser degree, was communicated to Elinor. He (Harris) promised to call again in the course of three or four hours, and left both the patient and her (Elinor) anxious attendant more composed than he (attendant) had found them.

With strong concern, and with many reproaches for not being called to their aid, did Mrs. Jennings hear in the morning of what had passed. Her (Jennings) former apprehensions, now with greater reason restored, left her (Jennings) no doubt of the event; and though trying to speak comfort to Elinor, her (Elinor) conviction of her (Elinor) sister's danger would not allow her (Elinor) to offer the comfort of hope. Her (Elinor) heart was really grieved. The rapid decay, the early death of a girl so young, so lovely as Marianne, must have struck a less interested person with concern. On Mrs. Jennings's compassion she (Jennings) had other claims. She (Jennings) had been for three months her (Jennings) companion, was still under her (Jennings) care, and she (Jennings) was known to have been greatly injured, and long unhappy. The distress of her (Jennings) sister too, particularly a favourite, was before her (Jennings);--and as for their mother, when Mrs. Jennings considered that Marianne might probably be to HER what Charlotte was to herself, her (Charlotte) sympathy in HER sufferings was very sincere.

Mr. Harris was punctual in his (Harris) second visit;--but he (Harris) came to be disappointed in his (Harris) hopes of what the last would produce. His (Harris) medicines had failed;--the fever was unabated; and Marianne only more quiet--not more herself--remained in a heavy stupor. Elinor, catching all, and more than all, his (Harris) fears in a moment, proposed to call in further advice. But he (Harris) judged it unnecessary: he (Harris) had still something more to try, some more fresh application, of whose success he (Harris) was as confident as the last, and his (Harris) visit concluded with encouraging assurances which reached the ear, but could not enter the heart of Miss Dashwood. She (Dashwood) was calm, except when she (Dashwood) thought of her (Dashwood) mother; but she (Dashwood) was almost hopeless; and in this state she (Dashwood) continued till noon, scarcely stirring from her (Dashwood) sister's bed, her (Dashwood) thoughts wandering from one image of grief, one suffering friend to another, and her (Dashwood) spirits oppressed to the utmost by the conversation of Mrs. Jennings, who scrupled not to attribute the severity and danger of this attack to the many weeks of previous indisposition which Marianne's disappointment had brought on. Elinor felt all the reasonableness of the idea, and it gave fresh misery to her (Elinor) reflections.

About noon, however, she (Elinor) began--but with a caution--a dread of disappointment which for some time kept her (Elinor) silent, even to her (Elinor) friend--to fancy, to hope she (Elinor) could perceive a slight amendment in her (Elinor) sister's pulse;--she (Elinor) waited, watched, and examined it again and again;--and at last, with an agitation more difficult to bury under exterior calmness, than all her (Elinor) foregoing distress, ventured to communicate her (Elinor) hopes. Mrs. Jennings, though forced, on examination, to acknowledge a temporary revival, tried to keep her (Jennings) young friend from indulging a thought of its continuance;--and Elinor, conning over every injunction of distrust, told herself likewise not to hope. But it was too late. Hope had already entered; and feeling all its anxious flutter, she (Elinor) bent over her (Elinor) sister to watch--she (Elinor) hardly knew for what. Half an hour passed away, and the favourable symptom yet blessed her (Elinor). Others even arose to confirm it. Her (Elinor) breath, her (Elinor) skin, her (Elinor) lips, all flattered Elinor with signs of amendment; and Marianne fixed her (Marianne) eyes on her (Marianne) with a rational, though languid, gaze. Anxiety and hope now oppressed her (Marianne) in equal degrees, and left her (Marianne) no moment of tranquillity till the arrival of Mr. Harris at four o'clock;--when his (Harris) assurances, his (Harris) felicitations on a recovery in her (Marianne) sister even surpassing his (Harris) expectation, gave her (Marianne) confidence, comfort, and tears of joy.

Marianne was in every respect materially better, and he (Harris) declared her (Marianne) entirely out of danger. Mrs. Jennings, perhaps satisfied with the partial justification of her (Jennings) forebodings which had been found in their late alarm, allowed herself to trust in his (Harris) judgment, and admitted, with unfeigned joy, and soon with unequivocal cheerfulness, the probability of an entire recovery.

Elinor could not be cheerful. Her (Elinor) joy was of a different kind, and led to any thing rather than to gaiety. Marianne restored to life, health, friends, and to her (Marianne) doting mother, was an idea to fill her (Marianne) heart with sensations of exquisite comfort, and expand it in fervent gratitude;--but it led to no outward demonstrations of joy, no words, no smiles. All within Elinor's breast was satisfaction, silent and strong.

She (Elinor) continued by the side of her (Elinor) sister, with little intermission the whole afternoon, calming every fear, satisfying every inquiry of her (Elinor) enfeebled spirits, supplying every succour, and watching almost every look and every breath. The possibility of a relapse would of course, in some moments, occur to remind her (Elinor) of what anxiety was--but when she (Elinor) saw, on her (Elinor) frequent and minute examination, that every symptom of recovery continued, and saw Marianne at six o'clock sink into a quiet, steady, and to all appearance comfortable, sleep, she (Marianne) silenced every doubt.

The time was now drawing on, when Colonel Brandon might be expected back. At ten o'clock, she (Brandon) trusted, or at least not much later her (Brandon) mother would be relieved from the dreadful suspense in which she (Brandon) must now be travelling towards them. The Colonel, too!--perhaps scarcely less an object of pity!--Oh!--how slow was the progress of time which yet kept them in ignorance!

At seven o'clock, leaving Marianne still sweetly asleep, she (Marianne) joined Mrs. Jennings in the drawing-room to tea. Of breakfast she (Marianne) had been kept by her (Marianne) fears, and of dinner by their sudden reverse, from eating much;--and the present refreshment, therefore, with such feelings of content as she (Marianne) brought to it, was particularly welcome. Mrs. Jennings would have persuaded her (Jennings), at its conclusion, to take some rest before her (Jennings) mother's arrival, and allow HER to take her (Jennings) place by Marianne; but Elinor had no sense of fatigue, no capability of sleep at that moment about her (Elinor), and she (Elinor) was not to be kept away from her (Elinor) sister an unnecessary instant. Mrs. Jennings therefore attending her (Jennings) up stairs into the sick chamber, to satisfy herself that all continued right, left her (Jennings) there again to her (Jennings) charge and her (Jennings) thoughts, and retired to her (Jennings) own room to write letters and sleep.

The night was cold and stormy. The wind roared round the house, and the rain beat against the windows; but Elinor, all happiness within, regarded it not. Marianne slept through every blast; and the travellers--they had a rich reward in store, for every present inconvenience.

The clock struck eight. Had it been ten, Elinor would have been convinced that at that moment she (Elinor) heard a carriage driving up to the house; and so strong was the persuasion that she (Elinor) DID, in spite of the ALMOST impossibility of their being already come, that she (Elinor) moved into the adjoining dressing-closet and opened a window shutter, to be satisfied of the truth. She (Elinor) instantly saw that her (Elinor) ears had not deceived her (Elinor). The flaring lamps of a carriage were immediately in view. By their uncertain light she (Elinor) thought she (Elinor) could discern it to be drawn by four horses; and this, while it told the excess of her (Elinor) poor mother's alarm, gave some explanation to such unexpected rapidity.

Never in her (Elinor) life had Elinor found it so difficult to be calm, as at that moment. The knowledge of what her (Elinor) mother must be feeling as the carriage stopt at the door--of her (Elinor) doubt--her (Elinor) dread--perhaps her (Elinor) despair!--and of what SHE had to tell!--with such knowledge it was impossible to be calm. All that remained to be done was to be speedy; and, therefore staying only till she (Elinor) could leave Mrs. Jennings's maid with her (Jennings) sister, she (Jennings) hurried down stairs.

The bustle in the vestibule, as she (Jennings) passed along an inner lobby, assured her (Jennings) that they were already in the house. She (Jennings) rushed to the drawing-room,--she (Jennings) entered it,--and saw only Willoughby.

CHAPTER 44

Elinor, starting back with a look of horror at the sight of him (Willoughby), obeyed the first impulse of her (Elinor) heart in turning instantly to quit the room, and her (Elinor) hand was already on the lock, when its action was suspended by his (Willoughby) hastily advancing, and saying, in a voice rather of command than supplication,

``Miss Dashwood, for half an hour--for ten minutes--I entreat you to stay.'' (him)

``No, sir,'' (she)
she (Dashwood) replied with firmness,
``I shall NOT stay. Your business cannot be with ME. The servants, I suppose, forgot to tell you that Mr. Palmer was not in the house.'' (she)

``Had they told me,'' (he)
he (Palmer) cried with vehemence,
``that Mr. Palmer and all his (Palmer) relations were at the devil, it would not have turned me from the door. My business is with you, and only you.'' (he)

``With me!'' (unknown)
--in the utmost amazement--
``well, sir,--be quick--and if you can--less violent.'' (unknown)

``Sit down, and I will be both.'' (She)

She (you) hesitated; she (you) knew not what to do. The possibility of Colonel Brandon's arriving and finding her (Brandon) there, came across her (Brandon). But she (Brandon) had promised to hear him (Colonel), and her (Brandon) curiosity no less than her (Brandon) honor was engaged. After a moment's recollection, therefore, concluding that prudence required dispatch, and that her (Brandon) acquiescence would best promote it, she (Brandon) walked silently towards the table, and sat down. He (Colonel) took the opposite chair, and for half a minute not a word was said by either.

``Pray be quick, sir,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
--said Elinor, impatiently;--
``I have no time to spare.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

He (Colonel) was sitting in an attitude of deep meditation, and seemed not to hear her (Elinor).

``Your sister,'' (he)
said he (Colonel), with abruptness, a moment afterwards--
``is out of danger. I heard it from the servant. God be praised!--But is it true? is it really true?'' (he)

Elinor would not speak. He (God) repeated the inquiry with yet greater eagerness.

``For God's sake tell me, is she (Elinor) out of danger, or is she (Elinor) not?'' (unknown)

``We hope she (Elinor) is.'' (He)

He (God) rose up, and walked across the room.

``Had I known as much half an hour ago--But since I AM here,'' (he)
--speaking with a forced vivacity as he (God) returned to his (God) seat--
``what does it signify?--For once, Miss Dashwood--it will be the last time, perhaps--let us be cheerful together.--I am in a fine mood for gaiety.-- Tell me honestly'' (he)
--a deeper glow overspreading his (God) cheeks--
``do you think me most a knave or a fool?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor looked at him (God) with greater astonishment than ever. She (Elinor) began to think that he (God) must be in liquor;--the strangeness of such a visit, and of such manners, seemed no otherwise intelligible; and with this impression she (Elinor) immediately rose, saying,

``Mr. Willoughby, I advise you at present to return to Combe--I am not at leisure to remain with you longer.-- Whatever your business may be with me, will it be better recollected and explained to-morrow.'' (she)

``I understand you,'' (he)
he (Combe) replied, with an expressive smile, and a voice perfectly calm;
``yes, I am very drunk.-- A pint of porter with my cold beef at Marlborough was enough to over-set me.'' (he)

``At Marlborough!'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
--cried Elinor, more and more at a loss to understand what he (porter) would be at.

``Yes,--I left London this morning at eight o'clock, and the only ten minutes I have spent out of my chaise since that time procured me a nuncheon at Marlborough.'' (he)

The steadiness of his (porter) manner, and the intelligence of his (porter) eye as he (porter) spoke, convincing Elinor, that whatever other unpardonable folly might bring him (porter) to Cleveland, he (porter) was not brought there by intoxication, she (Elinor) said, after a moment's recollection,

``Mr. Willoughby, you OUGHT to feel, and I certainly DO--that after what has passed--your coming here in this manner, and forcing yourself upon my notice, requires a very particular excuse.--What is it, that you mean by it?'' (she)
--

``I mean,'' (he)
--said he (Willoughby), with serious energy--
``if I can, to make you hate me one degree less than you do NOW. I mean to offer some kind of explanation, some kind of apology, for the past; to open my whole heart to you, and by convincing you, that though I have been always a blockhead, I have not been always a rascal, to obtain something like forgiveness from Ma--from your sister.'' (he)
