``Is this the real reason of your coming?'' (unknown)

``Upon my soul it is,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
--was his (rascal) answer, with a warmth which brought all the former Willoughby to her (sister) remembrance, and in spite of herself made her (sister) think him (Willoughby) sincere.

``If that is all, you may be satisfied already,--for Marianne DOES--she (Marianne) has LONG forgiven you.'' (unknown)

``Has she (Marianne)?'' (he)
--he (Willoughby) cried, in the same eager tone.--
``Then she (Marianne) has forgiven me before she (Marianne) ought to have done it. But she (Marianne) shall forgive me again, and on more reasonable grounds.--NOW will you listen to me?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor bowed her (Elinor) assent.

``I do not know,'' (he)
said he (Willoughby), after a pause of expectation on her (Elinor) side, and thoughtfulness on his (Willoughby) own,--
``how YOU may have accounted for my behaviour to your sister, or what diabolical motive you may have imputed to me.-- Perhaps you will hardly think the better of me,--it is worth the trial however, and you shall hear every thing. When I first became intimate in your family, I had no other intention, no other view in the acquaintance than to pass my time pleasantly while I was obliged to remain in Devonshire, more pleasantly than I had ever done before. Your sister's lovely person and interesting manners could not but please me; and her (sister) behaviour to me almost from the first, was of a kind--It is astonishing, when I reflect on what it was, and what SHE was, that my heart should have been so insensible! But at first I must confess, my vanity only was elevated by it. Careless of her (sister) happiness, thinking only of my own amusement, giving way to feelings which I had always been too much in the habit of indulging, I endeavoured, by every means in my power, to make myself pleasing to her (sister), without any design of returning her (sister) affection.'' (he)

Miss Dashwood, at this point, turning her (Dashwood) eyes on him (sister) with the most angry contempt, stopped him (sister), by saying,

``It is hardly worth while, Mr. Willoughby, for you to relate, or for me to listen any longer. Such a beginning as this cannot be followed by any thing.-- Do not let me be pained by hearing any thing more on the subject.'' (him)

``I insist on you hearing the whole of it,'' (he)
he (Willoughby) replied,
``My fortune was never large, and I had always been expensive, always in the habit of associating with people of better income than myself. Every year since my coming of age, or even before, I believe, had added to my debts; and though the death of my old cousin, Mrs. Smith, was to set me free; yet that event being uncertain, and possibly far distant, it had been for some time my intention to re-establish my circumstances by marrying a woman of fortune. To attach myself to your sister, therefore, was not a thing to be thought of;--and with a meanness, selfishness, cruelty--which no indignant, no contemptuous look, even of yours, Miss Dashwood, can ever reprobate too much--I was acting in this manner, trying to engage her (Dashwood) regard, without a thought of returning it.--But one thing may be said for me: even in that horrid state of selfish vanity, I did not know the extent of the injury I meditated, because I did not THEN know what it was to love. But have I ever known it?--Well may it be doubted; for, had I really loved, could I have sacrificed my feelings to vanity, to avarice?--or, what is more, could I have sacrificed hers?-- But I have done it. To avoid a comparative poverty, which her (I) affection and her (I) society would have deprived of all its horrors, I have, by raising myself to affluence, lost every thing that could make it a blessing.'' (he)

``You did then,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, a little softened,
``believe yourself at one time attached to her (Elinor)?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``To have resisted such attractions, to have withstood such tenderness!--Is there a man on earth who could have done it?--Yes, I found myself, by insensible degrees, sincerely fond of her (Elinor); and the happiest hours of my life were what I spent with her (Elinor) when I felt my intentions were strictly honourable, and my feelings blameless. Even THEN, however, when fully determined on paying my addresses to her (Elinor), I allowed myself most improperly to put off, from day to day, the moment of doing it, from an unwillingness to enter into an engagement while my circumstances were so greatly embarrassed. I will not reason here--nor will I stop for YOU to expatiate on the absurdity, and the worse than absurdity, of scrupling to engage my faith where my honour was already bound. The event has proved, that I was a cunning fool, providing with great circumspection for a possible opportunity of making myself contemptible and wretched for ever. At last, however, my resolution was taken, and I had determined, as soon as I could engage her (myself) alone, to justify the attentions I had so invariably paid her (myself), and openly assure her (myself) of an affection which I had already taken such pains to display. But in the interim--in the interim of the very few hours that were to pass, before I could have an opportunity of speaking with her (myself) in private--a circumstance occurred--an unlucky circumstance, to ruin all my resolution, and with it all my comfort. A discovery took place,'' (he)
--here he (myself) hesitated and looked down.--
``Mrs. Smith had somehow or other been informed, I imagine by some distant relation, whose interest it was to deprive me of her (Smith) favour, of an affair, a connection--but I need not explain myself farther,'' (he)
he (myself) added, looking at her (Smith) with an heightened colour and an enquiring eye--
``your particular intimacy--you have probably heard the whole story long ago.'' (he)

``I have,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
returned Elinor, colouring likewise, and hardening her (Elinor) heart anew against any compassion for him (myself),
``I have heard it all. And how you will explain away any part of your guilt in that dreadful business, I confess is beyond my comprehension.'' (him)

``Remember,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
cried Willoughby,
``from whom you received the account. Could it be an impartial one? I acknowledge that her (Elinor) situation and her (Elinor) character ought to have been respected by me. I do not mean to justify myself, but at the same time cannot leave you to suppose that I have nothing to urge--that because she (Elinor) was injured she (Elinor) was irreproachable, and because I was a libertine, SHE must be a saint. If the violence of her (Elinor) passions, the weakness of her (Elinor) understanding--I do not mean, however, to defend myself. Her (Elinor) affection for me deserved better treatment, and I often, with great self-reproach, recall the tenderness which, for a very short time, had the power of creating any return. I wish--I heartily wish it had never been. But I have injured more than herself; and I have injured one, whose affection for me---LRB-may I say it?-RRB- was scarcely less warm than hers; and whose mind--Oh! how infinitely superior!'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
--

``Your indifference, however, towards that unfortunate girl--I must say it, unpleasant to me as the discussion of such a subject may well be--your indifference is no apology for your cruel neglect of her (girl). Do not think yourself excused by any weakness, any natural defect of understanding on her (girl) side, in the wanton cruelty so evident on yours. You must have known, that while you were enjoying yourself in Devonshire pursuing fresh schemes, always gay, always happy, she (girl) was reduced to the extremest indigence.'' (unknown)

``But, upon my soul, I did NOT know it,'' (he)
he (I) warmly replied;
``I did not recollect that I had omitted to give her (girl) my direction; and common sense might have told her (girl) how to find it out.'' (he)

``Well, sir, and what said Mrs. Smith?'' (unknown)

``She (Smith) taxed me with the offence at once, and my confusion may be guessed. The purity of her (Smith) life, the formality of her (Smith) notions, her (Smith) ignorance of the world--every thing was against me. The matter itself I could not deny, and vain was every endeavour to soften it. She (Smith) was previously disposed, I believe, to doubt the morality of my conduct in general, and was moreover discontented with the very little attention, the very little portion of my time that I had bestowed on her (Smith), in my present visit. In short, it ended in a total breach. By one measure I might have saved myself. In the height of her (Smith) morality, good woman! she (Smith) offered to forgive the past, if I would marry Eliza. That could not be--and I was formally dismissed from her (Eliza) favour and her (Eliza) house. The night following this affair--I was to go the next morning--was spent by me in deliberating on what my future conduct should be. The struggle was great--but it ended too soon. My affection for Marianne, my thorough conviction of her (Marianne) attachment to me--it was all insufficient to outweigh that dread of poverty, or get the better of those false ideas of the necessity of riches, which I was naturally inclined to feel, and expensive society had increased. I had reason to believe myself secure of my present wife, if I chose to address her (wife), and I persuaded myself to think that nothing else in common prudence remained for me to do. A heavy scene however awaited me, before I could leave Devonshire;--I was engaged to dine with you on that very day; some apology was therefore necessary for my breaking this engagement. But whether I should write this apology, or deliver it in person, was a point of long debate. To see Marianne, I felt, would be dreadful, and I even doubted whether I could see her (Marianne) again, and keep to my resolution. In that point, however, I undervalued my own magnanimity, as the event declared; for I went, I saw her (Marianne), and saw her (Marianne) miserable, and left her (Marianne) miserable--and left her (Marianne) hoping never to see her (Marianne) again.'' (unknown)

``Why did you call, Mr. Willoughby?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, reproachfully;
``a note would have answered every purpose.-- Why was it necessary to call?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``It was necessary to my own pride. I could not bear to leave the country in a manner that might lead you, or the rest of the neighbourhood, to suspect any part of what had really passed between Mrs. Smith and myself--and I resolved therefore on calling at the cottage, in my way to Honiton. The sight of your dear sister, however, was really dreadful; and, to heighten the matter, I found her (sister) alone. You were all gone I do not know where. I had left her (sister) only the evening before, so fully, so firmly resolved within my self on doing right! A few hours were to have engaged her (sister) to me for ever; and I remember how happy, how gay were my spirits, as I walked from the cottage to Allenham, satisfied with myself, delighted with every body! But in this, our last interview of friendship, I approached her (sister) with a sense of guilt that almost took from me the power of dissembling. Her (sister) sorrow, her (sister) disappointment, her (sister) deep regret, when I told her (sister) that I was obliged to leave Devonshire so immediately--I never shall forget it--united too with such reliance, such confidence in me!--Oh, God!--what a hard-hearted rascal I was!'' (unknown)

They were both silent for a few moments. Elinor first spoke.

``Did you tell her (Elinor) that you should soon return?'' (unknown)

``I do not know what I told her (Elinor),'' (he)
he (God) replied, impatiently;
``less than was due to the past, beyond a doubt, and in all likelihood much more than was justified by the future. I cannot think of it.--It won't do.--Then came your dear mother to torture me farther, with all her (mother) kindness and confidence. Thank Heaven! it DID torture me. I was miserable. Miss Dashwood, you cannot have an idea of the comfort it gives me to look back on my own misery. I owe such a grudge to myself for the stupid, rascally folly of my own heart, that all my past sufferings under it are only triumph and exultation to me now. Well, I went, left all that I loved, and went to those to whom, at best, I was only indifferent. My journey to town--travelling with my own horses, and therefore so tediously--no creature to speak to--my own reflections so cheerful--when I looked forward every thing so inviting!--when I looked back at Barton, the picture so soothing!--oh, it was a blessed journey!'' (he)

He (Barton) stopped.

``Well, sir,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, who, though pitying him (Barton), grew impatient for his (Barton) departure,
``and this is all?'' (him)

``Ah!--no,--have you forgot what passed in town?-- That infamous letter--Did she (Elinor) shew it you?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I saw every note that passed.'' (unknown)

``When the first of hers reached me -LRB-as it immediately did, for I was in town the whole time,-RRB- what I felt is--in the common phrase, not to be expressed; in a more simple one--perhaps too simple to raise any emotion--my feelings were very, very painful.--Every line, every word was--in the hackneyed metaphor which their dear writer, were she (Elinor) here, would forbid--a dagger to my heart. To know that Marianne was in town was--in the same language--a thunderbolt.--Thunderbolts and daggers!--what a reproof would she (Marianne) have given me!--her (Marianne) taste, her (Marianne) opinions--I believe they are better known to me than my own,--and I am sure they are dearer.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor's heart, which had undergone many changes in the course of this extraordinary conversation, was now softened again;--yet she (Elinor) felt it her (Elinor) duty to check such ideas in her (Elinor) companion as the last.

``This is not right, Mr. Willoughby.--Remember that you are married. Relate only what in your conscience you think necessary for me to hear.'' (unknown)

``Marianne's note, by assuring me that I was still as dear to her (Marianne) as in former days, that in spite of the many, many weeks we had been separated, she (Marianne) was as constant in her (Marianne) own feelings, and as full of faith in the constancy of mine as ever, awakened all my remorse. I say awakened, because time and London, business and dissipation, had in some measure quieted it, and I had been growing a fine hardened villain, fancying myself indifferent to her (Marianne), and chusing to fancy that she (Marianne) too must have become indifferent to me; talking to myself of our past attachment as a mere idle, trifling business, shrugging up my shoulders in proof of its being so, and silencing every reproach, overcoming every scruple, by secretly saying now and then, 'I shall be heartily glad to hear she (Marianne) is well married.'-- But this note made me know myself better. I felt that she (Marianne) was infinitely dearer to me than any other woman in the world, and that I was using her (Marianne) infamously. But every thing was then just settled between Miss Grey and me. To retreat was impossible. All that I had to do, was to avoid you both. I sent no answer to Marianne, intending by that to preserve myself from her (Marianne) farther notice; and for some time I was even determined not to call in Berkeley Street;--but at last, judging it wiser to affect the air of a cool, common acquaintance than anything else, I watched you all safely out of the house one morning, and left my name.'' (unknown)

``Watched us out of the house!'' (unknown)

``Even so. You would be surprised to hear how often I watched you, how often I was on the point of falling in with you. I have entered many a shop to avoid your sight, as the carriage drove by. Lodging as I did in Bond Street, there was hardly a day in which I did not catch a glimpse of one or other of you; and nothing but the most constant watchfulness on my side, a most invariably prevailing desire to keep out of your sight, could have separated us so long. I avoided the Middletons as much as possible, as well as everybody else who was likely to prove an acquaintance in common. Not aware of their being in town, however, I blundered on Sir John, I believe, the first day of his (acquaintance) coming, and the day after I had called at Mrs. Jennings's. He (acquaintance) asked me to a party, a dance at his (acquaintance) house in the evening.--Had he (acquaintance) NOT told me as an inducement that you and your sister were to be there, I should have felt it too certain a thing, to trust myself near him (acquaintance). The next morning brought another short note from Marianne--still affectionate, open, artless, confiding--everything that could make MY conduct most hateful. I could not answer it. I tried--but could not frame a sentence. But I thought of her (MY), I believe, every moment of the day. If you CAN pity me, Miss Dashwood, pity my situation as it was THEN. With my head and heart full of your sister, I was forced to play the happy lover to another woman!--Those three or four weeks were worse than all. Well, at last, as I need not tell you, you were forced on me; and what a sweet figure I cut!--what an evening of agony it was!-- Marianne, beautiful as an angel on one side, calling me Willoughby in such a tone!--Oh, God!--holding out her (Marianne) hand to me, asking me for an explanation, with those bewitching eyes fixed in such speaking solicitude on my face!--and Sophia, jealous as the devil on the other hand, looking all that was--Well, it does not signify; it is over now.-- Such an evening!--I ran away from you all as soon as I could; but not before I had seen Marianne's sweet face as white as death.--THAT was the last, last look I ever had of her (Marianne);--the last manner in which she (Marianne) appeared to me. It was a horrid sight!--yet when I thought of her (Marianne) to-day as really dying, it was a kind of comfort to me to imagine that I knew exactly how she (Marianne) would appear to those, who saw her (Marianne) last in this world. She (Marianne) was before me, constantly before me, as I travelled, in the same look and hue.'' (unknown)

A short pause of mutual thoughtfulness succeeded. Willoughby first rousing himself, broke it thus:

``Well, let me make haste and be gone. Your sister is certainly better, certainly out of danger?'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

``We are assured of it.'' (unknown)

``Your poor mother, too!--doting on Marianne.'' (unknown)

``But the letter, Mr. Willoughby, your own letter; have you any thing to say about that?'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes, THAT in particular. Your sister wrote to me again, you know, the very next morning. You saw what she (sister) said. I was breakfasting at the Ellisons,--and her (sister) letter, with some others, was brought to me there from my lodgings. It happened to catch Sophia's eye before it caught mine--and its size, the elegance of the paper, the hand-writing altogether, immediately gave her (Sophia) a suspicion. Some vague report had reached her (Sophia) before of my attachment to some young lady in Devonshire, and what had passed within her (lady) observation the preceding evening had marked who the young lady was, and made her (lady) more jealous than ever. Affecting that air of playfulness, therefore, which is delightful in a woman one loves, she (woman) opened the letter directly, and read its contents. She (woman) was well paid for her (woman) impudence. She (woman) read what made her (woman) wretched. Her (woman) wretchedness I could have borne, but her (woman) passion--her (woman) malice--At all events it must be appeased. And, in short--what do you think of my wife's style of letter-writing?--delicate--tender--truly feminine--was it not?'' (unknown)

``Your wife!--The letter was in your own hand-writing.'' (unknown)

``Yes, but I had only the credit of servilely copying such sentences as I was ashamed to put my name to. The original was all her (wife) own--her (wife) own happy thoughts and gentle diction. But what could I do!--we were engaged, every thing in preparation, the day almost fixed--But I am talking like a fool. Preparation!--day!--In honest words, her (wife) money was necessary to me, and in a situation like mine, any thing was to be done to prevent a rupture. And after all, what did it signify to my character in the opinion of Marianne and her (Marianne) friends, in what language my answer was couched?--It must have been only to one end. My business was to declare myself a scoundrel, and whether I did it with a bow or a bluster was of little importance.-- 'I am ruined for ever in their opinion--' said I to myself--'I am shut out for ever from their society, they already think me an unprincipled fellow, this letter will only make them think me a blackguard one.' Such were my reasonings, as, in a sort of desperate carelessness, I copied my wife's words, and parted with the last relics of Marianne. Her (Marianne) three notes--unluckily they were all in my pocketbook, or I should have denied their existence, and hoarded them for ever--I was forced to put them up, and could not even kiss them. And the lock of hair--that too I had always carried about me in the same pocket-book, which was now searched by Madam with the most ingratiating virulence,--the dear lock--all, every memento was torn from me.'' (unknown)

``You are very wrong, Mr. Willoughby, very blamable,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, while her (Elinor) voice, in spite of herself, betrayed her (Elinor) compassionate emotion;
``you ought not to speak in this way, either of Mrs. Willoughby or my sister. You had made your own choice. It was not forced on you. Your wife has a claim to your politeness, to your respect, at least. She (wife) must be attached to you, or she (wife) would not have married you. To treat her (wife) with unkindness, to speak of her (wife) slightingly is no atonement to Marianne--nor can I suppose it a relief to your own conscience.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Do not talk to me of my wife,'' (he)
said he (you) with a heavy sigh.--
``She (wife) does not deserve your compassion.--She (wife) knew I had no regard for her (wife) when we married.--Well, married we were, and came down to Combe Magna to be happy, and afterwards returned to town to be gay.--And now do you pity me, Miss Dashwood?--or have I said all this to no purpose?-- Am I--be it only one degree--am I less guilty in your opinion than I was before?--My intentions were not always wrong. Have I explained away any part of my guilt?'' (unknown)

``Yes, you have certainly removed something--a little.-- You have proved yourself, on the whole, less faulty than I had believed you. You have proved your heart less wicked, much less wicked. But I hardly know--the misery that you have inflicted--I hardly know what could have made it worse.'' (unknown)

``Will you repeat to your sister when she (sister) is recovered, what I have been telling you?--Let me be a little lightened too in her (sister) opinion as well as in yours. You tell me that she (sister) has forgiven me already. Let me be able to fancy that a better knowledge of my heart, and of my present feelings, will draw from her (sister) a more spontaneous, more natural, more gentle, less dignified, forgiveness. Tell her (sister) of my misery and my penitence--tell her (sister) that my heart was never inconstant to her (sister), and if you will, that at this moment she (sister) is dearer to me than ever.'' (unknown)

``I will tell her (sister) all that is necessary to what may comparatively be called, your justification. But you have not explained to me the particular reason of your coming now, nor how you heard of her (sister) illness.'' (unknown)

``Last night, in Drury Lane lobby, I ran against Sir John Middleton, and when he (Middleton) saw who I was--for the first time these two months--he (Middleton) spoke to me.--That he (Middleton) had cut me ever since my marriage, I had seen without surprise or resentment. Now, however, his (Middleton) good-natured, honest, stupid soul, full of indignation against me, and concern for your sister, could not resist the temptation of telling me what he (Middleton) knew ought to--though probably he (Middleton) did not think it WOULD--vex me horridly. As bluntly as he (Middleton) could speak it, therefore, he (Middleton) told me that Marianne Dashwood was dying of a putrid fever at Cleveland--a letter that morning received from Mrs. Jennings declared her (Jennings) danger most imminent--the Palmers are all gone off in a fright, &c.--I was too much shocked to be able to pass myself off as insensible even to the undiscerning Sir John. His (Middleton) heart was softened in seeing mine suffer; and so much of his (Middleton) ill-will was done away, that when we parted, he (Middleton) almost shook me by the hand while he (Middleton) reminded me of an old promise about a pointer puppy. What I felt on hearing that your sister was dying--and dying too, believing me the greatest villain upon earth, scorning, hating me in her (sister) latest moments--for how could I tell what horrid projects might not have been imputed? ONE person I was sure would represent me as capable of any thing-- What I felt was dreadful!--My resolution was soon made, and at eight o'clock this morning I was in my carriage. Now you know all.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor made no answer. Her (Elinor) thoughts were silently fixed on the irreparable injury which too early an independence and its consequent habits of idleness, dissipation, and luxury, had made in the mind, the character, the happiness, of a man who, to every advantage of person and talents, united a disposition naturally open and honest, and a feeling, affectionate temper. The world had made him (man) extravagant and vain--Extravagance and vanity had made him (man) cold-hearted and selfish. Vanity, while seeking its own guilty triumph at the expense of another, had involved him (man) in a real attachment, which extravagance, or at least its offspring, necessity, had required to be sacrificed. Each faulty propensity in leading him (man) to evil, had led him (man) likewise to punishment. The attachment, from which against honour, against feeling, against every better interest he (man) had outwardly torn himself, now, when no longer allowable, governed every thought; and the connection, for the sake of which he (man) had, with little scruple, left her (man) sister to misery, was likely to prove a source of unhappiness to himself of a far more incurable nature. From a reverie of this kind she (man) was recalled at the end of some minutes by Willoughby, who, rousing himself from a reverie at least equally painful, started up in preparation for going, and said--

``There is no use in staying here; I must be off.'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)

``Are you going back to town?'' (unknown)

``No--to Combe Magna. I have business there; from thence to town in a day or two. Good bye.'' (He)

He (Magna) held out his (Magna) hand. She (man) could not refuse to give him (Magna) hers;--he (Magna) pressed it with affection.

``And you DO think something better of me than you did?'' (he)
--said he (Magna), letting it fall, and leaning against the mantel-piece as if forgetting he (Magna) was to go.

Elinor assured him (Magna) that she (Elinor) did;--that she (Elinor) forgave, pitied, wished him (Magna) well--was even interested in his (Magna) happiness--and added some gentle counsel as to the behaviour most likely to promote it. His (Magna) answer was not very encouraging.

``As to that,'' (he)
said he (Magna),
``I must rub through the world as well as I can. Domestic happiness is out of the question. If, however, I am allowed to think that you and yours feel an interest in my fate and actions, it may be the means--it may put me on my guard--at least, it may be something to live for. Marianne to be sure is lost to me for ever. Were I even by any blessed chance at liberty again--'' (he)

Elinor stopped him (guard) with a reproof.

``Well,'' (he)
--he (guard) replied--
``once more good bye. I shall now go away and live in dread of one event.'' (he)

``What do you mean?'' (unknown)

``Your sister's marriage.'' (unknown)

``You are very wrong. She (sister) can never be more lost to you than she (sister) is now.'' (unknown)

``But she (sister) will be gained by some one else. And if that some one should be the very he (guard) whom, of all others, I could least bear--but I will not stay to rob myself of all your compassionate goodwill, by shewing that where I have most injured I can least forgive. Good bye,--God bless you!'' (he)

And with these words, he (God) almost ran out of the room.

CHAPTER 45

Elinor, for some time after he (God) left her (Elinor), for some time even after the sound of his (God) carriage had died away, remained too much oppressed by a crowd of ideas, widely differing in themselves, but of which sadness was the general result, to think even of her (Elinor) sister.

Willoughby, he (Willoughby), whom only half an hour ago she (Elinor) had abhorred as the most worthless of men, Willoughby, in spite of all his (Willoughby) faults, excited a degree of commiseration for the sufferings produced by them, which made her (Elinor) think of him (Willoughby) as now separated for ever from her (Elinor) family, with a tenderness, a regret, rather in proportion, as she (Elinor) soon acknowledged within herself--to his (Willoughby) wishes than to his (Willoughby) merits. She (Elinor) felt that his (Willoughby) influence over her (Elinor) mind was heightened by circumstances which ought not in reason to have weight; by that person of uncommon attraction, that open, affectionate, and lively manner which it was no merit to possess; and by that still ardent love for Marianne, which it was not even innocent to indulge. But she (Marianne) felt that it was so, long, long before she (Marianne) could feel his (Willoughby) influence less.

When at last she (Marianne) returned to the unconscious Marianne, she (Marianne) found her (Marianne) just awaking, refreshed by so long and sweet a sleep to the extent of her (Marianne) hopes. Elinor's heart was full. The past, the present, the future, Willoughby's visit, Marianne's safety, and her (Marianne) mother's expected arrival, threw her (Marianne) altogether into an agitation of spirits which kept off every indication of fatigue, and made her (Marianne) only fearful of betraying herself to her (Marianne) sister. Short was the time, however, in which that fear could affect her (Marianne), for within half an hour after Willoughby's leaving the house, she (Marianne) was again called down stairs by the sound of another carriage.--Eager to save her (Marianne) mother from every unnecessary moment's horrible suspense, she (Marianne) ran immediately into the hall, and reached the outward door just in time to receive and support her (Marianne) as she (Marianne) entered it.

Mrs. Dashwood, whose terror as they drew near the house had produced almost the conviction of Marianne's being no more, had no voice to inquire after her (Marianne), no voice even for Elinor; but SHE, waiting neither for salutation nor inquiry, instantly gave the joyful relief;--and her (Elinor) mother, catching it with all her (Elinor) usual warmth, was in a moment as much overcome by her (Elinor) happiness, as she (Elinor) had been before by her (Elinor) fears. She (Elinor) was supported into the drawing-room between her (Elinor) daughter and her (Elinor) friend;--and there, shedding tears of joy, though still unable to speak, embraced Elinor again and again, turning from her (Elinor) at intervals to press Colonel Brandon's hand, with a look which spoke at once her (Elinor) gratitude, and her (Elinor) conviction of his (Colonel) sharing with herself in the bliss of the moment. He (Colonel) shared it, however, in a silence even greater than her (Elinor) own.

As soon as Mrs. Dashwood had recovered herself, to see Marianne was her (Marianne) first desire; and in two minutes she (Marianne) was with her (Marianne) beloved child, rendered dearer to her (Marianne) than ever by absence, unhappiness, and danger. Elinor's delight, as she (Elinor) saw what each felt in the meeting, was only checked by an apprehension of its robbing Marianne of farther sleep;--but Mrs. Dashwood could be calm, could be even prudent, when the life of a child was at stake, and Marianne, satisfied in knowing her (Marianne) mother was near her (Marianne), and conscious of being too weak for conversation, submitted readily to the silence and quiet prescribed by every nurse around her (nurse). Mrs. Dashwood WOULD sit up with her (Dashwood) all night; and Elinor, in compliance with her (Elinor) mother's entreaty, went to bed. But the rest, which one night entirely sleepless, and many hours of the most wearing anxiety seemed to make requisite, was kept off by irritation of spirits. Willoughby,

``poor Willoughby,'' (Willoughby/Mr. Willoughby)
as she (Elinor) now allowed herself to call him (Willoughby), was constantly in her (Elinor) thoughts; she (Elinor) would not but have heard his (Willoughby) vindication for the world, and now blamed, now acquitted herself for having judged him (Willoughby) so harshly before. But her (Elinor) promise of relating it to her (Elinor) sister was invariably painful. She (Elinor) dreaded the performance of it, dreaded what its effect on Marianne might be; doubted whether after such an explanation she (Marianne) could ever be happy with another; and for a moment wished Willoughby a widower. Then, remembering Colonel Brandon, reproved herself, felt that to HIS (Colonel) sufferings and his (Colonel) constancy far more than to his (Colonel) rival's, the reward of her (Brandon) sister was due, and wished any thing rather than Mrs. Willoughby's death.

The shock of Colonel Brandon's errand at Barton had been much softened to Mrs. Dashwood by her (Dashwood) own previous alarm; for so great was her (Dashwood) uneasiness about Marianne, that she (Marianne) had already determined to set out for Cleveland on that very day, without waiting for any further intelligence, and had so far settled her (Marianne) journey before his (Barton) arrival, that the Careys were then expected every moment to fetch Margaret away, as her (Margaret) mother was unwilling to take her (Margaret) where there might be infection.

Marianne continued to mend every day, and the brilliant cheerfulness of Mrs. Dashwood's looks and spirits proved her (Dashwood) to be, as she (Dashwood) repeatedly declared herself, one of the happiest women in the world. Elinor could not hear the declaration, nor witness its proofs without sometimes wondering whether her (Elinor) mother ever recollected Edward. But Mrs. Dashwood, trusting to the temperate account of her (Dashwood) own disappointment which Elinor had sent her (Elinor), was led away by the exuberance of her (Elinor) joy to think only of what would increase it. Marianne was restored to her (Marianne) from a danger in which, as she (Marianne) now began to feel, her (Marianne) own mistaken judgment in encouraging the unfortunate attachment to Willoughby, had contributed to place her (Marianne);--and in her (Marianne) recovery she (Marianne) had yet another source of joy unthought of by Elinor. It was thus imparted to her (Elinor), as soon as any opportunity of private conference between them occurred.

``At last we are alone. My Elinor, you do not yet know all my happiness. Colonel Brandon loves Marianne. He (Colonel) has told me so himself.'' (daughter feeling)

Her (Brandon) daughter, feeling by turns both pleased and pained, surprised and not surprised, was all silent attention.

``You are never like me, dear Elinor, or I should wonder at your composure now. Had I sat down to wish for any possible good to my family, I should have fixed on Colonel Brandon's marrying one of you as the object most desirable. And I believe Marianne will be the most happy with him (Colonel) of the two.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor was half inclined to ask her (Elinor) reason for thinking so, because satisfied that none founded on an impartial consideration of their age, characters, or feelings, could be given;--but her (Elinor) mother must always be carried away by her (Elinor) imagination on any interesting subject, and therefore instead of an inquiry, she (Elinor) passed it off with a smile.

``He (Colonel) opened his (Colonel) whole heart to me yesterday as we travelled. It came out quite unawares, quite undesignedly. I, you may well believe, could talk of nothing but my child;--he (Colonel) could not conceal his (Colonel) distress; I saw that it equalled my own, and he (Colonel) perhaps, thinking that mere friendship, as the world now goes, would not justify so warm a sympathy--or rather, not thinking at all, I suppose--giving way to irresistible feelings, made me acquainted with his (Colonel) earnest, tender, constant, affection for Marianne. He (Colonel) has loved her (Marianne), my Elinor, ever since the first moment of seeing her (Elinor).'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Here, however, Elinor perceived,--not the language, not the professions of Colonel Brandon, but the natural embellishments of her (Elinor) mother's active fancy, which fashioned every thing delightful to her (Elinor) as it chose.

``His (Colonel) regard for her (Elinor), infinitely surpassing anything that Willoughby ever felt or feigned, as much more warm, as more sincere or constant--which ever we are to call it--has subsisted through all the knowledge of dear Marianne's unhappy prepossession for that worthless young man!--and without selfishness--without encouraging a hope!--could he (man) have seen her (Marianne) happy with another--Such a noble mind!--such openness, such sincerity!--no one can be deceived in HIM.'' (unknown)

``Colonel Brandon's character,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``as an excellent man, is well established.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I know it is,'' (mother)
--replied her (Elinor) mother seriously,
``or after such a warning, I should be the last to encourage such affection, or even to be pleased by it. But his (man) coming for me as he (man) did, with such active, such ready friendship, is enough to prove him (man) one of the worthiest of men.'' (mother)

``His (man) character, however,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
answered Elinor,
``does not rest on ONE act of kindness, to which his (man) affection for Marianne, were humanity out of the case, would have prompted him (man). To Mrs. Jennings, to the Middletons, he (man) has been long and intimately known; they equally love and respect him (man); and even my own knowledge of him (man), though lately acquired, is very considerable; and so highly do I value and esteem him (man), that if Marianne can be happy with him (man), I shall be as ready as yourself to think our connection the greatest blessing to us in the world. What answer did you give him (man)?--Did you allow him (man) to hope?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``Oh! my love, I could not then talk of hope to him (man) or to myself. Marianne might at that moment be dying. But he (man) did not ask for hope or encouragement. His (man) was an involuntary confidence, an irrepressible effusion to a soothing friend--not an application to a parent. Yet after a time I DID say, for at first I was quite overcome--that if she (Marianne) lived, as I trusted she (Marianne) might, my greatest happiness would lie in promoting their marriage; and since our arrival, since our delightful security, I have repeated it to him (man) more fully, have given him (man) every encouragement in my power. Time, a very little time, I tell him (man), will do everything;--Marianne's heart is not to be wasted for ever on such a man as Willoughby.-- His (Willoughby) own merits must soon secure it.'' (unknown)

``To judge from the Colonel's spirits, however, you have not yet made him (Colonel) equally sanguine.'' (unknown)

``No.--He (Colonel) thinks Marianne's affection too deeply rooted for any change in it under a great length of time, and even supposing her (Marianne) heart again free, is too diffident of himself to believe, that with such a difference of age and disposition he (Colonel) could ever attach her (Marianne). There, however, he (Colonel) is quite mistaken. His (Colonel) age is only so much beyond hers as to be an advantage, as to make his (Colonel) character and principles fixed;--and his (Colonel) disposition, I am well convinced, is exactly the very one to make your sister happy. And his (Colonel) person, his (Colonel) manners too, are all in his (Colonel) favour. My partiality does not blind me; he (Colonel) certainly is not so handsome as Willoughby--but at the same time, there is something much more pleasing in his (Willoughby) countenance.-- There was always a something,--if you remember,--in Willoughby's eyes at times, which I did not like.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor could NOT remember it;--but her (Elinor) mother, without waiting for her (Elinor) assent, continued,

``And his (Willoughby) manners, the Colonel's manners are not only more pleasing to me than Willoughby's ever were, but they are of a kind I well know to be more solidly attaching to Marianne. Their gentleness, their genuine attention to other people, and their manly unstudied simplicity is much more accordant with her (Marianne) real disposition, than the liveliness--often artificial, and often ill-timed of the other. I am very sure myself, that had Willoughby turned out as really amiable, as he (Willoughby) has proved himself the contrary, Marianne would yet never have been so happy with HIM, as she (Marianne) will be with Colonel Brandon.'' (mother)

She (Marianne) paused.--Her (Marianne) daughter could not quite agree with her (Marianne), but her (Marianne) dissent was not heard, and therefore gave no offence.

``At Delaford, she (Marianne) will be within an easy distance of me,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
added Mrs. Dashwood,
``even if I remain at Barton; and in all probability,--for I hear it is a large village,--indeed there certainly MUST be some small house or cottage close by, that would suit us quite as well as our present situation.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Poor Elinor!--here was a new scheme for getting her (Elinor) to Delaford!--but her (Elinor) spirit was stubborn.

``His (Barton) fortune too!--for at my time of life you know, everybody cares about THAT;--and though I neither know nor desire to know, what it really is, I am sure it must be a good one.'' (a person)

Here they were interrupted by the entrance of a third person, and Elinor withdrew to think it all over in private, to wish success to her (Elinor) friend, and yet in wishing it, to feel a pang for Willoughby.

CHAPTER 46

Marianne's illness, though weakening in its kind, had not been long enough to make her (Marianne) recovery slow; and with youth, natural strength, and her (Marianne) mother's presence in aid, it proceeded so smoothly as to enable her (Marianne) to remove, within four days after the arrival of the latter, into Mrs. Palmer's dressing-room. When there, at her (Palmer) own particular request, for she (Palmer) was impatient to pour forth her (Palmer) thanks to him (Willoughby) for fetching her (Palmer) mother, Colonel Brandon was invited to visit her (Brandon).

His (Colonel) emotion on entering the room, in seeing her (Brandon) altered looks, and in receiving the pale hand which she (Brandon) immediately held out to him (Colonel), was such, as, in Elinor's conjecture, must arise from something more than his (Colonel) affection for Marianne, or the consciousness of its being known to others; and she (Marianne) soon discovered in his (Colonel) melancholy eye and varying complexion as he (Colonel) looked at her (Marianne) sister, the probable recurrence of many past scenes of misery to his (Colonel) mind, brought back by that resemblance between Marianne and Eliza already acknowledged, and now strengthened by the hollow eye, the sickly skin, the posture of reclining weakness, and the warm acknowledgment of peculiar obligation.

Mrs. Dashwood, not less watchful of what passed than her (Dashwood) daughter, but with a mind very differently influenced, and therefore watching to very different effect, saw nothing in the Colonel's behaviour but what arose from the most simple and self-evident sensations, while in the actions and words of Marianne she (Marianne) persuaded herself to think that something more than gratitude already dawned.

At the end of another day or two, Marianne growing visibly stronger every twelve hours, Mrs. Dashwood, urged equally by her (Dashwood) own and her (Dashwood) daughter's wishes, began to talk of removing to Barton. On HER measures depended those of her (Dashwood) two friends; Mrs. Jennings could not quit Cleveland during the Dashwoods' stay; and Colonel Brandon was soon brought, by their united request, to consider his (Colonel) own abode there as equally determinate, if not equally indispensable. At his (Colonel) and Mrs. Jennings's united request in return, Mrs. Dashwood was prevailed on to accept the use of his (Colonel) carriage on her (Dashwood) journey back, for the better accommodation of her (Dashwood) sick child; and the Colonel, at the joint invitation of Mrs. Dashwood and Mrs. Jennings, whose active good-nature made her (Jennings) friendly and hospitable for other people as well as herself, engaged with pleasure to redeem it by a visit at the cottage, in the course of a few weeks.

The day of separation and departure arrived; and Marianne, after taking so particular and lengthened a leave of Mrs. Jennings, one so earnestly grateful, so full of respect and kind wishes as seemed due to her (Jennings) own heart from a secret acknowledgment of past inattention, and bidding Colonel Brandon farewell with a cordiality of a friend, was carefully assisted by him (Colonel) into the carriage, of which he (Colonel) seemed anxious that she (Brandon) should engross at least half. Mrs. Dashwood and Elinor then followed, and the others were left by themselves, to talk of the travellers, and feel their own dullness, till Mrs. Jennings was summoned to her (Jennings) chaise to take comfort in the gossip of her (Jennings) maid for the loss of her (Jennings) two young companions; and Colonel Brandon immediately afterwards took his (Colonel) solitary way to Delaford.

The Dashwoods were two days on the road, and Marianne bore her (Marianne) journey on both, without essential fatigue. Every thing that the most zealous affection, the most solicitous care could do to render her (Marianne) comfortable, was the office of each watchful companion, and each found their reward in her (Marianne) bodily ease, and her (Marianne) calmness of spirits. To Elinor, the observation of the latter was particularly grateful. She (Marianne), who had seen her (Marianne) week after week so constantly suffering, oppressed by anguish of heart which she (Marianne) had neither courage to speak of, nor fortitude to conceal, now saw with a joy, which no other could equally share, an apparent composure of mind, which, in being the result as she (Marianne) trusted of serious reflection, must eventually lead her (Marianne) to contentment and cheerfulness.

As they approached Barton, indeed, and entered on scenes of which every field and every tree brought some peculiar, some painful recollection, she (Marianne) grew silent and thoughtful, and turning away her (Marianne) face from their notice, sat earnestly gazing through the window. But here, Elinor could neither wonder nor blame; and when she (Elinor) saw, as she (Elinor) assisted Marianne from the carriage, that she (Elinor) had been crying, she (Elinor) saw only an emotion too natural in itself to raise any thing less tender than pity, and in its unobtrusiveness entitled to praise. In the whole of her (Elinor) subsequent manner, she (Elinor) traced the direction of a mind awakened to reasonable exertion; for no sooner had they entered their common sitting-room, than Marianne turned her (Marianne) eyes around it with a look of resolute firmness, as if determined at once to accustom herself to the sight of every object with which the remembrance of Willoughby could be connected.--She (Marianne) said little, but every sentence aimed at cheerfulness, and though a sigh sometimes escaped her (Marianne), it never passed away without the atonement of a smile. After dinner she (Marianne) would try her (Marianne) piano-forte. She (Marianne) went to it; but the music on which her (Marianne) eye first rested was an opera, procured for her (Marianne) by Willoughby, containing some of their favourite duets, and bearing on its outward leaf her (Marianne) own name in his (Willoughby) hand-writing.--That would not do.--She (Marianne) shook her (Marianne) head, put the music aside, and after running over the keys for a minute, complained of feebleness in her (Marianne) fingers, and closed the instrument again; declaring however with firmness as she (Marianne) did so, that she (Marianne) should in future practice much.

The next morning produced no abatement in these happy symptoms. On the contrary, with a mind and body alike strengthened by rest, she (Marianne) looked and spoke with more genuine spirit, anticipating the pleasure of Margaret's return, and talking of the dear family party which would then be restored, of their mutual pursuits and cheerful society, as the only happiness worth a wish.

``When the weather is settled, and I have recovered my strength,'' (she)
said she (Margaret),
``we will take long walks together every day. We will walk to the farm at the edge of the down, and see how the children go on; we will walk to Sir John's new plantations at Barton Cross, and the Abbeyland; and we will often go the old ruins of the Priory, and try to trace its foundations as far as we are told they once reached. I know we shall be happy. I know the summer will pass happily away. I mean never to be later in rising than six, and from that time till dinner I shall divide every moment between music and reading. I have formed my plan, and am determined to enter on a course of serious study. Our own library is too well known to me, to be resorted to for any thing beyond mere amusement. But there are many works well worth reading at the Park; and there are others of more modern production which I know I can borrow of Colonel Brandon. By reading only six hours a-day, I shall gain in the course of a twelve-month a great deal of instruction which I now feel myself to want.'' (she)

Elinor honoured her (Elinor) for a plan which originated so nobly as this; though smiling to see the same eager fancy which had been leading her (Elinor) to the extreme of languid indolence and selfish repining, now at work in introducing excess into a scheme of such rational employment and virtuous self-control. Her (Elinor) smile however changed to a sigh when she (Elinor) remembered that promise to Willoughby was yet unfulfilled, and feared she (Elinor) had that to communicate which might again unsettle the mind of Marianne, and ruin at least for a time this fair prospect of busy tranquillity. Willing therefore to delay the evil hour, she (Marianne) resolved to wait till her (Marianne) sister's health were more secure, before she (Marianne) appointed it. But the resolution was made only to be broken.

Marianne had been two or three days at home, before the weather was fine enough for an invalid like herself to venture out. But at last a soft, genial morning appeared; such as might tempt the daughter's wishes and the mother's confidence; and Marianne, leaning on Elinor's arm, was authorised to walk as long as she (Marianne) could without fatigue, in the lane before the house.

The sisters set out at a pace, slow as the feebleness of Marianne in an exercise hitherto untried since her (Marianne) illness required;--and they had advanced only so far beyond the house as to admit a full view of the hill, the important hill behind, when pausing with her (Marianne) eyes turned towards it, Marianne calmly said,

``There, exactly there,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--pointing with one hand,
``on that projecting mound,--there I fell; and there I first saw Willoughby.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Her (Marianne) voice sunk with the word, but presently reviving she (Marianne) added,

``I am thankful to find that I can look with so little pain on the spot!--shall we ever talk on that subject, Elinor?'' (she)
--hesitatingly it was said.--
``Or will it be wrong?--I can talk of it now, I hope, as I ought to do.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
--

Elinor tenderly invited her (Elinor) to be open.

``As for regret,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne,
``I have done with that, as far as HE (Marianne) is concerned. I do not mean to talk to you of what my feelings have been for him (Marianne), but what they are NOW.--At present, if I could be satisfied on one point, if I could be allowed to think that he (Marianne) was not ALWAYS acting a part, not ALWAYS deceiving me;--but above all, if I could be assured that he (Marianne) never was so VERY wicked as my fears have sometimes fancied him (Marianne), since the story of that unfortunate girl'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--

She (girl) stopt. Elinor joyfully treasured her (Elinor) words as she (Elinor) answered,

``If you could be assured of that, you think you should be easy.'' (she)

``Yes. My peace of mind is doubly involved in it;--for not only is it horrible to suspect a person, who has been what HE (Marianne) has been to ME, of such designs,--but what must it make me appear to myself?--What in a situation like mine, but a most shamefully unguarded affection could expose me to'' (sister)
--

``How then,'' (sister)
asked her (Elinor) sister,
``would you account for his (Marianne) behaviour?'' (sister)

``I would suppose him (Marianne),--Oh, how gladly would I suppose him (Marianne), only fickle, very, very fickle.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor said no more. She (Elinor) was debating within herself on the eligibility of beginning her (Elinor) story directly, or postponing it till Marianne were in stronger health;--and they crept on for a few minutes in silence.

``I am not wishing him (Marianne) too much good,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne at last with a sigh,
``when I wish his (Marianne) secret reflections may be no more unpleasant than my own. He (Marianne) will suffer enough in them.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Do you compare your conduct with his (Marianne)?'' (unknown)

``No. I compare it with what it ought to have been; I compare it with yours.'' (unknown)

``Our situations have borne little resemblance.'' (unknown)

``They have borne more than our conduct.--Do not, my dearest Elinor, let your kindness defend what I know your judgment must censure. My illness has made me think-- It has given me leisure and calmness for serious recollection. Long before I was enough recovered to talk, I was perfectly able to reflect. I considered the past: I saw in my own behaviour, since the beginning of our acquaintance with him (acquaintance) last autumn, nothing but a series of imprudence towards myself, and want of kindness to others. I saw that my own feelings had prepared my sufferings, and that my want of fortitude under them had almost led me to the grave. My illness, I well knew, had been entirely brought on by myself by such negligence of my own health, as I had felt even at the time to be wrong. Had I died,--it would have been self-destruction. I did not know my danger till the danger was removed; but with such feelings as these reflections gave me, I wonder at my recovery,--wonder that the very eagerness of my desire to live, to have time for atonement to my God, and to you all, did not kill me at once. Had I died,--in what peculiar misery should I have left you, my nurse, my friend, my sister!--You, who had seen all the fretful selfishness of my latter days; who had known all the murmurings of my heart!--How should I have lived in YOUR remembrance!--My mother too! How could you have consoled her (mother)!--I cannot express my own abhorrence of myself. Whenever I looked towards the past, I saw some duty neglected, or some failing indulged. Every body seemed injured by me. The kindness, the unceasing kindness of Mrs. Jennings, I had repaid with ungrateful contempt. To the Middletons, to the Palmers, the Steeles, to every common acquaintance even, I had been insolent and unjust; with a heart hardened against their merits, and a temper irritated by their very attention.--To John, to Fanny,--yes, even to them, little as they deserve, I had given less than their due. But you,--you above all, above my mother, had been wronged by me. I, and only I, knew your heart and its sorrows; yet to what did it influence me?--not to any compassion that could benefit you or myself.--Your example was before me; but to what avail?--Was I more considerate of you and your comfort? Did I imitate your forbearance, or lessen your restraints, by taking any part in those offices of general complaisance or particular gratitude which you had hitherto been left to discharge alone?--No;--not less when I knew you to be unhappy, than when I had believed you at ease, did I turn away from every exertion of duty or friendship; scarcely allowing sorrow to exist but with me, regretting only THAT heart which had deserted and wronged me, and leaving you, for whom I professed an unbounded affection, to be miserable for my sake.'' (unknown)

Here ceased the rapid flow of her (I) self-reproving spirit; and Elinor, impatient to soothe, though too honest to flatter, gave her (Elinor) instantly that praise and support which her (Elinor) frankness and her (Elinor) contrition so well deserved. Marianne pressed her (Marianne) hand and replied,

``You are very good.--The future must be my proof. I have laid down my plan, and if I am capable of adhering to it--my feelings shall be governed and my temper improved. They shall no longer worry others, nor torture myself. I shall now live solely for my family. You, my mother, and Margaret, must henceforth be all the world to me; you will share my affections entirely between you. From you, from my home, I shall never again have the smallest incitement to move; and if I do mix in other society, it will be only to shew that my spirit is humbled, my heart amended, and that I can practise the civilities, the lesser duties of life, with gentleness and forbearance. As for Willoughby--to say that I shall soon or that I shall ever forget him (Willoughby), would be idle. His (Willoughby) remembrance can be overcome by no change of circumstances or opinions. But it shall be regulated, it shall be checked by religion, by reason, by constant employment.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

She (I) paused--and added in a low voice,

``If I could but know HIS (Willoughby) heart, everything would become easy.'' (She)

Elinor, who had now been for some time reflecting on the propriety or impropriety of speedily hazarding her (Elinor) narration, without feeling at all nearer decision than at first, heard this; and perceiving that as reflection did nothing, resolution must do all, soon found herself leading to the fact.

She (Elinor) managed the recital, as she (Elinor) hoped, with address; prepared her (Elinor) anxious listener with caution; related simply and honestly the chief points on which Willoughby grounded his (Willoughby) apology; did justice to his (Willoughby) repentance, and softened only his (Willoughby) protestations of present regard. Marianne said not a word.--She (Marianne) trembled, her (Marianne) eyes were fixed on the ground, and her (Marianne) lips became whiter than even sickness had left them. A thousand inquiries sprung up from her (Marianne) heart, but she (Marianne) dared not urge one. She (Marianne) caught every syllable with panting eagerness; her (Marianne) hand, unknowingly to herself, closely pressed her (Marianne) sister's, and tears covered her (Marianne) cheeks.

Elinor, dreading her (Elinor) being tired, led her (Elinor) towards home; and till they reached the door of the cottage, easily conjecturing what her (Elinor) curiosity must be though no question was suffered to speak it, talked of nothing but Willoughby, and their conversation together; and was carefully minute in every particular of speech and look, where minuteness could be safely indulged. As soon as they entered the house, Marianne with a kiss of gratitude and these two words just articulate through her (Marianne) tears,

``Tell mama,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
withdrew from her (Marianne) sister and walked slowly up stairs. Elinor would not attempt to disturb a solitude so reasonable as what she (Elinor) now sought; and with a mind anxiously pre-arranging its result, and a resolution of reviving the subject again, should Marianne fail to do it, she (Marianne) turned into the parlour to fulfill her (Marianne) parting injunction.

CHAPTER 47

Mrs. Dashwood did not hear unmoved the vindication of her (Dashwood) former favourite. She (Dashwood) rejoiced in his (Marianne) being cleared from some part of his (Marianne) imputed guilt;--she (Dashwood) was sorry for him (Marianne);--she (Dashwood) wished him (Marianne) happy. But the feelings of the past could not be recalled.--Nothing could restore him (Marianne) with a faith unbroken--a character unblemished, to Marianne. Nothing could do away the knowledge of what the latter had suffered through his (character) means, nor remove the guilt of his (character) conduct towards Eliza. Nothing could replace him (character), therefore, in her (Eliza) former esteem, nor injure the interests of Colonel Brandon.

Had Mrs. Dashwood, like her (Dashwood) daughter, heard Willoughby's story from himself--had she (Dashwood) witnessed his (Willoughby) distress, and been under the influence of his (Willoughby) countenance and his (Willoughby) manner, it is probable that her (Dashwood) compassion would have been greater. But it was neither in Elinor's power, nor in her (Elinor) wish, to rouse such feelings in another, by her (Elinor) retailed explanation, as had at first been called forth in herself. Reflection had given calmness to her (Elinor) judgment, and sobered her (Elinor) own opinion of Willoughby's deserts;--she (Elinor) wished, therefore, to declare only the simple truth, and lay open such facts as were really due to his (Willoughby) character, without any embellishment of tenderness to lead the fancy astray.

In the evening, when they were all three together, Marianne began voluntarily to speak of him (Willoughby) again;--but that it was not without an effort, the restless, unquiet thoughtfulness in which she (Marianne) had been for some time previously sitting--her (Marianne) rising colour, as she (Marianne) spoke,--and her (Marianne) unsteady voice, plainly shewed.

``I wish to assure you both,'' (she)
said she (Marianne),
``that I see every thing--as you can desire me to do.'' (she)

Mrs. Dashwood would have interrupted her (Dashwood) instantly with soothing tenderness, had not Elinor, who really wished to hear her (Elinor) sister's unbiased opinion, by an eager sign, engaged her (Elinor) silence. Marianne slowly continued--

``It is a great relief to me--what Elinor told me this morning--I have now heard exactly what I wished to hear.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--For some moments her (Elinor) voice was lost; but recovering herself, she (Elinor) added, and with greater calmness than before--
``I am now perfectly satisfied, I wish for no change. I never could have been happy with him (sister), after knowing, as sooner or later I must have known, all this.--I should have had no confidence, no esteem. Nothing could have done it away to my feelings.'' (she)

``I know it--I know it,'' (mother)
cried her (Elinor) mother.
``Happy with a man of libertine practices!--With one who so injured the peace of the dearest of our friends, and the best of men!--No--my Marianne has not a heart to be made happy with such a man!--Her (Marianne) conscience, her (Marianne) sensitive conscience, would have felt all that the conscience of her (Marianne) husband ought to have felt.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

Marianne sighed, and repeated,

``I wish for no change.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``You consider the matter,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``exactly as a good mind and a sound understanding must consider it; and I dare say you perceive, as well as myself, not only in this, but in many other circumstances, reason enough to be convinced that your marriage must have involved you in many certain troubles and disappointments, in which you would have been poorly supported by an affection, on his (husband) side, much less certain. Had you married, you must have been always poor. His (husband) expensiveness is acknowledged even by himself, and his (husband) whole conduct declares that self-denial is a word hardly understood by him (husband). His (husband) demands and your inexperience together, on a small, very small income, must have brought on distresses which would not be the LESS grievous to you, from having been entirely unknown and unthought of before. YOUR sense of honour and honesty would have led you, I know, when aware of your situation, to attempt all the economy that would appear to you possible: and, perhaps, as long as your frugality retrenched only on your own comfort, you might have been suffered to practice it, but beyond that--and how little could the utmost of your single management do to stop the ruin which had begun before your marriage?-- Beyond THAT, had you endeavoured, however reasonably, to abridge HIS (it) enjoyments, is it not to be feared, that instead of prevailing on feelings so selfish to consent to it, you would have lessened your own influence on his (it) heart, and made him (it) regret the connection which had involved him (it) in such difficulties?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Marianne's lips quivered, and she (Marianne) repeated the word

``Selfish?'' (she)
in a tone that implied--
``do you really think him (it) selfish?'' (she)

``The whole of his (it) behaviour,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
replied Elinor,
``from the beginning to the end of the affair, has been grounded on selfishness. It was selfishness which first made him (it) sport with your affections; which afterwards, when his (it) own were engaged, made him (it) delay the confession of it, and which finally carried him (it) from Barton. His (Barton) own enjoyment, or his (Barton) own ease, was, in every particular, his (Barton) ruling principle.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``It is very true. MY happiness never was his (Barton) object.'' (unknown)

``At present,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
continued Elinor,
``he (Barton) regrets what he (Barton) has done. And why does he (Barton) regret it?--Because he (Barton) finds it has not answered towards himself. It has not made him (Barton) happy. His (Barton) circumstances are now unembarrassed--he (Barton) suffers from no evil of that kind; and he (Barton) thinks only that he (Barton) has married a woman of a less amiable temper than yourself. But does it follow that had he (Barton) married you, he (Barton) would have been happy?--The inconveniences would have been different. He (Barton) would then have suffered under the pecuniary distresses which, because they are removed, he (Barton) now reckons as nothing. He (Barton) would have had a wife of whose temper he (Barton) could make no complaint, but he (Barton) would have been always necessitous--always poor; and probably would soon have learned to rank the innumerable comforts of a clear estate and good income as of far more importance, even to domestic happiness, than the mere temper of a wife.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``I have not a doubt of it,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne;
``and I have nothing to regret--nothing but my own folly.'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)

``Rather say your mother's imprudence, my child,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said Mrs. Dashwood;
``SHE must be answerable.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Marianne would not let her (Marianne) proceed;--and Elinor, satisfied that each felt their own error, wished to avoid any survey of the past that might weaken her (Elinor) sister's spirits; she (Elinor), therefore, pursuing the first subject, immediately continued,

``One observation may, I think, be fairly drawn from the whole of the story--that all Willoughby's difficulties have arisen from the first offence against virtue, in his (Willoughby) behaviour to Eliza Williams. That crime has been the origin of every lesser one, and of all his (Willoughby) present discontents.'' (she)

Marianne assented most feelingly to the remark; and her (Marianne) mother was led by it to an enumeration of Colonel Brandon's injuries and merits, warm as friendship and design could unitedly dictate. Her (Brandon) daughter did not look, however, as if much of it were heard by her (Brandon).

Elinor, according to her (Elinor) expectation, saw on the two or three following days, that Marianne did not continue to gain strength as she (Marianne) had done; but while her (Marianne) resolution was unsubdued, and she (Marianne) still tried to appear cheerful and easy, her (Marianne) sister could safely trust to the effect of time upon her (Marianne) health.

Margaret returned, and the family were again all restored to each other, again quietly settled at the cottage; and if not pursuing their usual studies with quite so much vigour as when they first came to Barton, at least planning a vigorous prosecution of them in future.

Elinor grew impatient for some tidings of Edward. She (Elinor) had heard nothing of him (Edward) since her (Elinor) leaving London, nothing new of his (Edward) plans, nothing certain even of his (Edward) present abode. Some letters had passed between her (Elinor) and her (Elinor) brother, in consequence of Marianne's illness; and in the first of John's, there had been this sentence:--

``We know nothing of our unfortunate Edward, and can make no enquiries on so prohibited a subject, but conclude him (Edward) to be still at Oxford;'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
which was all the intelligence of Edward afforded her (John) by the correspondence, for his (Edward) name was not even mentioned in any of the succeeding letters. She (John) was not doomed, however, to be long in ignorance of his (Edward) measures.

Their man-servant had been sent one morning to Exeter on business; and when, as he (Edward) waited at table, he (Edward) had satisfied the inquiries of his (Edward) mistress as to the event of his (Edward) errand, this was his (Edward) voluntary communication--

``I suppose you know, ma'am, that Mr. Ferrars is married.'' (mistress)

Marianne gave a violent start, fixed her (Marianne) eyes upon Elinor, saw her (Marianne) turning pale, and fell back in her (Marianne) chair in hysterics. Mrs. Dashwood, whose eyes, as she (Dashwood) answered the servant's inquiry, had intuitively taken the same direction, was shocked to perceive by Elinor's countenance how much she (Elinor) really suffered, and a moment afterwards, alike distressed by Marianne's situation, knew not on which child to bestow her (Marianne) principal attention.

The servant, who saw only that Miss Marianne was taken ill, had sense enough to call one of the maids, who, with Mrs. Dashwood's assistance, supported her (Dashwood) into the other room. By that time, Marianne was rather better, and her (Marianne) mother leaving her (Marianne) to the care of Margaret and the maid, returned to Elinor, who, though still much disordered, had so far recovered the use of her (Elinor) reason and voice as to be just beginning an inquiry of Thomas, as to the source of his (Thomas) intelligence. Mrs. Dashwood immediately took all that trouble on herself; and Elinor had the benefit of the information without the exertion of seeking it.

``Who told you that Mr. Ferrars was married, Thomas?'' (unknown)

``I see Mr. Ferrars myself, ma'am, this morning in Exeter, and his (Ferrars) lady too, Miss Steele as was. They was stopping in a chaise at the door of the New London Inn, as I went there with a message from Sally at the Park to her (Sally) brother, who is one of the post-boys. I happened to look up as I went by the chaise, and so I see directly it was the youngest Miss Steele; so I took off my hat, and she (Steele) knew me and called to me, and inquired after you, ma'am, and the young ladies, especially Miss Marianne, and bid me I should give her (Marianne) compliments and Mr. Ferrars's, their best compliments and service, and how sorry they was they had not time to come on and see you, but they was in a great hurry to go forwards, for they was going further down for a little while, but howsever, when they come back, they'd make sure to come and see you.'' (unknown)

``But did she (Marianne) tell you she (Marianne) was married, Thomas?'' (unknown)

``Yes, ma'am. She (Marianne) smiled, and said how she (Marianne) had changed her (Marianne) name since she (Marianne) was in these parts. She (Marianne) was always a very affable and free-spoken young lady, and very civil behaved. So, I made free to wish her (Marianne) joy.'' (unknown)

``Was Mr. Ferrars in the carriage with her (Marianne)?'' (unknown)

``Yes, ma'am, I just see him (Ferrars) leaning back in it, but he (Ferrars) did not look up;--he (Ferrars) never was a gentleman much for talking.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor's heart could easily account for his (gentleman) not putting himself forward; and Mrs. Dashwood probably found the same explanation.

``Was there no one else in the carriage?'' (unknown)

``No, ma'am, only they two.'' (unknown)

``Do you know where they came from?'' (unknown)

``They come straight from town, as Miss Lucy--Mrs. Ferrars told me.'' (unknown)

``And are they going farther westward?'' (unknown)

``Yes, ma'am--but not to bide long. They will soon be back again, and then they'd be sure and call here.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Mrs. Dashwood now looked at her (Dashwood) daughter; but Elinor knew better than to expect them. She (Elinor) recognised the whole of Lucy in the message, and was very confident that Edward would never come near them. She (Lucy) observed in a low voice, to her (Lucy) mother, that they were probably going down to Mr. Pratt's, near Plymouth.

Thomas's intelligence seemed over. Elinor looked as if she (Elinor) wished to hear more.

``Did you see them off, before you came away?'' (unknown)

``No, ma'am--the horses were just coming out, but I could not bide any longer; I was afraid of being late.'' (unknown)

``Did Mrs. Ferrars look well?'' (unknown)

``Yes, ma'am, she (Ferrars) said how she (Ferrars) was very well; and to my mind she (Ferrars) was always a very handsome young lady--and she (Ferrars) seemed vastly contented.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)

Mrs. Dashwood could think of no other question, and Thomas and the tablecloth, now alike needless, were soon afterwards dismissed. Marianne had already sent to say, that she (Marianne) should eat nothing more. Mrs. Dashwood's and Elinor's appetites were equally lost, and Margaret might think herself very well off, that with so much uneasiness as both her (Margaret) sisters had lately experienced, so much reason as they had often had to be careless of their meals, she (Margaret) had never been obliged to go without her (Margaret) dinner before.

When the dessert and the wine were arranged, and Mrs. Dashwood and Elinor were left by themselves, they remained long together in a similarity of thoughtfulness and silence. Mrs. Dashwood feared to hazard any remark, and ventured not to offer consolation. She (Dashwood) now found that she (Dashwood) had erred in relying on Elinor's representation of herself; and justly concluded that every thing had been expressly softened at the time, to spare her (Elinor) from an increase of unhappiness, suffering as she (Elinor) then had suffered for Marianne. She (Marianne) found that she (Marianne) had been misled by the careful, the considerate attention of her (Marianne) daughter, to think the attachment, which once she (Marianne) had so well understood, much slighter in reality, than she (Marianne) had been wont to believe, or than it was now proved to be. She (Marianne) feared that under this persuasion she (Marianne) had been unjust, inattentive, nay, almost unkind, to her (Marianne) Elinor;--that Marianne's affliction, because more acknowledged, more immediately before her (Marianne), had too much engrossed her (Marianne) tenderness, and led her (Marianne) away to forget that in Elinor she (Elinor) might have a daughter suffering almost as much, certainly with less self-provocation, and greater fortitude.

CHAPTER 48

Elinor now found the difference between the expectation of an unpleasant event, however certain the mind may be told to consider it, and certainty itself. She (Elinor) now found, that in spite of herself, she (Elinor) had always admitted a hope, while Edward remained single, that something would occur to prevent his (Edward) marrying Lucy; that some resolution of his (Edward) own, some mediation of friends, or some more eligible opportunity of establishment for the lady, would arise to assist the happiness of all. But he (Edward) was now married; and she (lady) condemned her (lady) heart for the lurking flattery, which so much heightened the pain of the intelligence.

That he (Edward) should be married soon, before -LRB-as she (lady) imagined-RRB- he (Edward) could be in orders, and consequently before he (Edward) could be in possession of the living, surprised her (lady) a little at first. But she (lady) soon saw how likely it was that Lucy, in her (Lucy) self-provident care, in her (Lucy) haste to secure him (Edward), should overlook every thing but the risk of delay. They were married, married in town, and now hastening down to her (Lucy) uncle's. What had Edward felt on being within four miles from Barton, on seeing her (Lucy) mother's servant, on hearing Lucy's message!

They would soon, she (Lucy) supposed, be settled at Delaford.--Delaford,--that place in which so much conspired to give her (Lucy) an interest; which she (Lucy) wished to be acquainted with, and yet desired to avoid. She (Lucy) saw them in an instant in their parsonage-house; saw in Lucy, the active, contriving manager, uniting at once a desire of smart appearance with the utmost frugality, and ashamed to be suspected of half her (Lucy) economical practices;--pursuing her (Lucy) own interest in every thought, courting the favour of Colonel Brandon, of Mrs. Jennings, and of every wealthy friend. In Edward--she (Jennings) knew not what she (Jennings) saw, nor what she (Jennings) wished to see;--happy or unhappy,--nothing pleased her (Jennings); she (Jennings) turned away her (Jennings) head from every sketch of him (Edward).

Elinor flattered herself that some one of their connections in London would write to them to announce the event, and give farther particulars,--but day after day passed off, and brought no letter, no tidings.
