Though uncertain that any one were to blame, she (Elinor) found fault with every absent friend. They were all thoughtless or indolent.

``When do you write to Colonel Brandon, ma'am?'' (unknown)
was an inquiry which sprung from the impatience of her (Brandon) mind to have something going on.

``I wrote to him (Colonel), my love, last week, and rather expect to see, than to hear from him (Colonel) again. I earnestly pressed his (Colonel) coming to us, and should not be surprised to see him (Colonel) walk in today or tomorrow, or any day.'' (unknown)

This was gaining something, something to look forward to. Colonel Brandon must have some information to give.

Scarcely had she (Brandon) so determined it, when the figure of a man on horseback drew her (Brandon) eyes to the window. He (man) stopt at their gate. It was a gentleman, it was Colonel Brandon himself. Now she (Brandon) could hear more; and she (Brandon) trembled in expectation of it. But--it was NOT Colonel Brandon--neither his (Colonel) air--nor his (Colonel) height. Were it possible, she (Brandon) must say it must be Edward. She (Brandon) looked again. He (Edward) had just dismounted;--she (Brandon) could not be mistaken,--it WAS Edward. She (Brandon) moved away and sat down.

``He (Edward) comes from Mr. Pratt's purposely to see us. I WILL be calm; I WILL be mistress of myself.'' (she)

In a moment she (mistress) perceived that the others were likewise aware of the mistake. She (mistress) saw her (mistress) mother and Marianne change colour; saw them look at herself, and whisper a few sentences to each other. She (mistress) would have given the world to be able to speak--and to make them understand that she (mistress) hoped no coolness, no slight, would appear in their behaviour to him (Edward);--but she (mistress) had no utterance, and was obliged to leave all to their own discretion.

Not a syllable passed aloud. They all waited in silence for the appearance of their visitor. His (visitor) footsteps were heard along the gravel path; in a moment he (visitor) was in the passage, and in another he (visitor) was before them.

His (visitor) countenance, as he (visitor) entered the room, was not too happy, even for Elinor. His (visitor) complexion was white with agitation, and he (visitor) looked as if fearful of his (visitor) reception, and conscious that he (visitor) merited no kind one. Mrs. Dashwood, however, conforming, as she (Dashwood) trusted, to the wishes of that daughter, by whom she (Dashwood) then meant in the warmth of her (Dashwood) heart to be guided in every thing, met with a look of forced complacency, gave him (visitor) her (Dashwood) hand, and wished him (visitor) joy.

He (visitor) coloured, and stammered out an unintelligible reply. Elinor's lips had moved with her (Elinor) mother's, and, when the moment of action was over, she (Elinor) wished that she (Elinor) had shaken hands with him (visitor) too. But it was then too late, and with a countenance meaning to be open, she (Elinor) sat down again and talked of the weather.

Marianne had retreated as much as possible out of sight, to conceal her (Marianne) distress; and Margaret, understanding some part, but not the whole of the case, thought it incumbent on her (Marianne) to be dignified, and therefore took a seat as far from him (visitor) as she (Marianne) could, and maintained a strict silence.

When Elinor had ceased to rejoice in the dryness of the season, a very awful pause took place. It was put an end to by Mrs. Dashwood, who felt obliged to hope that he (visitor) had left Mrs. Ferrars very well. In a hurried manner, he (visitor) replied in the affirmative.

Another pause.

Elinor resolving to exert herself, though fearing the sound of her (Elinor) own voice, now said,

``Is Mrs. Ferrars at Longstaple?'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``At Longstaple!'' (he)
he (visitor) replied, with an air of surprise.--
``No, my mother is in town.'' (unknown)

``I meant,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, taking up some work from the table,
``to inquire for Mrs. EDWARD Ferrars.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

She (Elinor) dared not look up;--but her (Elinor) mother and Marianne both turned their eyes on him (visitor). He (visitor) coloured, seemed perplexed, looked doubtingly, and, after some hesitation, said,--

``Perhaps you mean--my brother--you mean Mrs.--Mrs. ROBERT Ferrars.'' (He)

``Mrs. Robert Ferrars!'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
--was repeated by Marianne and her (Marianne) mother in an accent of the utmost amazement;--and though Elinor could not speak, even HER eyes were fixed on him (brother) with the same impatient wonder. He (brother) rose from his (brother) seat, and walked to the window, apparently from not knowing what to do; took up a pair of scissors that lay there, and while spoiling both them and their sheath by cutting the latter to pieces as he (brother) spoke, said, in a hurried voice,

``Perhaps you do not know--you may not have heard that my brother is lately married to--to the youngest--to Miss Lucy Steele.'' (he)

His (brother) words were echoed with unspeakable astonishment by all but Elinor, who sat with her (Elinor) head leaning over her (Elinor) work, in a state of such agitation as made her (Elinor) hardly know where she (Elinor) was.

``Yes,'' (he)
said he (brother),
``they were married last week, and are now at Dawlish.'' (he)

Elinor could sit it no longer. She (Elinor) almost ran out of the room, and as soon as the door was closed, burst into tears of joy, which at first she (Elinor) thought would never cease. Edward, who had till then looked any where, rather than at her (Elinor), saw her (Elinor) hurry away, and perhaps saw--or even heard, her (Elinor) emotion; for immediately afterwards he (Edward) fell into a reverie, which no remarks, no inquiries, no affectionate address of Mrs. Dashwood could penetrate, and at last, without saying a word, quitted the room, and walked out towards the village--leaving the others in the greatest astonishment and perplexity on a change in his (Edward) situation, so wonderful and so sudden;--a perplexity which they had no means of lessening but by their own conjectures.

CHAPTER 49

Unaccountable, however, as the circumstances of his (Edward) release might appear to the whole family, it was certain that Edward was free; and to what purpose that freedom would be employed was easily pre-determined by all;--for after experiencing the blessings of ONE imprudent engagement, contracted without his (Edward) mother's consent, as he (Edward) had already done for more than four years, nothing less could be expected of him (Edward) in the failure of THAT, than the immediate contraction of another.

His (Edward) errand at Barton, in fact, was a simple one. It was only to ask Elinor to marry him (Edward);--and considering that he (Edward) was not altogether inexperienced in such a question, it might be strange that he (Edward) should feel so uncomfortable in the present case as he (Edward) really did, so much in need of encouragement and fresh air.

How soon he (Edward) had walked himself into the proper resolution, however, how soon an opportunity of exercising it occurred, in what manner he (Edward) expressed himself, and how he (Edward) was received, need not be particularly told. This only need be said;--that when they all sat down to table at four o'clock, about three hours after his (Edward) arrival, he (Edward) had secured his (Edward) lady, engaged her (lady) mother's consent, and was not only in the rapturous profession of the lover, but, in the reality of reason and truth, one of the happiest of men. His (lover) situation indeed was more than commonly joyful. He (lover) had more than the ordinary triumph of accepted love to swell his (lover) heart, and raise his (lover) spirits. He (lover) was released without any reproach to himself, from an entanglement which had long formed his (lover) misery, from a woman whom he (lover) had long ceased to love;--and elevated at once to that security with another, which he (lover) must have thought of almost with despair, as soon as he (lover) had learnt to consider it with desire. He (lover) was brought, not from doubt or suspense, but from misery to happiness;--and the change was openly spoken in such a genuine, flowing, grateful cheerfulness, as his (lover) friends had never witnessed in him (lover) before.

His (lover) heart was now open to Elinor, all its weaknesses, all its errors confessed, and his (lover) first boyish attachment to Lucy treated with all the philosophic dignity of twenty-four.

``It was a foolish, idle inclination on my side,'' (he)
said he (lover),
``the consequence of ignorance of the world--and want of employment. Had my mother given me some active profession when I was removed at eighteen from the care of Mr. Pratt, I think--nay, I am sure, it would never have happened; for though I left Longstaple with what I thought, at the time, a most unconquerable preference for his (Pratt) niece, yet had I then had any pursuit, any object to engage my time and keep me at a distance from her (niece) for a few months, I should very soon have outgrown the fancied attachment, especially by mixing more with the world, as in such case I must have done. But instead of having any thing to do, instead of having any profession chosen for me, or being allowed to chuse any myself, I returned home to be completely idle; and for the first twelvemonth afterwards I had not even the nominal employment, which belonging to the university would have given me; for I was not entered at Oxford till I was nineteen. I had therefore nothing in the world to do, but to fancy myself in love; and as my mother did not make my home in every respect comfortable, as I had no friend, no companion in my brother, and disliked new acquaintance, it was not unnatural for me to be very often at Longstaple, where I always felt myself at home, and was always sure of a welcome; and accordingly I spent the greatest part of my time there from eighteen to nineteen: Lucy appeared everything that was amiable and obliging. She (Lucy) was pretty too--at least I thought so THEN; and I had seen so little of other women, that I could make no comparisons, and see no defects. Considering everything, therefore, I hope, foolish as our engagement was, foolish as it has since in every way been proved, it was not at the time an unnatural or an inexcusable piece of folly.'' (he)

The change which a few hours had wrought in the minds and the happiness of the Dashwoods, was such--so great--as promised them all, the satisfaction of a sleepless night. Mrs. Dashwood, too happy to be comfortable, knew not how to love Edward, nor praise Elinor enough, how to be enough thankful for his (Edward) release without wounding his (Edward) delicacy, nor how at once to give them leisure for unrestrained conversation together, and yet enjoy, as she (Elinor) wished, the sight and society of both.

Marianne could speak HER happiness only by tears. Comparisons would occur--regrets would arise;--and her (Marianne) joy, though sincere as her (Marianne) love for her (Marianne) sister, was of a kind to give her (Marianne) neither spirits nor language.

But Elinor--how are HER feelings to be described?--From the moment of learning that Lucy was married to another, that Edward was free, to the moment of his (Edward) justifying the hopes which had so instantly followed, she (Lucy) was every thing by turns but tranquil. But when the second moment had passed, when she (Lucy) found every doubt, every solicitude removed, compared her (Lucy) situation with what so lately it had been,--saw him (Edward) honourably released from his (Edward) former engagement, saw him (Edward) instantly profiting by the release, to address herself and declare an affection as tender, as constant as she (Lucy) had ever supposed it to be,--she (Lucy) was oppressed, she (Lucy) was overcome by her (Lucy) own felicity;--and happily disposed as is the human mind to be easily familiarized with any change for the better, it required several hours to give sedateness to her (Lucy) spirits, or any degree of tranquillity to her (Lucy) heart.

Edward was now fixed at the cottage at least for a week;--for whatever other claims might be made on him (Edward), it was impossible that less than a week should be given up to the enjoyment of Elinor's company, or suffice to say half that was to be said of the past, the present, and the future;--for though a very few hours spent in the hard labor of incessant talking will despatch more subjects than can really be in common between any two rational creatures, yet with lovers it is different. Between THEM no subject is finished, no communication is even made, till it has been made at least twenty times over.

Lucy's marriage, the unceasing and reasonable wonder among them all, formed of course one of the earliest discussions of the lovers;--and Elinor's particular knowledge of each party made it appear to her (Elinor) in every view, as one of the most extraordinary and unaccountable circumstances she (Elinor) had ever heard. How they could be thrown together, and by what attraction Robert could be drawn on to marry a girl, of whose beauty she (Robert) had herself heard him (it) speak without any admiration,--a girl too already engaged to his (it) brother, and on whose account that brother had been thrown off by his (brother) family--it was beyond her (girl) comprehension to make out. To her (girl) own heart it was a delightful affair, to her (girl) imagination it was even a ridiculous one, but to her (girl) reason, her (girl) judgment, it was completely a puzzle.

Edward could only attempt an explanation by supposing, that, perhaps, at first accidentally meeting, the vanity of the one had been so worked on by the flattery of the other, as to lead by degrees to all the rest. Elinor remembered what Robert had told her (Robert) in Harley Street, of his (Edward) opinion of what his (Edward) own mediation in his (Edward) brother's affairs might have done, if applied to in time. She (Robert) repeated it to Edward.

``THAT was exactly like Robert,'' (unknown)
--was his (Edward) immediate observation.--
``And THAT,'' (he)
he (Edward) presently added,
``might perhaps be in HIS (Edward) head when the acquaintance between them first began. And Lucy perhaps at first might think only of procuring his (Edward) good offices in my favour. Other designs might afterward arise.'' (he)

How long it had been carrying on between them, however, he (Edward) was equally at a loss with herself to make out; for at Oxford, where he (Edward) had remained for choice ever since his (Edward) quitting London, he (Edward) had had no means of hearing of her (Lucy) but from herself, and her (Lucy) letters to the very last were neither less frequent, nor less affectionate than usual. Not the smallest suspicion, therefore, had ever occurred to prepare him (Edward) for what followed;--and when at last it burst on him (Edward) in a letter from Lucy herself, he (Edward) had been for some time, he (Edward) believed, half stupified between the wonder, the horror, and the joy of such a deliverance. He (Edward) put the letter into Elinor's hands.

``DEAR SIR,

``Being very sure I have long lost your affections, I have thought myself at liberty to bestow my own on another, and have no doubt of being as happy with him (Edward) as I once used to think I might be with you; but I scorn to accept a hand while the heart was another's. Sincerely wish you happy in your choice, and it shall not be my fault if we are not always good friends, as our near relationship now makes proper. I can safely say I owe you no ill-will, and am sure you will be too generous to do us any ill offices. Your brother has gained my affections entirely, and as we could not live without one another, we are just returned from the altar, and are now on our way to Dawlish for a few weeks, which place your dear brother has great curiosity to see, but thought I would first trouble you with these few lines, and shall always remain,

``Your sincere well-wisher, friend, and sister, ``LUCY FERRARS.

``I have burnt all your letters, and will return your picture the first opportunity. Please to destroy my scrawls--but the ring with my hair you are very welcome to keep.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor read and returned it without any comment.

``I will not ask your opinion of it as a composition,'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)
said Edward.--
``For worlds would not I have had a letter of hers seen by YOU in former days.--In a sister it is bad enough, but in a wife!--how I have blushed over the pages of her (wife) writing!--and I believe I may say that since the first half year of our foolish--business--this is the only letter I ever received from her (wife), of which the substance made me any amends for the defect of the style.'' (unknown)

``However it may have come about,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor, after a pause,--
``they are certainly married. And your mother has brought on herself a most appropriate punishment. The independence she (mother) settled on Robert, through resentment against you, has put it in his (I) power to make his (I) own choice; and she (mother) has actually been bribing one son with a thousand a-year, to do the very deed which she (mother) disinherited the other for intending to do. She (mother) will hardly be less hurt, I suppose, by Robert's marrying Lucy, than she (Lucy) would have been by your marrying her (Lucy).'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

``She (Lucy) will be more hurt by it, for Robert always was her (Robert) favourite.--She (Robert) will be more hurt by it, and on the same principle will forgive him (I) much sooner.'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

In what state the affair stood at present between them, Edward knew not, for no communication with any of his (Edward) family had yet been attempted by him (Edward). He (Edward) had quitted Oxford within four and twenty hours after Lucy's letter arrived, and with only one object before him (Edward), the nearest road to Barton, had had no leisure to form any scheme of conduct, with which that road did not hold the most intimate connection. He (Barton) could do nothing till he (Barton) were assured of his (Barton) fate with Miss Dashwood; and by his (Barton) rapidity in seeking THAT fate, it is to be supposed, in spite of the jealousy with which he (Barton) had once thought of Colonel Brandon, in spite of the modesty with which he (Barton) rated his (Barton) own deserts, and the politeness with which he (Barton) talked of his (Barton) doubts, he (Barton) did not, upon the whole, expect a very cruel reception. It was his (Barton) business, however, to say that he (Barton) DID, and he (Barton) said it very prettily. What he (Barton) might say on the subject a twelvemonth after, must be referred to the imagination of husbands and wives.

That Lucy had certainly meant to deceive, to go off with a flourish of malice against him (Barton) in her (Lucy) message by Thomas, was perfectly clear to Elinor; and Edward himself, now thoroughly enlightened on her (Elinor) character, had no scruple in believing her (Elinor) capable of the utmost meanness of wanton ill-nature. Though his (Edward) eyes had been long opened, even before his (Edward) acquaintance with Elinor began, to her (Elinor) ignorance and a want of liberality in some of her (Elinor) opinions--they had been equally imputed, by him (Edward), to her (Elinor) want of education; and till her (Elinor) last letter reached him (Edward), he (Edward) had always believed her (Elinor) to be a well-disposed, good-hearted girl, and thoroughly attached to himself. Nothing but such a persuasion could have prevented his (Edward) putting an end to an engagement, which, long before the discovery of it laid him (Edward) open to his (Edward) mother's anger, had been a continual source of disquiet and regret to him (Edward).

``I thought it my duty,'' (he)
said he (Edward),
``independent of my feelings, to give her (mother) the option of continuing the engagement or not, when I was renounced by my mother, and stood to all appearance without a friend in the world to assist me. In such a situation as that, where there seemed nothing to tempt the avarice or the vanity of any living creature, how could I suppose, when she (mother) so earnestly, so warmly insisted on sharing my fate, whatever it might be, that any thing but the most disinterested affection was her (mother) inducement? And even now, I cannot comprehend on what motive she (mother) acted, or what fancied advantage it could be to her (mother), to be fettered to a man for whom she (mother) had not the smallest regard, and who had only two thousand pounds in the world. She (mother) could not foresee that Colonel Brandon would give me a living.'' (he)

``No; but she (Brandon) might suppose that something would occur in your favour; that your own family might in time relent. And at any rate, she (Brandon) lost nothing by continuing the engagement, for she (Brandon) has proved that it fettered neither her (Brandon) inclination nor her (Brandon) actions. The connection was certainly a respectable one, and probably gained her (Brandon) consideration among her (Brandon) friends; and, if nothing more advantageous occurred, it would be better for her (Brandon) to marry YOU than be single.'' (Edward/Mr. Ferrars/Edward Ferrars)

Edward was, of course, immediately convinced that nothing could have been more natural than Lucy's conduct, nor more self-evident than the motive of it.

Elinor scolded him (Edward), harshly as ladies always scold the imprudence which compliments themselves, for having spent so much time with them at Norland, when he (Edward) must have felt his (Edward) own inconstancy.

``Your behaviour was certainly very wrong,'' (she)
said she (Elinor);
``because--to say nothing of my own conviction, our relations were all led away by it to fancy and expect WHAT, as you were THEN situated, could never be.'' (she)

He (Edward) could only plead an ignorance of his (Edward) own heart, and a mistaken confidence in the force of his (Edward) engagement.

``I was simple enough to think, that because my FAITH was plighted to another, there could be no danger in my being with you; and that the consciousness of my engagement was to keep my heart as safe and sacred as my honour. I felt that I admired you, but I told myself it was only friendship; and till I began to make comparisons between yourself and Lucy, I did not know how far I was got. After that, I suppose, I WAS wrong in remaining so much in Sussex, and the arguments with which I reconciled myself to the expediency of it, were no better than these:--The danger is my own; I am doing no injury to anybody but myself.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

Elinor smiled, and shook her (Elinor) head.

Edward heard with pleasure of Colonel Brandon's being expected at the Cottage, as he (Edward) really wished not only to be better acquainted with him (Edward), but to have an opportunity of convincing him (Edward) that he (Edward) no longer resented his (Edward) giving him (Edward) the living of Delaford--

``Which, at present,'' (him)
said he (Edward),
``after thanks so ungraciously delivered as mine were on the occasion, he (Edward) must think I have never forgiven him (Edward) for offering.'' (he)

NOW he (Edward) felt astonished himself that he (Edward) had never yet been to the place. But so little interest had he (Edward) taken in the matter, that he (Edward) owed all his (Edward) knowledge of the house, garden, and glebe, extent of the parish, condition of the land, and rate of the tithes, to Elinor herself, who had heard so much of it from Colonel Brandon, and heard it with so much attention, as to be entirely mistress of the subject.

One question after this only remained undecided, between them, one difficulty only was to be overcome. They were brought together by mutual affection, with the warmest approbation of their real friends; their intimate knowledge of each other seemed to make their happiness certain--and they only wanted something to live upon. Edward had two thousand pounds, and Elinor one, which, with Delaford living, was all that they could call their own; for it was impossible that Mrs. Dashwood should advance anything; and they were neither of them quite enough in love to think that three hundred and fifty pounds a-year would supply them with the comforts of life.

Edward was not entirely without hopes of some favourable change in his (Edward) mother towards him (Edward); and on THAT he (Edward) rested for the residue of their income. But Elinor had no such dependence; for since Edward would still be unable to marry Miss Morton, and his (Edward) chusing herself had been spoken of in Mrs. Ferrars's flattering language as only a lesser evil than his (Edward) chusing Lucy Steele, she (Steele) feared that Robert's offence would serve no other purpose than to enrich Fanny.

About four days after Edward's arrival Colonel Brandon appeared, to complete Mrs. Dashwood's satisfaction, and to give her (Brandon) the dignity of having, for the first time since her (Brandon) living at Barton, more company with her (Brandon) than her (Brandon) house would hold. Edward was allowed to retain the privilege of first comer, and Colonel Brandon therefore walked every night to his (Colonel) old quarters at the Park; from whence he (Colonel) usually returned in the morning, early enough to interrupt the lovers' first tete-a-tete before breakfast.

A three weeks' residence at Delaford, where, in his (Colonel) evening hours at least, he (Colonel) had little to do but to calculate the disproportion between thirty-six and seventeen, brought him (Colonel) to Barton in a temper of mind which needed all the improvement in Marianne's looks, all the kindness of her (Marianne) welcome, and all the encouragement of her (Marianne) mother's language, to make it cheerful. Among such friends, however, and such flattery, he (Barton) did revive. No rumour of Lucy's marriage had yet reached him (Barton):--he (Barton) knew nothing of what had passed; and the first hours of his (Barton) visit were consequently spent in hearing and in wondering. Every thing was explained to him (Barton) by Mrs. Dashwood, and he (Barton) found fresh reason to rejoice in what he (Barton) had done for Mr. Ferrars, since eventually it promoted the interest of Elinor.

It would be needless to say, that the gentlemen advanced in the good opinion of each other, as they advanced in each other's acquaintance, for it could not be otherwise. Their resemblance in good principles and good sense, in disposition and manner of thinking, would probably have been sufficient to unite them in friendship, without any other attraction; but their being in love with two sisters, and two sisters fond of each other, made that mutual regard inevitable and immediate, which might otherwise have waited the effect of time and judgment.

The letters from town, which a few days before would have made every nerve in Elinor's body thrill with transport, now arrived to be read with less emotion than mirth. Mrs. Jennings wrote to tell the wonderful tale, to vent her (Jennings) honest indignation against the jilting girl, and pour forth her (Jennings) compassion towards poor Mr. Edward, who, she (Jennings) was sure, had quite doted upon the worthless hussy, and was now, by all accounts, almost broken-hearted, at Oxford.--

``I do think,'' (she)
she (Jennings) continued,
``nothing was ever carried on so sly; for it was but two days before Lucy called and sat a couple of hours with me. Not a soul suspected anything of the matter, not even Nancy, who, poor soul! came crying to me the day after, in a great fright for fear of Mrs. Ferrars, as well as not knowing how to get to Plymouth; for Lucy it seems borrowed all her (Lucy) money before she (Lucy) went off to be married, on purpose we suppose to make a show with, and poor Nancy had not seven shillings in the world;--so I was very glad to give her (Nancy) five guineas to take her (Nancy) down to Exeter, where she (Nancy) thinks of staying three or four weeks with Mrs. Burgess, in hopes, as I tell her (Burgess), to fall in with the Doctor again. And I must say that Lucy's crossness not to take them along with them in the chaise is worse than all. Poor Mr. Edward! I cannot get him (Edward) out of my head, but you must send for him (Edward) to Barton, and Miss Marianne must try to comfort him (Barton).'' (she)

Mr. Dashwood's strains were more solemn. Mrs. Ferrars was the most unfortunate of women--poor Fanny had suffered agonies of sensibility--and he (Dashwood) considered the existence of each, under such a blow, with grateful wonder. Robert's offence was unpardonable, but Lucy's was infinitely worse. Neither of them were ever again to be mentioned to Mrs. Ferrars; and even, if she (Ferrars) might hereafter be induced to forgive her (Ferrars) son, his (son) wife should never be acknowledged as her (Ferrars) daughter, nor be permitted to appear in her (Ferrars) presence. The secrecy with which everything had been carried on between them, was rationally treated as enormously heightening the crime, because, had any suspicion of it occurred to the others, proper measures would have been taken to prevent the marriage; and he (son) called on Elinor to join with him (son) in regretting that Lucy's engagement with Edward had not rather been fulfilled, than that she (Lucy) should thus be the means of spreading misery farther in the family.-- He (Edward) thus continued:

``Mrs. Ferrars has never yet mentioned Edward's name, which does not surprise us; but, to our great astonishment, not a line has been received from him (Edward) on the occasion. Perhaps, however, he (Edward) is kept silent by his (Edward) fear of offending, and I shall, therefore, give him (Edward) a hint, by a line to Oxford, that his (Edward) sister and I both think a letter of proper submission from him (Edward), addressed perhaps to Fanny, and by her (Fanny) shewn to her (Fanny) mother, might not be taken amiss; for we all know the tenderness of Mrs. Ferrars's heart, and that she (Ferrars) wishes for nothing so much as to be on good terms with her (Ferrars) children.'' (He)

This paragraph was of some importance to the prospects and conduct of Edward. It determined him (Edward) to attempt a reconciliation, though not exactly in the manner pointed out by their brother and sister.

``A letter of proper submission!'' (he)
repeated he (brother);
``would they have me beg my mother's pardon for Robert's ingratitude to HER, and breach of honour to ME?--I can make no submission--I am grown neither humble nor penitent by what has passed.--I am grown very happy; but that would not interest.--I know of no submission that IS proper for me to make.'' (he)

``You may certainly ask to be forgiven,'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)
said Elinor,
``because you have offended;--and I should think you might NOW venture so far as to profess some concern for having ever formed the engagement which drew on you your mother's anger.'' (Elinor/-- Elinor/ELINOR)

He (I) agreed that he (I) might.

``And when she (mother) has forgiven you, perhaps a little humility may be convenient while acknowledging a second engagement, almost as imprudent in HER eyes as the first.'' (He)

He (I) had nothing to urge against it, but still resisted the idea of a letter of proper submission; and therefore, to make it easier to him (I), as he (I) declared a much greater willingness to make mean concessions by word of mouth than on paper, it was resolved that, instead of writing to Fanny, he (I) should go to London, and personally intreat her (Fanny) good offices in his (I) favour.--

``And if they really DO interest themselves,'' (Marianne/Marianne Dashwood/Dashwood)
said Marianne, in her (Marianne) new character of candour,
``in bringing about a reconciliation, I shall think that even John and Fanny are not entirely without merit.'' (character)

After a visit on Colonel Brandon's side of only three or four days, the two gentlemen quitted Barton together.-- They were to go immediately to Delaford, that Edward might have some personal knowledge of his (Edward) future home, and assist his (Edward) patron and friend in deciding on what improvements were needed to it; and from thence, after staying there a couple of nights, he (Edward) was to proceed on his (Edward) journey to town.

CHAPTER 50

After a proper resistance on the part of Mrs. Ferrars, just so violent and so steady as to preserve her (Ferrars) from that reproach which she (Ferrars) always seemed fearful of incurring, the reproach of being too amiable, Edward was admitted to her (Ferrars) presence, and pronounced to be again her (Ferrars) son.

Her (Ferrars) family had of late been exceedingly fluctuating. For many years of her (Ferrars) life she (Ferrars) had had two sons; but the crime and annihilation of Edward a few weeks ago, had robbed her (Ferrars) of one; the similar annihilation of Robert had left her (Robert) for a fortnight without any; and now, by the resuscitation of Edward, she (Robert) had one again.

In spite of his (Edward) being allowed once more to live, however, he (Edward) did not feel the continuance of his (Edward) existence secure, till he (Edward) had revealed his (Edward) present engagement; for the publication of that circumstance, he (Edward) feared, might give a sudden turn to his (Edward) constitution, and carry him (Edward) off as rapidly as before. With apprehensive caution therefore it was revealed, and he (Edward) was listened to with unexpected calmness. Mrs. Ferrars at first reasonably endeavoured to dissuade him (Edward) from marrying Miss Dashwood, by every argument in her (Dashwood) power;--told him (Edward), that in Miss Morton he (Edward) would have a woman of higher rank and larger fortune;--and enforced the assertion, by observing that Miss Morton was the daughter of a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds, while Miss Dashwood was only the daughter of a private gentleman with no more than THREE; but when she (Dashwood) found that, though perfectly admitting the truth of her (Dashwood) representation, he (gentleman) was by no means inclined to be guided by it, she (Dashwood) judged it wisest, from the experience of the past, to submit--and therefore, after such an ungracious delay as she (Dashwood) owed to her (Dashwood) own dignity, and as served to prevent every suspicion of good-will, she (Dashwood) issued her (Dashwood) decree of consent to the marriage of Edward and Elinor.

What she (Elinor) would engage to do towards augmenting their income was next to be considered; and here it plainly appeared, that though Edward was now her (Elinor) only son, he (Edward) was by no means her (Elinor) eldest; for while Robert was inevitably endowed with a thousand pounds a-year, not the smallest objection was made against Edward's taking orders for the sake of two hundred and fifty at the utmost; nor was anything promised either for the present or in future, beyond the ten thousand pounds, which had been given with Fanny.

It was as much, however, as was desired, and more than was expected, by Edward and Elinor; and Mrs. Ferrars herself, by her (Ferrars) shuffling excuses, seemed the only person surprised at her (Ferrars) not giving more.

With an income quite sufficient to their wants thus secured to them, they had nothing to wait for after Edward was in possession of the living, but the readiness of the house, to which Colonel Brandon, with an eager desire for the accommodation of Elinor, was making considerable improvements; and after waiting some time for their completion, after experiencing, as usual, a thousand disappointments and delays from the unaccountable dilatoriness of the workmen, Elinor, as usual, broke through the first positive resolution of not marrying till every thing was ready, and the ceremony took place in Barton church early in the autumn.

The first month after their marriage was spent with their friend at the Mansion-house; from whence they could superintend the progress of the Parsonage, and direct every thing as they liked on the spot;--could chuse papers, project shrubberies, and invent a sweep. Mrs. Jennings's prophecies, though rather jumbled together, were chiefly fulfilled; for she (Jennings) was able to visit Edward and his (Edward) wife in their Parsonage by Michaelmas, and she (Jennings) found in Elinor and her (Elinor) husband, as she (Elinor) really believed, one of the happiest couples in the world. They had in fact nothing to wish for, but the marriage of Colonel Brandon and Marianne, and rather better pasturage for their cows.

They were visited on their first settling by almost all their relations and friends. Mrs. Ferrars came to inspect the happiness which she (Ferrars) was almost ashamed of having authorised; and even the Dashwoods were at the expense of a journey from Sussex to do them honour.

``I will not say that I am disappointed, my dear sister,'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
said John, as they were walking together one morning before the gates of Delaford House,
``THAT would be saying too much, for certainly you have been one of the most fortunate young women in the world, as it is. But, I confess, it would give me great pleasure to call Colonel Brandon brother. His (Colonel) property here, his (Colonel) place, his (Colonel) house, every thing is in such respectable and excellent condition!--and his (Colonel) woods!--I have not seen such timber any where in Dorsetshire, as there is now standing in Delaford Hanger!--And though, perhaps, Marianne may not seem exactly the person to attract him (Hanger)--yet I think it would altogether be advisable for you to have them now frequently staying with you, for as Colonel Brandon seems a great deal at home, nobody can tell what may happen--for, when people are much thrown together, and see little of anybody else--and it will always be in your power to set her (Brandon) off to advantage, and so forth;--in short, you may as well give her (Brandon) a chance--You understand me.'' (Mrs. Dashwood/John/Mrs. John Dashwood)
--

But though Mrs. Ferrars DID come to see them, and always treated them with the make-believe of decent affection, they were never insulted by her (Ferrars) real favour and preference. THAT was due to the folly of Robert, and the cunning of his (Brandon) wife; and it was earned by them before many months had passed away. The selfish sagacity of the latter, which had at first drawn Robert into the scrape, was the principal instrument of his (Brandon) deliverance from it; for her (Robert) respectful humility, assiduous attentions, and endless flatteries, as soon as the smallest opening was given for their exercise, reconciled Mrs. Ferrars to his (Brandon) choice, and re-established him (Brandon) completely in her (Ferrars) favour.

The whole of Lucy's behaviour in the affair, and the prosperity which crowned it, therefore, may be held forth as a most encouraging instance of what an earnest, an unceasing attention to self-interest, however its progress may be apparently obstructed, will do in securing every advantage of fortune, with no other sacrifice than that of time and conscience. When Robert first sought her (Robert) acquaintance, and privately visited her (Robert) in Bartlett's Buildings, it was only with the view imputed to him (Bartlett) by his (Bartlett) brother. He (Bartlett) merely meant to persuade her (Robert) to give up the engagement; and as there could be nothing to overcome but the affection of both, he (Bartlett) naturally expected that one or two interviews would settle the matter. In that point, however, and that only, he (Bartlett) erred;--for though Lucy soon gave him (Bartlett) hopes that his (Bartlett) eloquence would convince her (Lucy) in TIME, another visit, another conversation, was always wanted to produce this conviction. Some doubts always lingered in her (Lucy) mind when they parted, which could only be removed by another half hour's discourse with himself. His (Bartlett) attendance was by this means secured, and the rest followed in course. Instead of talking of Edward, they came gradually to talk only of Robert,--a subject on which he (Edward) had always more to say than on any other, and in which she (Robert) soon betrayed an interest even equal to his (Edward) own; and in short, it became speedily evident to both, that he (Edward) had entirely supplanted his (Edward) brother. He (Edward) was proud of his (Edward) conquest, proud of tricking Edward, and very proud of marrying privately without his (Edward) mother's consent. What immediately followed is known. They passed some months in great happiness at Dawlish; for she (mother) had many relations and old acquaintances to cut--and he (Edward) drew several plans for magnificent cottages;--and from thence returning to town, procured the forgiveness of Mrs. Ferrars, by the simple expedient of asking it, which, at Lucy's instigation, was adopted. The forgiveness, at first, indeed, as was reasonable, comprehended only Robert; and Lucy, who had owed his (Edward) mother no duty and therefore could have transgressed none, still remained some weeks longer unpardoned. But perseverance in humility of conduct and messages, in self-condemnation for Robert's offence, and gratitude for the unkindness she (Robert) was treated with, procured her (Robert) in time the haughty notice which overcame her (Robert) by its graciousness, and led soon afterwards, by rapid degrees, to the highest state of affection and influence. Lucy became as necessary to Mrs. Ferrars, as either Robert or Fanny; and while Edward was never cordially forgiven for having once intended to marry her (Robert), and Elinor, though superior to her (Elinor) in fortune and birth, was spoken of as an intruder, SHE was in every thing considered, and always openly acknowledged, to be a favourite child. They settled in town, received very liberal assistance from Mrs. Ferrars, were on the best terms imaginable with the Dashwoods; and setting aside the jealousies and ill-will continually subsisting between Fanny and Lucy, in which their husbands of course took a part, as well as the frequent domestic disagreements between Robert and Lucy themselves, nothing could exceed the harmony in which they all lived together.

What Edward had done to forfeit the right of eldest son, might have puzzled many people to find out; and what Robert had done to succeed to it, might have puzzled them still more. It was an arrangement, however, justified in its effects, if not in its cause; for nothing ever appeared in Robert's style of living or of talking to give a suspicion of his (Edward) regretting the extent of his (Edward) income, as either leaving his (Edward) brother too little, or bringing himself too much;--and if Edward might be judged from the ready discharge of his (Edward) duties in every particular, from an increasing attachment to his (Edward) wife and his (Edward) home, and from the regular cheerfulness of his (Edward) spirits, he (Edward) might be supposed no less contented with his (Edward) lot, no less free from every wish of an exchange.

Elinor's marriage divided her (Elinor) as little from her (Elinor) family as could well be contrived, without rendering the cottage at Barton entirely useless, for her (Elinor) mother and sisters spent much more than half their time with her (Elinor). Mrs. Dashwood was acting on motives of policy as well as pleasure in the frequency of her (Dashwood) visits at Delaford; for her (Dashwood) wish of bringing Marianne and Colonel Brandon together was hardly less earnest, though rather more liberal than what John had expressed. It was now her (John) darling object. Precious as was the company of her (John) daughter to her (John), she (John) desired nothing so much as to give up its constant enjoyment to her (John) valued friend; and to see Marianne settled at the mansion-house was equally the wish of Edward and Elinor. They each felt his (Edward) sorrows, and their own obligations, and Marianne, by general consent, was to be the reward of all.

With such a confederacy against her (Marianne)--with a knowledge so intimate of his (Edward) goodness--with a conviction of his (Edward) fond attachment to herself, which at last, though long after it was observable to everybody else--burst on her (Marianne)--what could she (Marianne) do?

Marianne Dashwood was born to an extraordinary fate. She (Dashwood) was born to discover the falsehood of her (Dashwood) own opinions, and to counteract, by her (Dashwood) conduct, her (Dashwood) most favourite maxims. She (Dashwood) was born to overcome an affection formed so late in life as at seventeen, and with no sentiment superior to strong esteem and lively friendship, voluntarily to give her (Dashwood) hand to another!--and THAT other, a man who had suffered no less than herself under the event of a former attachment, whom, two years before, she (Dashwood) had considered too old to be married,--and who still sought the constitutional safeguard of a flannel waistcoat!

But so it was. Instead of falling a sacrifice to an irresistible passion, as once she (Dashwood) had fondly flattered herself with expecting,--instead of remaining even for ever with her (Dashwood) mother, and finding her (Dashwood) only pleasures in retirement and study, as afterwards in her (Dashwood) more calm and sober judgment she (Dashwood) had determined on,--she (Dashwood) found herself at nineteen, submitting to new attachments, entering on new duties, placed in a new home, a wife, the mistress of a family, and the patroness of a village.

Colonel Brandon was now as happy, as all those who best loved him (Colonel), believed he (Colonel) deserved to be;--in Marianne he (Colonel) was consoled for every past affliction;--her (Marianne) regard and her (Marianne) society restored his (Colonel) mind to animation, and his (Colonel) spirits to cheerfulness; and that Marianne found her (Marianne) own happiness in forming his (Colonel), was equally the persuasion and delight of each observing friend. Marianne could never love by halves; and her (Marianne) whole heart became, in time, as much devoted to her (Marianne) husband, as it had once been to Willoughby.

Willoughby could not hear of her (Marianne) marriage without a pang; and his (Willoughby) punishment was soon afterwards complete in the voluntary forgiveness of Mrs. Smith, who, by stating his (Willoughby) marriage with a woman of character, as the source of her (woman) clemency, gave him (Willoughby) reason for believing that had he (Willoughby) behaved with honour towards Marianne, he (Willoughby) might at once have been happy and rich. That his (Willoughby) repentance of misconduct, which thus brought its own punishment, was sincere, need not be doubted;--nor that he (Willoughby) long thought of Colonel Brandon with envy, and of Marianne with regret. But that he (Willoughby) was for ever inconsolable, that he (Willoughby) fled from society, or contracted an habitual gloom of temper, or died of a broken heart, must not be depended on--for he (Willoughby) did neither. He (Willoughby) lived to exert, and frequently to enjoy himself. His (Willoughby) wife was not always out of humour, nor his (Willoughby) home always uncomfortable; and in his (Willoughby) breed of horses and dogs, and in sporting of every kind, he (Willoughby) found no inconsiderable degree of domestic felicity.

For Marianne, however--in spite of his (Willoughby) incivility in surviving her (Marianne) loss--he (Willoughby) always retained that decided regard which interested him (Willoughby) in every thing that befell her (Marianne), and made her (Marianne) his (Willoughby) secret standard of perfection in woman;--and many a rising beauty would be slighted by him (Willoughby) in after-days as bearing no comparison with Mrs. Brandon.

Mrs. Dashwood was prudent enough to remain at the cottage, without attempting a removal to Delaford; and fortunately for Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, when Marianne was taken from them, Margaret had reached an age highly suitable for dancing, and not very ineligible for being supposed to have a lover.

Between Barton and Delaford, there was that constant communication which strong family affection would naturally dictate;--and among the merits and the happiness of Elinor and Marianne, let it not be ranked as the least considerable, that though sisters, and living almost within sight of each other, they could live without disagreement between themselves, or producing coolness between their husbands.

THE END

End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of Sense and Sensibility, by Jane Austen
